You need to do your homework so you know why the people memorialized here are heroes to the Hungarians. You can hire a guide or read a guidebook. You don't need to do much, but a plain visit will do little for you. There's a fair amount to see in the vicinity too.

A must see when in Budapest. Large monument depicting the seven Chieftains of the Magyars, who were the leaders of the Hungarian tribes. Beautiful site to take pictures. Make sure to check out the Cafe Varosliget across the street for great views of the lake.
Great place to visit. The square in huge. Statues are beautiful. We went there on a weekend. Nice stands with all kinds of food and drinks.
Impressive square. Impressive square , go visit the national park behind and the national museum of art to the left . nice

Impressive. An Impressive square and area at the end of Andrassy UtWe first visited on the hop on hop off bus tour, but you can easily walk from the Opera house and take in the sights en routeThere is a large and tranquil park close by with many attractions including the thermal baths

must in budapest. It is far from the Danube and you have to go with a bus or something else.Near the zooI take the hop on hop off buses during all my vacation to Budapest (i have only 2 days there)., with a valid ticket for 2 days (extra discount for students).

Centre of Town. This attraction is in the center of town. Driving Andrassy avenue it can be spotted in the distance and most tour operators stop here as well. It is the entrance to the city park and the attractions around it like the baths, wheel of time etc.
Very Impressive Sculptures. What a entrance to a beautiful public park and open space. The statues are amazing and portray all the key leaders of Hungary over time.

Amazing!!!. The whole area is amazing! Wouldn't miss it! There is an amazing park behind it, with a beautiful castle, and a lake full of pedal boats you can rent for 2000 huf for half hour. I recommend to read about heroes square before you get there. There is a metro line right next to it.

Just a photo op. I thought there would be more information about the statues when we got to the square. It really is just a place to take pictures. It is quite far away from the main tourist area, so unless you are visiting one of the museums there, I wouldn't bother.
read up. the large square looks impressive but if like me and my friends you dont read up then you cant graps the true definition of the square
Impressive. Took a long walk down to the square and it was well worth it. fabulous statues and behind the square found a park and zoo... a lovely day's walk.
Heroes'Square. I was thoroughly impressed with the symbolism, artistry, and thought (not to mention the grand scale) that went into this...

Powerful. Myself and my boyfriend visited Heroes Square before heading onto Szechenyi Baths. The statues of the Heroes are very powerful and the square is very well located close to Vajdahunyad Castle,a large rowing lake that is converted to an ice-rink in the winter, and Szechenyi thermal baths.
Quick visit. Worth a stop if you are on your way to the zoo or the park. We thought there would be more activity at the square, but it really is just a photo stop.

Definitely worth a look. There isn't a whole lot to do here, it is more of a photo opportunity.
The statues and monuments are pretty impressive though and it is definitely worth a visit. There are art galleries and a park nearby so you can stop by on your way to them.

A day among the statues . Visiting heros square is pretty cool. There's lots of cafes around and stalls where you can pick up a quick coffee which is nice! It's really near the famous spa too so you could do the baths and heros square in the same day! A definite must!

Nice place to visit. Easy to get to via the HOP-ON HOP-OFF bus company option but we didn't get much time here so perhaps we will visit again, but it was definitely impressive to look at and makes a nice back drop for photos!

Worthwhile. This is one of the classic Budapest sights, and it's worth a look. The monument here depicts the most famous Hungarian kings, as well as statues representing Labor, Wealth, War, Peace, Knowledge, and Glory. A walk up Andrassy Avenue to Heroes' Square and beyond into the City Park is a fantastic way to spend an afternoon.
Nice. Visited here on our way to the baths. Great if you are into sight seeing and keen in the history of cities.

Take a tour to explain everything. Heroes' square is only cool if you have someone with you or a book that explains what all of the statues and history are. If you do, it's fascinating. It's also central to a lot of other places you are going to want to visit so take some time to visit.
Great monuments. This is a must see for Budapest visitors. The monuments are gorgeous and the square offer great photo opportunities and some understanding of the history and culture of this country

Impressive Square. We walked across the square on our way back from the Szechenyi Baths and the park just to have a look a\t it. The metro is just across the road from the square. The square is huge and impressive with grand statues and impressive buildings on either side. It's probably not worth travelling to just to see the square but it can be combined with other activities in the area. I imagine it’s on all the tour routes so if you are on a tour or the hop on hoop off bus then no doubt you will visit the square. Good for a few photos.
Impressive yet empty square. Impressive square with large statues, perfect spot to take pictures. The square itself is empty and on a hot day it's too warm.
A square. Wish there were guides around to organize private tours. We literally got out from the subway, took a selfie from afar and went back to catch the next subway.

check it out. I went to Budapest twice and i got to visit it once in the summer and once in the winter,i actually love the rain and taking pictures so i loved it because i took some great shots while it rained,however no matter what sightseeing plan you will take this will be on it so dont bother and plan a trip just to check it out

Tour group. Was part of a tour and it's well planned out with bus parking to one side. Hero square itself is large enough to cope with the crowds, and there are a number of surrounding buildings to keep your attention. Interesting to have the background of the square explained to us.

Avoid crowds later in day.. By visiting later in the day, you have more chance to view the monuments and get some photos, otherwise you have coaches of other holiday makers all getting in the picture. Near by is a lake that offers boat pedalling and electric boats. Pick up points for Budapest sightseeing buses just a 2 minute walk away.
wide and far. Typical monumental place, it remembers Paris and the Bastille place even if you do not feel the same sacred reverence. More tourists than local people.
Whitish beauty. Before getting to the thermes this place welcomes you and you feel like you're a king getting the triumph after a battle. Wonderful
Sightseeing. This is a must! It is absolutely fabulous and full of statues of heroes of Hungary. It should be visited by all who visit the city.

Impressive. One of the most impressive public squaress I have ever seen, it pictures how hungarians see their nation. The wast space infront of the monument makes it look even bigger. Liked it very much.

Nice Memorial. I think given that this was one of the last stops of the final day of touring and it was very warm out, I decided not to get off the bus but just looked at the Square through the windows. There were a number of tour buses queuing to get a parking spot and it just seemed so crowded at this point. There is the water spa and museums here as well. Time to wind down and relax before heading home!

Very impresive Square. The square is very large and impressive.In the Middle of the square stands a statue of the Archangel Gabriel and Next to it there are statues of Hungarian heroes from different periods.Heroes Square is the entrance to the city park.
Where history comes to life. Here you can see great heroes of hungarian history all in one place, looking at you solemnly from above. Great monumental building worth the visit
Great Place to visit. Well worth visiting this part of Budapest; it right next to a large park with an old spa and lovely gardens.

Beautiful Place to Enjoy History. Walking through Heroes square is almost unjust as a normal citizen of earth while staring down the amazingness of heroes of the war that actually saved lives. Lots to see in Budapest but this takes the cake besides the castle on the hill.

You'll See It on the Buda Side. You'll pass by this when you're visiting the Buda side, so no need to make a special trip. It is impressive and historical, of course, so worth seeing, but not necessarily if it were the only reason you were crossing the river.
Beautiful collection in a lovely setting. Incredible, proud statues in a really lovely setting. Worth a look if you're in the area - go to the spas and museum near by to make it all worth the trip.

Nice Photo Op & Free - but not much else. Heroes' Square - you are likely going to pass this on the way to the Baths (which are a must). Lovely square - but there are a hundreds of these in the world. A nice photo for the album and free - but not a priority.
great. We visited the square and there was a group gathered as well as a lovely food market where we could taste craft beers and eat local food.
Lovely to see!. Beautiful place and yes there are a lot of statues here and they are all so different. If you love looking at statues then this is defiantly a place for you to visit .

it was hot the morning we were there. You have to have a guide for this site. The story of generations of lost wars is told in the states of heroes. It is a testament to courage and endurance and hope.
Huge!. This is a neat area with lots of people milling around. Our tour group took us here for photos and told us the history. You can walk to the city park and a nice restaurant near there.

Heroes' Square in Budapest. Heroes' Square is a beautiful open area on the far side of the fashionable Andrassy Utca, or Avenue in the city of Budapest. You can take a subway, or a bus and even a tram to visit the square and the adjoining park but you can also just take a rather log but pleasant walk up the beautiful Andrassy admiring the large and once very fashionable homes on the way. In addition to the Square, the monument, and the park, there is also a Museum, a really terrific Budapest main Museum which features great special exhibitions as well as a permanent collection on view.

Worth a visit. Very easy to get to and well worth the visit if you enjoy a bit of history. We spent around half an hour looking round the square itself, which is pristine, then spent a few hours looking around the area immediately surrounding it which boasts a large park with a museum, a zoo and the naturally heated spa baths. Tube is the easiest way to get there but buses and trams are available too.

Worth a visit. Highly recommended to visit after u went to the Szenchyi Bathhouse.Walk down and take picture here and then you can take the metro back to your place as there's a metro nearby this place. It's called " Hosok Tere"
Spectacular. A spectacular square with plenty to do around. A long walk from the centre go by hop on,it gets very busy, so good photo opportunities are not easy.

A "must-see" in Budapest. Having lived in Budapest for over 5 decades I have visited this beautiful place several dozens of times.The statues of historical heroes and kings, the column in the middle with Gabriel Archangel on the top, the seven horsemen representing the seven tribes settling in the Carpathian basin, are all reflecting the energy of ancient roots and history.The two neo classical buildings of the two sides, housing museums, with Vajdahunyad Castle in the background, surrounded by the small lake which serves skaters in winter time.All this quite close to the heart of the city, approachable by the first underground railway, which was the first on the European continent (second after London).It is really something, everybody should see, who happens to visit our beautiful capitol.

Heroes' Square & City Park. We enjoyed this, a good walk from the city centre to find it but it was lovely to see and right beside an enormous park, with lake, pedaloes, restaurant & cafes, so a good place to be with the kids, mixing history, culture and fun!

Such a difference from the rest of the city.. We spent a long weekend in Budapest and visited Heroes Square while here.The area is such a welcome change from the inner city, big and spacious and much cleaner. There is a park and a river behind the square it's self where we spent a few hours before sitting in the cafe at the front of the museum while we took in the sights of the square.Lovely afternoon out.

Fascinating Statues. We were on a city bus tour that made a stop at Heroes' Square. Glad we didn't go out of our way but happy to stop here. Lots of history, statues are fascinating. "The Millennium Monument in the middle of the square was erected to commemorate the 1000-year-old history of the Magyars. Archangel Gabriel stands on top of the center pillar, holding the holy crown and the double cross of Christianity. The seven chieftains who led the Magyar tribes to Hungary can be seen on the stand below. Statues of kings and other important historical figures stand on top of the colonnades on either side of the center pillar."
You need a guide. To understand this square and what the characters mean, you really need a guide. Otherwise its just a big open square. I would avoid if it is wet and windy as there is no cover.

Perfect memory . HERO square is very good for amazing pictures and for a good memory to keep of Budapest.Its nice to walk a bit in Andrassy street and have the beautiful view of it.Must see at least once.

the trip on the old metro makes the trek well worth it. the ride on the old metro is amazing the old stations are beautifully restored and super clean. The metro cars are small with just a few seats. Heroes' Square is another of the many monuments but just past the square on the other side of the road is a nice park for a picnic. Pack a lunch and watch the tourists taking selfies of themselves.
An impressive monument. This a striking monument with several other statues and figures surrounding it. I would thoroughly recommend this as a photo opportunity.

Lovely place for pics. We headed this way as it on the map for sightseeing, the statues are amazing, loads of space for tourists and wr even sae people having wedding photos taken here. Close to the castle once you cross over the bridge. And you can sit by the big pond. Close to metro station to take you straight into the centre of Budapest.
Beautiful. A beautiful square that you definitely should go and visit. Very overwhelming when you first see it as it's simply stunning.
Interesting. One of the stops on the tourist bus route, next to a park which has boating (summer) ice skating (winter) It is a powerful monument but probably not worth going there on its own
excellent. This is noted for its iconic statue complex of seven tribal cheiftain and other noted leaders. Many political events took place in this square.

An Excellent Square & Wonderful Park. My comments are below.The following information is from visitbudapest.travel: "Laid out in 1896 to mark the thousandth anniversary of Hungary, Heroes' Square (Hősök tere) is the largest and most impressive square of the city. Located at the end of Andrássy Avenue and next to City Park, Heroes’ Square is one of the most visited sights in Budapest. Surrounded by two important buildings, Museum of Fine Arts on the left and Kunsthalle (Hall of Art) on the right, Heroes’ Square is also a station of the Millennium Underground.The Millennium Monument in the middle of the square was erected to commemorate the 1000-year-old history of the Magyars. Archangel Gabriel stands on top of the center pillar, holding the holy crown and the double cross of Christianity. The seven chieftains who led the Magyar tribes to Hungary can be seen on the stand below. Statues of kings and other important historical figures stand on top of the colonnades on either side of the center pillar.When the monument was originally constructed, Hungary was part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire and thus the last five spaces for statues on the left of the colonnade were reserved for members of the ruling Habsburg dynasty. The Habsburg emperors were replaced with Hungarian freedom fighters when the monument was rebuilt after World War II.In 1989 a crowd of 250,000 gathered at the square for the reburial of Imre Nagy, former Prime Minister of Hungary, who was executed in 1958"I absolutely loved the visit here, until the bus loads started arriving. I had some time to kill this morning so decided to hop on the Metro to the Square. It's really beautiful and worth the effort and so easy to get to.However what drives me insane is people's need to climb on top of monuments - so disrespectful & destructive!!!!!!! I really hope the authorities address this!!Pop into the City Park while you're there....it's just beautiful and would be excellent for a picnic

Great stop on a sunny day, packed with 'Kodak moments'. This is a terrific tourist spot brimming with history and culture. well worth spending an hour or 3 with (longer if you have the time) a guide book and camera.

IF IT HADN'T BEEN POURING DOWN !!. It was absolutely belting down - nearly swore then - so it really did spoil the mornings visit. I'm sure in dry conditions it would have been really interesting. Our guide gave up she was drenched, as were we.

Beautiful!. The square beautiful to visit and there are lots of museums and the castle nearby to see all in one day. We also then spent the day at the river next to it which was fun. Definitely recommend seeing the square. There isn't any info about the history or what the statutes are of though but I suppose you can always google it!

Quite interesting. This place is very interesting because it was build as a part of celebrating 1000 years since the Hungarians settled in the area. The main statue is dedicated in part to the leaders of those tribes which migrated. Around the main statue there are columns with most famous hungarians in history with their names below each statue. This is very nice feature, but there should be more information on the site in form of some tourist info boxes or something.One of the most photographed places in the city. Quite a lot of tourists, and the level of decay is visible. Should be more well-looked after in my opinion.

Beautiful. It is worth visiting this square twice: by day as the starting point of a trip to city park, the nearby galleries, zoo or Szechenyi Baths; and by night, when it is spectacularly lit up.Amazing statues

Fine but not a destination in itself for most. Fine but not a destination in itself for most. Like many such squares it has lots of significance and symbolism but for casual tourists nothing much happens there.
Fantastic place. Fantastique place and close to other important attarctions such as a beautiful castle and the baths (Szechenyi).

FULL OF HISTORY. Heroe's Square is chock full of history and part of a World Heritage site. There is a huge column in the middle of it and a couple of museums on either side. To the back of it is the City Park, the world's first public park.

Impressive. Firstly I can't believe how far out this is, it took around 30 mins to walk to from Elizabeth Square! Luckily it was beautiful and worth it. A bit strange how it's in the middle of the road with no barriers etc as cars are flying past. Lovely way ti recognise heroes.

Take a walk to the Heroes' Square. You can almost smell the greatest times in Hungarian history when you stand at Heroes' Square. It is quite big and monumental. Both the square itself and the neoclassical buildings surrounding it.There is a metro station at the square. I would however recommend to take a walk from the city centre via Andrássy Avenue. This way you can also enjoy the impressive architecture from around 1900.

Like big heroic statues? This is the place for you. Originally full of flower beds this large paved area was an entrance to the Budapest World Fair of 1896. You can still see some pavilions in the park nearby. It is basically a large open space with some huge statues of all sorts of Hungarian virtues. There is a group of impressive horsemen, representing the founding tribes who settled in Hungary in 896. Worth a photo or two. Also check out: the two art museums, and the place where Madonna as Evita stood on her balcony. This is next door to a very nice crepe cafe.

Interesting square that honors the heroes of Hungary. We stopped at Heroes' Square on our tour of Budapest as part of our Viking River Cruise. It is an interesting area near museums, the zoo and one of the famous bath houses. It is worth a quick visit.

Impressive momument of Hungarian heroes. This Square is an impressive plaza decorated with statues of Hungarian heroes - statues of the leaders of the seven tribes that founded Hungary in the 9th century and other important figures of Hungarian history, as well Hapsburg era monarchs (since Hungary was part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire when the monument was built). The Square is the entrance to the City Park. One either side there are art museums that are worth visiting. The famous Thermal Bath is behind the Square in City Park. There is a convenient Metro (subway) stop at the Square.

Rainy quick trip. While on a Viking River Cruise one of our stops was Heroes' Square - in July - it was a cool and rainy day but we were fortified with umbrellas and jackets - got out of bus and had our guide give us a thumbnail of information about the Square. Very cool to see.

Wandering amid the castles. You can just meander through this huge park, pretending you're back in a time where castle ruled the day. This huge green area is sprinkled with immense buildings. Plus, there were a very cheap Bach concert in the chapel, which was a pleasant surprise!

Popular Spot for Photo Oportunity. A large paved area with impressive monuments. Archangel Gabriel on top of a 36mt pillar flanked by tribal chieftains. In front of the pillar is the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. To either side of the pillar are curved colonnades depicting 14 of Hungary's rulers/statesmen.Either side of the square are a couple of museums/Exhibition halls.Excellent for photos but you will be lucky to get a photo without other people in unless you are pointing skywards

Definitely a must. Amazing monument with numerous statues celebrating the country's past. Well worth spending time to visit here, and it's away from the other tourist places so you get to see more of the city on the way.There is a nice park behind where you can escape from the traffic and tourists.
Interesting monument. We took the tour with Gate 1 travel. The square is sort of unique if you can hear about all the history of Buda and Pest. It is not a must see, but is interesting.

Inspiring. A large area of big monuments. Would be nice to have bigger signs down lower to show who each "hero" is. Beware it's impossible to take a photo just of the statues because stupid tourists insist on climbing the statues and taking selfish-ies!!
For a picture . It's a 3D background for vacation photos. You can read stories about the statues in the hotel on Wikipedia but still not extremely entertaining.

Budapest difficult history. An interesting stop. We took the metro and exited across the street from this square on our way to the Szechenyi baths. We enjoyed the park nearby and stopped for lunch in a small cafe. The square contains many statues of Hungarian heroes and kings. I believe it is also the location of the protests that led to the failed attempt of revolution in 1956 where many lost their lives.

Well worth a visit, close to many other attractions. Heroes square celebrates the heroes of the Hungarian nation. the square is very impressive and is flanked on two sides by museums and is the gateway to the city park, the zoo and the City Circus, which is well worth a visit in its own rite. You can easily get to the square by taking the Underground (Yellow line) which is also of interest as the first underground system in Europe after London.

A must visit located right next to the city park. A visit to the heroes' square is a must do when you visit Budapest. The grand square and it's pillars and statues represents important national leaders and also there's the tomb of the unknown soldier. After you've seen the square itself you have the museum of fine arts on one side and the art exhibition hall(Kunsthalle) on the other.

Rather expensive for the money. We went to see the dinosaurs exhibit with my 8 year old son. We chose to go on Monday as price differ for each day. Monday is the cheapest. Adult: 2300FtChild (2-14 years): 1600Ft. I am glad we did. The exhibition starts with an hour and half movie that you can watch sitting on folding chairs or sitting on the floor - we didn't watch it as it was not really about dinosaurs, it was more about bulling and the movie used personalized dinos' characters trying to create a rather boring story. After entering the exhibit we found our self in a rather dark place. They tried to create a night set I think. There were about 8 different dinosaur on display that was suppose to be interactive. All they did was occasionally they moved their mouth and tail and there was growling sound coming out from their mouth in about every 20 seconds. The figures were about 1/3 of a stated real size of the animals. They also had two mammoth species on display with a rather impressive size and a couple of other creatures from the late cretaceous time. It was hard to take a good picture is it was dark there.Exiting the exhibition there was a small dinosaur with a saddle and the children were able to ride it for a jetton that you need to buy at a rather small souvenir shop - one shelf of items but mostly catering for the other exhibition - GOAL.The chair on the dinosaur was moving up and down on the back of the rubber animal and that was it. On the other side of the dino ride there was a huge sand box set up so children were able to experience what it takes to be a paleontologist.I would recommend this place with children under 8. Time required for the visit: 20 minutes + the movie time if you are interested. Length of the movie: 1.5 hour.A Dinosaurs exhibit is from 2016. June 20 to August 22. There is an exhibit called Invisible Exhibit which is to educate the visitors about the world of the blind people. It offers either massage, dinner or vine tasting experience. Recommended for older children or adults.There is an exhibit for soccer fans called GOAL, right next to the Dinosaur place but we didn't visit that one.

Hungary’s heroes. In City Park (Városliget) at the northeast end of Andrassy (opposite the Danube) is a paved plaza with dozens of statues. Heroes’ Square is one of Budapest’s major squares. The iconic statue complex features the Seven Chieftains of the Magyars and other important national leaders, as well as the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. It is a phenomenal photo op, and hosts the Museum of Fine Arts and the Műcsarnok. The square plays an important part in contemporary Hungarian history and has been a host to many political events, such as the reburial of former Prime Minister Imre Nagy in 1989, who had died in 1948. The sculptures were made by sculptor Zala György. The Square is surrounded by the significant Museum of Fine Arts and Palace of Art (or more accurately Hall of Art).
Visit the zoo. Behind the square there is a fab zoo. A must visit. Then cross the road and have a walk around the lovely castle. Then in the square itself take a selfie in front of the Budapest sign.
Much to see. There is much to see at Heroes' Square. Visiting it is free. Next to square there is an old castle and a big park.
Heroe's Square. Not to be missed. Beautiful sculptures. Also see the lake behind it. The thermal baths and zoo are close by.
10 minutes visit. I am not super interested in this square, though it is beautiful & grand. We were there for just 10 minutes.

Walking in Budapest. Hi!Hero square is one of main sightseeing points of Budapest. Monuments and surrounding building and attraction can be found on google map and official website. These are much accurate than my knowledge. Be sure if you would like to visit the (e.g.>National Art Gallery, Vajdahunyad vár) it takes minimum one day. Around the square there are some good restaurants also. e.g Robinson, Gundel. Be sure not the cheapest one, but quality is fine.

Interesting show rehersal. We had a wonderful treat as they were in the midst of rehearsing a huge show with horses, dancers and costumes. From what we could tell it was the history of Hungary. The statues are nice and there are many museums that surround the square as well as a nice restaurant right on the water.

Unique, and historically interesting. Fascinating to see how Hungarians liked to view themselves 120 years ago, at the height of the country's power, pre-WWI: their ancestors had not just moved there 1000 years earlier - no, they had CONQUERED. Look at the wild horsemen at the centre of the square: each one of them could give you the shivers. There is plenty more to see around Hero's Square; this just happened to catch my attention (i am a lover of horses).

Nice visit. Well the nice square is the main enterence to the park. Its very nice walk. Zoo, Circus, playground, trampolines, littel "lake" with small boats to hire, beautiful castel and its garden, and many resturants. We visit the place on sunday mornings it was busy mostly with locals and has open dance and music shows. Great time.

A brief look at the history of Hungary. Heroes Square is on every tour of Budapest. It tells the history of Hungary in its statues. Be prepared for crowds because every tour company comes here. Free to visit.
Hero's Square. Unfolds many heroic stories and is pictures in many hollywood movies, music videos and Bollywood films too. Loved visiting the square for pictures
a must see in Budapest. On the -Pest side of Budapest. A very impressive square, with statues of historical rulers and "heroes" and even a tomb of their unknown soldier.

Breathtaking sight. From riding the hop on hop off from the inner city chain bridge stop, the route takes you through the town houses (now mainly embassy's) and the square appears at the end of the street. Located near the square is also the szechenyi thermal baths, zoo and circus which can all make up a few good hours itinerary! The square itself is a must see when visiting Budapest and I recommend taking the hop on hop off to learn a little bit about the square itself. A great photo opportunity and would recommend anyone to make sure it's on the list to see!

History and Fun . large square in the heart of Pest, characterized by monuments in the ranks of the various kings of Hungary. very nice and fun, even the back of the square, with beautiful gardens, historic attractions such as museums and churches and even from touristic attractions and entertainment as a frozen lake for skating .... romantic and fun !!
Beautiful Square. Don't miss out, easy to access via underground. All the past heroes of Hungary are represented as statues, and very close to a lovely park, the Szecheny Baths & Pool and a zoo.
Lifelike bronzework. I had read about this Square in novels and newspapers, but was not prepared for what I saw. It's amazing , statues are lifelike well worth visit.

Lovely clean square with well maintained statues. Stumbled across this square while walking to the spa. Nice looking with some large statues to look at. Reminded me of the brandenburg gate in berlin.
Free to look at and wheelchair accessible as all flat.
Surrounded by busy roads but a nice park other side with the spa and hapsburg place In.
worth the visit but not much there. We visited hero's square as part our Leger coach tour. while the monuments were good there is not much e;lse to do once you have seen them

In front of a beautiful park there is a huge monument. The heroes' square tells us about the origin of Hungarian people and the history of the 7 tribes. The statues are supernatural and worth to stay there a bit more. Around the square is an art gallery, the Vajdahunyad castle, the park and Andrassy Avenue.You can combine all these and the zoo in a beautiful day walk.

Lovely area. We spent the morning at the Baths and then walked across to this area through a park. The square itself is very dramatic and well worth a visit. Across from the square is a museum and park which is absolutely beautiful. It was so peaceful and we were there at lunchtime. There are huge ponds where you can hire paddle boats. Absolutely beautiful location and very romantic. Only a ten minute metro (1) ride from centre. It was one of the most beautiful places we visited in Budapest.
All the Hungarian Heroes. Beautiful monument with lots of historical background. Need to take a guided tour like we did to really get the full history.
you feel the history. A big and space square. You can feel the speace and history going through Hungary. When you come in the evening it is nicely iluminiated.
sightseeing must. Tells you all you need to know about Budapest historical past. A must if visiting the city. Right next to fabulous city park as well.
A huge monument. It is a must as a tourist to visit this monument. It is too big to miss. Lots of people on and arround the statue.
Beautiful square. A very beautiful square. Can recommend visiting the place early morning or late evening to avoid vast amounts of tourists. It is also very beautiful at night.

Quite impressive. The architecture is quite impressive here and quite moving to walk through and look at the different statues, however it's more of a walk through for a few minutes but it's quite a beautiful square and worth the visit.
Beautiful. A popular bus drop off point but it worth a visit and is also close to the park, boating lake and the zoo. The statues are well looked after and a nice spacious area.
Take in the history. Again using the hop on and off bus to get to this place, the recorded audio on the bus will explain what Heroes' Square is about. It is also close to Szechenyi Bath and Spa

Glad I stopped by.. I visited Heroes Square around 10:30am on Saturday, July 2nd. I was early for the opening of the Terror Museum, so I walked from the Oktogon M1 stop to the Heroes Square. It was a very hot morning, so the shaded walk to Heroes Square was very comfortable. And along the way there are some very cool buildings to check out. When I got there it was fairly busy with tourists. There are a lot of tour buses in the area. I did not venture very far in the square and I may have missed out on things to see or do. But what I did see was very impressive. i am glad that I took the time to check it out.
Solemn and dramatic. This place is the epitome of the Hungarian spirit emphasised by its bronze sculptures: strong, dramatic, and unbreakable.
Beautiful Square!. This is one of the top 10 monuments in Budapeste.Is a large square with great sculptures and architecture.

Lots of interest in this part of Pest. This is an altogether interesting part of Pest to spend some time.....with the Square itself the central area surrounded by the city zoo and parkland, and historic bathing house. You could easily spend half a day or more just browsing around this part of town

Impressive square at the end of Andrassy on Pest. Situated at the end of the very elegant Andrassy is Heroes' Square with a large semi circle of statues of all the previous leaders and prominent figures. At one end is the National Museum - closed for refurbishment until 2017. Behind is a large park with ice skating in Winter or boating in Summer, a market selling crafts and the famous Szechenyi Baths and pool which are well worth a pit stop after all that pounding of the streets.

Recommended on sundays, there're people dancing salsa at a close palace. It's a very nice place, wide and opened. At summer nights there are no so much traffic and I was the opportunity to go to a monument a the eastern side of the square where you could dance salsa and have a drink. It's only available on sundays but every day of the week is good to visit this place. In summer, I recommend to go near the sunset because there are no so many places with shadow and it's usually very hot.
amazing. we arrived by car and were thrilled by its beautifullness. We walked arount and it was better. we visited it 2 times during the day and by night.
Heroes Square. A must see. Statues of all their heroes. Very interesting history and a must see while in Budapest. It is a very wide park and lots of tourists....
A sense of history. Very well kept historical structures only enhance the feel of the area and the history of the City and country.
Very scenic. Lovely monument and two nice museums along either side. Easy access from the subway. Also easy walking distance to the Szezny baths and the park

Very beautiful suare. A very big and beautiful square. easy to access by Metro.
Next to the park, the Zoo and the Circus. recommended.
Very impressive.. Very impressive meeting point of National significance. Very busy but can't be missed. Fine sculptures and great photo spot.

Great, but better with a guide. It's a place you visit, enjoy and forget about if you don't have a guide to tell you the story of the monument... Don't go on a rainy day as it is far from city center.
Very busy square in Budapest well worth visiting. Lots of people gather here and many museums around to see. The Zoo is not far way either. Also near by are the Baths and the City Park.

Interesting but you need a guide to get the most out of this . We went here as part of a Segway tour so we're lucky enough to have the history of all of the statues explained and how they relate to the history of Hungary.
Great if you have a guide.

Magnificent memorial . The column and the arches have some really beautiful statues on them all the kings of hungry sculptures depicting war and pease. The angel at the top of the column with the cross. The thumb un known soldier. Zoo and city park are not far away worth a stop as well

Amazed!. While on. Pest, went to visit this great and big square which to my surprise it was really amazing. Love the scenery, the symbols, the space around! The tour guide explained it all and how and when it was used during the Nazy and Communist times. It's a must to see and understand!
Pretty but not amazing . Wandered here by accident on the way to the baths. It was cool to see and right near the park but I wouldn't purposefully have gone here if I wasn't going to the baths.
Looks great!. Looks really great, but parking is difficult. Still the park is really relaxing and you can go to the Huniads Castle from there.
Best place. Very monumental square. The states are huge and very detailed. Lot of museum all around the square. The Budapest Zoo is very near. And you can take lot of picture.
Worth the visit . It's a must-see in Budapest, and worth the visit. But, it is not much more than a square. Good for pictures, and on the way to the thermal bath further down the street.

Nice place to see a piece of Hungarian history. The square itself is nice, but not that breathtaking at all. The statues of monarchs of the country are nice way to think about Hungarian history, see their heroes, famous and also not that well known monarchs of the country.

Lots of places to see for FREE. First, it's easy to get to by metro. It was a bit crowded but we managed to get good pics regardless. Behind the square is a great park with a gorgeous castle. It costs to go in so we just meandered through and it was gorgeous. There are paddle boats, the zoo, and circus are close by. A short metro ride away is the Terror House. An amazing museum to check out while in the area! Overall, go on a good weather day and bring a picnic or bottle of wine!!
If you're passing. Worth a look If you're passing or going to the City park, quite impressive but full of tourists.....
Very nice. Heroes' Square is a wonderful place, many statues of figures of Hungarian history. We had a great walk in the park behind. The Museum of Fine Arts deserves at least a couple of hours.

An impressive column and surrounds if you can avoid the crowds. Maybe I was unlucky but this was the one place I visited in my 10 days in Budapest that was heaving with tourists - I counted 9 coaches parked in the square. I was there at about 10.30 on a Saturday morning. The layout of the square makes it most attractive to view from the West, so I would recommend late afternoon and perhaps to avoid the weekend.

Πλατεία των Ηρώων (Hősök Tere). A big wonderful place! The statues are just amazing! I was without breath from the view! They are so good keeping and each one separate has his one beauty. I can choose which time is better to visit day or night.. Take your camera and prepare to take a lot of pictures!

A good city square. This is a place to visit, but not in summer at noon!
The statues and the design of them are wonderful, and it is very easy to get there by taking the yellow metro line. It is an interesting line, which you can enter by just going down the stairs 2-3 meters below
Hero`s Square a must see!. An absolute must see for any history buff! The massive expanse lets your imagination run wild as to the visitors that viewed this venue before you!

Beautiful area. Heroes Square is a beautiful plaza with statues of great Hungarian leaders and is at the center of many other attractions like the art museum and opera house. However, if you don't know what it is, and you don't read Hungarian, there is not much information at the site. Do your homework before you go or have your phone ready to get more information. Definitely a must see and a starting point for many other must see places like Andrassy Ut, Varosliget, museums, the circus, the Zoo and Széchenyi bathhouse.

Truly magnificent. It is difficult not to be impressed by this location. Surrounded by museums, decorated with the tomb of the Unknown Soldier, and breathtaking statues and monuments, this is a must do activity. Within walking distance of the city park and at the end of the major boulevard from the city centre. Many photo taking opportunities at a place of significance.

Meaningful to Hungarians. This is a very meaningful square to Hungarians. It has sculptures of all of their ancient kings, their 'founding fathers.' From my Hungarian friends I can attest to the fact that this elicits the kind of feelings that the Lincoln Memorial elicits in Americans. However for a non-Hungarian it is not a powerfully moving square, with only the figures on horseback to capture one's attention.

Heroes's Square. You really need a guide & unlike me, pay attention to what is said, to know the importance of this huge square. Not as crowded as other sites, but nevertheless, a good photo op.
Must see!!. Beautiful setting and gorgeous statues, absolute must see. Walked around here and went around as part of the bus tour and found it very interesting!

Somber, but you need a guide to explain what you are seeing. This is a large square with a lot of history, much of it actually prior to the 1956 "events" here. In order to understand everything that has happened here, I strongly recommend a tour guide. You will also be approached constantly by vendors trying to sell you things which you do not want or need. Awe inspiring. Great to see - everyone should visit on a trip to Budapest (ignoring the idiots climbing on the statues of course). Great for photos and to people watch, the beer bike tours leave from here so you're guaranteed many comedy moments watching them coming back... and tourists falling over the floor drunk.

Impressive. This square is huge and impressive. The statues and column give this square an imposive look.
You can't miss this square when going to the Szechenyi Baths.
Huge square with splendid architecture . That one is a bit further away from center but you should still go there and take a look. Afterwards go to the city park. The square itself is grand!

Lovely for photos . Brilliant open square..great baths nearby so take your swim wear! There are lots of tour buses and local buses that take you to this place but all in all its around a 23 minute walk back to budapest central e square.
Great. A large area having statues of war heroes but useful to spend some time specially seems great in night for a photo & relaxing

Not worth travelling all the way out for, but it is nearby a few museums and galleries that are worth visiting. The photos pretty much show you what you will get. It is a nice monument to marvel at and is not too crowded with tourists.

Beautiful place. It is an excellent place to start your way around this area, it has a big park behind it and museums next to it. When you hear the history related to Heroes' Square, you get to like it more. Excellent place to take panoramas.

Thought provoking. Heroe's Square is thought provoking, the statues as in all Budapest are beautiful but if you read up on the history a little before you go, you will find yourself taking a minute to think of all those who have list their lives for their country.

NOT THAT BIG A DEAL. This landmark is famous for being famous. Actually, it is impressive, but the surrounding area is much more interesting. Within a few minutes of walking, you'll find the zoo, the Szechenyi Baths, the Fine Arts Museum (which was closed when I visited in April), parks with nice walking paths and some excellent restaurants.

Great History. The history which this square represents is fascinating. The key is to have a licensed tour guide with you to explain the detail and representation of the various statues. Be sure to visit Heroes' Square when in Budapest.

Quick look at some statues. We just took a quick look at the statues. This is a very big, not-very-friendly square with statues of famous Hungarian rulers. A few minutes walking past with the kids is about all they could handle. There are no explanations or signs, besides the names of the people under their statue, so you have to know Hungarian history in order to appreciate it.

Stunning. For some inexplicable reason some visitors appear to be underwhelmed by Heroes' Square. We thought that it was stunning. Follow this with some refreshment in a cafe overlooking the lake and the fairytale castle before strolling across the bridge to take a closer look at the castle etc.
A must see in Budapest. Besides the square, the surrounding area is nice as full of parks and water canals. It's a good place for families as well.
Beautiful landmark. This landmark is beautiful. There are also museums surrounding the square and an ice skating rink behind it. Worth the visit!
To be seen. Monumental square at the end of long Andrassy street, views and photos are nice, as well as the park behind

Great square with a lot of history. Great square filled with activity. Especially on the weekends. There are musicians playing and fun activities. There is also a public park next to it where you can relax. The Vadjahunyad is great for photos, but not to tour. There are limited restrooms in Heroes Square for free, but the Mucsanok building adjacent to he square in the basement floor had excellent restroom facilities free of charge. Worth your time to experience. When you leave walk down the road leading away from it back to town. (I forget the name, but there are many local places to eat).

Lovely square. Beautiful square !! Next to a really nice park the spa nearby is over rated but regardless very historic and worth a visit. There is an information desk nearby and the staff there were excellent and very helpful in comparison with other people we met on our trip. Worth a photo and amazing detail. You can also get a bus service free to the aquaworld which i really recommend !!

Beautiful square. Well worth visiting along with the park and castle. Lovely square seeped in history would recommend going with a tour so you can learn about all the statues and who they represent. Very interesting
huge space. Who does not know? If you go in Hungary will likely fall your way if you are looking for not only the city center. Set in a large park near!

Looks cool but.... Heroes Square is definitely a cool spot to swing by and take pictures. However, when I had visited, there was either some construction going on or an event set up that prevented me from venturing further into the square for pictures.Despite not being able to see much due to the objects in the way, this place definitely is nice to stop by. Also, the park nearby is pretty sweet, so I do recommend walking around the area!

Amazedby the history . A tribute to the rich history of Hungary. Well worth exploring. It is free and very informative.Wouldhelp to read a little prior to visiting in order to understand the Hungarian spirit that never gives up and fights for justice. A truly impressive experience

Must-See Site . On the Pest-side of the city, the Heroes' Square must be the key attraction with the ever growing visitors. However the vast square is quite sufficient to accommodate the large influx of visitors. Just don't expect a clean photo. Expect crowd as part of the photo with the monuments and all will fall into place. Lately, the Bike's Bar became part of the scene. The Heroes' Square is en route for the new invention of combining the moveable bar paddle by the clients around the restricted route with free flow of beer. Watch out for it.
heroes square. really gorgeous park with plenty to do places to eat and drink in abundance we spent a lovely day there make sure you visit its a must

Remembering Hungary's important people. Located at the end of Andrassy Street by Varosliget/City Park, Heroes Square is too far to walk from St. Stephen's Cathedral, but is certainly accessible by tram and metro. The square was very spacious even though the monuments on it were huge. The square was built in 1896 to commemorate 1000 years since the Magyars settled in Hungary and had been used as a parade area during communist times.In the center of the square was the Millennium Memorial. It consisted of a very tall fluted column on top of which a bronze statue of a winged Gabriel held St. Stephen's crown and the double cross of Christianity. What caught my eye, however, was the dais surrounding this column. It had bronze statues of the 7 Magyar tribal leaders sitting on horses. These rugged looking men were responsible for the Magyars settling in Hungary 1000 years ago. On either side of this column were 2 colonaded semi-circular structures on which stood 14 bronze statues of important people in the history of Hungary - 7 on each side. Underneath each was a plaque with the name of the person represented and a scene from his life, done in relief. It was interesting to see what all these important people in Hungary's history like St. Stephen or Matthias looked like. While 7 of the statues were kings of Hungary, the 7 others were men who were associated with important battles/victories. On the ends of the colonaded structure were 4 statues. Two of them were the common ones often seen on triumphal arches - 2 horses drawing a chariot. The male figures in each represented war and peace. The other two had groups of figures which represented wealth coming from work and knowledge. All of these bronze figures had aged to a lovely turquoise patina which contrasted impressively with their beige marble surrounds. This memorial was very interesting to look at as there were so many details to examine. I also liked that Hungary celebrated these people who had contributed in different ways, but all significantly, in making Hungary a country. I was really impressed with this tribute and the skill it took to cast these figures.  In front of this huge memorial, was a memorial stone or cenotaph for all of Hungary's other unknown war heroes. It was surrounded by an ornamental chain barrier. We just had about a 15 minute stop here on our city bus tour. The guide did point out 2 buildings on the side of the square - the Museum of Fine Arts and the Kunsthalle/Hall of Arts should we wish to return as well as the City Park behind which looked like a great place for a stroll under the shady trees.
Fit for Heroes. A very large square with a very large impressive monument. Built more than 110 years ago to commemorate the 1000 years of the Magyars of Hungary.

Nice Large Square. Beautiful proportions, stunning sculptors all this make for a square which is truly artistic. it has a great ambience and here it is all about scale. Just to appreciate the great artists who created this space
Holidays in Budapest . One of the main places , that you need to see during your visit to Budapest. Not big square but nice, and now touristy place.

Memorial to the fallen soldiers, to the Hungarian kings. The square is huge. In the middle of the square there are the statues of the Hungariuan kings. Here is also the memorial to the unknown soldiers. It is used several times in a yaer for bigger events, like concerts, or even political meetings.
Impressive. This historical site is absolutely awe inspiring. The statues tell a complete history of the Hungarian rise to power. The square itself is really beautiful.

One of the highlights not to be missed. Had a little trouble getting here at night but the subway was the answer and easy to navigate once you made the attempt. You must see this in daylight and at night. Night time is spectacular.

Interesting but ideal with a tour. My partner and I walked past the heroes square the first time after the spar party and spent a while looking around it and all the statues in the square. Whilst this was an amazing sight, it was hard to really know the significance of the statues. However after doing a hop on hop off bus tour we were given more of an insight into the meanings. Therefore if you have time I would recommend doing tours that go past it. If not just have a look and take it all in.
Good to See. A great lesson in history at Heroe's Square. Easy access but often crowded. Do be aware there may be pick pockets.
great to see. using the hop on hop off bus is a great way to see the sites and this is on the tour, you can get off here and have a walk round, pretty park and boating lake nearby
Nice spot. you should come here once when sun is setting down ;) in the day light it looks great but even better in twilight
Nice. Nice memorial, however not a must see in Budapest in my opinion. Closed off when we were there so perhaps put me off

Part of Fungarian Public Transportation Tour. Our guide from Fungarian - Balazs - offered a brief history of Hungary based on the statues of the kings in Heroes Square. Excellent background to the nation and the people. It was good to have a local guide explain the history using the stories of these leaders.

Not the nicest. Aside from the historical value, the square is not the nicest. But it is at the entrance of a beautiful park that leads to the popular bath. It is as well at the end of the Andrassy street which is worth walking

Great sculptures and structures in the middle of the city & great river side picnic opportunity!. You can take buses here or the hop on hop off.
Make it your lunch time point & bring a cut lunch, there is plenty of places to have a quick picnic or pick up something.
The structures are just magnificent, make time to read the inscriptions! Not a great activity for a rainy day sadly!

Interesting Place. It's a large square dedicated to the heroes of the country. We came at night and it seemed more impressive than when we passed by it earlier in the day. The statues were great to look at. Don't speak the language so couldn't decipher who they were or why they were admired, but artistically it was impressive and aesthetic. Also a great place to people watch as we saw more people than expected at that time of night.

Wonderful spot. Well wort a visit. We used the hop on hop off big bus company to get there. As with most of Budapest the architecture is stunning. Lots of beautiful statutes to admire and really close to several art galleries.
Best seen at night. We visited the site both during the day and at night time. The lights at the beauty at night. It is safe to visit there at night with family or friends

Nice place to hang out. This area is quite popular with people on their bachelor and hen parties. Groups of people who "Party While you Pedal" can be seen around. These can be rented around the Heroes' Square.

Labor Day - May 1st - what a party!. In case you stay in Budapest on May 1st - it is a must to spend some hours amongst the hundred thousand people enjoying a good time here - and a time to contemplate on social welfare and labor rights. IN between you can choose amongst local food and drinks. Enjoy!

Great statues, worth going to see. The square is larger than expected with various statues and monuments. We should have read up on it more since there is no information available at the site to explain what you are looking at. Take a tour book or something similar.

Not much to see here. It is a monument which is on every tourist guide and consistently has good rating here, but honestly it is just a giant open square with very large statues. And that's it! Even for someone like me who is definitely interested in the history and the people of Hungary, just looking at the statues is not a great experience. If you want to know more about the history go to the national museum. Besides, it is a huge open space, so on a sunny day it is most unrecommended. I can understand that for Hungarians it is a place of huge symbolism. But for the visitor it offers little. The up side, if you are going to Szechenyi baths and you take the bus or the metro, it is on your way to give it a quick look.

Iconic and Wonderful Monument!. We came by this place for a photo-stop visit after visiting the Mattias Church and the Fisherman's Bastion as part of our city walking tour (do refer to my earlier reviews on these places here too). It was already late morning and sunny but there were lots of visitors there as well.The monument from afar looked great and magnificent. Each of the statue there has a story behind and our guide explained to us in details about the historical background of this monument. It does invoke some sense of patriotic feeling.Unfortunately during our visit, we were not allowed to enter the square as the area was fenced off as there was a rehearsal for some kinds of national or anniversary event on gong as we saw performers, horse riders taking up their positions and roles intensely. On the other side, site workers were busy wiring up the lightings and arranging the seats. As such, we could only stand from a distance to watch it and taking photos and of course could not see the entire square from where we stood.We trust the night view here will be more beautiful and grander due to the special lightings that add splendor to the status and monument!Fortunately, our coach driver later drove us past the square 2 times to allow us to see the entire square (though we were on the coach and only seeing faintly but its better than nothing). It was then we realized how magnificent and grand the place was and the fine work that were done in setting up this place during those days!From here, the Kunsthalle (Contemporary Art Museum) is just directly opposite where one could visit and just next to it, are an open market with several makeshift stalls selling food and drinks, candies and souvenirs etc, in front of the car park. The entire area is full of vibrancy and energy and one can simply spend hours exploring the place to understand more about Hungary culture, arts, history and the lifestyle of the people!Highly recommended.
Impressive. Impressive monument and a good photo opportunity. Easy to get to with a metro station only a minute away.
Was expecting more somehow!. Very Roman in design this is a large empty square with some pillars and statues. Seen it done better in Rome.
Impressed. A sight not to be missed - very impressive an excellent tribute to the heroes - lots of traffic around but plenty of space to enjoy the view .

Beautiful attraction. Heroes' Square is truly a beautiful monument in Budapest. It is definitely one to see! Before you cross the bridge to enter the park, on the right is an area where you can hire boats to go on the lake, and hire electric cars. We hired both, but one of our highlights of our Budapest trip was the cars around the park. It is a great way to see the park, as well as have fun in something you wouldn't usually do. They do pick up some speed, and you can go offroad with them as well - I would 100% recommend anyone in Budapest to do this!

impressive. not too large, but a very well designed square. what I especially like the the terrace at the Museum: you can have a drink in the loggia and watch life go by on the square. Absolutely great!

Awe Inspiring. This monument is much larger in person that it appears in photographs since it's difficult to capture the entire square in one frame. We were pleased to be able to wander around the square and look at all of the statues of the seven chieftains of the Magyars who founded Hungary. The tomb of an unknown soldier is also here and is often covered with flowers. Parking in this area can be difficult so public transportation would be advisable.

Must See. Easy to get to by metro and amazing sites around this area. It was humbling to stand in Heros Square and take the time to look at all the heros statues and appreciate the view. Be warned ot was 34° when we visited and its a suntrap so take your sunscreen and a hat if you visit when its warm :)
History! . Nice place for pictures. Quite open. And most of activities are around hero square. Thermal bath just walking. Beer bikes in evening but it's painful. Need a gang. Lot of tourist.

Closed when we were there!. I was disappointed that you could not get access into the square when we visited. It was all set up for a concert of some sort and full of seats and lighting/sound towers with a fence covered in sheeting all round. So we could see a little of the outside but really disappointed because the photos look good.Next to the City park and easy access from the Metro so you may be luckier than we were when you visit!
Very Intersting. This is a great place to take photos with the monument statues they are wonderful has craftsman ship and are part of the Hungarian history.

Impressive.. Resembling Nelsons Column it is a great square to relax for a bit. The 3 directions of busy traffic comes to a halt when the square appears. We visited it before our spa trip and tied the park into the visit too. A great place to visit if you are in that area

History of Hungary. Very nice square, our guided tour started here, after a short bus ride. Hungary history starts here for tourist, large area that attracted a lot of tourist. The artistic statues are really beautiful.

Must see. This is one of the"must see"parts of Budapest. It is a lovely square where you can easily go by CitySeightseeing busses or other one like that (Hop on-Hop off). It was the place where a festival took place in april, lots of souvenirs and food.
An awesome attraction.. This is a must see stop on the city tour, the square is an amazing place to visit and listen to the stories of the hero's statues.

STUNNING!!!. You may not spend a lot of time admiring the square, but it is a mix of what appears to be hellenistic artistry inspired by the heroes' of the past. You simply cannot go to Budapest and not gaze upon the wonder and mystery of heroes' square.
Very Impressive. The Hungarians know how to remember the leaders in their great history, with beautiful statues in an impressive square. It is well worth a hop off on the hop on hop off bus.
Beautiful square!. A beautiful square with great sculpture. It was raining when we visited, so little activity around, but still worth a visit.

Great to walk along. Steeped in history, lots to see, why have I not been here before! Go north of the river to visit the Basilica, Heroes square is also a must, nip into the train station to witness the grandeur, behind the train station is a shopping mall, lots of shops that you would find in UK city centres, explore the city by open top bus, you'll see more.

Very nice spot in Budapest. Heroes square is a must visit if you go in Budapest.It's one of the major squares in Budapest noted for its iconic statue complex featuring the Seven Chieftains of the Magyars and other important national leaders.

interesting and picturesque. I wouldn't recommend planning this as a whole day activity, or even an hour activity, it's great to go and see if you are in the area or to view on the hop on hop off bus, but its a very short story behind it and it is just a monument, there's not much to do here. Rather like Nelsons column. You need to visit here with a guide or something to understand what it really represents.

Stag drop off. We stopped off here on our beer bike tour and it's an amazing place in the sun. Loads of open space and is the centre point of the city, you can't miss it. The architecture here is amazing.

Central, touristic, must visit. Heroes' square has got a lot of activity and histrory around it. There is a food street lined where u can get traditional hungarian food and beer. Budapest zoo, central park , museum are all 5 minutes walk from the square. U can also try your 'feet' at the beer peddler.
Grand Square. Rented a motorcycle and my gf and I went around the whole city! This was one of the places we stopped at and it was well worth it!

Nice if youre walking by. Everyone said that this was a must see spot but I was disappointed . It wasn't bad, just not awesome. It was also a hive of tourists. I went on a Sunday morning and there were coach loads of people there. I'd recommend a quite time.

Interesting plaza butget a good guide for explanation.. An interesting history to the square. Several statues depict important figures in Hungarian history but it is not obvious without some help. Quite interesting how the square evolved after Communism was expelled.
It's more of a circle. lol. Hero square is a landmark in Budapest located in one of the city's busiest roundabout. It is a great square to learn about the beginning of Budapest.

Impressive. Impressive statues, Hungary does a good statue!Not much else to see except if you have time to go to the park. Lots of stag and hen do's in the area at the time we were there but also doing a free concert that evening by the statues.Easy to get there by the metro...beware, we saw many people being fined at this spot on the metro because they had not validated their tickets, in fact one large group of lads looked as though they were fleeced.We had a three day travel pass which does not need validation and is well worth the 10£ price

Meaningful and beautiful!. This place is helping us recall history and memorialize the many persons who fought for freedom of the country. it only requires a few minutes of your time but is a reminder of spirituality and man's strengths and weaknesses.

A Tourist Trap, but Lovely. You have to see this marvelous square, but you'll be there with everyone else. Our guide from the Viking River Cruises explained why this was so important to his people, but what I loved was the sculpture. György Zala became my new favorite sculptor. Had I not been tied down to the tour, I would have loved to explore the wonderful park that abuts the beautiful square, but that wasn't on the itinerary. If you keep your eyes on the monuments you'll be fine, but if you allow one of the strolling vendors to catch your eye you'll be sorry. There were a lot of women wandering around hawking sweaters that looked very "Made in China" to me, but they won't bother you if you use the right body language. I noticed several women on our boat ended up with one of these sweaters and I discovered they'd made the mistake of engaging the vendors in conversation and they were pretty much forced to buy the sweater to get away. If sculpture or history is important to you, include a visit to this site, but it won't take long to appreciate it and move on. We happened to be there in the city for some sort of special celebration and that's how we were treated to the fun sculpture which spells out Budapest.
Perfect for a walk!. Excellent site to go for a stroll. When I was there there was a lovely market just off the square - worth the visit!

Heroes' Square. Heroes' Square is one of the most-visited attractions in Budapest. Many tourists arrive here by metro, an attraction in itself: the M1 metro line that stops at Heroes' Square is one of the world's oldest and has even been declared a World Heritage Site.
Must see. Think this is a must see in Budapest because of what it means to the locals.It is free to walk around so why not visit.Much better than L'arc de Triomphe in Paris - more to see.
Incredible. The statues and monuments in this square I are fantastic. Don't forget your camera as their are some amazing shots.
vast monument. nice to read about the history of the square and how it was opened up by the soviets - and their influence shows. nice place to people watch

Go with a guide - stories worth hearing!. Impressive and imposing....like the Hero's represented here. Take a knowledgeable guide to add value to this piece of rich history that has shaped the lives of Hungarians thru the ages.

this is main tourist spot in Budapest. Heros' Square is one of the main attractions of Budapest. It is a big square with a central structure called the Millennium Monument and in the back ground are statues of famous leaders. It is a must visit .

Heroes' Square is one of many attractions in the area. Nothing out of the ordinary but an interesting site if you have read the history to appreciate what you are viewing. Take the time to explore by foot all the other attractions nearby.

Nice picture place . Nice place to be a but photogenic. I like to visit this place at night (everything in Europe is generally prettier at night) but you could also enjoy during the day. Do opera and this place on the same day cuz it's the same metro line and they are very close anyway.

Didn't See Too Much. Unfortunately when we walked up to this Square we found that it had been converted into a stage for a huge Musical/Opera and couldn't get a good picture to it's best advantage as it was virtually covered in lights and sound eqipment. Can't give an honest opinion due to this.

Impressive square - lot's to see in the area. Relaxing park and ponds, many restaurants. We visited Heroes' Square on a warm afternoon. It's a very impressive space. Lot's of museums and activities (zoo and botanical park) are nearby. We chose to stroll the park area and sit by the pond and people watch. There are many waterside restaurants and cafes as well. Great place to spend a spare afternoon in Budapest.

A big open square with lots of monumwnt. We came en route to Szchenyi Thermal Bath. They were setting up for a concert so the entire area was closed off. It's one big open space with some monuments. The city park inside seems to be more interesting to me.
Impresive. Amazing square. Is far away so you need bus to go, but must go.Great statues everuwhere. Opportunity to take a lot of pictures.

Especially pretty by night. Heroes square at the end of the andrassy blv is one of the must see sightseeing places, especially by night when the lights are on -its simply magical. I suggest to combine it with visiting the city park next to it

Musical Show Itt elned halnod kell. We attended to this musical show, the theme was Hungarian history, and the Heroes Square gave a fantastic background to the show. Very well organized, absolutely good visual management, so thousands of people reached their seats without need of asking. The statues in the square were somehow included in the show, and the result was memorable.

Hard to appreciate due to construction. Rode by today and the whole area near the monument was full of what looked like construction platforms for some type of performance. Really distracted from the ambiance.
Amazing.. Great monument, very impressive. It took a while to walk there. But it's up by the zoo if you wanted to do both in one go. Well worth seeing.
Really impressive. Hero's Square is an impressive place. There was some type of performance-oriented going on when we were there telling the story of communism in Hungary. Very interesting.

In my view overrated . History of the Hungarian Chieftains is interesting but you best view the square from your car. Just drive around the square couple of times and call it good.
If you are on foot beware of vendors of table cloth, sweaters maps etc.
Pickpockets are often present so keep your belongings close to you.

Great monument. well worth a look, great statues and monument, fascinating piece of Hungarian history.
Take plenty of pictures

Beautiful Park and Memorial. I really enjoyed my stroll through here. I am a fan of history so it was great to see a beautiful part of the city AND get a little slice of history. It's not off the beaten path so make a point to meander by.

Beautiful!. Not only is Heroes Square gorgeous but it is directly in front of the most beautiful park! If you have a few hours to kill after walking around the square, check out the park and all of it's beautiful grassy areas!

Wow, its majestic. I loved the heroes square for the unique character of the statues, the scale and the beautiful location at one end of the beautiful Andrassy avenue. A must visit, easy accessible by metro station Hosok tere

Not worth it. The day we went the square was blocked off. The tour bus drove around the outskirts of the square but for me it's not worth the visit if you can't walk around
You should have a guide or guide book to have some sense of what the monument is all about

Budapest Heroe`s Square. Hungary`s premier ntional ceremoy site is dominated by the "Millenium Monument", a statue of the seven Hungarian tribesmen who conquered lands in year 896.
They pose at the foot of a high column with Archangel Gabriel on top in front of semicircular sttues of other historical figures

Definite Must See. Definite must see. Fantastic statues and a beautiful wide open space near the zoo and city park. Lots of attractions nearby but this is just a lovely place to spend an afternoon, taking in the atmosphere. Has to be seen to be believed.

Good to Stroll through . The Heroes Square is a must see, and it is close to the zoo, parks, Deak, City Center. When visiting Budapest one must read up on the history of Hungary to grasp the significance of the square.
It is in the middle of a huge roundabout, which is part of many Hungarians daily commute. This breath taking tourist destination...
must see. This large open area with huge statues of important persons from Hungary's history is a must see. Do a little reading beforehand so you'll know who they are.

Beautiful. Budapest is so beautiful, that I almost forgot the heroes square. Ok, it is beautiful. You have to go there, but if you have to choose between this area and the place around danube (chain bridge, buda castle, fishermans bastion), choose the second!

Much better than I thought . This is a fantastic square. The scale is huge. The central statues are amazing- I loved the warriors expressions. It wasn't busy when we were there so there was plenty of time to wander round and take photos and just admire the artistry.

Excellent View from all sides. Heroes square is surrounded by 4 buildings, each representative a different key faculty, arts, science etc. It is also close to a wonderful castle and a good restaurant in the park
A Square. Visit if you are in the area. The cafe on the steps of the gallery is well worth a visit though the iced fruit tea was amazing.
Heroes' Square. Take a walk around if you're in the area, but I wouldn't go out of my way for a visit. Some might enjoy walking to it via Andrassy, a famous old street.

Impressive Monument. The Heroes Square in Budapest is something one should visit while in the city. In addition to the impressive statues representing Hungary's history, this monument is adjacent to the Museum of Fine Arts, the Contemporary Art Museum, and Vajdahunyad Castle and grounds. There is a lot to see in this small area of Budapest. This monument presents a number of photographic opportunities.

Mmmmmmm........ Meh. . Heroes they may be. Heroic, I'm sure. But..... This is surprisingly unimpressive in the flesh/bronze. Packed with school age tourist groups, oddly empty in emotional impact, full of touristy 'stuff', it underwhelms. Disappointing. The statuary, however, is exceptional. An odd contradiction of a national monument. Loved Hungary. Love the Hungarians I met. This 'monument'? Not so much......

Nice square well worth the visit. This large square has various memorials in it and is well worth visiting. Tip: take the metro to the Oper station and walk from the Oper building to Hook Square. The walk is about a mile and you will be well rewarded with the sites of many architectural interesting buildings along Andrassy Ut.

Impressive. Huge statues but that's about all. Busy area for traffic and very noisy. Square was closed in preparation for some big event so couldn't get near but it is next to the metro station and worth a quick look.
Great monuments and statues. An interesting location of historical significance that is well worth a visit. Best value would be a guided tour so that the associated history is understood.

Wonderful historical square . One of the most beautiful and historical squares in Europe, the presence of Hungarian leaders and Magyar horsemen is felt from every corner. Plenty of historical and culture inspiring sites that surround the square make it the best destination to reflect on the beauty and grand history of Budapest.
good. i was there day and night time. but i like night time more as it wasn't hot at all. I was after bath and walk abck to my hotel.
Picture perfect location. Perfect place for taking photos and enjoying some amazing history and architecture. One of the city highlights!

magnificent. A vast area to look round and it is better to have someone explain all the statues that surround it to make it much more interesting. Some of the statues look very fierce but the explanation helps put them into place. Bit windy

Stunning statues and tributes to heros. Comparable to Paris. We saw it at night the first time and it was jaw dropping. I only wish there were English descriptions and information. Exceptional monument.
Impressive dimensions!. Heroes Square is immense. When one walks up to the monument and statues, one can only be awed by it's magnificent beauty and detailed history.
Very nice . This is an impressive square. With statuses. On both sides there are museums. One of them is not operating for the last 2 years.

Doing your homework first will help. Another ‘must see’ site of the city but it helps if you know what you are looking at. If you are not with a tour guide it’s useful to do a little reading on who the ‘heroes’ are.
Nice little park nearby and a lake that is used for ice skating in the winter.
