Majestic!. This is a phenomenal square. Amazing history and works of art. easy to get to on the tram with a beautiful park and lake nearby.

Nice. Classic tourist stop on way to baths in the park next door.
No obvious explanation for what any of it is. But another thing to your repertoire of cheesy tourist pics.
Hero's square. The square is huge, we just have a quick view from the city sightseeing bus. It's in the centre and near the city park and the szechenyi termal Bath.

Huge square. Read some Hungarian history before you come to visit this square! Otherwise, it will not be interesting for you.
This square is big and it was constructed for the Millenium of Hungary.
A must visit place in Budapest!
Beautiful monument in Budapest. Great and beautiful monument to visit. Nearby Kunsthalle that exhibitions of contemporary art in a 19th-century neo-classical gallery and an Ice ring every winter

Busy place worth a visit. We were busy trying to cram loads of sites in so didn't manage to spend lots of time here or visit the museums and park next to the Hero Square. It's an impressive monument to visit and part of Hungarian history. It's at the end of Andrassy ut Budapest's tribute to the Champs Elyse.

Grand scale, but a bit dull if you don't know the culture. The square is vast in scale, and feels like a huge area of flat tarmac with big roads on three sides, a (nice) park at the back, a couple of ornate museum type buildings on the flanks and some statues and a column in the middle. The latter is very Nelson's column style, only smaller.The square is grand but without that much of a wow factor and the statues are good but not amazing. I'm sure it means a lot more if you are Hungarian and/or understand the cultural significance of the place and the statues. But other than a quick look, there's not much to do in the square, and no seats or cafés from which to take it in.You could get the metro or a taxi here or walk a mile or so up Andrassy. I normally like squares and cultural monuments, but this felt like an effort to reach it for a 10 minute look around. Probably better to double a visit up with a trip to the City Park or its palatial thermal baths.
Heroes square. This monument was also covered from outside only. Since there was no space to park the vehicle nearby, we proceeded to next point

Amazing Site - Very Well Kept and huge..... The whole area is very well maintained, thinking how open and large the area is. It is an amazing sight to see the various statues and the buildings nearby. The area is very peaceful and good to visit.
Visit at night. I recommend visiting just as it is turning dark. The statues are much prettier illuminated. We felt safe taking the metro there at night, and we were two women.

Epic Square. Beautiful and epic square with big statues of Hungarian hero's. Nice to walk the boulevard from the centre and end at the square. Will take you around 30 minutes. We then found a nice cafe nearby to rest after the walk & visit.
Hungarian history in sculptures. It is great sightseeing place, shows all kings and rulers during Hungarian history. We've got there by mistake looking for ZOO :)

Amazing place. Well, if you think that the Magyars were ferocious take a look at these statues, all on horseback and quite spectacular. Depicting the Hungarian tribesmen who fought oppression these are probably the best statues I have seen anywhere, and, they are huge!
average. the place is quite big . there is a railway museum ( closed when we were there ). will suggest that one take the bus trip that takes you around the whole park.
Big square. Glad we had our tourist book with us for this one as there is very little markings as to what things are and what they represent. Great statues though if you know what they are!

Hero's square.. A very important and prominent tourist place. The area is always full of tourists and is situated next to the Art museum and gallery of fine arts. Not much to do here, other than the visit itself and some snaps for your album. The statues of important figures from Hungarian history decorates the square.

Amazing Hero's Square and Surrounding Areas. It will not sufficient a day for seeing the beautiful and historic Hero's Square and the nearby Vidahunyad Castle, and the small lake in between where peddle boats are available. The Budapest Zoo and the central park is adjacent to it. Across the bridge over the lake there is food stalls, fun and fair type activities for children, street shopping and lots of colorful events and activities for children and youngsters as well. We spent almost a day visiting all these areas but still time was short.

Don't miss everything else there!. Hero's Square is really a must see while you are in Budapest, not just because of the monuments, but also because so much of Hungarian history has occurred here. But it's not just the Square (which can be seen in 20 minutes). It's City Park directly behind-with many, many options, and the two museums on either side. Even without entering the museums, the buildings are amazing. And the city has posted details there of the plan to restore the park and museums to their full glory by 2019. I spent much longer than I had planned, wandering the park!
Historical Place. Heroes' Square in Budapest is a slice of Hungarian history. Special mention must be made of the sculpture on the two arches and the tall column.
Huge open square. Go to the river beyond the square and see the paddle boats. Cross the short bridge over the water and enjoy the outdoor vendors.

Beautiful at night. We stumbled upon this square by accident at night. It is absolutely stunning all lit up.Visit the ice skating rink across the way and the walk across to the Castle behind the rink. It was also very impressive lit up.

Square, park and Andrassy Utca. The heroes square is a large square with diffrent statues. The Andrassy Utca ("the champs-elysees of Budapest, it is calles) reaches to here.
From here you can walk to and through the city park. Europe's first metro line was build here. This is not deep underground, so you feel the grounds shake when the metro goes by!
Outstanding . Looking for architecture and history, then go to Heroes Square and learn. Take in Szechenyi Thermal Baths whilst there and relax in healing pools. Both well worth a visit.

One of the Budapest essentials. Take the Millenial Undergound Train or walk Andrássy út and you will see a pantheon of the greatest Hungarian kings and leaders from historical times - sculpted in bronz I guess. It's also a nice start to walk around the City Park a bit and it's close to some of the best institutions in the city like Fine Arts Museum, Műcsarnok (Kunsthalle) and the Zoo.

Great monument (definitely visit). If you learn Hungary's history you will realise that all of its history is in this amazing place. All emperors are standing in line... It is such an amazing plqce. Ι stayed quite a while with our guide and we loved all the stories that are hiding behind these statues
Impressive. Truly historic with fantastic statues. The park nearby was interesting too. A band was playing at the art gallery which add to the atmosphere.
Worth seeing. Large square with statutes of past leaders of various tribes, and the tomb of the unknown soldier. Very large area easy to walk around, a lot of history to the area.
This is designed to make you feel small and it does just that. If you see it and it impresses you in the day, take the time to go see it at night! What a sight and tribute to those that have fallen
History in Review. If you go with someone knowledgeable, you can get a review of much of Hungarian history here in this square.
Interesting but emotionless.. Standing statues of all of the past leaders. Like visiting a black and white version of a wax museum. Evoked no emotion at all.

Beautiful at nighttime.. Me and two friends were staying in a nearby hostel (baroque hostel) and found a nice cafe nearby which we had lunch till the evening in and we saw the whole square lit up from our table which led us to go and investigate and take a fair few pictures of the various columns and statues present. A lovely setting, especially at night time!

Bronzes . Budapest has the most bronze sculptures that I have ever seen in one city with maybe the exception of Paris. This massive square has many commemorating many of the country's historic figures. There was a symphonic concert taking place when we strolled through after returning from the baths.
Monumental monuments. The monuments in this square are huge, there is an impressive centrepiece of the arch angel Gabriel and this square is well worth a visit.
Must see. A must see that leads to the parks, museum and baths all worth a look and if you can manage it try walking the boulevard from Pest to the square
A must see. The walk from down town Budapest to Heroes Square is well worth it - it is a beautiful tree lined avenue opening out into the square at the end and a lovely park behind.
Lots to see. So much culture and sight seeing in this area...from lakes to parks the architecture and arts surround your senses.
Beautiful Square. Hard to find parking because this square is well visited. You can drive all the way around it if you just want a visual or to snap a quick photo.

Iconic square with character. The visit to Heroes Square and the city park is an obligation when you visit Budapest. Easy access with transport, it takes about half an hour walking from St Stephen's Basilica through Andrassy Avenue. Alternatively you can get on the second oldest underground line in Europe! Quite an iconic place to visit!

Impressive. An impressive square full of iconic statues. A UNESCO site. Busy traffic buzzing round but well worth a visit. The square is surrounded by the Museum of Fine Arts on the left and Hall of Art on the right. Nice view of Andrássy Avenue.

Nice place for people watching. Hero Square is a very popular place. There are many many tourist buses ferrying loads of tourists to this place. The square has interesting architecture, especially the statues to please the visitors' eyes, and of course, the many many tourists become a view to admire too.

Worth a visit. Walked here along a tree lined boulevard full of foreign embassies, which were fun to spot. Sat at the cafe outside The Museum of Art with a great view and fun to people watch. We then walked to the park behind and had a pleasant stroll around. See if you can spot the Bela Lugosi bust!

Great historical monument. Very impressed by the monument and the details. There are names of the different heroes as well. There are lights all around the monument so there is not any problem seeing it in the evening. You must visit the Vajdahunyard castle in City Part, only 6/7 min from the Hero Square.
sightseeing. Interesting history,if you use the hop on hop of bus you get a running commentary,the square is by a lovely park and lake and Szechenyi baths.We preferred the Gellert spa.

Nice sqare. Its nice sqare to walk and take photos but you will not need to stay there for along time,but you can then go to the area near the square which you can find a small shops and snacks and a good place to spend some time..in the weakened you can find a dj Party in the open air..but most of the people there are young like 17s to 20s if you are in the same age you wil merge with them if you are not like me you can still have a good time

Beautiful Statues Memorial. This memorial was constructed to commemorate Hungarian soldiers who lost their lives in many wars. The square is vast and the statues are exquisitely detailed. Do take a guided tour of the square with a hired guide, or use a guide book to get a better understanding of the significance of Hero's Square. You can easily reach it by the M1 subway.
Impressive monument . Reminder of the grand scale of Communism's ways of trying to impress people and how hollow they were. Nice park behind the square.

Located at the end of Andrassey terrace. Lovely area and restaurant nearby. To the right of the square is a museum, lake and park which is beautiful and peaceful. The hop on hop off buses stop there and Lots of designer shops down Andrassey terr if a long walk suits. The opera house is nearby with lots of outside eating places
A Cultured Visit. Whatever you do, do not fail to visit Heroes Square you can get to it by using the hop on hop bus service.

Spectacular . Budapest is a city with many landmarks in the firm if Squares or Ter as they say.Hero's Square is a majestic monument. It is at one end of Andrassy Street.Besides the square is a small lake with tourist info center and a restaurant near the water. Mukul ShuklaAhmedabad, India.
You should come here. A very good place to visit in Budapest. I recommend to come at daytime and at night too. And if you are here, go and have a trip in the big park nearby!
Must visit. A trip to Budapest wouldn't be complete without visiting here and the surrounding park / gardens, spectacular!

Feel the open air freedom. It reminded me of freedom under the sky in open air, rather than thinking about the historical figures surrounding the square.
Perfect place to be and look deep into the clouds!

This rivals many other city's grand monuments. If you are going to the baths stop past and see this square. Extraordinary sculptures and scale. An evening visit to this might also be good as I can imagine it lit up would be lovely

Nice place, cool statues, fantastic park. Heroe's square has some very cool statues, and is a large clean open are with a large park with a river on one side, it's a good place to go for relaxing, this is also the place to go if you have booked beer bike

Impressive Statues & Lots of Visitors. We caught the Big Bus to Heroes Square, the bus stopped opposite the square. The statues are impressive, and there were many visitors taking photographs. Cross the road behind the square and walk around the park, it's well worth it.

Impressive monument at the end of Andrassy. Your walk along Andrassy will take you Hero's square, an impressive monument. The square holds significant historical representation and is a gateway to City Park.

Impressive area well with the time. Climbing out of the metro station onto Heroes square is an impressive sight and the area is busy with tourists and locals. We went on a Sunday and ask the parks were full of people eating food and listening to live music across the area. The gardens and castle were cool to walk around, but the experience of "hanging with the locals" was the best. We had the most fun sitting in the shade bear one end of the boost pond where there are two small waterfalls. People would cross the narrow wall back and forth and we watched for quite some time hoping someone would take an unplanned dip!

Magnificent huge square at the end of Andrassy Avenue.. A nice walking tour from the center if you follow andrassy Avenue, which ends in this square. Further it is just in front of the City Park, which is also worth a visit.Lots of traffic around the square but it is an impressing monument.

What a beautiful space this is. Whilst visiting it, ordinary people were rejoicing, dancing and singing and celebrating the freedom of the Jewish people when they were liberated after the 2nd World War. The people really respect their traditions and always seemed to dance and sing in unison.
Stunning . Visited Hero's Square at night, it was truly beautiful when illuminated and quiet. A short walk from other attractions.

Paying tribute to heroes here... Again, another must-see attraction in Budapest. Flanked by Museum of Fine Art, Palace of Art, Millennium Monument.....the stuff of honour and memory of the great leaders in Hungary's history. Awe-inspiring. And of course, it is a World Heritage Site.

Awe inspiring . Seeing is believing when it comes to this square. The whole square evokes a feeling of a bygone soviet era. Fascinating sculptures and a wonderful view down the boulevard into the city centre. Time your visit right and you may even be lucky enough to have the square almost to yourself. The local park is a nice walk.

Historic and Beautiful. Square full of beautiful monuments, columns, statues and buildings, depicting Hungary's history. Located next to one of Budapest's best historic public spa baths, the Zoo, the Circus and a popular park.

Memorable Landmark. Saw heroes square many times on TV over the years, and always wanted to visit. Very impressive, and intricately detailed statues line the columns. A large wide open area, free of traffic, and safe for children. Getting a decent photo of the monument can be difficult in the middle of the day because there are so many tourists (like me) trying to do the same. Other impressive landmarks closeby. Well worth a visit, even if just to strike your landmarks bucket list.
Great place on a sunny day. A vast open space filled with numerous statues of the old heroes was well worth the visit. Wouldn't have been on a rainy day, I think.

More statues to war. It's a quick walk around the square to take in the statues and buildings. Appreciate the architecture and forget that war memorials keep filling parks and squares around the world.

Not really worth it. A very famous and beloved spot in Budapest that lots of tourists like to visit.I cant really say that i found it worth the visit. Its fine to stop by if you happen to be in the area, but i would not recommend making a special trip to see it.One or two photo's and its on to other things.It is close to a lot of other things in the area like museums and the Zoo.One tip, if the weather is good.. walk on past Heroes square a bit on the right side (where the hop on, hop off busses stop). There behind a restaurant building there is a lake with a great castle view. You can rent rowing / paddle / electric boats for cheap to float around.

Historic Hungary. A real gem showing an insight into the culture and history of the Hungarian capital. Located at the end of Andrassy Avenue one of the main roads in the city. Offering great scenic views with a large piazza and several monuments, be sure to visit the 1956 revolution monument located 5-7 mins walk away.

A central meeting point. The statuary is most amazing. You will also get to see the human side -- people from every place on earth. The hawkers selling popular folk clothes; the tourist guides speaking in a variety of languages, each with his own story.
It's the getting there that is nice. We walked straight towards this monument and the street feeding intro it was like Pairs without all of the filth, quite nice in the late afternoon.
Impressive square and statues. This impressive square and statues located near the park with the baths, castle and restaurant. Also beautifull buildings (museums) located right at the square.

A must see. Our second trip to Budapest found us in an apartment overlooking the square. Yes it gets busy especially with the coach tours but not so much that you can't enjoy it. well worth a photo stop on your way around the city.
Photo op & museums . Good place to take some pictures. The lake behind is interesting. Can buy a combination card to get into both museums.
Wonderful vibrant square. A great place to visit on a sunny day. Great photos, vibrant, colourful and on the wY to the park. Nowhere really to sit but good to meet people then head to the park

A Large Square. This large square with many elegant statues remembering the heroes, was very lively when we visited the place. The flash mob dance of some tourists was enjoyable. The Central Park is next to it with provision of boating in the lake.
Yet another Beautiful Square!. The whole area around Heroes Square is interesting. There is a very nice park right across the street with beautiful views.

Historical site. Heroes Square is one of the most important squares in Budapest and is very impressive. it commemorates the seven Magyar chieftains and other important leaders of Hungary. It also contains the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. City Park is behind the Square.
Pretty impressive square. Coming up out of the metro at sunset and seeing this square in front of you is an awe-inspiring sight, a view at least as equal to something you'd see in Paris.

the Hungarian Brandenburger Tor. When I saw the constructions on this Heroes Square, I had to think of the Brandenburger Tor in Berlin. This square is situated in a City Park, just outside the centre of Budapest and is really worth a visit.
beautiful square when the sun is shining... massive square with monuments at the far end with a large park behind, very busy with tourists and definitely a must see part of budapest
Great tribute to former leaders and heros. Impressive statues and as the guide said - as they are all in one place, they can hang out and talk to each other.

Vast. It was quiet when we walked to the square - a bit serene. The square could hold many people for special events and commemorations. It's on the way to the szechenyi baths and at the end of Andrassy Ave.

Art and patriotism come together. Hero's square was built at the end of the 19th century to commemorate the first millennium of the foundation of the Hungarian state. It is located at the Northeastern end of Andrassy Avenue, one of the most fashionable and beautiful avenues in Budapest. on the opposite end of the square starts the major city park (Varosliget), which deserves a visit on its own merit. On the Northwestern side of the square is the Museum of Fine Arts and on the opposite side, the Palace of Art. The Museum of Fine Arts houses an excellent collection of European masters, including Durer, Goya, Rembrandt, Rubens and TItian. Other wings of the museum offer collections from Antiquity through the Middle Ages and Renaissance until the recent past. The Palace of Art is mostly an exhibition hall and it si frequently used for contemporary or visiting exhibitions. Both museums were built on the model of classical Greek architecture, with massive colonnades in the front, including elaborately carved capitels at the top of each column. The Museum of Fine Arts deserves at least a couple of hours; the Palace of Arts is certainly worth visiting, although the required time will depend on the collection being exhibited. In the center of Heroes' Square is an imposing monument that reflects much of Hungarian history in the center, there is a large column and on top, you will see the archangel Gabriel holding St. Stephen's crown. St. Stephen was the first king of Hungary and converted the country to Christianity. At the base of the column there are equestrian bronze sculptures representing the 7 tribal leaders or chieftains who conquered and occupied the Carpatian basin and thus settled the territory that currently includes Hungary and parts of Slovakia, Romania, the Ukraine and Serbia. Surrounding the central column there are two semicircular colonnades, each with seven statues: on the left colonnade (arriving from Andrassy avenue) are seven if the most prominent Hungarian kings; on the right, Hungarians who had a major role in Hungarian history, regardless of the place in society. The square is easy to access by subway or bus, although on a nice day, walking down Andrassy avenue makes for a lovely stroll. Around the square, there are multiple restaurants, including Gundel, that historically used to be one of the top restaurant in Budapest. The Square, statues, the surrounding museums and city park will occupy a good part of a day.

The Seven Magyars. It is a beautiful square with the city park on one side, two museums adorning two sides and the magnificent Andrassy Avenue on the other side. This square witnessed a lot of historical events of Hungary.Statues of The seven Magyars, other important leaders of Hungary and the tomb of the unknown soldier makes the square.
square. Next to this square, discover a very big park where you can walk and see a very strange castle,. The lake is nice too and you can also enjoy the baths in this park.
Go on a sunny day. This is a beautiful square a bit away from the center of Budapest. Rent a bicycle and make it one stop on your tour!

A good tourist Landmark. A must do when your in Budapest simply for the history it holds. It's also very convenient if you merge this with a visit to the famous Szechenyi Baths, as they're only round the corner from here.
Heroic place. The statues at the Heroes' square are unique and have a story to tell. The guards stand in the hot sun and are meticulous.
Great must see location. A good place to add to your travel list when visiting, local cafe is not very expensive but also not cheap. The park nearby and other attractions make for a great day out.
Vacations . Very nice square. Lots of history. We took pictures and did the boats. Very nice for walking. The park had a fair with tents selling sweets and souvenirs

It is a historic site, but it is not that convenient to walk to. There is no easy place to park or take a bus, so you have to walk into the square. and then once you are in the square, you are surrounded by cars.
But it is easy to take a few pictures since it is not flooded by tourists given its location is not so convenient.

Budapest's famous landmark. In Budapest, you must visit the Chain Bridge, the Castle District/Castle Hill, the Parliament, and the Heroe's Square in order to call it "complete." It's a square at the end of Andrassay Street, the famous high end shopping street, full of famous western brands like Gucci. This square is huge, with statues around it displaying the Hungarian history. I would take time to look at the statutes as they were all well made.
beautiful memorial statues. jumped off hop on hop off tour bus here - well worth a visit - makes you feel quite humble and reflective - lovely park to walk around near

Visit whilst the sun sets. I visited Budapest last summer and happened to pass through here whilst on my way to a gig at Durer Kert. The sun was setting and it was one of the most stunning things I saw all of last year.

Magnificent. The first time I visited this Square, I was overwhelmed with the magnificence of it. It continues to delight me each time I am there. I was pleased this time that the gates to the Hungarian equivalent of the 'Tomb of the Unknown Warrior' were open. Unfortunately, there was no sign in English to inform the world, so people did not treat it with respect. Those historical figures still command attention, and the space is awesome.
great night and day. massive area with stunning statues and surround by fantastic buildings, worth a visit day or night, loved it
Heroic interlude. You might go to Trafalgar/Times/Red Square? So you have to go to Heroes Square in Budapest to experience a grand public space and place!

Millennium Monument. Statues representing the seven tribes who settled in Hungary surround this fascinating site. Our guide gave us a brief but important summary of the Magyars conquest of the region. The park behind and the museum on one side and Palace of Art on the other make this stop a wonderful photo opportunity.

A remarkable statue compilation of the historical heroes of the Hungarian past.. Impressive set-up of many, large scale, bronze statues from the Hungarian history. It is interesting, that the Chinese people fount it also so impressive, that they build a duplicate of the entire set up and displayed it somewhere in Chine.

Worth a look!. Not much to do here but the statue and the square itself are very beautiful. The while place is kept very well and is definitely worth a look!Situated right near the castle and also a lake with some nice cafes!

Good sight. Easy to visit via the metro, bus, or trolley bus. Set within a big square that can cater for in excess of a thousand tourists or visitors. No entry fee applies as this site is a square that's surrounded on on all sides by a busy road. Take extra care when crossing the road if you have mobility problems and please wait for the 'green' man to appear when using the lights.I try to not be intolerant of others if I can help it, as I may very well annoy people but was disappointed to see people climbing over the statues for their colleagues to take pictures. Would be good if guards were present to minimise people climbing all over monuments. If you have kids with you then it's worth visiting the nearby small boating lake where you can hire pedalos that are formed in the shape of cars. You can also head towards the huge spa baths which are nearby too. Additional Info - - - We purchased a Budapest pass which allowed us free access to a spa bath in Buda; which was frequented more by locals than tourists.We signed the back of the pass and therefore could hop and off the trolley bus, the tram, and the metro. We were stopped several times by transport guards and were asked to produce our travel ticket/pass. I understand that if people buy a one or two day travel pass is that they must be validated by a ticket machine prior to travelling. If you do not validate your ticket prior to travelling, you will incur an on the spot fine for approximately €30.... You have been warned. I bought a 3 day Budapest pass for 9900 HUF which equates to £8.33 a day and once it's signed; it's validated for the ticket/pass duration. I could hop on and off the trolley bus, tram, metro as I pleased and I also had some attractions thrown in as free and discount for other attractions too.
Elsofany . Historical feelings to this big square with plenty to enjoy learning and viewing and get the feeling of what the history and traditions of this country and its land marks
Must visit place. One of the most attractive place to visit in Budapest surrounded with lot of historical buildings. Nice photographic place.
historic figures on display. Expansive square with museums on either side. Local tour guide explained each historic figure. A team of basketball players were entertaining the tourists too!

Very popular attraction. I wanted to photograph the square empty.... Some chance! You'd need to be up at dawn. Next time maybe. Hundreds of visitors, many clambering on to the amazing statues for photos. Why is that allowed?
Free. Free to watch, great sculptures. Recommended for history lovers. The area in Budapest is pretty expensive. I do not recommend to buy anything near Heroes square.
great place to visit. Great day out in heroes square, not too far from the Zoo which i highly recommend,Great views and lots to do.
Trip to the dentist. Impressive, fine old monuments to a proud past. Nice Italian restaurant overlooking the square, serves good food and a nice house red
Nice for walk. You can walk from the river bridge, take a look to the square and the death angel (nice face uh?) and then continue to the main street, you will look a very nice houses over there.
Nice place - walkable from the circus and baths. However, quite a stretch from the city center. App 30 minutes walk from the chain bridge in the centre. Unesco world heritage site.

Interesting. We went on a group tour through our Viking River boat cruise. It was interesting as they have statues of famous Hungarians on display. If you weren't on a tour you wouldn't readily know who the statues were and why they were selected. It's in a park like setting and very spacious.
Impressive beautiful. Glad we walked the mile or so there on a lovely day. Great statues, clean area, poient worth visiting, especially if you are in the area, lots of tourists

Great sightseeing opportunity!. Fantastic open space, impressive and with lots of equally interesting sites right nearby. We had a great walk in the park behind. I recommend getting a ticket for the touring buses because you can hop on and off wherever you like, you get the commentary on all the historic places of the city and it's a great way to get directly to the best spots. As Heroes' Square was at the opposite end of the city from our hotel, we may not have troubled to see it without the tour bus tickets so I'm really glad we did!

stunning and a must-see site. Despite the cloudy, cold weather we walked through the Hero's Square after visiting the nearby art museum. It is a central landmark in Budapest and should make it on your short list of sites to see.
Nice to look at. This is a very long walk through Andrassy Ut coming from the house of terror. Personally it was not as special as i hoped, but the weather was good so we walked back in the sun.

Grand in every sense. The size and scale of this monument is just a show stopper. At the end of a spectacular boulevard bordering the art gallery ' park and baths it is a must see. Memorials of this size are few and this one is very impressive
Very Impressive. We really enjoyed visiting Heroes Square, which is also very close to the Baths and a magical castle. Wonderful way to spend a morning.

Saturday Morning Visit to Heroes Square. 25 min walk from Hotel in Pest Centre - could have gone by Metro or Bus but nice weather for a walk. Interesting to see Hungarian Heroes and tomb of unknown warrior. Unfortunately nearby Museum of Fine Arts closed for renovation and Museum of Contemporary Arts was disappointing just being photographic display.
great place.. lovely parks nearby with the zoo and famous baths in the area.can get there from city centre by the quaint yellow line metro with its old style little carriages and stations.

interesting place to visit. we hopped off the sightseeing bus to take a stroll round the square and found so much more to see there is a lovely park just beyond with a lake where boats can be hired and not far away there is budapest zoo and botanical gardens

Must see - the people's monument. There is an interesting fountain and a people's exhibit here. Seems that the people felt that the monument was not really representative of the issue, and the people's exhibit (left after protests) represents some real issues...
Need to know the history. Worth a short visit if you are in the vicinity and know the history. There is very limited parking nearby but it's close to public transportation.

Amazing place. We only saw this place from the open top bus tour but it was well worth a mention just because it is spectacular to look at and because of what it represents. An amazing tribute to previous rulers of Hungary.

1000 years of Hungary. The largest square in town, started in 1896 and finished only 33 years later commemorates the landfall in 896 with the Archangel Gabriel on top of the central monument and the surrounding statues of hungarian historical figures.

Great attraction. This is a very busy tourist attraction for both locals and foreigners. The statuary is excellent and the column makes this an easy place to spot as you come along the beautiful Andrassy boulevard

Historic square with a feeling of recent and times. Historic square with a feeling of recent and times, nice to walk around and enjoy the gardens on one side, with the varied architectural buildings, lake and museums. And the spa and open pool complex on the other side. And it was easy to park around the corner!

Nice sight, not worth a stop off. We passed by here on your way to the bath install the statues on the Square that way. They were nice and I would recommend to just take a look as part of a tour, there's no need to stop off

Unique to The former Eastern Block, history and grandeur. A fair walk down a main street where many of the countries diplomatic residences are. Many statues of figures of Hungarian history. Very educational, and a vast number of Hungarian contributors of the arts, Governments, army, and great figures is enlightening. Free and a place to sit for coffee makes is a truly unique places, integrated into the City. Do not miss it out!

Good stop on adventures through Budapest. We went to Heroe's square on our way to the baths. It's a very impressive plaza with interesting statue and stone work. It doesn't take long to walk through the appreciate the monument, it's worth the quick stop if you're in the area.

great landmark to meet friends. it's (as Trump would say) huge! nice restaurants nearby - don't go for swanky, go for crowded. Park is nice, but the history is the thing - my wife is Hungarian so this type of stuff is special.

Recovering. The Communists made a muck of the square and the surrounding park. Both are now under rehab, but well worth the walk or ride from the center. The adjacent park is huge and filled with treats while the square is a grand memorial to the Magyars who invaded this part of Europe and ran out the Celts who had lived here before. Conquest is in the face of every limestone hero.
Definitely worth a walk. Definitely worth going to see this monument and spend the time going for a walk around the park as it is stunning! Very picturesque.

A nice square, but not impressive!. We passed this square on Segways and experienced all the bachelor parties cycling round enjoying beer. Nice place to see, but not a place I will remember as "Special". Not a must.

Interesting historic Budapest landmark. While taking a tour of various sites throughout Budapest, our driver took us to the Heroes' Square monument park. I think we circled the round-about three times so he could explain all of the history and importance of the park and its statues! We shall remember it!
impressive. This is located at one end of Andrassy Avenue (either the beginning or the end, depending on your starting point).

Heroes' Square . Heroes' Square, also an UNESCO Heritage Site, is a must see whenever you are in Budapest. Its the largest square in Hungary. There is a Millennium Statue erected in the middle of the square. Together with Millennium Statue, Gellert Hill, Danube it made up the Hungarian history.There are many domestic and international visitors to this square. Also find an erected word "BUDAPEST" to take a individual or group photo to mark that moment there.

Fabulous Tribute. Fab walk up to Heros Square, manificient statues representing the history of the kings of Hungary. Beyond the statues is a wonderful lake/park area where we spent the afternoon. It was a public holiday the day we were there and a a food festival and amusements were in the park which proved to be a fun filled day. Def worth a visit.

Loved the iceskating!!. We visited Heroes square after a walk down Andrassy avenue. The statues really are impressive and the history of the square is worth looking into as it is extremely interesting. We visited in Feb 2016 and as it was winter the ice skating by Vajahund castle, just near the square, was open. Ice skating beside a beautiful castle really was one of the highlights of our trip, and we went back the next day to do it again! Definitely worth a visit.
nice. bring umbrella on a sunny daythis pl;ace u can take good pictures and walk around the lake behind. worth the trip

Great statues & great photo taking . Was staying nearby at a hotel so had a look at this many times I was there.The statues really are great!!!!!Try to go in the mornings or evenings, afternoons can be a nightmare as I realized due to school kids, school trips,visits etc etc you get the idea, but of a nightmare to take that photo of you.If you want to see it for its beauty go in the evening, if you want to see it just for that photo in the square then most definitely go in the early morning.Afternoons are great if you don't mind mingling with tourists, kids, more traffic nearby and it's sounds etc etc you get the idea.It's a place to pay a visit once.

Meh.... It was pretty, and a great place to take group pictures, but unfortunately we weren't the only ones with that idea. It was absolutely packed!! We spent maybe 10 minutes there before we left...
Amazing statues. The statues are amazing, the history of the square is interesting and the surroundings are both cozy and full of things to do - in total: A must whilst in Budapest!
Heroes' Square. Heroes' Square is a wonderful place to promenade in Budapest and is located near the Zoo. It is a place frequented by many tourists and is near a subway station.
Magnificent statues in a truely "heroic" square.. With it's size and magnificent statues, Heroe's Square is a must-see location whilst you visit beautiful Budapest.

Attractive during night. We only visited the square during night time and it was amazing. The lighting make it all look so different than days. Really good place to take pictures. A must do in Budapest.
Impressive Square. Worth getting out to as there is a lot to do in the park nearby which has the baths, zoo, circus and Grundel's restaurant.

An extraordinary monument. We passed by the square while driving to Vajdahunyad Castle, there wasn't any parking space available nearby so we came back at night time. It was more beautiful at night when the lights turned on, there were only very few people around and it was cold also we didn't know how safe was the neighborhood after dark so we only stayed there a brief period of time, I could be just taking too much of precaution, though. The statues in the square are as beautiful as fine arts. Recommended.
Meeting place for beer bikes. We went to drink excessively but we actually found ourself in a cultural hot spot. An amazing place - beer bike was also very good!
Very nice. Beautiful and it is very close to the Baths and the park. It is a long, but nice walk here from the opera house.
Very nice square. Hear this is a recent consider made to look old but I couldn't tell the difference myself. Great for photos and is a must visit.
Lovely . Went there the place amazing , and we are lucky we find that fiesta vinto u can walk around sit in the gardens have your food taste new wine it's amazing ,

It's alright. It's a cool place to visit but there's honestly not much to see. It's not too close to everything else and I guess you can spend just 5 minutes there and leave. I'd still recommend people to go though.
Heroes. At the entrance to the Park and the restaurants behind it is an easy stop with an interesting history. On the bus route.

Heroe's square. This is a place, where you can see a big part from the history of the Hungary and the town. It is close to the park and the gallery. There are a lot of green places, where you can rest with the family.

Magnificent sculptures of ancient heroes. Worth visiting. The sculptures of the ancient heroes are very powerful and impressive. The square is located right next to a park filled with big attractions such as the citys biggest thermal bath and the zoo.

A brief stop.. We could only stop here briefly as armed police surrounded the area.A nice photo stop paying tribute to Hungarians of the past.This area/square is simply wonderful lit up at night......too many people there today.The largest square in Budapest.......but you are better off visiting at night time.visited 4th may 2016.
Just a fantastic place near the baths. What a great place to be just near the park we were able to get our bearings to other attractions easy walk great transport links

Centrally located historical center. The Heroe's Square is a large open expanse, with statues commemorating different periods of history. Very active, on lower end of City Park - bordered on each side by museums.
A square, nothing special.. It's a square with some monuments. Nothing special from my point of view but you shoul go and take a look, maybe you will have different opinion.

Impressive sight but no info. Beautiful and impressive sight. The lights in the evening made the statues and square look even better. Would have liked it if there was an info plaque about the artists or the statues history but to be fair I should have bought a book. None the less still great photo op

Go at night or don't go at all. I went both at night and in the day and honestly I couldn't get a decent photo for all the tourists climbing all over it during the day. save yourself the hassle!! It's deserted at night and looks beautiful all lit up!! Warning tho! The lights turn off at 1am on the dot as I discovered part way through a panoramic shot!
Beautiful monument. The monument it self is fantastic, but don't miss out on the area surrounding it- absolutely fantastic architecture, so this is more a review of the area all in all.

Quite interesting . Quite impressive as squares go. There are many statues of famous persons that are important to Hungary's past. It would have been great to have some explanation somewhere. We didn't see one. Took the underground to the square. It's obviously a very old line. The carriages are small too. Leads onto the famous Andrássy út which we weren't too impressed with. Would've advise walking all of it.

A huge square with the tomb of the unknown soldier - worth seeing. This is one of the main squares that needs explanation from a tour guide. It did have in the center the tomb of the unknown soldier. Lots of people about too.

Touristy . Stopped here with tour group for photos and to take a pic of the Budapest sign. It was nice but such a tourist attraction it's hard to get a photo without being unintentionally being photo bombed

Largest square in Budapest. Millennium monument originally built to celebrate 1000 years of Magyar history. Numerous statues of the important chieftans topped with a large statue of Archangel Gabriel. Other than that, the square is mostly empty paved area. It is a meeting place for protests and celebrations alike and can probably hold upwards of 100,000 easily.
Great history of Hungary. At the end of Andrassy Avenue. It has a massive monument in the center and statues of each of the important Madgyar leaders in their 1000+ years of history.
Meh. Apart from the statues there is not much if you are not familiar with Budapest's history. Feels quite isolated from the rest of the attractions
awesome. very nice square we stopped to take some memorial photos of a bachelor party of a friend of mine ,its a place not to be missed in Budapest. enjoy

Impressive. This Square is at the end of Andrassy Ave and driving up to it you first see "Budapest" spelled out in large wood type sticks, which is fun to see and photograph. Then you see the Millennium Monument in the center with the Archangel Michael on top of this very tall column. Behind that are two colonnades with statues of famous Hungarian leaders that are being honored. I believe this was completed and opened around 1896. There is a beautiful Museum of Fine Arts across the street that we didn't have time to see.

Impressive Square. Large and impressive square close to the zoo. I am glad that I
had an opportunity to see it and get a photo.

A wonderful opportunity to think about the long history of Budapest and all it's rulers.. Definitely worth popping up to the top of Andrassy utca to visit these amazing statues. Also worth a visit to the city park while you are there.

Nice place and thats it. Its nothing special after being in budapest for a couple of days... a lot of squares looks like that. Its nice walking there on the way to Széchenyi thermal bath, but dont go there just to see it

Beautiful square at the edge of the park. Beautiful place at the enterence to the park. It is a good idea to visit this place on a guided tour (we were there on a bicycle tour) or read a little about its history in order get the right context.

Made an afternoon of it. My husband and I visited her I square whilst visiting the park behind it and the embassy avenue. TIP: to get an even better view pay a visit to to museum bar where you can sit on the piazza/entrance area and watch the city go by with a coffee or beer. One of my favourite memories of Budapest!
Wonderful. This is a really nice place to visit on a sunny day. Enjoy the monument, but don't forget to walk through the beautiful park, with all the lakes, bridges and museums.

Picturesque. Brilliant view, heroes square was right opposite our hotel.
There magnificent statues and Columns.
Would recommend and there's also a beautiful garden with a lake across the road near the little bridge.
Good for 15 mins. We passed by here on the way to the park. Wortham visit but it's not somewhere to spend an hour more a brief visit. Was busy whilst we were there. Got some good photos.

Breath taking landmark. We were there after we visited the Széchenyi thermal bath. It is right above the Hösök tere metro station and just 5 minutes walk from the bath. It was breath taking and particularly on a sunny day. It's a landmark you won't miss in Budapest.

Heroes' Square, Budapest. This Millennium Monument which is in the center of Heroes' Square according to our tour guide, has been designed in 1894 by Albert Schickedanz. Right on top of the column is a statue of the archangel Gabriel, and in semicircular arrangement are many statues of famous Hungarian historians. Around the base of the monument are a number of equestrian statues honoring the seven chieftains of the Hungarian tribes who, led by Árpád, conquered the area now known as Hungary.

Beautiful outdoor walk. I definitely recommend walking around this square, it is beautiful.. There is a park nearby as well as other popular destinations. If you visit here make sure you have enough time to explore around.
On the way to the bath!. We walking through here on the way to Széchenyi Thermal Bath. Glad we saw it, but it's a few columns what can I say! Worthy of a picture!

Must visit!. Its worth taking the time to walk or catch the underground to the square as the sheer size is amazing, take the chance to see by night also as the photos are great. its next to the Park so great to wander there also, there was a skating rink there also which looked great fun but having 2 left feet decided to give it a miss but would recommend the baths and outdoor pools in the park as that was one of our highlights of our trip
Great place on a sunny day. Impressing and imposing square, a definite touristic centre, best to visit early morning before the crowds arrive
Stunning In Its Simplicity. A guided tour markedly helped us understand the history of this country. The site is stunning in its simplicity especially on a sunny day. Beware pickpockets and vendors.
Amazing sculpture composition. Truly a heart of Budapest and a must see. Even if you're not into 'historical facts', the mere beauty of the sculptures is worth admiring.
nice. very nice place to visit and take some photos.its a big square in the midle of budapest and near the zoo

Beautiful. This square is quite large and it surrounded by museums, etc. It has beautiful statues all with some significance. Since my last visit to this square, they have added a really cool sign "Budapest" in the front. Beware of locals selling things. We were warned not to do business with them.

Room for more heroes. The column and semi circular wall are impressive enough but they look a little lost in a huge square which is largely featureless. It has held 250,000 people in the past which gives you an idea of how large it is. When comparing against Trafalgar Square which has numerous water features surrounding the main column, it does look a little barren.

A definite when visiting. After doing a city hop on hop off tour spent 15 minutes taking photos. Came back on our final day in Budapest for a stroll around the adjacent parks and Fontaine whilst also a trip round the lake a pedalo! Stunning buildings either side of hero's square and a tourist trap! Happy!

It needs to be seen. This is a bit off the beaten track but worth a visit. It's next door to the gardens and the zoo which is a leisurely stroll. When we were there , there was a huge 999 day with free rides in fire engines, dress up etc which for my Fireman hubby was fabulous. So we ended up spending a good few hours in the park which I don't think we would have done ordinarily. This is impressive and as everywhere in Hungary, spotlessly clean. We used the trams for a change but you can walk nearly everywhere as long as you're fit .

Beautiful. Beautiful location, a must visit! This is a huge area of some grand scale statues in the heart of the city. Highly recommended to get some cool photos of your visit. It is walking distance to Liget and Budapest Zoo

Hungry are proud of their statues. The square is easily reached by public transport and within easy reach of spa baths. The statues are magnificent and once the crowds disappear it is easy to take advantage of the views
Heros. Big square , nothing special and different than the pictures , but backside Castle must visit ... Also castle towers as well

A place your camera will go nuts over!. When at Heroes Square it is hard to get a clear uninterrupted shot of the scenery due to the scale and number of people trying to do the same. Buy a photo or do your best but do take it all in for a few minutes.
Arpad's throne.. This area bears a lot of relevance to the heritage of the city. You need a really good guide though. Our Andrew was packed with information.
A MUST. Amazing square with great art and museums.Lot of green park and lot of places with great thing to eat ! (:

Nothing so special . Large nice square with lots of statues and lots of tourists. Not so much to see, but nice place to start for example walking tour in nearby huge park with lots of activities. By the way, the millennium metro line stops here too, beautiful metro trains and stations!

Big and bustling tourist magnet :). Beautiful big square. My 2nd visit here and loved the big wooden Budapest sign. Makes you feel like you must go get your photo taken which is why I'm sure they built it hehe. Tourist magnet indeed. Look up the history of the square whilst you're there as it's all part of the Hungarian history
Memories. This has a historical beauty to see. This is also a place I always want to return to even if it's for a shorter vieuw

The Heroes' Square. It's in the Városliget, next to the rink where you can iceskating in the winter. This place is between the Art Gallery and the
Museum of Fine Arts.
Hop on hop off. we took Tram number 2 which is a lovely scenic journey along the Danube and through Heroes Square. Old Soviet grandeur on a large scale!
Outstading !!. What a beautiful landmark. Open to all public. Took plenty of pictures. You can visit it at any time because of no boundaries. Perfect !!

Great city with great history. This was the first time I have been to Budapest and it was the most amazing experience. I have never seen a city with such rich history. The people are very proud of who they are and their army. In just a few years after getting independence from communism they have developed really fast. I visited in Dec 2014.

No great shakes. I would not make the trip for this square. But the park behind it has a set of castles (don't pay for admission--not work it). And there is a famous bath where you can look at the outdoor pools.

Wow!!!. One cannot help but be impressed walking around Heroes' Square, but it sure helps to have someone knowledgeable at your side as that is the only way to truly appreciate what the square represents. There is so much history built into this site, with imposing statues of kings and other historical figures of Hungary's yesteryears. The site is a photograph's dream, an opportunity to take so many fascinating photographs.
Beautiful . Hero square is a beautiful area, we passed this as we were walking to the baths, it's a good stop off for tourists looking photos and beautiful on a sunny day.

Loved the Budapest sign. Located near the city park and lake, Heroes square is a great place to spend half an hour to get vistas of the city, pose for photos on the Budapest sign and laugh at the people on beer buses ( pedal busses for 12 with beer on board).

One of the must-have photos of Budapest. Heroes' Square is indeed impressive but as stated elsewhere, really only needed for a photo opportunity of the "Budapest" sign with the monuments in the background.The city tour buses all pass here (I think) but the square is directly in front of the park and Szechenyi Spa, which are definitely worth a visit, so you can take your pics then.

Great if you love history!. We found this Square of interest because I am a history buff, and my husband is into war related history. The monument is quite large, surrounded by statues of mounted heroes. There are many plaques to read describing these people, but not in English. Behind the monument is a wall of columns, again the description is not in English. So it is nice to see, and a nice piece of art. If I remember correctly, there was a sign giving a summary of what it is all about.

Worth a Visit -- Not Amazing. If you have time to venture a little out of the center of the city, visit Heroes' Square. Bring a guide or interpretation, because there is a lot of symbolism in the monument and other statues you will miss without an explanation. The monument ties Budapest back to its eastern/Asian Magyar roots, which was interesting for us. A period in the history you can't readily see evidence of anywhere else we visited.
Very impressive. Gives a perfect picture of the main historical actors in Hungary over the ages. Needs some pre-reading.

Nice 😊. Definitely worth visiting, especially at night when there are letters (Budapest) that change colors! It is very monumental and grandiose square and after visiting it you can go straight to the City park or take a walk to the city center along the famous Andrassy avenue.

Go beyond it into the park. The square itself is fabulous but step beyond it and into a lovely park. A nice place to amble and the lovely buildings of Vajdahunyad Castle and museum. There are also baths and the zoo.

Big & Beautiful!. Lovely square with lot of hustle and bustle around... Of course with a lot history to it.Right behind it, it has a park and when we went there; it was hosting a festival/fair with lots of food & fun. Plus, there is also a lake area with boat hire possibility. More importantly a large Spa as well. All these can be combined to a make a day out of it like we did.

Good for a photo on your way to the Baths. Heroes' Square is impressive but really only needed for a quick photo opportunity of the "Budapest" sign with the monuments on the background whilst on the your way past to the Hungarian Baths.

Hungarian History in a Single Panorama. This presentation of statues of Hungarian heroes covers 11+ centuries from Arpád and Szint István (St. Stephen, after whom the cathedral is named) to Kossuth. It is quite interesting to see the progress in typical garb progressing through the centuries, and the individuals selected are also interesting ... at least to a history buff like me. And on a nice afternoon, simply wandering the square and then continuing into the nearby parkland is enjoyable as well. I'll try to post a picture or two later.

nice place to visit if you have extra time. ı believe this area is in my second choice of to see list. there is so much to see in budapest that you have to priorotize. We spent the sunday afternoon here which was quite enjoyable to walk around the lake, see the castle eat at the cafe and in fact there were many outside vendors selling diffrent stuff

Heros Square. One of the most known squares of Budapest, and therefore a must go, the place is stunning as the avenue in front of it, the buildings just next to it are also very beautiful, you should pass it in you way to the Szczesny Baths in the park behind.

Big square with large statues, many tourists. Visited with our Trafalgar tour group. Had an excellent guide that explained the signifigance of the statues and sculptures and other building surrounding the square.

Must to visit in Budapest . It's an amazing setting for this square. Always lively with lots of people and it's a must visit place on your trip to Budapest. There is also a beautiful old spa near the square

historical, famous. a huge `square`, with history of the country, also the square itself has its own history with protests, revolution, events, concerts, different days, different experiences... Very nice place though, however used to be crowded if there is some event and not easy to find parking place. A must to see if someone visits the capital. Easy access from there to the museums and to the central of the city.
Nice walk from the center of town to the square. Walked from the basilica area to the square. Many embassy's along the way as well as the park and zoo right behind the square. Great people watching.

Unbelievably breath-taking. Andrassy is the main avenue and the monuments are perfectly located in this place to honor the very people who defended their country all through the centuries. The huge area of the square provides you perfect photographs.

Fantastic square steeped in history. The Heroes' Square is worth a visit with its historical significance and also with how beautiful it is. The surrounding area is also well worth exploring in addition to the square
Amazing square. . When I was on my way there, I did not expect Heroes' square to be as incredible as it is. I am very impressed with it. A must see.
Big square . big park near by. Nice big square . with big BUDAPEST letters. alot of traffic . big nice park near the square with a lot of flowers, trees and small lake .

Superb history. Hostock tere contains the two sweeping galleries of Hungary's greatest heroes and leaders. The column in the centre of the plaza is the Millennary Monument, celebrating Hungary's 1000 years since King Stephen assumed the crown.In front of this is the tombs of the unknown warrior and the leaders of the 1959 uprising.Think Trafalgar square, but with a less watery feel.

Neat History. This is a must see, without a doubt and if you can, get a tour guide to sit and tell you the history of who these statues are of. Not only will you learn some interesting facts, but you will also get to hear the immense pride Hungarians have for their country.
Very beautiful. A famous touristic attraction in the "pest" side of Budapest. A must-be and must-see place ;) This is also very close to the zoo and some castles.

Impressive and rich in History. This is one of those sites where you just stand in the middle of Hero's Square and you just have to stop, slowing turn 360 degrees and savor. At first I wasn't thrilled about seeing a bunch oh statues, but once there the history and enornomity of the area is overwhelming. Hero's Square is a must see.

One of the main tourist attractions in Budapest. This is not simply a square with beautiful statues (each one of which has a lot of history behind it) , but a landmark of Budapest's turbulent history. It is also a good starting point to visit the City Park (northwards) or Addrassy street (southwards) (Heroes Square is at the northern end of Addrassy street)

Worth a visit. Lovely square to pop by for a visit - lots of opportunities for a photo. Could spend as long as you wanted here relaxing or simply pop by to tick if off your list of things you've done.

Marvelous grandness. This emerges in front of you the moment you step out of the train station and takes your breath away. You will see tourists clicking away and locals having their kids skate/ scoot around near the square.

Beautifull Big Square, not the best though.. It is a big square with marnelous statues, next to an astonishing park with beautifull castles, which worth the visit. Definetally should be compined with another activity to the area. Easy access with the Metro Station.
interesting area. A lovely square to sit and relax or to have a nice walk- interesting monuments - there is a nice restaurant nearby

Great place to learn the history of Budapest. While touring Budapest you should definitely stop at Heroes' Square next to City Park. You would do better if you have a tour guide with you when visiting. Our tour guide went over all the figures with us and told us how they helped shape the Budapest of today. It was a great place to visit while touring the city.
heldenplein. a great spot, special with the lettres of Budapest in front of the Heros. we took a lot of pictures, together with the Chinese people.

Wouldn't make a beeline for it. As part of a walk from the baths diem Andrassy it's worth a stop, but without the guide book I couldn't understand what it was commemorating. It's a nice monument but not breathtaking. Sorry... Feel offensive writing this!
Another Budapest must-see. It is easy to soak up some of the history represented here. It is a good, but interesting, walk from the centre and easy to take the Metro back again.

Ride the oldest undgergound in Europe to get there. This square has a lot of history, but there is not much to see here but a few statues on pedestals. There is a castle behind it in walking distance which is kind of cool. And a park if you want to relax with some paddle boats that look like cars. You take the 1 subway to get here which, I am told, is the oldest underground in Europe. Easy trip from the city center.
Tourist spots. Well maintained and easy to navigate.Liked all what I saw. Food is excellent and reasonable priced. People are very courteous.

Worth a look at!. This square is definitely worth a visit. It is easy to get too, and you can get the underground there and walk to the Szchenyi Baths from there easily. Only takes about 5-10 mins to look at so nice quick activity!
Worth a Visit. Lovely walks around the lake and superb architecture of the buildings, also a fabulous lakeside restaurant and bar
Worth a look. We walked past after our visit to the Széchenyi Thermal Bath, well worth a passing photo. Some impressive statues, it is a fitting monument, but not something that takes long to view.

Nice Day Trip. This is a lovely area to explore. The statues are really cool, and I was happy to have a list of the states (thanks, Rick Steves!) I enjoy history, so to see the important Magyars and Hungarian leaders being honored.The Square is a nice entrance to the City Park behind it. It is easily accessible by the Budapest metro, and I enjoyed walking down Andrassy Street once we were finished.

Beautiful architecture and statues. Huge wide open square featuring Hungary's Tomb of the Unknown Soldier and statues of important national leaders. The square is located near City Park and has 2 very nice art galleries on either side of the square. The Square is one of the stops on the Hop on Hop off bus excursions.

Beautiful. We took a hop on hop off bus to learn where the most interesting places are, this was one of the first stops and was well worth seeing. Close to the zoo and the baths makes this a great destination for a day in Budapest. The statues are beautiful and the whole area really interesting. Bus is the best way to get there as it is a long walk from the city centre.
Nice place. Nice place. Go see it if you are in the area. The big park is close by, so is the metro line, so you can go to the city centre in 10 minutes after a walk around the place.
Beautiful square.. Beautiful square in front of the park. When we were there, there was a lot of construction going on, but not on a level that it became annoying.

Amazing place!. Absolutely spectacular monument. Breathtaking to look at during the day and night. Many restaurants and bars nearby too! Would love to visit again, made great photos and was very interesting to see and understand up close. Highly recommend!

Nice area. It is a nice area to walk around on a sunny day.
All together is is worthwhile if you have a guide.
Without a guide it is difficult to learne about the history.

A very impressive and beautiful monument. Beautiful, went with a guided tour associated with our river cruise.
The history and grandeur of the monument was very much an
enjoyable and memorable sight to see and learn about.
Why not?. Impressive monument. Crowded. A lot of traffic. But why not? Good photo opp, and there a loads of see nearby as well.

All attractions are next to each other...you can spend a day here. We started the day by visiting this square, continued to the park of Varosliget, visited the Vajdahunyad castle and ended the day by a bath at the Szechenyi Bath's...all these attractions are literally next to each other
Very Impressive at night. Looks brilliant floodlit and its right near theSzéchenyi Thermal Bath and parks. Impressive statues.
Must do!!!!!!!. You have to do this! During the zebra bike tour, our guide told us about the historical significance of each statue. Interesting history, beautiful park.

Little beauty spot. Despite its reputation for being big, it isnt big at all. And apart from some view snazzy snaps there is nothing there to do. Shame as I've still no idea who or what the statues are/represent and I understand its a big part of Hungarian History! This is the reason it's getting 4 stars unfortunately. We literally spent 30 mins there and went to wander around the park
Pretty!. Was in Budapest a few weekends ago for a hen party and came across this on one of our nights out. The structure is great, and really eye-catching. Very clean and well looked after too
Love the 7 horsemen statues. We spent ages in Heroes Square looking at the 7 tribesmen statues on the centre podium. We also walked around the park and stopped for drinks at a bar nearby.

Impressie square.. Even more impressive at night. After you have visited the square, you have to go in the park to have a look at the nice castle. If you have kids, take advantage of the zoo and the circus in the park. We enjoyed them both. And When we went to the circus, we took the cheapest tickets and were close enough to enjoy the show. In this same park, you have the world largest outdoors spa.
Quick visit. This is an interesting area to check out and you can do so on your way to or from the bath house. Not a lot of time is needed to see the monument.

Just as a Heroes Square should be!. This is just the sort of square that we would have expected in a former eastern-bloc country, and we could just imagine the masses ranks of soldiers and weapons trundling past here in earlier times. It is grand and very photogenic.
Beautiful!. Great location. I visited when I completed the Budapest marathon and the start and finish were located in heroes Square. Really beautiful views and has a great atmosphere.

A nice open space and impressive monument. The open space here really breaks up the city, the monument is impressive and grand and on route to the baths or the park you cant not pass this place and is a lovely place to take 5minutes on a nice day

Surrounded by Museums. The square itself has some impressive statues and the museums have lovely artwork on them. However it is worth walking there along Andrassy Avenue. The adjoining houses show the variety of Budapest- an elderly relative in a combination of a threadbare ball gown and diamond necklace. The houses vary from beautiful renovated period pieces to soviet era blocks, from tatty villas to museums and embassies.
Fabulous sculptures. Worth a visit for the incredible sculptures....easy to access by train and plenty of sights around as well. We found it easy to take photos without the ubiquitous crowds....

An eye catching square. We took the hop-on hop-off bus there. From the top deck of the bus we could see this monument square before our bus stop. What an eye catching square. We can see the archangel Gabriel on top of the Millennium column. Below is the statue of the seven chiefs of Magyar tribes and the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. There are more national leader’s statues at the semicircular colonnade behind the column. There are Museum of fine Arts and Palace of Art close by. We had a refreshing visit.Happy Travelling!

Fantastic square. Situated in the northern part of the city, Heroes square is listed as a World Heritage site. It is one of the major squares in Budapest and commemorates the thousandth anniversary of the foundation of the Hungarian state.

Pittoresque . A few minutes away from the best baths in Budapest, this beautiful square in the heart of the city sits next to a cute park.The architecture of the square is definately picture worthy and you kind of have to visit it as part of your stay.
Must see. Beautiful square, with the variou kings andtheir history inscribed. The place has a fairy tale feel to it.

Interesting History. If you have the time, it's worth walking around this whole area, as the other sights are very close, as is the Park, Ice rink, Castle etc. Using the Hop on, Hop off buses are an easy way to view these prime attractions, as they are quite a walk from the City centre.

Beautiful place. The place is beautiful. We visited in the end of the afternoon and later at night. Both were great times for excellent photos. Also there weren't many people. It is probably crowded during spring or summer. Very easy access through metro yellow line. It is s great spot for skating. Not much to do there though. It is just a pretty place. If you enjoy photography you can't miss it.

Another symbol - budapest. You can see picture of heroes square on all post card of budapest. So nice statues of the heroes of hungary. You feel hungary at heroes square. Don't come back without seeing thatmonument

One of the best Monuments in Europe. I love this monument which was built to commemorate the Magyar tribes. It reeks of history and is so beautiful. The Archangel Gabriel stands on top of the center pillar, holding the holy crown and the double cross of Christianity. The seven chieftains who led the Magyar tribes to Hungary can be seen on the stand below. Statues of kings and other important historical figures stand on top of the colonnades on either side of the center pillar. Take time to see it during the day and at night!

Very attractive square. near the zoo and the Vajdahunyad Castle...it's big or should I better say it is huge, enormous, surrounded by amazing buildings such as the museum of fine arts and the Mucsarnok. Stroll around the city park, go to the zoo for a fantastic experience and then take the Andrassy utca for your return to the city centre...don't forget to take photos of the statues and the whole square...one more reason for you to love Budapest!Not to mention that visiting teh Vajdahunyad castle nearby is more than a must.

Worth a visit on a nice day. Very easy to get to using the underground and it is a spectacular place for a good weather visit. To see how much work went into building this is a tribute to it's Eastern European history... Andrassy Ut is the boulevard leading up to it and I walked back the 2 or 3 miles into the city centre passing museums and the Opera House. A lovely walk as a bonus.

My favourite sight in Budapest. . This is by far the coolest place that you can walk around. With all the statues and the sheer size of the square . It is steeped with history . The statues of Kings are class.

Nice and Grand to Take Pictures. It's a nice place to take pictures and learn about the history. Make sure you have a good guide so they can explain things to you. BEcareful of people trying to sell youthings and beware your belongings here.
Quite interesting. Sadly we were harassed by gypsies the whole time so made it a bit hard to concentrate on our tour guide.Very impressive structure and historical background tho.
Nice place. It is not a must to go there but if you are nearby it is a nice place to visit. There is also a park behind it and a zoo is also not far from it.

Just a square . Nothing special about the square itself. Big statue.
Museums on both sides are worth a visit.
Nice city park beyond the square.

The end of Andrassy that everyone should visit!. Heroes' Square was built in 1896, a year of 1000th anniversary of Hungary. Even that it is located away from the center of Budapest, we (a couple) recommend you to come here by using yellow metro line or even by walking through the whole Andrassy street. In general, this square is quite empty during day. However, it might get very crowdy during national holidays. Horse races and other events take place on this square from time to time.Also, this square might be your starting point of exploration of nearby sights like Museum of Fine Arts, Palace of Art, Budapest Zoo, Circus, Szechenyi baths and many other places as well.All in all, come here to explore another important part of Budapest!

Beautiful at night. We rode the metro at night to visit Heroes statute and saw it lit up. It was magnificent. It is right near the baths and there was ice skating in front of the nearby castle when we visited. Very poignant statue and stunning when viewed at night.

Must See. A memorial to see in Budapest, with the statues giving the history of the city, many photos can be taken here, there is a hop on hop off bus stop close by, well worth a visit with the park being in the area as well.

Lovely ice skating. While in Hungary we went to the ice skating rink located at Heroes Square. Now I had never been ice skating in my life before and even I jad a good time so it woukd definitely be fun for people more competent than me! You can take your own boots or hire them. Be sure to take a passport for identification as they're not very happy with people who don't have one!

Budapest must-visit. I think this is a very iconic place in Budapest, that's why it is worth to visit. Take one or two photograph there as a proof that you have been there. It is very easily reached by Metro, stop Hősök tere. The square is just located across the metro exit.
Must see. Easy to reach from all over town . Surrounded with a lot of interesting sights . You can walk in the near by park . As Budapest has long walks save energy !!!

Nice walk. There is a lovely park and lots of monuments and building to admire and photograph. If you're a dog lover this is a great place to meet some beautiful dogs being walked in the grounds by their owners. All very well behaved.

You cant really miss it!!. Heading to the castle, the zoo or the baths? You cant miss this huge memorial dedicated to the countries heroes! located at the end of andrassey avenue you will be stopped the the huge structure that you may recognise from Michael jacksons song HISTORY. Enjoy!
Very impressive. even on a cold rainy day, this square is huge and imposing. I'm sure on a sunny day it is full of people also close the park

Heroes' Square, Budapest. A location, with statues, which is very important to the Hungarian people for major historical reasons.
Worth a look.

Must visit. In the 14 years I've lived here, I never tire of this place. Having traveled all over the world and visited many squares in many cities, I can say that HS takes a back seat to none.Flanked by two interesting and imposing museums on either end and with the City Park as a backdrop, it has an impressive appearance. Knowing something of Hungarian history as one studies the 7 ancient chiefs of the tribe that migrated from the Urals over 800 years (beginning with Attila and settling in the now Budapest by Arpad. Contrast that with the rows of Soviet tanks which occupied it during the 1956 uprising, and you get a bit of a chill up your spine. In the rear of the square are famous Hungarian kings and leaders beginning with the founder of the country, King St Stephen to a hero of the 1848 revolution, Kossuth Lajos.It's a great place for photo-ops, followed by a visit to the museums, Szenchenyi Bath, the zoo or City Park. Excellent restaurants are in the vicinity.

Amazing Buildings. Look up....look down...look left...look right...look ahead....look around. Stop take reflection, soak in the architecture, the view, the thinking behind the statues. Then venture forward and explore.A must do for Budapest.
Square of all kings. Nice square, big park, museums, lake in the summer and iceskating ring in the winter, castle, Szecseni Bath is 2 minutes by walk!
