The history of the Huns and Hungary. You'll see the seven main Hun leaders depicted on their horses. The square is beautiful and sometimes BMX pros and other street artists practice or mess around, making the square an excellent place to people-watch.

Breathtaking architecture. We walked to this from our prime reason for going to this part of the city to visit the adjacent Varosliget park. Traffic moves around this square, treating it as just a huge roundabout, but to stand in the middle and admire the stonework and statues is such an experience. Size and spectacle of the monument gets across the scale of what it celebrates.

A vast square. The heroes square is vast. The view is fanatastic as you can see the statue and the pillars behind it.Along the sides are two museums which are pretty good to see.There is a tour bus called "Hop on Hop off" which comes here to drop the tourists off. It is a very handy way of transport
Picture perfect. Lovely monument near the park at the end of Andrassy Avenue. Lovely to read the inscriptions and take pictures.
Magical. A wonderful place to stop off if you are on a hop on hop off bus there is also a nice skating rink there

A big open square encircled by traffic. You have to come and see it, see the city founders sculpture.
There's not much here but it leads on to the City Park and Andrássy út. There's a small cafe under the shade of the Hall of Art, which is a welcome place for a coffee or a cold drink.
Very nice open square. Great for a photo opertunity amd very close to the zoo and circus. Not very busy and plenty of space.

Stunning end to the Andrassy- Elegant Entrance to City Park. This is one of the first places I visited 13 years ago as a lover of history. This grand area at the conclusion of the section housing the diplomats from around the world, is flanked on either side by art museums (fine and contemporary) and features the chieftains of Hungary's long and storied history who are arrayed at the back of the square. I imagined what it was like back in '56 when the landscape was dominated by a thousand Soviet tanks getting ready to rumble against the freedom fighters. Great spot for photos.This is a can't miss part of the city which you can easily combine with visits to the zoo, Szechenyi Baths, or City Park (Varosliget).Gundel restaurant offers a fine dining possibilities nearby though pricey.
great place to visit. you must visit heroes square, monuments and statues are magnificent, must take camera, the best attraction .

Majestic historic - must visit. This is a central location and you can take the old metro line hereNearby is the zoo - also worth seeingThe spa - great spa - and Kunsthalle which has interesting art exhibitionsOn Sunday's flea market in park nearby
Ice rink and zoo. Nice place and lots of room to take photos and see the sights. Just around the corner is an ice rink- in the winter which is 1500huf entry and 800huf for skates. Worth a visit.

Great!. Looks like just a square, but we really had a great time there! Statues look amazing and you can just be there to 'chill out' and enjoy the place. There was a 'walking bar' like a car with people having drinks where they cycled and it moved around. They sang '100 Miles', SO FUNNY!!

good for a walk. Museum, park, Szechenyi spa nearby. Good for a walk especially on a sunny day, to get a glimpse of the Hungarian history as well. Closeby is the Arts Museum, Varosliget park or the famous Szechenyi bath, the Zoo. Easy access via Yellow Underground.

I'd Pass on this next time.... We walked out here from Pest...a good hike. Enjoyed the walk but the site didn't do much for us. Lots of tour buses, not that much to see. Go to the nearby park instead...nice restaurant there too.

Wonderful Location. we were here ahead of the crowds one morning and had this wonderful area to ourselves. There's not a great deal to see, but plenty of atmosphere. Stand back and take in the grandeur.
big square..must see.. Really big square and there is a metro stop to reach it! once you go there you can visit also the Budapest zoo and the Vajdahunyad Castle (Vajdahunyadvar) !!
Breathtaking History. While on a visit to Budapest, we took a tour on Heroes Square. The history and the the statuary were both incredible and definitely worthwhile and worth your time.
Pretty Square. Square is really interesting and statues show a variety of times. Close to the metro and has access to the park and the boulevard.

Good history lesson!. This square is a memorial to all of the heroes who helped to form Hungary from Attila the Hun from whom the Hungarian people are descended from down through the various kings who helped to liberate them from the steady stream of invaders who kept conquering the country and creating a human melting pot. Each hero is individually named and you really need a guide book or google to get a sense of each persons contribution in the overall picture of Hungary. Plan for avou 15-30 minutes with great photo-op.

it is just a square but it is there for a good reason. it is worth getting off and walking around here also the zoo and one of the open air baths you can go in and walk around or take you trunks and swim
Impressive plce. Impressive and very nice place. Do not forget to visit it when you are in Budapest - me personally liked it a lot
worth going to see. We enjoyed our visit in the rain and snow today, the square is beautiful. Very close to the ice skating rink, the metro and the park.

Pretty impressive.... . We visited here as part of our city with our guide! It was pretty impressive, its good to see it show important people from history from St.Stephen to people from the revolution!

Magyar Millennium. This monument commemorates the 1000th anniversary of the founding of the Hungarian nation by 7 tribal Magyar chieftains who are depicted at the base of the column on horseback. The expressions and facial details (men and horses) are wonderful, as is the whole exuberant assemblage. I loved it!

A highlight.. Visited Heroes Square today. Spectacular area with a lot of history. A great place for photos. Wss disappointed the Budapest sign was gone but I should have researched that myself. Certainly worth a visit and easy to get to as it is on all of the tourist bus routes. Nice outdoor ice skating arena is nearby, my only complaint is that there are no public toilets that I could find. Not saying that there are none but I could not find any. Definitely should visit when in Budapest.
Heroes Square memorial. Such a beautiful tribute to lives lost and battles fought, and magnificent architecture. A vast area of beautiful and poignant tribute

History Lesson. Yes, a history lesson, but to an American, not a very good one. If I had a pamphlet to describe the heroics of each of the people whose statues were there, it would have been helpful. Or, if there were placards with the information below each in several languages, including English, it would have been helpful.Had some kind of information been readily available, the rating would be a 5.I would hope that citizens of Hungary would know all of the heroes and their claim to fame.Despite the criticism, it is a large area and beautiful structure...very well done. A great way for a country to remember, and salute, their past.
Beautiful and thought provoking!. Beautiful square/monument to Hungarian heroes but bringing to mind thoughts of heroes and victims everywhere at this time!
Stunning architecture. Best to go in the evening. Wonderfull opportunity for photography, plenty of options to get there, public transport excellent
Interesting place. I really enjoyed the area - the statues were magnificent.The area was a bit big, so you can enjoy a little stroll around it.

Intresting. Recommended. Nice esplanad with statues representing the heroes of the fights/wars. It was a bit crowded with tourists but as it's really large you won't feel it. We were there around 10 am so all was good. Weather was lovely with not a lot of sunshine. It's an open place!

It's great to visit during the night when it's less busy. I came here after a visit to Szechenyi baths. It's a short walk and a great place to see at night when it's less crowded and all the lights are on.
Beautiful square. Lovely square with monuments and statues! An interesting display was set up on the history and future of the nearby city park.

Last stop . We were only in Budapest for 2 full days; and it hero's square was the last place to visit on a very busy itnerary. We took a bit of a detour to get there; using the tram instead of the metro( id suggest using the metro to get there) but my goodness it was worth the effort; it was a perfectly stunning day & I spent at least half hour soaking in the statutes.. make the effort to go here; you won't be disappointed

Night Walking. A few friends and I were walking around at night at this place...It was awesome then, and even better when we came back the next day. It's a great activity to do for free, as long as you don't stop to listen to the street musicians.
Very moving. I suggest you read up the history before you visit as the sign plaques are in Hungarian (understandably).
cool. big and spacious with museums etc nearby, we were walking by it in the evening but i think on a summers day it would be class just to sit and chill out

Not the best sight in Budapest, but still nice. In a city with so many beautiful historic buildings as Budapest, squares as this one, although impressive, just don't seem all that, after visiting all the other beautiful sights. Having said that, it is definitly a must-see.

Impressive and big square. Spend some time in this square you have a chance to look at the "founding fathers" of magyar , it is a good point to go and do different things, the art museum or museum of fine arts or continue to completely different experience in the park.
Impressive but usual. Have seen very similar memorials in other cities on my tour. I'm sure it would be more impressive had there been a ceremony in the square.
Worth seeing. Lots of statues and history - in an interesting area and worth a quick stop - nothing exceptional to see but of great significance to the Hungarians
Budapest. Beautiful place next to a huge park with lakes and walks. if you take the tourist bus you can stop here and take some nice pics.

A wonderful place. This place is such a beauty. It shows how rich the Hungarian history is. The statues are very beautifully crafted and it is such a monumental place that even the Hungarian people stop by when they see it.
Massive square filled with statues of Hungarian Kings and Dukes. This square looks very pretty and is well worth a visit. The only downside was the number of people trying to sell you clothing.

On the way to go to the bath. We took few photos because it was on your way to go to the baths across the park, we understood the significance of the place for Hungarians.
Beautiful place surrounded by 2 museums but we didn't stayed that long.

You need to be fit!. We fully underestimated how tough of a climb it was to the top. Thankfully there are little pocket coves you can slip into and take in the views as you work your way up to the top. I'd recommend sensible shoes as there are uneven paths and quite a few steps. When you get to the top the pain of getting there is all forgotten about and you appreciate what a beautiful city you're in.
Impressive. Beautiful square. We visited this site on a wet and rainy day so did not get the full benefit of seeing this beautiful architecture.

One of the great monuments.. Stand back in awe and just take in the size of this monument, which I believe to be on of the worlds greatest, beautiful and elegant, do not miss it out of your itinerary, a perfect photo to show your friends.

Nice. Beautiful square with referrences to Hungarian history. Statues are interesting. When visiting this, check the which exibitions are at the museums and visit the City park with Hunyadi castle which is at the back side of the square.

Beautiful and well kept square. Really enjoyed visiting this square and admiring the wonderful statues and architecture. This is a must-see for anyone visiting Budapest. One note of warning - watch out for people trying to sell you souvenirs and apparent Hungarian crafts. Our guide warned us they are pickpockets so stay away from them if they approach you.
Grandiose!. Grandiose place! Huge open place with giant statues! It is a bit out of the city centre, but next there is a nice park with a lake.
HISTORICAL. Very interesting information regarding the design and statues on this attraction, we found we got the most information from the bus tours.

Vast statues in large square. 22nd October 2015. At one end of the gorgeous Andrassy Boulevard, and worth walking to not just to see this, but also to admire the many glorious buildings lining the Boulevard. The statues were erected in 1896. Beyond this square is City Park which we were not that impressed with. There is a good Tourist Info office within yards of the square. The zoo is here too (not visited by us).
Historical Site. Various status and monuments to those who founded and led the Hungarian state. Worth an hour to enjoy and take pictures. Easy to reach and not far from other Budapest attractions.

Worth a visit. Heroes' square is at one end of Andrassy Ut, accessible by the old metro (line 1). It was built in the late 19th century, and commemorates some of the country's most famous historical leaders, from the founding tribal chiefs to those fighting in the various Turkish invasions. A very pleasant way to spend an hours or so on a fine day.
great location. lovely place to visit and the bronze status were great, took some amazing pictures and there was an outdoor festival going on across the road with lots to eat and drink and buy.
Impressive square with monuments. Located at the end of Andrassy Ut, this is an impressive square. Several monuments commemorating the Hungarian history and close to Szechenyi Baths.
Cool place . I loved it here . Big square to commemorate their herosSo grand and beautiful with all the statues Go to castle and baths near by
Cool Statues. This is a walkabout area close to museums and baths. It is very impressive and beautiful in its own way. It is most impressive for its history and worth a visit.

Heroes' Square closer many important places. The Heroes' Square is good location that people to visit the opera house, museum, park and Czecheny bath. There are also many cafes, restaurants & shopping store short distance from the Heroes' Square. The Heroes' square is that I recommend travelers to visit in budapest.

Interesting to history buffs. Hungary has amazing history and this place is full of it, myth, legend and acknowledging their past. Can get quite busy at times but plenty of space to wander around and read the plaques and take in the architecture.

A bit disappointing. If you are pressed for time, you can skip this landmark--especially if you are not a museum person. Those are on either side of square. It was more interesting to use this as a starting point of a walk down famous Andrassy St.
Beautiful. What a great place to visit beautiful views history and easy to get tooA lovely spot to have a stroll and relax watch the words go by

Has to be see.. Nice big statues of old Hungarian Heroes.
My only remark would be, we have to cross an avenue to access the place, and no traffic light for pedestrians are present. You need to be careful when crossing.

What and amazing sight. During my stay I was able to visit the Hero’s square. It’s such a beautiful and historical place at a wonderful location. The statues were enormous and beautifully crafted. No doubt, if you’re in Hungary then you must visit this place.

A triumph.pf Hungarian history. When you go and visit, make sure you take a guide because this monument takes you back to the foundation of Hungary. It is quite interesting to learn about the different Magyare tribes that united to create the country and of the Arpad dynasties. Never forget that the king was elected by the aristocracy and also overthrown by the same aristocracy. Very interesting indeed.

Worth the visit only if you have to be in that area. It is located a distance from the center, so only worth while when you are going anyway to see the nearby museums, or the zoo and park. It is a very impressive square, but not worth the 20 minute ride from the center of Budapest.

A stunning tribute. This square is a tribute to past heros of Hungary. Huge bronze statues overlook a massive square. Look for the sculpture of a rider on a horse with elk or deer horns on it's bridle. Lovely
Need to take photo!. The most beautiful place that I'be ever been. In this place Michael Jackson made a "History" video clip and I recommending to take here a photo!

Cool place. Amazing statues, close to the famous Szechenyi Baths, there's an art gallery close by, and it's at the end of a nice walk down Budapest's Champs-Elysee. Well worth seeing, the square is huge and the statues are quite amazing.
statues rulers. Took bus to square. Spa is close by. Walked to restaurant from here. Visitors center here and lovely park
Really big square. This square is huge! I visited at night and it's really nice, but I would recommend visiting it during sunset as I think you can take wonderful pictures there.
A great place to be seen. This is a must place to visit just to be seen in and spend time taking photos. Easy to get to with a good cafe nearby

Tribute to Hungarian Heroes. This popular square in Budapest reflects the history of the country. It is best if you visit
with a guide who can give you the historical background. The sculptures are magnificent.

sculpture, gardens and museums. This place is famous for its sculptures but as well for both museums that are around.
Note that the budapest circus, the zoo and the famous gundel restaurant are very close.
Great. Nice austrohungarian imperial architecture. Next to the Baths and many cute bistros in the Embassy areas. You can combine it with going to the baths.

A long walk from the river. didn't realise how long a walk it would be when we left the parliament building. Would advise worth looking at public transport options unless its a sunny day & you want to stretch your legs

A very movig experience for anyone!. This is a very moving experience for anyone, but particularly for anyone who has ever been in a war. They have their own tomb of the unknown solder(s) guarded by two young Hungarian Honor Guard. Arc Angel Gabriel stands high upon the perch in the center of the square watching over and protecting all who ask for his help...

Lovely place. Visited here whilst staying in Budapest - what a great place. As soon as we got out of our coach we were confronted with beautiful European architecture - there were various beautiful and historical statues scattered around the square. It was fascinating to learn about the history behind the statues and was a great insight into Hungarian history.

Beautiful and super clean . Heroes square was a great display of cleanliness in Budapest. It was lovely to see and a must see when in Budapest. It is close enough that you can walk to other attractions from here.

Heroes' Square. This is one of the stops on the Hop On Hop Off tours and should be included in any visit to Budapest. It has major historical significance with a wide open square and statues. It is also close to one of the famous bath houses and the city zoo. Public washrooms are adjacent to the square which is always important when travelling.
Good walk . It is a beautiful place to visit. Nice little walk to see the history of Budapest. Can get crowded but it is large so it doesn't feel to crowded.

Hero's Square. .The main feature of Heroes' Square is the Millennium memorial monument which consists of a large stone cenotaph surrounded by a ornamental chain and was constructed between 1896 and 1900 . At the back of the Millenium monument is the statue complex that has monuments of Hungarian National leaders,the seven chieftains of the Magyars and also the tomb of the unknown soldier.This square has had a important role in Hungarian history and many political events have been held on this large ground..During my tour there was a huge police parade in progress at the square and on inquiry learnt that it was a parade of the induction of new Hungarian police into the police force.Vajdahunyad castle,Szechenyi thermal baths ,Budapest zoo and the Capital circus are within walking distance from Hero's square.
Changing of the guard. Walked here from Vaci Street and arrived just in time to see changing of the guard , nice water feature here too.
Glorious place to be.. The outdoor! ice rink here is HUGE but obviously it needs to be freezing ! The square and surrounds are worth the visit. The Zoo is within a shortish walk

Beautiful Monument. It is worth to visit, beautiful monument from the root of the creation of Hungary, with its evolution, as Empire, Republic, Country. It really is one of the most beautiful monuments built. I recommend a visit.
Russian occupation memorial. We walked through coming from the Belvedere museum. Nice memorial, but I wouldn't go out of my way to see it. Great dogs across the street for $2usd.

The Trafalgar Square of Budapest. Heroes Square built in 1896 celebrates the 7 kings and heroes which shaped Hungary and is very easy to get to using the metro to the Hosok tere stop and worth seeing great for photos also there is a big park behind plus other places to see close by .
Open and great picture takeing. Go during the day and get some beautiful pictures. Plus there are a few other notable buildings in the immediate area to take in and walk around.
Magnificent Statues. The square presents a tribute to the historical heroes of Hungary, displayed on a grand scale. Easily accessible by transit.

All leeds to Heroes Square. Is one of the major squares in Budapest, with lots of Hungarian Heroes performing a large complex. In the center you have as well as the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. It's located at the outbound end of Andrássy Avenue next to City Park . Opposite side of Danube. At right and left you have 2 museums: Museum of Fine Arts on the left and Palace of Art on the right.
Great for kids. Kids loved playing in between the hero's massive statues. Big ground for kids to run around. We went there on Halloween to look at lots of pumpkins and meet a real witch as well :)
Monumental square. It is monumental square with the Columm, Colonnade and sculptures. But maybe very monumental and empty.
Night view is amazing. It's different when you go to the place at night. Wonderful and nice to photo taking. Go when you have time. There's a subway in front of the place.
Beautiful. It is worth going to this place. It is magnificent and after taking photos, u can take a stroll in the garden behind it and there is a castle in the garden and thermal bath nearby.

Take the time. This is a very important space in Budapest. It has been a place in history. Before you go, do the research so you know what the statues mean, the markers are all in Hungarian. Always consider the time of day - where the sun will be - for any outdoor site you will want to take pictures. You will want to time to have the sun behind you.
wonderful photo area!. this was a lovely place to go and photos are a must here. they are cool to look at and is fabulous at night. there is a restaurant beside it and the hot chocolate is fantastic!

The top most attraction. Visited as a part of my city tour. A very big square with great architecture of the various things located on this square. Good for photo ops. A brief visit independently is also fine.

Interesting. Beautiful place and really big. I was able to see it while the weather was really good and sunny. There are also beer pong wheels one could hire around the area for those in groups. There are also restaurants nearby.

Green to be seen. This is a huge square close to the city park. The curving of one of the monuments is very specific allowig for great photos. Lots of green statues and although visited by many tourist buses wasnt busy because of its size.

NATIONAL MONUMENT. Historically significant (even as late as 1956 as the site of the squelched Hungarian uprising against communism) for remembering the kings of the country. This open plaza is huge, surrounded by architecturally massive and ornate buildings, the pride of Hungary. It helps to know the specifics of the kinds on the monument.

Go and see it by night.!. This is something to see. It is on a grand scale and lovely to see at night. The statues are like something from the game of thrones and this is the entry to the beautiful park
Hungarian heroes. Walked here to pass a couple of hours and it is down a long straight road so very easy. The square is large and many figures from history are depicted. Good photo spot!

Very good. Reading a bit of history of Hungary and Budapest would be highly recommended to appreciate even more the memories that this square carries and therefore, its name. It is a must visit whenever in Budapest. Highly recommended.
Very impessive place!. Great historical place! Nice memorial! Very nice restaurant Robinson nearby with great food & bear! and very nice decoration! Not really expensive!

A huge area with the monuments of the Hungarian rulers and heroes. A huge area with the monuments of the Hungarian rulers and heroes.
On the area of a large museum, within walking distance of the castle and the zoo. One of the most interesting places in Budapest.
Amaziiiiing. Beautiful statues, nice, big square with interesting people. Much more amazing place all around, so close to each other.

Worth a walk to visit it. Quite a big area that is full of historical facts, although some of those facts are quite sad. Best seen with a tour guide to explain the history and give you the local facts.

Bronze at it's best. Take the Metro, exit station and BANG you're in the Square!You just go photograph crazy. Take time to enjoy from a distance to get the whole square in perspective and size. As you walk closer the size is remarkable and the cleanliness is rewarding. The chariot figures are best viewed some way back and zoomed in on to stop you viewing the underneath view. Try it!Careful positioning gets all the statues and walled plinths in the same shot. Just take your time and go early so the shots can be people free!

Bold and imposing monument. We walked the entire length of Andrassy ending at Heroes Square. Catching glimpses along the way does not prepare you for the sheer size and impressiveness of this monument to heroes of Hungarian history.
Majestic. This has a very roman feel and look about it, it is very open with plenty of great photo opportunities
A must. Lots of heroes, it is a big part of Hungarian history. Nice sunny day activity. You could even bring a sandwich to eat while here.
Historic. You need a guide to get the full impact of the importance of this historic site in Budapest. The story is incredible.

Love those Heroes. Impressive square with statues of various hugarian heroes. It's a bit busy during the day but beautiful and somewhat eery at night when it's quiet. FYI. They do turn off the lights after midnight. It would be helpful if there were english descriptions of these various heroes.
Ok. Square is massive. Impressive statues with great buildings around it. You get hounded by street sellers peddling their wares. Annoying and distracting.

A stunning public memorial but not much else to do.. This a beautiful memorial to the heroes of Hungarian history done in a grand bit of architecture. It is worth seeing, but there isn't a lot otherwise to do around there. There are museums on either side of the square but that is about it and you can take it in by car from the roundabout that surrounds it.

Go with a Guide. not exactly stunning, but everything around it is nice. since it is very historical you would need to learn about the historical significance of the site. Andrassy street is quite beautiful to walk down.

Worthy of heros. This beautiful site in Budapest is one of my favorite with its great sculptures of the heroes of Hungarian history is a grand entrance to the VarosLiget where there is a lot to enjoy like the Szechenyi Bath and VajdaHunyad castle.
Fantastic square. The square was beautiful and we'll designed. It was like most of communist squares in the Russian systems. But the architecture of the square is besutiful .
Magnificent. Well worth the walk! what can I say go and see for yourself you will not be disappointed we were impressed

Statues and more statues. We started our private tour here. The guide talked about each statue and what they contributed to the history of Hungary. It was sort of interesting but not a must see. We were lucky to have a guide otherwise we would of walked around for 5 minutes and left .

Built for the 1896 Millennium Celebrations. Expansive square, flanked by the Museum of Fine Arts and the Palace of Art, walk to this venue along Andrassy street then you can really appreciate the grandeur of the square. Magnificent statue of Prince Arped and his men

A quick look on your way to the Szechenyi baths... Arriving by the metro, you have to cross several streets to reach it. In all honesty, this place probably holds significance to Hungarians or historians. We had a guide book with pages explaining which statue is who, but even then... 15 minutes tops for pictures, and only on a good weather day. Else, there's not much else around, except for the bath.
Beautiful.... We did the Red Bus hop on hop off.. this is one stop. Take a few minutes to walk around and take photos. A lovely place to see

A must see!. Definitely make time to visit this monument. Beautiful view with a lovely atmosphere. Surrounded by museums, a large park, zoo, circus and Szechenyi Baths and Pool. The Metro station brings you out directly onto Heros Square.
Centuries of heroes in one place. Budapest is a city of statues--amazingly beautiful works, that tell the world who brought them here.
Quick Tour. We stopped here for about 15 minutes on a bike tour and its just a large square, it was plenty of time. It was good to see it with our tour as he helped give history to the square.

Worthy of a Quick Visit. We visited on a very rainy afternoon, so ours was a short but sweet stay. In the center is a statue of 7 men astride horses, and they represent the 7 chieftains of theMagyars who came together and founded Hungary in 896 AD. The monument is calledthe Millennial Monument because it celebrated 1,000 years since the founding ofthe country. In front of the Millennial statue the tomb of the Unknown Soldier,similar to what we have at Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia. Thedifference is, there are no real remains of soldiers below, just a memorial. Thesquare also contains two marble semi-circles containing statures of all theHungarian Kings. Beautiful, worth a quick stop. One cautionary, there are vendors like flies wanting to sell you every cheap trinket. Our guide cautioned us away from them, saying their product is cheap and prices are confiscatory.

A clean open space. The square is very clean and when we went very deserted (get there early before the crowds and you have time to see everything and take fantastic photos. Be aware of the vendors that descend on the tourists though.
Not to be missed. This square is beautiful and uplifting. Of course, it speaks to another era -- the late 1800s. But it is majestic and a must see.

Nice. Pros: Nice sculpturesCons: Not much to see/do apart from the statues eg we got off to take pictures and by the time the hop on, hop off bus came bsck 30 minutes later, we were bored. Would be good if there were more places to sit so one could sit and snackTips:Supposed to be walkable to the zoo
Great spot. Loved this part. Popped off the big bus tour. It's not far from one of the baths. Big square and we'll worth a visit and capture your pics or selfish.
Hero Square Budapest. Tour guide explained the history of the square and the significance of many of the statues that are present.
Atmospheric. We found the heroes square to be very atmospheric and moving. It is next to the first ever urban park.
Great spot to absorb some history. Really enjoyed Heroes square and what it has to offer. There is such a variety of history there from many different periods. The statues are amazing.

Huge Square. Visited during National Gallop festival where the square was turned into an equestrian race course with parts of the adjacent City park turned into temporary stables. Seems lots of fun though with a traditional food festival running concurrently offering lots of wines, sausages, and other traditional Hungarian finger foods.
A must see in Budapest . It's a lovely place to see on a nice day. Great statues and buildings. All very ingesting. It's worth going over to the park after you are finished on the square
Walk one end to the other. Walk one end of the main street to the other taking this attraction in on the way. The square is quite large and not far from the Spa. Ice-skating rink close by
Memorial Square. Good open space surrounded by a number of statues remembering the chieftains of the Magyars, other national leaders and the tomb of the unknown soldier. Worth a quick visit.

A Square filled with the Hungarian heroes. Its a very large square, with a semi-circle of old Hungarian warriors and Kings. They are proud of their history, which is long and has certainly been difficult. A great display.

Large square. This is just a big square -lots of statues that would probably have a lot more meaning if you had someone to tell you more about them. We had a guide but she didn't say that much about them. The statues were quite nice but we only had a few minutes in the rain before jumping back on the bus.
A hughe area for a tribute.. Heroe's square is a very traditional tribute to all of the Kings and people that were a part of Hungary's long past.
A fine civic square. An interesting place to visit and take photographs of the many fine statues and monuments in this square.
Wonderful for photo ops. Near by the park, museums and baths. Great little area for photos. You can spend about 15 minutes to an hour here.

Interesting, but there are no benches. Wasn't real "taken" with this place. The statues and history (built for the 1896 celebration) were interesting but that's abut all there is. The place sorely needs a place to sit and take in the atmosphere.
In honor of the Fallen heroes. A beautiful monument to see if you are visiting Budapest. Bundle up though if you are visiting in the cold season as the site is so wide open.

A stunning centrepiece surrounded by other attractions. Surrounded by parks art galleries the zoo etc the sheer scale of it has to impress. It reminded me very much of the Brandenburg gate area of Berlin without the chilling overtones.
Worth spending a day here. Great access to many attractions ( Zoo, Hunyadvar castle and a few museums). The squere itself is quite large and impressive.

Inescapeable. If you are in Budapest you will not escape this monument which is located on the way to the hot springs (baths). the site quite reminds one of the Champs Elysees in paris, however the history of the square is unique to Hungary. A good quide will help you to understand the relevance of each statue and the reasons behind why it was made. Do visit it wont require much effort

HONOURING PAST HEROES. Constructed in 1896 this huge paved square with angel topped pillars, iconic sculptures and monuments features the Seven Chieftains of the Magyars and other important national leaders, as well as the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. Nostalgia for the "old times" is alive and well here and Heroes' Square is one of the major squares in Budapest, and worthy of a visit.
Not to be missed. An historic square in a great setting used even today by demonstrator/protesters etc. An attraction not to be missed.

Couldn't really see because of the horse races. The square was filled with the horse races (9/19-9/20) so you couldn't get the real feel of it and could only partially see the monuments there. Don't miss out on the park. It was so jam packed with people everywhere that we did not stay in this area for very long, we headed back down Andrassy Ut to get away from the insanity of it all.Because of the event, there were tons of food trucks around.

freezing in winter. Great attraction ,had an excellent guide who took us around the city,,try real Hungarian goulash on a cold winters day,a lovely city with lovely people,good walking shoes a must as the pavements have a layer of ice

Definitely a see in Budapest. It's a must in Budapest.
After seeing the monuments, visit the city park behind. Highly recommended.
Hungarian Place de Concorde. Truly beautiful entrance to the City Park. Must see it in the daytime, and must return at night. Worth time.

Worth a visit . We visited this place on our own backs so we had no guidance as far as the significance of these statues. It would have been good to have some information close by to give us a basic background and piece it all together. Good place to get happy snappy!

A very large square with stunning view. This large square of 400' by 600' situated near the famous Szechenyi Bath has big iconic bronze stutues representing seven Chieftains of the Magyars and the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. Beautiful view.
Lovely Square. Nice square, surrounded by a lovely park with some nice restaurants overlooking a pond. Not far from city centre so worth going to see.
Massive monument. Beautiful open square at the very top of Andrassy Ave. Take the old original underground from downtown

Heroes it is. Surrounded by so many monuments and at the center. Hero square represent the 8 tribes of Hungary to conquer the land. See the kings of hungary and princes of Transylvania as people offer flowers to them
Ok. Not worth a visit just for the square, but you'll be here anyway, on your way to the park and it's public baths and it looks nice on a sunny day.
Nice site to visit while in Budapest. Enjoyed the site that had a lot of visitors. Monument was done nicely with kept quite clean and has a lot of Hungarian history behind of it.

IMPRESSIVE AREA. The last stop of our visiting in Budapest was in the Heroes' Square.And it was one of the most effective.There are a lot of sensational statues, and also a lake where the people are able to boating.There are also museums and the hot springs.It is a place that every visitor must scedule to visit.

Iconic part of Budapest. While the square is well maintained, I found it disturbing that slovainly young tourists are allowed to climb on the base of the monument of the 7 Chieftains and eat and drink there. There was no police present to complain to. A beautiful place like that should be respected and protected as National and World Heritage not used for eating hamburger and drinking beer on top. I was aghast.
History in a line. Fourteen Hungarian leaders are represented. So interesting if you are with someone who knows the history and character of these leaders.
Gorgeous. I don't think you can really find the words to describe how gorgeous this square is. You really need to go to experience its full beauty.

Very impressive - helps to know the history. The more you know Hungarian history, you more you will get from visiting this square. We came here while it was raining. I'm glad we came but even more glad that our guide gave us a lot of background.
Amazing Sight. Very impressive too see the square is big and on the day we visited there was a ceremony with Hungarian Soldiers worth a visit

Fantastic plaza. Archangel Gabriel is At the top of the column and at the base the seven Maygar chieftains. Those statues are huge and beautiful. Check the horse with the antler as a head protection (there probably is a name for the its gear but sorry I ignore it ) I would love to know more about Hungarian history to really appreciate this plaza. Still worth seen it.
Budapest break. Came here for a Budapest break and had a city tour that stopped here. It has some beautiful buildings around here and is worth a stop

Heroes Square, a must!. This place is located between to very nice museums, and also to a nice and interesting park! It is also close to a nice bath. All the statues are wonderful, just go and join to be happy!
Awe inspiring place. This square holds statues of the most famous kings of Hungarys past. They were also the leaders of the Magyar tribes. Of great historical interest if this is your thing
an impressive square. This is an impressive square that was constructed in 1896. There are impressive statues representing their kings since the 11th century.

Must see. Take the yellow metro (1) and get off at "Hosok tere" the sight when you come above ground is amazing!
Plenty of picture opportunities.

For the history buffs. very popular attraction with lots of tourist buses visiting. The annoying sellers of cheap clothes will harass you but they generally walk away if you are firm with your rejection of their advances.

A Must Visit for all Heroes out there!. A Nice Square it took us around 30 min walk from city center but it was worth it. The square is nice, nothing spectacular, The Good thing is that it is surrounded with cultural buildings and great restaurants! Walking by this square is pleasant.
Square with statues. This square is large, grand and beautiful. Imagine how beautiful when the square was just completed. .

Another Must See. All those Magyars looking a though they had just leapt from the pages of the Lord of the Rings. You must not leave Pest without seeing it and nearby is the interesting park, the zoo and two great museums as well as super restaurants.
HEROE'S SQUARE. It is huge and nice to take pictures and walk around. I recommend this attraction a lot. There is a park in the back of the square with a little lagoon.

do a combo 1st thermal spa and... This place just 500 feet tgrough the park and ask for the sand clocm too. Arrive at 10 fkr tge soa Metro no One. Walk to the square and sand clock. . Some lunch places close by and in tbe park. Also a small zoo. Recommended MeuterMedia

Huge. Visited as part of an Imperial City tour organised by Rail Discoveries of York. This gets very busy in the morning with Tour Groups so go later in the day it is far less crowded. We visited the day after a 3 day horse racing event so they were clearing up and the Square didn’t look its best – mud underfoot! It is impressive – the statues are enormous. As usual there are lots of souvenir sellers around to bother you. This is worthwhile visiting on a hop on/hop off bus or on the Millienium underground. The stop is just over the road from the square.

Short walk along the square. Although the weather was not that nice for sightseeing, the square is almost always crowded with tourists! The statues are elaborated and can reflect for a foreigner Hungary's past magnitude. Luckily M1 metro has a stop at this place so no need to walk through Andrassy if you are not in a mood.

Very impressive square.. Incredible that they have removed two of the statues because it reminded them of their Austro-Hungarian past and replaced them. Great space but we have seen places like this all around the world.

Pretty Spectacular. It does not take a long time to visit this attraction but it is outside so the weather conditions might be important. It is a very attractively assembled memorial in a large open area in the center of a city district although not in the City Center.

We had a guide with us at this square and learned a lot, especially liked the political satire posters. It helped to have an understanding of the purpose and history of this square. While we were there, a contest was being held for political satire, as is done every year. It helped having a local translation but it was informative that these events actually occur.

Heroes' Square‬. We visited the Heroes' Square‬
Its a very nice place to visit, especially the park around it.
It's also the start point for the Budapest Marathon

square history. This square represents Hungarian difficult history . It is kept clean , with many statues.
Behind there is a beautiful park.One should take some time and see it .

Great place for people watching. If you walk from Szecheyney park through heroes square, there a couple of nice outdoor bars to sit at on the other side. Great for people watching and even better if it is a sunny day but the bars are covered and have heaters - great for smokers as well!
Stunning!. Situated at the end of a very long boulevard this towering statue can be seen. It is only close up however that you discover impressive this really is.

Hungary pays respect and never forgets. This square represents Hungary's tough history. A huge yet clean square with great statues. Behind the square is the picturesque park and close by is the zoo,circus,adventure park and the szeche I baths. Lots to do here....no.1 stop on big bus route. Want to know more just ask :-)
A tremendous square. No doubt - despite the sad story of Hungary there have been several heroes and big men in Hungarian history, too. To be recommended.
A national monument worth visiting. A large public square set in a nice neighbourhood, the columns and statues are worth seeing of course and the parks around and other buildings equally of interest.

Worth a visit. Decideed to hop off the sightseeing bus to take some photographs but was rather disappointed as the lake was drained and so the big concrete mass looked totally different to the photos seen of it. We walked around and there is one fountain working which looked quite splendid. We did not visit the zoo but I understand this came from Chester Zoo and so is worth a visit. There is a lovely cafe where we had the most delicious hot chocolate.
hike up to the Heroes' Square. You can either walk from St, Stephen (a bit of a walk) or take the metro. There's a cozy cafe near the Square by the metro entrance.

Great monument to stop by on your way to the even better spa. While I wouldn't recommend coming out all to way to see just the Hero's Square, if you happen to have plans for the nearby Szechenyi thermal bathhouse it's definitely worth your time to stop by. True to the Budapest way, there are little limitations to your access to the site - you can even climb up the monument if you for some reason want to. The surrounding piece of city is also beautiful, charming eastern European streets and a lush, expansive park.
Great Insight into Hungarian History.. This square offers great insight into how Hungary was created hundreds of years ago. The statues of all their heroes are exquisite. Well worth seeing.

Beautiful. A large expansive square with the millenium statue with Arcangel Gabriel atop. This is a memorial to those who fought for national independence. This square is located just outside the City Park
It's okay. This is just an average tourist spot. The part behind it that leads to the bath is nice, but nothing special about this place.

Marathon Day, Great Views. We went to Budapest to take part in the marathon and the start was at Hero's Square. It is a marvoulous place with great views. Stunning to take in all the views and great to walk around. We spent a good few hours walking around on the Saturday and had a great atmosphere.

Love to be here. Every time we have visitors from abroad, i take them to Heto Square. It is a nice spot to start for a Varosliget tour, or to talk about history, or even just walk on the nice square to feel the taste of Budapest. The statues of the tribe leaders, perhaps a little idealistic, but at least you get some hints of ancient time without visiting museums.

The Heroes’ square is just one of the wonderful sights you have to see in Budapest.. The square with the beautiful Andrassy street in front of it is part of the World Heritage. It has a lot of history, and I think it’s a good idea if you are planning to visit the place to take a little research before you go there so you can find out a little bit more the story behind the statues. The square is huge and really unique with all of the statues and the Millennium monument. Every statue itself is a masterpiece of the heroes of Hungary. The three main parts of the square are the Art Gallery, the Museum of Fine Arts and the Millennium monument in the middle. This beautiful memorial looks magnificent after the sun goes down and with all the lights you can truly try your inner pohotografer self and give a little work to your camera. The Heroes’ square is just one of the wonderful sights you have to see in Budapest.
Spacious and beautiful. Budapest does open spaces and monuments exceedingly well and Heroes' Square is no exception. I found the openness and the energy of the place delightful.

A must for the Budapest visitor.. The wings of history is apparent in the Heroes' square, Hösök Tere. I would say that this is a must for the Budapest visitor and you wouldn't leave without a photo of the famous Millenium statue with the Arcangel Gabriel, in the center of the square. Visit daytime and nighttime if you can. Approaching it from Andrássy Út is perfect since this avenue is on the UNESCO's World Heritage site. The square is also easily accessible by underground (station Hösök Tere). Why not also stroll around in the City Park or visit the zoo, circus, and the amusement parc or have a relaxing swim at the lovely Szècheny Baths since they're located nearby? Or the museum of Transport maybe?
Well worth a visit. We were walking through this area on the way to a Sparty on Saturday night. The square by night was amazing. It's a must see landmark if you're visiting the city
Heroes Square. Very impressive square in the middle of Pest. Close to the Baths and several other places of interest

AWESOME!. Such an impressive square full of history and wonderful statues. This place speaks of a proud heritage of the past and an exciting future. If you'd like a laugh look at the undercarriage of the horses.

amzing large square with fab statues. an amazing story of the history of Hungary, stunning statues and monument in a huge open square. Museums are alslo located close by as is the Zoo and the Ice Rink

A monument to Hungary's Heroes. This is a large and spacious square with its main attraction being the Millennium monument for the heroes who fought for national independence. We saw this as part of a guided tour around the city. recommended.
Big heroes. Large open space celebrating leaders from the past. Worth spending some time finding out the history of this important landmark.
yes. we were here, and we are heroes, greeting by bar bikes and drunk people, we were in a micra and we are cool

Heroes' Square. Beautiful square commemorating the Magyar chieftains, other national leaders and the tomb of the unknown soldier. The square is at the end of Andrassy Ut and leads into the city park. I also learned that within the square lies an artesian well that provides water to the nearby Szchenyi Baths.

Impressive square. Large - slightly empty - square, impressive columns and statues. Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. Behind the square is a park which is home, among other things, to the most unusual Vajdahunyad castle, the Budapest Zoo and the fantastic Szechenyi Baths. So, do visit the square by all means, but take time to adventure a little further while you're there.
Very bold. The place is huge and very unique. Located in front of big park and nice Andrassy boulevard starts there. Can be seen very good in nice weather from Hop On Hop Off open bus-Recommended

Lovely place. visited this location on a lovely sunny day, was gorgeous with all the statues - would of been nice to have some information on who everyone was as nothing at site that explains why they are there. There' is a little market to the back of this site across the road, with a gorgeous restaurant around a lake - just remember to have 180 florints or 1 euro if you need to visit the toilet... As can be a shock to some people as most places charge except pubs/restaurant..

Do your research to get the most out of this site. I hired a guide one day and we started at Heroes' Square. I got a very good synopsis of the history of Hungary. Otherwise, it's just a bunch of statues.

Hero's indeed. I had not been hear since the late 1990's and remembered it well and it did not disappoint. Just impressive.The lake we rowed on was drained but probably just a temporary measure. All beautiful

Magnificent Square.. This masterpiece of statues and architecture was completed in 1900Ever since that time it served for celebration of mostly military reviews and graduations of military academy students. Behind the unknown solders memorial are the seven horseman with Arpad in front the father of the Magyars. The two semi circles represent the 14 kings and statesman of Hungary. On the tall column you see angel Gabriel.

Beautiful Statues Tell of a Heroic Age. Seeing the magnificent statues in Heroes Square, you are whisked back to the times of Magyar hordes overtaking the city. The statuary are well carved and each figure has a unique personality. Feel free to move around and gaze at the view from different perspectives and truly enjoy.

OK but not high on my list.. We took the subway to Hero's square from central Budapest. The monuments were nice. The castle reproduction was cute. But I don't think I'd make the trip again. The Bath's are nearby and if you are going to the Bath's anyway it is worth a stop.
Nice square. Nice place to see. Watch for traffic around it. You don't need a long time here to see the square. ...........

Amazing memorial. This is an amazing memorial and very moving. I recommend you visit it on a tour so you can get the full history and meaning of each element. However it is not necessary to do this and you can just visit it yourself. It was quite busy with a lot of tours happening at the same time, but is still well worth the visit. Our guides warned us to keep a track of our valuables as it is a known spot for pick pockets. We didn't have any problems though.
Impressive. Another wonderful place to look at and photograph whilst in Budapest on the Pest side. Just worth a stop and a walk round and know the history.

Lots to see and do around here. Every tour will take you here and give you the history of the square. You can access it easily by public transit. Lots of good photo ops, there is a mineral bath a short walk away, as well as a park and a display of different castles nearby. Lots of ladies selling lace and sweaters. The sweaters were 2o Euros at the start but we bought one for 10.

Heroes at Night. I was in awe of Heroe's Square in the day time, but, please do take the time to visit it at night. The lighting and solitary feeling that comes with seeing these works of art with less distraction is worth the time. Less crowds, and time to just appreciate this part of this amazing city.

An overwhelming & important sight not to be missed.. Don't miss this overpowering sight. The giant statues all around tell their own story. Behind the Square you'll find a park, restaurant and the huge Szechenyi Spa.
Moving monument. Very moving monument to the conflicts in Hungary. A very busy venue with tourists jostling for photos.
Interesting. Interesting square with the statues, though I did feel we took our lives in our hands crossing the roads to get to it

One of Budapest's main squares with an impressive monument at the entrance to City Park. At the entrance to City Park and with galleries on either side (The National Gallery is closed for refurbishment), it is worth also travelling there on the metro - this is one of the historic lines. The impressive monument houses statues which represent heroes in Hungary's history by sculptor Zala György including the Seven Chieftains of the Magyars and the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. .There are two museums facing the square, one of which (The National Gallery) is undergoing refurbishment.
great place. its a huge square. have lot many monuments. a few museums are also located near it. very easy to find out. the square is huge and very historical. u should not miss it i u r in budapest.
Heroes' Square. A wonderful, hastlefree experience. The statues of 7 Chieftains on their horses are mesmerising. Do not miss this place.

Impressive Heroes Square. Huge and impressive monument to the Hungarian uprising against the Russian Soviets in 1956. Hungarians didn't get their full freedom then, but they did get a more individualised form of Soviet oversight that enabled them to become the so-called 'happiest' borough within the USSR at the time. The square is huge, and fronts the entrance to City Park, a great place to relax and enjoy Budapest's open spaces.
Lots to do in the area. An interesting place to visit and always busy so get there early. Near the baths and Vajd castle so there is plenty to see around the area.

Worth a Visit. Very interesting, but you have to know your Hungarian History to appreciate the statutes. It would help if they offered more information that you could read while you are visiting. There are restaurants close by and a visitors center. The castle is also close by, so you can walk to it.
Spend an hour here. We had about an hour to kill, so we jumped on the metro and walked around the square. Nearby is a wonderful park and river, we walked around there as well. Worth checking out.
Amazing do get off the bus and look around. Amazing place, worth getting off the hop-on-hop off bus to appreciate all the buildings and monuments.

Very interesting. Very interesting place to visit although it does not give you much information, I had to look this up online. There are cafes and restaurants nearby and also a tourist information and the zoo. Always very busy and I can understand why

Great iconic landmark definitely should not be missed when in Pest!. Don't forget your camera, plenty of pictures to take in this iconic landmark in the Pest side of Budapest. This square is surrounded by museums and parks so make sure to spend more than a day in this part of town.

A must see. The hero square - hosok tere - is a must see place when you arw in budapest, located in the end of andrassy street. You can reach it with metro number 1.
In the square you can find a beautiful scolptures, beautiful museums, and the liget park is right there.
Historic site. Large venue...full of history. To enjoy it I would recommend a guide book or guide for the full experience. There is a large park behind the structure that is very pretty

A place not to be missed.... All of the Hop on Hop off, Big Bus, bus tours come here, its on the route. Get off here and stroll around... you won't forget it... know the history, you'll get shivers...
Highly recommended.

A Half Moon You Will Never Forget. These guys are huge. I could not believe how big this monument was. We walked to this from the city center and spent time in the park on what was a glorious June day. A must see, wow.
Must be seen. The square is dedicated in memory of the heroes' who gave their lives for the freedom of the people. The architecture, as with most buildings in Budapest, is very elegant.

Prepare for your visit. OK it's a big square and pretty impressive, but we only went there because the metro stop for the big city park was nearby.We should have prepared ourselves and come armed with a guide book to explain all the statues and memorials - that's a tip for others planning a visit. Some people appeared to have an audioguide downloaded on the mobile phones - another trick we missed.

Worth seeing.. As part of our holiday here in Budapest, we came to this beautiful square with it's monuments. Well worth the visit here to see the settings and learn a bit about the history of Budapest. Accessed by public transport easily. It is also by the zoo so if you wanted to do that as well it is easy to do 2 things on the same day.
Imressive square. The history of this square is quite interesting. It is helpful to have some idea of that history when visiting. We were on a hop-on hop-off bus tour and walked around the square.
HEROE'S SQUARE. When in Budapest it is a must to see, visited a while back, The sculptures o The Seven Chieftains of Hungary are amazing.

Inspirational . Apon arriving at the heros square you can not help but to be blown away by the size and beauty of this inspirational and historical place.It is truly a work of art and shows the national pride of the Hungarian Worriors and the many skills and knowledge. they are a proud nation and proud of their heritage.It was easy to get to by public transport or by joining a hop on hop off bus tour Well worth the time to immerse yourself in some authentic Hungarian art

Grand and Depressing. The front piece of here's square is a large assortment of monumental sculptures depicting people who led Hungary through every bad military decision they've made for hundreds of years. You read a tour book going from figure to figure in plain disbelief. It's on the way to the park.

The history.... So amazing, this square is host to the homage if many unimportant figures through the history of Hungary. Definitely get a guide to this commemoration, and check out the nearby vajdahunyad castle museum. Skip the gate house tour there though

Beautiful Square close to the zoo. Interesting to see during sightseeing in Budapest. Located close to a park and the zoo, it's known for the statues featuring the Seven Chieftains of the Magyars, as well as the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

Huge square in a lovely park. Surrounding gardens around this huge square has a lovely castle to visit. The castle grounds are free and worth walking are round. Then walk a little more to the bath house which is also lovely. Also looks grand like a castle. Walk then to heros square and take photos from every angle.
A Brilliant Look into History. When in Budapest, do not miss the chance to visit this attraction. There is so much to learn about the history and previous hero's of this magnificent city.
Hungarian are the nation. nice place where every Hungarians can be proud on his nation. I can recommend go to or from there by metro line (first metro in Europe) it is perfect combination
Grand view. A lovely open space to see some history. Lovely view, saw this on a bus trip which was worth doing to see it all.
Nice place for an evening stroll. This is a great tourist area. It is within the Pest neighborhood. Nice area for an evening stroll...

Must-go in Budapest. The most important square of Budapest (Hősök tere), and the place of many historic manifestations. The monuments at Heroes' Square are worthwhile viewing (depicting the 7 leaders of the Magyars tribes, and other historic figures in Hungarian history. And the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier).At one side of the square you find the Hall of Art / Kunsthalle (Műcsarnok), an exhibition gallery of contemporary visual arts in Hungary. At the other side is the Museum of Fine Arts, unfortunately closed for refurbishment until well into 2016.You want to go to this landmark anyway, as it also offers access to the enjoyable City Park (Városliget), that includes the Vajdahunyad Castle and the Szechenyi Spa Baths).
Quite a nice open space. Many hero statues of past Hungarians Not quite true to their actual looks and steeds but awesome in its grandeur. Great castle nearby and historic tram to ride. Yellow line.
Historical. Interesting sculptures well kept, not to busy . On the weekend was closed off due to large yearly celebration with racing.
The Heroic Pride of Budapest. Magnificent Plaza. Excellent photo stop on our morning tour of Budapest. This and other beautiful points in Budapest are definitely worth seing.
Good. This was very good- they had a horse show on when I went so you couldn't get into the square as the stands were in the way but it looked really good
An important heritage. Visited this place in the night. One of the biggest squares and a must visit in Budapest. This place has all the historical memorials and statues of the glorious warriors.
Pretty and important place. A pretty and important place in the city and Hungarian history. Well worth a visit. From there you can easily walk to city Park or opera house.
Worth a view. Worth a drive by on the city tour but would not spend the time to get back for any detailed view. It is a bit of a walk from the river area.
Heroes 'Square impressived. Interesting site to see if you have some free time. we visited on a rainy day and the statues of the heroes were impressive. Can then walk to Vajdahunyad castle.

A nice place to stop on your way somewhere else.. Nice statues if you can see them. A pair of binoculars would be handy to make out the finer parts of the heroes. Best go on a sunny day which we did on our way to the park And Vajdahunyad castle which is their Agriculture Museum

Impressive - and crowded. We viewed this many times from the top of the Hop on Hop off buses. Each time after 10.00am it was heaving with tourists so we didn't actually bother to get off and explore it more closely as we could see it all clearly from our elevated position, If you go, go early!
Large Park, Museums. Visited on hop on hop off bus tour. Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. Lovely, large park. A number of museums at this location.

A Lasting Tribute of Hungarian Unity. Andrassy Ut is the main artery for many trekkers. The Heroes' Square is a handsome centerpiece of endless cultural venues. A methodical flow of mass transit will get you there and back at minimal cost. If you are going to tour Budapest I would suggest the weekly pass at around $20 US, it covers the metro, bus, and streetcar inside the city. Once you are at Heroes' Square Hungarian historical and cultural masterpieces are literally surrounding you, excellent restaurants also. Venture out a bit and chat the locals up for dining tips. Most of the dining in the city is very competitive, just meander back toward the Danube on Andrassy Ut and make your choice. You could spend a full week on the surrounding blocks of Heroes' Square and continue to discover wonderful attractions
Amazing. Amazing and a lovely walk through the park to get there. Wonderful photo opportunities. Other sights nearby.

Very Interesting. It was a very crowded Sunday when we visited Heroes' Square. In fact, we had to wait until a guard lifted up the barricade to let us and probably 75 other people in. The statues are impressive as is the entire area. What we didn't realize is that once in, we couldn't get out for about 30 minutes. Turns out they have horse races in a path around the square. Just know if there's a crowd and people waiting to get in, odds are you're at the races!

A must see for Hungarian History. An enormous, monumental place. The equestrian statues of Arap and the other 6 Magyar chieftains, so proud and arrogant, give some idea of the warlike and ferocious warriors the Magyars must have been. The statues in the colonnade, from St Stephen to Kossuth Lajos, cover many of the greatest leaders and Hungarian statesmen. A totally impressive national monument, giving an insight into the national pride of the Hungarian people.

Exciting visit!. Heroes Square is a remarkable monument! However, when we visited, there was an annual festival going on - National Gallop - when participants from all over Hungary took part in horse races around the square. It was wonderful to sit alongside locals to cheer on the riders who were all dressed in national costume! There was a race track of sand all around the outside of the square with plenty of tiered seating! A lovely afternoon in the sunshine!
Awesome Attraction. This square is very beautiful, mostly at night, when is possible to see almost all Ambassy Ut lightened up. Definitly one of the best places in Budapest!
A top attraction. A monumental place! A little bit of the history of Hungary and it's heroes. It's as also the unknown soldier tomb, and it's near many other attractions.
A must see when in Budapest.. Excellent place to visit. Actually a must if you visit Budapest. Also take the park behind it with a nice castle
Quick history lesson in great surroundings. Impressive and great to wander around. Lot's of statues and you get a history lesson on the development of the state of Hungary.

Big monument with lots of statues. Interesting to see but if you don't know the history of Hungary for the past 1000 years or so you will be scratching your head a bit. And of course, it isn't in English! But the surrounding area is very interesting, wide open, and worth seeing.
Huge open space. Impressive monument and huge open space. Can get busy, so hit and miss with what time of day to view it.

Absolutely brilliant a must visit!!!!!. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit to Heroes' Square in the heart of the city :-) The gardens are laid out wonderfully well and it's so clean. A great place for young and old especially children as there are loads of cafes & boat trips. Visiting there in high summer is wonderful for nature lovers as its bursting with colour. You could easily spend over two hours meandering around Heroes' Square but you will be very disappointed to miss out on this attraction :-)
Good stop. Stopped here on the hop off bus tour. Not prepared for the scale of it all. The statues are magnificent. Certainly one to visit and take in the park area next to it.
Impressive. Go early to avoid the tour buses. This square with its magnificent statues and buildings is a tourist cameraman's (cameraperson's ??) paradise

Origin of Hungarian civilization. Here you come across the people who came to Hungary from Central / East Asia & settled here to start a civilization. I forget the name of the warrior, but I remember it starts with letter "A".
Worth the trip to see. Impressive area although on the day we visited was extremely busy as the Budapest marathon was in full flow. However well worth a visit
Nice place . Very interesting place. Easy to arrive through the metro. The statues and the museum are worth examining.
Simply amazing. Great structures and memorials statues. Beautiful square. Within walking distance of the great zoo. Full of tourists is the only downside

Great history here. Visited this very special square and was very impressed with the details on each of the statues and the various dates that they served and the time gaps featured that they served also

Beautiful Monument. Visited this place in first week of Sept 2015. I would say this place is quite clean. Nice monument. The crowd was on and off here when we were there last 2 weeks. We just walk about 10 minutes from our homestay. Got carpark nearby the monument. The zoo is just behind this place.

Impressive monuments. Heroes square has some magnificent statues in the centre and is surrounded on all sides by some impressive buildings with amazing architecture. It is accessible via the metro line 1 (yellow line) and there is a lovely park nearby to walk through, with cafe for a rest stop. We visited the square 19-20 September when they were holding the National gallop. Apparently they wanted to hold an event that would unite the city and country folk and decided that horses and horse racing were the common denominator. So for the past four years, once a year, the square is closed off to local traffic and a sand race track is laid around the monuments. Horse teams come from all over the country to compete dressed in all their fine racing colours and uniforms.........we really did see Hussars racing round the course! Around the surrounds there is also a medieval Fayre with tradional foods and craft stalls. It really does have a carnival atmosphere and the main road leading back into town (approx 3 km) is completely encompassed on both sides by various stalls and places to eat or drink!!Szechenyi spa and baths are nearby so you can combine the two in one visit

View it by night from a distance. Not possible to reach near it due to some active construction going on.. It was not accessible at all due to some construction or fabrication work going on. looked like someone had acquired the space for some event.
Lovely walk. We got here when there was some festival on, we walked around and checked out the stalls and medieval gear.Nice place to walk with a coffee.

Good historical summary. If you have a guide book like Rick Steves that explains the historical figures, this is a worthwhile thing to see. Each statue represents a major person in the history of the country and there is a relief under the statue depicting a scene from their life. In the center is the original Magyar chieftains who settled Hungary topped by an angel. Lots of tour groups in the square and also a popular party/concert/demonstration spot for locals.
A very impressive monument. We visited Hero Square in morning before it became very crowded.The square itself is quite impressive and the statues are amazing.Well worth a visit.

Good site to visit with guide or good guidebook. Site to visit in Budapest. Large square surrounded by museums and filled with a lot of history. Have a guide to explain history or just another huge square.

tomb of the Unknown Soldier. This very large, open Square, that is a World Heritage Site in the heart of Budapest is hard to miss. It also has the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. The column at the square is a statue of archangel Gabriel, holding a crown in his right hand. At the bottom of the column are seven equestrian statues of warriors that settled their people in the area.

Great site for show and street market. Large square with statues, surrounded by some nice buildings. The whole area was a giant street festival when there Saturday. Some great food stands, and everything from antique buses, new buses, bin lorries, children's games, tourist stands and much more. Several large free shows, including one in centre of the square.
Very Impressive Square. This is a very impressive square that's definitely worth visiting. There's a nice park behind it, where you can feed the ducks and visit the baths. A fun day.

spoiled by disrespectful locals. A very impressive open space is also home to the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. I was mortified to see locals sitting atop the sculptures and climbing the structures to eat their lunch - surely this isn't allowed, however no security or police appeared to be on site to prevent it from happening. (These people also ruined all my photos of this place)

Nice site. Impressive, very. Although it's a good thing there is the park too. The square itself is worth a trip but you won't need hours there. Fortunately there is a nice park near it, where you can walk and see more things
Hop Off and Walk Around. A destination point on the red line of the Hop On-Hop Off bus, this is, of course, a national landmark and a must see. MOST HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

Hungarian History on Display. The Heroes' Square was right across from our hotel and we enjoyed learning more about the history of Budapest and Hungary after exploring the statues and sculptures in the Square. At night, it is brightly illuminated and, often, the museum next to the Square had concerts going on, so the ambience was very nice. Very easily accessible from the subway station!

Impressive space!. Heroes Square is a very large, traffic-free space in a busy city. It commemorates many of Hungary's past heroes with suitable style and grandeur. In addition to the fine statues and columns there are interseting museums to visit arround the square.
Very Impressive Square. After walking up Andrassy Avenue from the Oktogon, Heroes Square is a very impressive sight when it comes into view & the sculptures are superb.
Must visit. Love this place and surroundings area which is full of tourist attractions and easy access by tourist bus.

Nice statues, but pretty plain otherwise. My review title says it all! Nice to walk through on the way to somewhere, but otherwise not a lot to see, the parliament building square is much more impressive.

Classic city square. There are a multitude of squares in Budapest but this is the best-known and is an icon for the city and its history. A large number of impressive statues line one end of the square, with figures representing famous Hungarians both real and allegorical who are important in the long history of Hungary. The statues and your visit will be more meaningful with a little advance research.
Nice, not more. Nothing special about the square besides its historical angle. The park behind it is much more intresting

Historical ancestry. We walked to Heroes Square on a bright sunny Sunday afternoon in April. The statues spoke to us of the ancient fights for freedom the Hungarians always valued. There was a festival at the park promenade and we walked to find the statue of George Washington which our great grandfather Alexander Kalassay dedicated to the Hungarians in 1906. It was a life changing experience for my cousins and I.
Heroes' Square. Statues of founders and other historical figures are around this square. Interesting history that goes with the statues.

Mighty Impressive!. An imposing square, dominated by the impressive statue complex of the Seven Chieftains of the Magyars, and the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. The two huge colonnades are certainly impressive.On one side of the square is the Museum of Fine Arts, opposite it is the Palace of Art, both architecturally fascinating.This is obviously a place of seriously significance for Hungarians, a place of beauty for tourists.

Majestic nationalism on show. You won't know any of the persons depicted by the statues, but if you appreciate the theme of Hungarian Nationalism, you will get the right feeling from the square.If the big statues don't thrill, you have the baths and a circus nearby in the park.It's a little way out of central Budapest, but it's worth learning how to use the metro as it's the cheapest & quickest way to get around, and the "Millenium Line" (yellow line 1) is a treat to ride in itself, it being a museum piece in action. It was the first built in Budapest & is the second oldest in the world after London's. Hero's Square is on the Millenium line.

If in the area worth seeing. We have often crossed through the square. I always like to look at the seven chieftains of the Magyars which I find very impressive. Also here is the tomb of the unknown soldier..

A historical monument with nationalist significance for Hungarians.. The Heroes' Square (in Hungarian: Hősök tere) is one of the main squares of Budapest, capital of Hungary. It is located at one end of Andrássy Avenue (with which part of the assembly declared a World Heritage designated Budapest, with the Danube Embankment, the Buda Castle Quarter and Andrássy Avenue), near the city park. In the center of the square stands the Millennium Memorial, a set of special relevance in Budapest, with statues of the leaders of the seven Magyar tribes that founded Hungary in the ninth century and other personalities of Hungarian history.In row of the left column (left to right): St. Stephen I of Hungary, St. Ladislaus I of Hungary, Coloman of Hungary, Andrew II of Hungary, Charles I of Hungary and Louis I of Hungary (the Great).In the right row (from left to right) are John Hunyadi, Matthias Corvinus, Stephen Bocskai, Gabriel Bethlen, Imre Thököly, Francis Rákóczi II and Lajos Kossuth.In the central column: Archangel Gabriel (on top of the pillar). Around are the seven Hungarian chieftains: Árpád, Előd, Tas, Huba, Töhötöm, Kond and Ond.
