Stunning magnificent square. Incredible Square, original city Baths,great venue for festivals , public functions, all the history wrapped up in one square
For history buffs. Beautifully structured but not much was known regarding the characters depicted in statues here, best to read up before visiting.
Adventure Budapest. Heroes Square was amazing , a beautiful site worth the visit. It is conveniently located with easy access by all. The statue's were fabulous.

7 days well spent in Budapest.. Loved Budapest, a very beautiful city. lots of things to do and great for walking in the evening after dinner. Good food and easy public transportation. One of the best streetcar rides that we have ever been on.

Good for pictures. Not much going on there, but brilliant to see and take some pics. Impressive!
We took a night bus which stopped there.
Was great to see, but a bit empty;)

Picture Perfect. We went to Heroes' Square after a good day at the baths , this is a perfect spot for great pictures and very close to city park. Unfortunately the Museum of Fine Arts(very close by) is closed for reconstruction till 2018 !!

An imposing and impressive square!. After visiting Szechenyi Baths, we walked through the park and visited Heroes' Square. The statues are intricately detailed amongst the fine columns. It is an imposing and impressive space, and a great spot for photos.
Have a wander. Majestic place with a nice park. Worth visiting. Nice park to relax in around it. A spot of peace in the busy city
Not much to do, but great history. Great place to take pictures. Make sure to walk past the gates to the nice city park. Just behind, to the left you can find a popular bath house too.

Are you going to City Park or the Széchenyi baths, do not miss this square.. If you are heading to the City Park or the Széchenyi bath, you should definitely pass through this square and on the pasa be impressed by its design and monuments.

A large square with much Hungarian history. Hero's square (on the Pest side of the river) was the first stop on our bus tour of Budapest provided by our river cruise company. I understand that it was designed in 1898 to commemorate the 1000th anniversary of Hungary. It is quite impressive and definitely worth a visit. The millennium monument in the center of the square commemorates the Magyar tribes with Archangel Gabriel on top of the center pillar. The statues on the monument are well done and detailed. The square is surrounded by several museums that we did not have time to visit.There were many very aggressive women selling Hungarian shirts/blouses. We were told by our tour guide that although the clothing sold there is inexpensive, it is poorly made and will not hold up. Stick to legitimate vendors.

Long climb for best view. Long climb to a small hill will bring you to this square. Even though it suppose to be impressive place, we weren't impressed by the site but the view from that hill is the best view in Budapest.

Nice enough. It is easy to metro over to Hero Square. It was fairly empty with few tourists around. However, we did see one of those drink and peddle trolly things which had a large group of people drinking and loudly singing American pop music. I could have done without that.

Walk like the locals see like a tourist. Walk up the easy hill thru the park to see a different view of the city. Very worthwhile while meeting the locals strolling and tourists exploring. It commemorates the end of WW2 but could mean the celebration of the end of all wars.

Impressive and good overview of Hungarian history. A good starting point to visit the city park
Read the names of the kings and read about them in the internet

Monumentally Powerful. Skateboarders, demonstrators, families, and tourists wander around this huge square near city park. Fearsome men on horseback circle the pillar topped by the angel Gabriel. Our memorials in Washington DC cannot approach these warrior Magyars.
Nice park. We visited on a Saturday & the square was hopping. There were lots of things going on. The statues are nice & the columns make great photo ops.

A landmark worth visiting. The drive up the boulevard leading to Heroes' Square reminds one of Paris and the square,being on the classic day tour route, is well worth a short visit. Do get the guide to explain the significance of the statues and history-we found that the Tomb of the Dead Soldier is actually empty which makes the wreath laying by foreign signatories a tad strange.Another gem we learned was that the giant carpark to the West was were the Communists held their demonstrations and May Day Rally's and when freedom came the towns people decreed that for posterity it should be a car park but always FREE(dom)
Sightseeing activity. One place not to miss when visiting Budapest. Easily reached via Metro and literally in between Andrassy Avenue and the extensive gardens / castle on the other side.
Worth the trip. Beautiful area near the castle. Great picture opportunity, easy to get to by any On/Off bus company. highly recommend as a site ti visit
Nice statue . Like many of the statues in budapest they are incredible and this one is no exception very beautiful.
Holiday. Had a tour through this square, really magical place. Right next to the museum of modern arts as well.

Truly amazing. If you have the energy and time to spare - you should take a walk on Andrassy street from the city centre. The building that you see will remind you of Paris. At the end of the long walk, you will come to Heroes Square. You could also take the Metro to get here.There is a column upon which the archangel Gabriel stands. The seven chieftans of the Magyar empire are represented. This square has the tomb of the unknown soldier.On either side of the square are the Hall of Art and the Museum of Fine Arts - both are beautiful buildings.There are two colonnades. The left one has a statue of a man with a scythe and a woman sowing some seeds - and these represent labour and wealth. There is also a statue of a man riding a chariot using a snake as a whip which represents war. On the right colonnade is a woman in a chariot holding a palm leaf which represents peace. On the top of the colonnade is a statue of a man holding a little golden statue and a woman with a palm leaf which represents knowledge and glory.At night, the heroes square is lit up and it is a sight to behold. Truly amazing and beautiful.
Great Architecture. Beautiful architecture in idyllic surroundings. The architecture is truly amazing, we would highly recommend a visit due to it being one of Budapest's landmarks.

Not just a Monument!. We were on the Hop-on-hop-off bus and decided to alight at this stop. So glad we did. Behind the square is a superb park area with beautiful listed buildings and an open air skating rink! It was fascinating to watch the skaters of all abilities including (what appeared to be) ex world class figure skaters passing on their skills to youngsters!
Heroes through the ages. A spacious and impressive memorial to the past leaders of Hungary, located on hop-on, hop-off routes with the associated park and eateries for a break.
Such a monument!. The day before we left Budapest when we though we have seen everything in the city... We found this fascinating monument with such a beauty and great meaning. Wow!!!

Another beautiful spot.. Really pretty and very impressive. Would recommend visiting with a tour guide or a good guide book though. All the informations obviously in Hungarian and is really interesting however it not be as good if you didn't get to hear the interesting facts about all the different parts.

Heroes Square.. Heroes Square is a very broad square near the entrance to the city park. The square is surrounded by wide streets with much traffic. Visit the square to see the tall column and beautiful columns and after stroll in the park and take a coffee ad pasty brea

Historical land mark that mus be seen. This is the end of the line for a very important street. behind it is one of the big mixed public baths. in front of it is the most important street in the city ( the channelize of Budapest as they put it). very busy with cars. but again very nice to know the history behind it. if you read my other reviews, you know by now, this is one of the attractions on the route of the hop-on hop-off bus. Behind it is a beautiful park as well near the baths.
Impressive !. Impressive collection of monuments and statues it is a busy road to cross to get to but is worth a look around.
historical. the square is lovely and big and well laid out. loads of people about no matter time of day or night.lovely park close by to wander around also.

Impressive Historic Landmark of Budapest. A visit to Budapest should include at the very least three places: St. Stephen's Basilica, the Matthias Church, and Heroe's Square. This landmark contains impressive statues of important historic figures in Hungary's history including the chiefs of the Magyars and several of the country's kings including St. Stephen. The high central column is topped by a statue of the Archangel Gabriel. Heroe's Square is worth a visit either during the daytime or at night when it is floodlit.
Nice to see as part of overall city tour. A lot is said about Heroes' Square and it Igives a good picture of Hungary' s history. Nothing to break your neck to get too, however.

Beautiful statues and park behind it. Well worth a visit but can get busy on the roads nearby as plenty of tourist buses visit this attraction.The cafe looks very nice here but the service is incredibly slow so don't go if you are in a hurry

Nice large open square for memorial and heroes square . Nice large open square to people watch, sit and enjoy the vast square. Middle of square is memorial and heroes in Budapest. Statues circled the memorial with 2 side museums. Corner the memorial. Part of Budapest city park. Inside is the szecheyni thermal bathhouse. Metro stop is "hosok ter" on yellow line.

Hosok ter - grand statue formations.. Hosök ter or Heroes square in English is a large open square at the entrance to the park with Varosliget. The are several heroic statue formations and columnal gates in the square. It is surrounded by a ring road and has some museums on the outside. It is easy to get around on the square but beware the traffic on the surrounding roads. The tour buses for Varosliget also park there, but the square is so big that the tourists are dwarfed.

Beautiful . Great area inside of a fantastic park. It's a beautiful piece of history and very easy to get to. I wish I would have gone at night but still very happy I saw this and was able to explore the park.

Large impressive monument. Large impressive monument at the northern end of Andrassy. Served by Hosok Tere metro station. Consists of a central column and a colonnade behind with historic Hungarian heroes. Constructed in the late 19th Century to commemorate the thousandth anniversary of the Hungarian state. Photogenic at all times of day and also at night. Well worth a visit.

Go just before sunset. This is a nice place for a day out. I would recommend going just slight before sunset so you can experience it in the day at sunset and a little later. NIce place to walk about.
Blown away by the size. Good little place to visit just to see the size of the monuments. Went to look around after visiting the baths.
Week in Budapest. Big square! Again lots of people so go early if you want pics with few people. FREE and worth walking through if you are up in the City Park area one day.
Very nice!. A grand square at the top of Budapest's biggest boulevard (think Champes Ellyses). It is also adjacent to City Park which is a beautiful escape from the city and a chance to relax.

A bit of culture. We went here last year for our anniversary and wanted to come to Heroes square as read a lot about it. If history and culture isn't your thing then I don't recommend it. Very beautiful statues and architecture
love this. Nice area to visit .. We done the big red bus hop on hop off tour .. weather was ok bit chilly but didnt stop us visiting these places .....,

Good starting point. An easy and good starting point. A large open square with amazing statues depicting the founding of a nation. The Big Bus hop on hop off tours start from here. There is a large park to the right an easy 10 min walk there is a transport museum. Unfortunately it was closed for refurbishment but from the outside it looked impressive. Check it is open before you go.
Impressive. A very impressive sight to behold. Detailed statues and a nice area to look at in awe. An amazing array of statues.

TRUE HEROES!. This square was laid out in 1896 to commemorate the thousandth Anniversary of Hungary. Archangel Gabriel is on top of the center pillar. It had members of the Hapsburg dynasty in the colonnade. They were removed and replaced with Hungarian freedom fighters after world war II. You really need to visit it at night is well. We never got a chance to.

Picturesque. Worth a visit if your heading this way. Beautiful and clean. Trafalgar square eat your heart out! Getting to it is tricky as there is only 2 zebra crossings to it so be careful! Art museums, vajdahunyad castle and the szechenyi baths are close by too.
Nice district....... Worth seeing of you are in Budapest, good to take pictures, beside the statues there isn't much else unless you count the very open space.
Unique Monument. Very impressive monument to national heroes. Superb sculptures and monuments to historical National heroes.

Grandeur times about ten!. Take the metro - a delightful experience in itself and cheap as chips - all the way to Heroes' Sq and simply gape and gawp at the ostentatious grandeur of it. Wonderful fun!

Historical place.. Go over there only if you have extra time. Is nice and interesting but there's nothing else around. Reach it with the old underground metro. This line is the oldest of the city. Tiny and pretty.

Lovely historical square.. Gorgeous square! Definitely recommend a walking tour from the Szchenyi baths, through the Heroes Square, down to the Basilica area. There are a few museums in the square as well.

Beautiful Monument with lots of Attractions nearby.. The Square is beautiful however be aware that the Museum of Fine Arts is closed until 2018. Next to the Ssuare are the Hot Sping Baths and the Zoo is a short walk from the Square as well.

Must see site on your tour of Budapest. Square in the middle of the city, with various monuments around, lovely park at the back of the square. Be careful crossing to the square its across a very busy road!

Beautiful district.. On the other end of Andrassy Ave. Big open square with monuments. Great for photo. It has 2 museums on each side. Walk past the square across the bridge is the public bath house to the left and Sleeping Beauty castle on the right.

The History of Famous and Revered Hungarians on Display. This sits right at the end of Andrassy Avenue, a Workd Heritage site, so it's not hard to find. It was built in 1896 on the anniversary of the Hungarians reaching the area. It holds the tomb of the unknown soldier and statues of kings, governors, and famous people of Hungary. It's a nice area with museums, the zoo, and city park nearby.

Quite Spectacular. The size of the monument is not justified in pictures: it is absolutely huge! The square it is in is also very very large. From the city centre, I would recommend the metro from Deac Ferenc to Hosok Tere rather than walking up Andrassy - after walking the distance twice in one evening it does take a long time and gets quite exhausting. Visiting in the middle of the day is probably the best for well-lit photos, but if your camera is good in the dark I would certainly recommend visiting at night. When one visits later, the crowds are all but gone and the statue is lit up until about 01:00 just like St Istvan's Cathedral down the other end of Andrassy. In summer months, the square gets swelteringly hot too, so visiting early or late is preferable for this reason as well as to miss the crowds. One could really, however, do with more information around the square about the monument. As it is, one needs to go online and do all the research beforehand or afterwards - a placque or two in the square with some basic facts would certainly not go amiss.
WORTH THE WALK. Fantastic walk, the area is very beautiful near the castle and the ice ring. The park is worth a walk, and there is a beautiful restaurant on the left as you enter.

Statues galore. Probably built during the communist era, a large square with lots of statues of Hungarian kings and heroes, I bet they replaced the communist era statues, which by the way have their own museum outside of the city

History focal point. Great deal of history in this monument, the statues representing the tribes of historical Hungary. You can follow the history of the founding of the country and the heroes of the wars they endured.

Good to check out as part of a city tour.. The Square is an important landmark but not worth a specific visit. Better to combine it with a visit to the boating lake / ice skating rink, nearby castle, zoo or Thermal Baths.

Cool - must-see.. It's so different from how I had imagined it, but definitely deserves a look - you can get there easily from the Museum of Terror and from Szechenyi's Baths (and they both deserve more than just one look).

Iconic Square. This Heroes Square situated opposite the city park,more than 1200 years old; is the largest & most impressive heritage sight square in Budapest.It is an iconic & most visited sights of the city with two other important buildings next to it-The museum of Fine Arts to the right & the Hall of Arts to the left & also the underground Millenium station.The monument consists of two semi-circles on top of which the symbols of war & peace,work & welfare,knowledge & glory can be seen.Archangel stands on top of the center of the pillar holding the crown & the double cross of Christianity.The seven chiefs who lead the Magyar tribes to Hungary are shown on the stand below.Statues of kings & other historical notables stand on top of the colonnades on either side of the center pillar.There also stands a tomb of the` Unknown soldier`in the square.The square is worth visiting in the night also.

Grandious Heroes Square in Budapest. Another landmark of Budapest is the Heroes Square. It is quite a large square with various monuments of important persons involved in the history and development of Budapest and Hungary. It affords a good photo opportunities for the tourist. The Gallery of Arts is adjacent to the square (to the right if facing the pillar with Gabriel on top), and the National Museum of History is also close by. A good attraction to visit, but can be missed if time is short.

Take a picture with the huge Budapest sign. Great part of the city. Next to the zoo and the Central Park where you can have a romantic boat trip, there is this huge square. Museum of fine arts and a gallery of (contemporary) exhibitions give a frame to the square and leads your view onto the Andrássy Avenue where you can find great fashion brands and some outstanding restaurants such as Perle Noir.
Impressive. It's a must see landmark but shadeless on a hot day and lacking information on the many interesting statues.
Not the first attraction on my to see- list.. Huge square, huge statues. We went there after the Sunset to get more impressive photos of the lightened statues. Takes about 5 -15 minutes to visit.

trip to Budapest. I was on a trip to Vienna in Dec, 2014. I went for a day trip to Budapest. It was great. Heroes' square and nearby ice skating were all looking great. I wish I had stayed for few days to enjoy the city more rather than a day trip.

good photo opportunity, not much else though. A very grand momument, we just happened to see it on the way past. Good place to take some pictures but little information or any facilities there. Also the roundabout it's on is very busy
Massive and colossaly beautiful. A beautiful place indeed. Magnanimous and huge, perfect for some photos. It feels historic and grand.

Great place. This is the second time I have visited the monument and I have to say I love this place. When viewing from the front it is a very impressive monument honouring historically important Hungarian figures. Surrounded by museums is a very nice setting. A must see if you are in Budapest.
Beautidful place to see. Beautiful place to visit and when we were there, it was nice and quiet too. On the main route, so very easy to get to.

Definitely worth a visit. A trip to Budapest should include a visit to heroes' square, either as part of a walking tour or just "passing through". Keep the sun in mind if it's summer as this is a wide open space with minimal shade!

Spectacular Square and Monument. A tour guide will tell you all about its history, but even without one go visit it is a spectacular open space with marvellous statues, well worth the walk from the city centre.

What are all the disrespectful dolts doing climbing up on the monuments?. What should be a wonderful review is marred by all of the idiots that climb the monuments in Heroes' Square. If you are one of them, you should be ashamed of yourself. And if you think it is OK, you should re-evaluate your position.Is this what the people of Budapest, let along Hungary, had in mind when they built this incredible square? When I first visited it about 6 years ago it was a solemn place that recognized and respected Hungary's heritage. But when I visited it 3 weeks ago every selfie-craving idiot dolt was using it as a "Jungle Jim". I would have liked to have gotten at least a couple pictures of its incredible statues ... but unless the statues were 36 meters above the square, that was not going to happen.I beg the people of Hungary to immediately put up signs requiring that visitors stay off the monuments. And if they do not the violators should be fined and/or put into jail. What has common sense and respect come to? I don't know for sure but I'm willing to bet that anyone that climbed up on the Lincoln statue at the Lincoln Memorial would be immediately removed. And at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier I would bet that the guard would unceremoniously "take them out".Heroes' Square is a solid 5 in my book. But they need to address a societal issue as it relates to all of the disrespectful idiots that are ruining it.

Very nice; must visit attraction. This attraction has a character of its own. Great architecture, provides a good photo op and is well connected with public transport. Information centre is right behind heroes square

One of the most beautiful sight I can remember! Go by night!. I went there with some friends at night, after having spent the afternoon in the baths just next to it. We walked across the park to this place and when we arrived we were mesmerized by the sight.I still vividly remember standing in the middle of the square facing the statues with a medieval castle on the left and a cathedral on the right. The wole thing perfectly lit! I don't know if it's the baths that put me in such a state, but I do remember never having been that impressed before!
Beautiful open area with lovely statuary. Beautiful open area with amazing statues. Within walking distance to Szechenyi Baths and other sights. A must see in Budapest!

Nice in winter and summer. My favourite place in Budapest, you can fell as in USA :-), In the winter is possible to skate on the iced lake next to Heroes´ Square with nice winter atmosfere and hot wine

Cross to the Square SAFELY!. This is pretty awesome for a city square, and it helps to have some guide or guidebook (as we did) to give you some historic tidbits. Just don't get killed getting there! We could not figure out the safest way in and ended up crossing three lanes of a roundabout quite brusquely! We visited at the END of our time in Budapest, so we also had gotten familiar with several of the statued leaders which made it more interesting.

Magnicifent at night. The square changes dramatically at night time, when everything is illuminated. There's an enchanting mood at night when everything is illuminated, but it's not an attraction itself, but a nice break passing from one part of the city to another - especially at night time.
Great monument. Great monument but the museum of fine art, which was the purpose of our visit is closed for three years for renovation! The beer bikes for stag dos are worth a look, hilarious!,

Visit day or night. You need the help of a proper tour guide to understand the history of Budapest, Hungary and the reason why this is called Hero's Square. Located near a park area that has thermal baths and a zoo. Lovely architecture in the area. We walked by during the day and also visited at night.

An iconic square. The main piazza in Budapest known for its statue featuring the Seven Chieftains of the Magyars and other important national Heroes. Festivals in summer and ice skating in winter are going on there.

Heroes' Square Festival. Went to see Heroes' Square and ended up spending a lot of time there! A small festival was going on in the park beside Heroes' Square, so we ended up spending a lot of time around the area. It was a nice day and had amazing cuisine choices. Also, there was a race going on at the time. So fun to see everyone enjoying the area.

Another piece of hungarian history . Heroes square is large scale monument to the past glory of these proud people it's like a who's who of the past greatness of the rulers of Hungary. the statues are very impressive and well looked after like most of the city's monuments make sure you have time to see this impressive structure and like most of Budapests architecture it's free to see

A must visit place in Budapest. The Millennium Memorial is the center piece of the Heroes Square was completed at 1900 AC. To commemorate the thousandth anniversary of the Hungarian conquest of the Carpathian Basin and the foundation of the Hungarian state in 1896 AC.

Just Meh. We stopped here on our tour, and I'm glad we didn't make a special trip to see it. It's just a big square with some monuments, of which you'll see hundreds during your Budapest visit. You can safely skip it unless you're visiting the baths, park, or another landmark in the area.
Beautiful Budapest. This is the heart of a wonderful city offering wonderful views of the park and square with access to good nearby museums!

A monument to the country's heroes!. Received a guided tour of this historic attraction. Interesting information on all the past country's war heroes and politicians. Located on the "pest" side and on periphery of the city adjacent to some foreign embassies; a lake that doubles as an ice skating rink in winter and also an adjacent museum and more. Worth the trip to see it!

An Outline of Magyar History. Located at the end of Andrassy Avenue, Heroes' Square is part of a UNESCO World Heritage site since 2002. It was built in 1895 to commemorate the 1000th anniversary of the arrival of the seven Magyar chieftains to the Carpathian Basin. It was completed in 1929. To get there you can take the Millennium Underground (M1) to Nosok tere (Heroes' Square).In the middle of the square sits a 36 meter Corinthian column with a statue of the Archangel Gabriel resting on top. Gabriel is a symbol of the Roman Catholic church as he holds the holy crown and cross of Christianity. Below on a pedestal surrounding the column are the seven Magyar chieftains. Arpad (9th-10th) century is prominent being center forward. His descendants formed the royal Hungarian dynasty. Each side of the column is flanked by a colonnade. On top of the colonnade s are four statues depicting (Peace) female in a chariot holding a palm frond, (Glory & Knowledge) man holding a golden statue and woman with a palm frond, (Labor & Wealth) man with a scythe & woman sowing seed and (War) man riding a chariot with a snake whip. Between the columns of the colonnade are 14 statues of the most prominent figures in Hungarian history. King Stephen I, the first king of Hungary is among the 14 represented. There is a relief under each of the 14 figures which depicts an important event in each of their lives. King Stephen shows him recieving the crown from the Pope's emissary. The memorial to the Unknown Soldier can also be found here. Surrounding the square is the City Park, The Museum of Fine Arts and the Art Gallery. Nearby is the city Zoo.

Heroes Square & Andrassy Avenue - a must for A visit to Budapest.. We walked from our hotel to the Heroes' Square and then onto the gardens behind it on our own while exploring Budapest. Very impressive. Enjoy a walk from Heroes Square along Andrassy Avenue and read the history of the Velvet revolution which is very inspiring.

Place to see! . If in Budapest, this square is a must see! It shows some great work going into it and some history to not be forgotten.Behind heroes square is the most beautiful park you will ever visit, it's a big park so don't get lost!

Vast. This vast monument is a must visit while in Budapest. The square itself interesting to walk around and there are also a number of other attractions in the surround area so worth the trip slightly out of town.
Impressive. Very nice square and interesting to see...a tour guide will tell you about the history of Hungary way better then audioguide

Lovely walk. 30 minutes away from the Central Market you will find yourself surrounded by nature. The tourist office was very helpful. There's free wifi inside, in case you are lost and don't really know what to do. Strolling along the lakeside is a wonderful escape from the city's busting environment. Restaurants around are quite pricy, even though man are labelled as cheap-eats.
A must see. Heroes Square as name suggests is a square dedicated to the Heroes of the Hungarian history. It is vast and apt for photo opportunity.
History. Nice if you have a guide to tell you about Hungarys early history . Pitty about the people trying to sel you trinkets .

MUST see if you are in Budapest!. Your guidebooks will tell you the details about this Square and the surrounding buildings. What is seldom mentioned (in the guidebooks) is the Skating Ring very close to it that is a Paradise for kids and young adults in the Winter.

Very impressive. This fabulous square is located at the Varosliget end of the Andrassy Ut. Hősök tere is a monument built to honor all the heroes of Hungary. Angel Gabriel rises above all the figures holding the Hungarian cross and crown. Seven tribal chieftains of Magyars surround the central pillar. Next come the statues of all the important rulers of Hungary from the first Hungarian king, Saint Stephen, to the nineteenth century revolutionary leader, Lajos Kossuth, who rose against the Hapsburgs. Ironically, statues of Emperor Franz Joseph and his family used to be here too but they were never replaced after they were damaged in WWII. There is also a tomb of the unknown soldier and a centopath in the square dedicated to all the people who gave life for Hungary.

A must see!. We visited here during the day and it was still an impressive view! It is easy to find and is even better in person compared to the pictures we saw beforehand.You can't really spend a long time here (unless you visit the gallery next to it loke we did) but it's a great place to see on your way to somewhere else and snap a view pictures and have a wander round.

Lovely place . A must visit. The Square has the unknown soldier's tomb and just very beautiful sculptures. However, it is not old. It was recently built to improve the cosmetics of the city. Props to Budapest.I must admit that my visit was in 2013 but I imagine it is pretty similar now. I have not gotten around to evaluating it until now that I've discovered some photos. Hope you enjoy! By the way, it is gorgeous at night.

Wide perspective. The square is at the end of Andrassy Ave. In the middle of the square it is located the Millennium Monument which celebrate the 1000-year-old history of the Magyars. Crossing the street is the Városliget Café & Restaurant and nearby is the Vajdahunyad castle (Dracula's castle as some locals calls the construction). Just because of those 2 places, the trip to square as starting point, it is worth it.
Dont miss Heros square. The square is very well laid out and impressive. 2 museums are right there in walking distance and the spa is not that far. We went there by Hop on Hop off

Beautiful at Night. Located at the entrance to the city park, this large monument has Hungary's Heroes through the years. Close to Andrassy Utca, where the old subway line is. It will take you all the way down to the water. The neighborhood, Andrassy, is filled with many restaurants too.

heroes square, very nice tourist spot. heroes square offers wide open space to enjoy the view. the square is at the entrance to the large city park with many different things to do, paddle boats, zoo and much more. the square has a impressive selection of old statues and monuments to Hungarys past. definatley worth a visit

Amazing statues. Again took a tour with the hop on hop off buses 14.000HUFS for 2 of us unlimited travel for 48hrs and 2 boat trips Amazing value so if you miss something you can always go back Hero's square is a must see
Glad we went. Heroes square was a pleasant trip with our guide Elizabeth. It was very hot and hard work as ste had to translate in two languages but nevertheless we were looked after very well.
Nice view. Great place for photos! Also a bunch of local histories about the heroes.The view in the night is awesome, it's also near the City Park and the Baths.

Beautiful Architecture and Monument. It is an amazing monument. A vast square with historical statues and a centre column. It is a popular attraction with tourists. I found early morning or late afternoon is a good time to visit as the temperature is kinder and the place is less crowded. The two semi circular monuments behind the column are not only beautiful but have standing male periodical figures.
Imposing on a hot day. We visited on the way to the nearby castle. The day we went was so hot and bright, though, it was hard to see or appreciate much.

Don't miss!. Beautiful and very impressive monument on a beautiful square. Great view all around. We combined with beers in the park behind, right on the water, and was great way to chill from the hot weather.
Good. There is so many good statues and you can climb to take a picture too.The only bad thing:air conditioners (in the museum) were broken.It was really hot there.
Impressive!. Massive square with many statues of most important figures of Hungary. One of the tourist places so you should be there too!

Amazing. Really a place to see ! I took the Hop on hop off bus in Budapest and it was a great choice. Got to see the whole city in one day and one of the most memorable places was Heroes Square. So powerful and magnificent statues and history
Fantastic square. You can not miss it. This is a very important, I'd say one of the most important square in Hungary! VISIT it!!
Not bad but not good. We saw it quickly after a visit to the Zoo and I did not think it was particularly amazing or impressive, a lot of better things to see in Budapest.

Beautiful place. Cost nothing and it is a must in the walking avenue. You will pass by a group of people who give you free water. A wonderful experience that i will never forget. Bring umbrella coz during summer it burns.

Amazing Square. This is an expansive square which highlights many heroes represented by huge, detailed statues. Besides the square, there are other sights within an easy walk. There is the zoo and the baths nearby. Continue your stroll down Andrassy to check out the lovely neighborhood.

Beautiful Square in beautiful area. Not at all surprised that so many people visit this square - it reminded me of Trafalgar Square in London and is about as impressive. The tomb of the Unknown Warrior and the Millennium Monument make a stunning impact on the view, and I was lucky enough to stay at a hotel opposite (Mirage Fashion Hotel) so I walked through the square a few times. Worth the walk across the square to the bridge over the lake beyond - and the lovely Vajdahunyad Castle set in City Park. If you visit nothing else, make sure you don't miss this!
Very nice area must visit. Came out from the hot bath on a very hot day.Very nice and eazy to get there bt metro and all other transport services

Great Square. Loved this square with all its monuments. The square itself is very large, be aware though that there are no shady spots or places to sit. So just walk around and admire. Boat rides nearby as well as other attractions.

Worth a visit. Part of a coach tour around Europe visited hear really enjoyed Heroes Square lovely statues get up close to really admire them. Great photos can be taken but do take care crossing the roads to the square the traffic can be crazy.

Amazing Collection of Historic Statues. This giant square is filled with statues of the heroes of Budapest and Hungary. The statues are incredibly intricate and detailed, and the scale of the monument and square is immense. Most impressive lit up at night, you can access Heroes Square from downtown Budapest on the yellow subway line. Take the subway to the square and then walk back on Andrassy past all kinds of attractions, such as the Terror House, cafes, businesses, the Octagon, and ice cream stands all along the avenue.
Beautiful. Loved the square and the castle and the boating beside it. Good spot and one can spend a whole day there with the various things around like the baths, zoo museums etc.
Stunning Budapest. We stopped off here on the Hop On Hop Off bus. It's central to nice gardens, thermal pools. I's also worth visiting in its own right. More impressive statues and monuments.

Centeral Location. The square is beautifully situated at the end of the famous Andrassy Avenue. in the center is the Millennium Monument surrounded by the statues tribute to the great leaders of Hungary. It is easily reached by the metro, hop on hop off or as a result of a long stroll in Andrassy. From here you can easily reach City Park, stations, Budapest zoo & Széchenyi Baths, Vajdahunyad Castle and the Operah House.

Historic venue. At the end of a Boulevard from the city lies this semi-circular monument dedicated to the heroes of Hungary encompassing Kings and Saints. Was part of our bus tour of the city where we were allowed a picture stop and had a narration of the past 1000 years of Hungary. The monuments were impressive and another visit at night under lights confirms why this is one of the visitor's favourite. We were lucky the weather by day was good but there is definitely no shelter with regards to the elements.

NICE AREA WITH BEAUTIFUL TOWER. We were in Budapest in last Easter holidays and on 6th April 2015 we started our tour in the afternoon with the Szechenyl Thermal Bath. It was quite away from our Hotel in Budapest. We took Yellow line metro from Deak Ferrenc ter (M1) for going to Szechenyi Thermal bath and got down at Szechenyi Ter which was about 9th stop .The Hero’s square area is about 10 mins walk from the bath area.It is a large square constructed in 1896. The millennium monument is at the middle of the square and was built in 1896 to remember 1000 year history of Magyars.We spent 1 hour here and took lots of photos.

Only walked by. This can't be a full review, because we only walked in area, but it is a clean and unique site even from a distance. There are many connection points there and a info center very close. You can ask questions and exchange money. I think even a toilet near it too. It is close to the river and not far from a Castle or zoo. If I read more on the history, it may have been more fascinating. The statues were in good shape. Hot during the summer. No shade!

A Massive Memorial in Budapest. Hero's Square in Budapest is a landmark that attracts tourists. A vast area amidst the city and located around bustling traffic, this Square has remarkable bronze statues of seven historic heroe's of Hungary. The Monument,is built in a semi circular design. It is worth stopping over this monument and enjoy the architecture.

Very large and impressive square. I ended one of my days of walking the city here. It is quite a ways back from the Danube and I thought I might have missed it but was glad I didn't. It is a very large and open square with steps for sitting, people watching and making conversation. The statues perched high above are impressive but I'm sure I would have gotten more out of it had I been on a guided tour to have each significance explained to me.

Impressive monument to Hungarian History. We visited the square as part of a city tour. Our excellent tour guide provided us with a great narration of the the history of the monuments in the square.  A definite must see when visiting Budapest.

Extremely impressive. This is a very impressive momument and well worth the detour from the city centre, its great in scale and detil and also has some very nice surroundings in the park behind containing a castle, zoo and baths.

memories. Not much to say about this as you really have to be there to see it the architecture and statues are amazing but you need a person who can read what is written so you would know all of who is there and what it stand for

One of the most beautiful squares in Budapest. If you only have time to really explore one square in Budapest, Heroes Square should be it. From Arpad to later kings the statues are beautiful. The architecture of the square is also terrific.

expansive square with impressive monuments. we visited the square twice during our stay in budapest, once on the hop on hop off bus tour, the other on foot later in the visit, and i recommend the later if you get the chance as it is more impressive when on foot as the sheer scale can be appreciated.

Take a guide book and it's really interesting. The monuments are impressive, but the history is very interesting, so take a guide book to give you the background. Otherwise it's just some impressive looking statues.
cool monuments. really pretty area, i'd recommend visiting as part of a tour (i saw it as part of a bike tour, so i had the chance to learn about the history and meaning behind all of the monuments)

Very impressive, especially when you're prepared. Beware of the fans.. To be prepared is always good, it's especially so for this attraction. Anyway, it's one of the places not to be missed in Budapest.
As far as we understood, it's also a meeting place of football fans, some of them can be very aggressive, so take care.

Big Square Full of Statues. Heroes Square is one of the largest squares in the city and has statues of famous and notable Hungarians. It's near the entrance of Varosliget Park and close to the baths. It is worth a stroll to snap some shots and get a feel for the history. There are bathrooms in the nearby visitors center.
Not a "must see.". The monument and statuary are beautiful, but there is little else to see or do in the immediate area. We also encountered aggressive street vendors in the square.

Very impressive monuments. Heroes' Square is a very impressive area of Budapest, showing statues of many different famous people in Hungarian history. A lot of non-Hungarians would not know who most of the people are, but it is still impressive to look at, if you happen to be near the area anyway. The only down sides are that there is no shelter, so on a hot day, or a cold and rainy one, it would be uncomfortable to stand around viewing the statues. The other down side is that it is in a very remote part of Budapest, far from almost everything else, so if you are staying in the main part, it would be either a long trek, or you would have to try to figure out the public bus or tram service (or the tour bus!) But if you are going near the Zoo and the public gardens anyway (as I was, after getting off the tour bus), and are near anyway, then Heroes' Square is definitely worth a look!
Don't go. This is just a square and of course has a nice garden behind it, but if you are in Budapest just a few days it's far away from Vaci Utca.
Great!. Great spot to stop in while on a walk. An important and beautiful monument. A must see while in Budapest!

Marching ground. The art museum at the square is closed until summer 2018 and there really isn't much else about the square which has been cut into pieces by heavy traffic from all sides.The boulevard from the center is however worth seeing. It ends at the square.We used bus 105 from Deák Ferenc and the fascinating old Metro 1 back.

Very Interesting ....... ....if you have someone to explain it (or a book will do). We did this as part of an organised tour and it made the experience 10 times better as we were told the history behind it. The square covers the last 1000 years of Hungarian history and each statue represents an important person from St Steven in 1000AD through to the end of the 19th century. Without the knowledge of what they represent I can see why people thought...just a few more statues. The history of the Hungarian people is fascinating and worth understanding.
Historic and Glorious. It is a hot spot for tourists, you can feel the Greatness of this Square while walking around or driving by. A must see while in Budapest.

Well worth a visit. Although away from the town centre it is well worth visiting the Square as there are some other nice places t o visit in the area. The Statue towers above the square and represents the History of Hungary. Well worth a visit.
Heroes, just for one day..... Bit of a sun-blasted piazza with pretentious grand monuments, meh! You gotta think about Heroes, whose heroes, when, and for how long....

Heroes on a grand scale. This square is situated at the end of the main thoroughfare in Budapest and is easy to get to.It is dedicated to the kings and warriors that fought for and saved the Magyars from the Turks and recreated Hungary.The magnificent statuary are very impressive.The colonnades are very impressive as well.The square is flanked by two ornate art galleries.Well with a visit.

A weekend in Budapest . On limited time we had to try and see a much as possible, having walked from our hotel we hit the square first, very impressive bordered by museums and fronted by a timeline of Hungarian hero statues is very cool. One end leads to a large boulevard that will take you to the terror museum and the other leads to the large baths and castle so lots to see in a short period of time.
So so.. A lot of history represented, but likely is of more interest to Hungarians. The square itself was monumental.

total disappointment. I took my daughter here looking for the apparently closed science museum. The weather was over 100 degrees. This "park" has no grass and barely any shade. The children's play park had no shade and was dangerous - I cut my leg on a piece of wire sticking out in one of the play areas. It might be a tolerable place to pass a bit of time when there is not a heat wave going but without the science museum what would you waste any of your time in this beautiful city by spending it here? My advice is not to bother!

Worth a look, but pretty isolates. Traveled out to Heroes' Square to see the impressive memorial. Without being part of a formal tour group had to figure out on our own what it meant and who it was for. Nearby tourist center was closed and on a sweltering hot day the lack of shade forced us to stay for just a few minutes. Close to the castle so take a quick walk over to check that out too.

More than just a square. There's lots to do here - a massive park, a cool old castle with a port cullis (seriously), and boat rentals on the mini lake. At the square, check out the sculptures of the Hungarian Greats - all in that early 20th century nationalistic style. Did the horses really have horns for armor? Probably not, but the statues are imposing and awesome.

7 Magyar Heroes . Yes, there are seven statues of 7 Magyar Heroes in addition to the tomb of the unknown soldier. Good place to explore the surrounding in the evening. In the vicinity you also have the circus, zoo & the Szechenyl Thermal bath. So one can actually spent a whole day here.

Grand Square. It is an imposing square with statues of warriors around it. It was very hot when we visited and there is no shade whatsoever in the square. The surrounding buildings are magnificent and make the square less austere-looking. The walk down from the square across the bridge to the castle is very charming. You can get glimpses of rah castle behind the shady trees.

Nice plaza, but there's more. When you visit the Square, be sure to read up on it first, or go with a local guide! The statues make much more sense, as it depicts a historical timeline. Then, walk on into the park behind it. A wonderful stroll, castle, baths, lake, and several places for a relaxed lunch.

Huge square with impressive statue, but scorching on a hot day. At the far end of a wide, tree lined boulevard leading away from the Danube, reminding of Hungary's grand but faded past, Heroes Square is impressively large but without shade, so scorching on a hot Budapest Summers day. Immediately behind is the City Park with the Vajdahunyad Castle, built like a Disney creation, using most of the different styles of castle architecture over the ages - interesting but bizarre. The park itself provides a leafy break from the hot streets of Pest but, like many parts of Budapest, is in need of some tender, loving care.

Not to be missed. We "hopped off" our bus tour here, it certainly has the "wow" factor. We spent a couple of hours wandering around the area, marvelling at the sights and soaking up the atmosphere. Not to be missed.

Huge park close to the center. Very easy to get to either on foot or by metro/trolley bus from the city center. Great park, with a river/lake, castle, restaurants, spa baths, exhibition hall and a huge zoo.

Stunning Location. Visited here during our recent City Break in Budapest. This was one of the drop off points on the Hop on Hop off bus. The square itself has several statues depicting the history of Hungary of particular interest are the monuments to the leaders of the 7 Tribes. A great place to spend and hour just wandering round. There are several cafés nearby to take refreshments.

We cycled here and enjoyed it even more. Heroes square is a grand open space with some monumental bronze sculptures of Hungarian historical figures . You can walk or get here by tram but why not cycle here? Budapest is very cycle friendly with designated bicycle lanes and the motorists , in my experience ,were very considerate .Bicycle hire is very reasonable . Heroes square adjoins a park which has a castle .
History . This a símbolo of history and a beautiful park next to it. Also you have the castle vajdahuynd Neary by. You can circle arround the park qith several bar .

Grand Square. Beautiful and spacious square with grand monuments telling the complicated history of Hungary. Easily reached by the oldest in Europe metro line 1. Great place to visit and walk around. I would do it in connection with a trip to city park and near by bath house.

Breathtaking statues depicting Historical events. Coming upon the square you notice the monumental statues telling the history of Budapest. They are a very striking depiction with strong features. Definitely worth the stroll among those who stand watch over this square.
fantastic view. It is a nice area and a good little walk around the square. The historical part of is is also interesting. It is really sad that people never learn to be nice to each other though..

Striking square. The sheer size of this square really took my breath away, especially seeing as it was almost empty and I'm used to Trafalgar Square! We walked through here on the way to Szechenyi baths and I made a point of looking for the tomb of the unknown soldier. We ended up spending a long time looking at all the beautiful figures, definitely the most beautiful square I have ever visited!
Grand Square. Imposing and impressive, heroes square is truly grand in its scale. The nearby bath or a good reason to stop here for a few minutes and consider this country's history
In awe of Hungary's history.... We visited this square after dark and there were very few tourists so we could truly enjoy the sights and take in the incredibly fascinating history of Hungary.

Great place to visit. A lovely place for a stroll around and to soak up history at the same time. Easy to get to on the metro with its own station at Hosok tere. Some fantastic architecture and statuary - the level of detail in the people and horses is excellent. All overseen by Archangel Gabriel on the central column. The square is flanked by two attractive neoclassical museum buildings. Rather than the marching soldiers of old I saw a Hari Krishna rally pass through the square.

A beautiful spot to begin your explorations. Beautiful setting. Great for pictures. Across the street from several museums and very close to the baths, ice skating rink and zoo. All a few minutes walk

Best place to learn the Hungarian history of 1100 years. I always try to find time to bring all my foreign guests here: This spacious and monumental square not only depicts ancient tribal lords and war chariots as a running tourist in time deficit thinks, but it represents very high values: The unique pure romantic architectural design - the whole conceived to the Millenium of the Hungarian State - and the statues in the middle and around. They tell the entire history of a christian European state. The statues themselves are beautiful too: in the middle the leaders of the 7 tribes who led the folk to the Carpathian Basin, with archangel Gabriel at the top of the column, who handed over the crown (believed: gift of God) to our first king St. Stephan, and around in the left wing the most important kings of Hungary, in the right wing the important Hungarian leaders. The Museum of fine arts and the Art exhibition hall are well managed houses with internationally famous artworks. they (opposite to each others) close the square very harmonically .

You can see the goosestepping soldiers. Heroes s Square is a Soviet era parade ground which pays homage to the heroes of the republic. Flanked by museums, the marching soldiers have given way to artists, street musicians, and camera bearing tourists.
great statuary. were there during a political rally. it was great. seeing all the great staues of the historical leaders of hungary. it was beautiful.
Another Statue!. I wasn't very impressed with this one. It just seemed like another Statue to me. It would be better if there was some explanation to what it means .
Nice area for a picnic. The square itself is really picturesque, a nice area just to walk around. Theres a big park and lake behind it which is nice for picnics and just sitting around in the sun.

Unexpected bit of Hungarian history in the center of Pest.. This very popular site is on every tour operated in Budapest, and is well worth seeing. The monuments carry important historical stories about the settlement of what is now Hungary and the thousand-year history of this city. Aside from the square itself, there are museums surrounding the site so it would be possible to spend hours nosing around if you have the time.

A must see!!. When you get out of the underground metro at Hősök tere, the first thing you see is a beautiful view of Hero's square. There is so much to see in the area - Hero's square monuments with beautiful sculptures and statues, Kunsthalle (Art museum), a nice castle nearby which look like one from Disney movies.

Another Photo Op. Hero's Square was a quick stop on the scooter tour we took in Budapest. We took photos, heard about its history, and left for the next stop. Not amazing but worth taking pictures of it.

Impressing and depressing at the same time. A huge roundabout with a square in the middle with some impressive monuments arranged in a semi-circular fashion, depicting ancient tribal lords and war chariots. In the middle is a massive stone column with an angel on top spreading his wings.While it is all certainly huge and visible from far away, it is quite honestly not a whole lot to look at. We were planning to visit the museums on both sides, but everything was shut and looked rather uninviting.Lots of tourists taking selfies or attempting to take "that special shot", but of course not something that hasn't already been photographed a gazillion times before. A lot of cars, buses and beer bicycle vehicles. All pretty awesome, but also a bit depressing as it remonds of a long gone dream of a grand and rich Hungary. The square is not particularly worth visiting on its own, unless paired with a visit at the nearby park area.To be honest, I found the derelict Pest neighborhood with those once georgeous buildings totally worn down to almost ruins much more interesting to check out.

Impressive Area.. A large impressive area with many amazing statues representing major historical figures of Hungary. There was also some interesting areas nearby;including a zoo,an ice skating area and some amazing old medieval buildings made out of wood.Worth visiting.
Amazing statues and column. You'll be sure to pass Heroes' Square on your way through the city gardens and perhaps onto the baths. The statues are fantastic. Either side are museums.

Short stop on tour, not a destination. While on a city-wide private tour by van, we stopped at Heroes' Square. The monolithic statuary seemed consistent with what we saw throughout Budapest. the square is open, and has a museum on either side. Unfortunately the main museum is closed for renovations, and will not be open for some time. While interesting, I would not make a visit to the square a priority.

Truly Triumphant!. Our tour guide took the Viking group to Hero's Square in Budapest. It is a magnificent and monumental tribute to the heros and kings of Hungary. Certainly a must see when visiting the city.

AMAZING. thıs place ıs awesome. budapest ıs my favourıte cıty ın europe. warm peaole, mıxed culture. ıt ıs lıke europe and hıstory of ottoman empıre ın the same tıme. you feel the hıstory ın the aır. also very cheap and delıcıous foods you can taste! must vısıt
A Place of heroes.. A very Beautiful place in Budapest. Very picturesque and in the middle of Budapest. One should must visit here to feel the beauty of this place.
UNESCO World Heritage Site. This squase has and very unique design. Admire it.There are two more cool buildings neat this square: Museum of Fine Arts and Hall of Art.
Stunning Monument. Stunning monument with lots of history, a must see on a trip to Budapest. Lots of photo opportunities.

Classic East European square.. Really good place to stand and take pictures and think a bit about the history of this complex country. Don't allow your teenage son to climb on any of the monuments though. Quite rightly they treat this place with a great deal o respect.

A grand and magnificient square,. No trip to Budapest would be complete without visiting the Heroes square. A sight to behold and should spend some time there. Beautiful and grand statues and square. Though all over Budapest we see various such statues but this whole combination is a majestic sight.

So meaningful. One of the biggest square of Budapest. Located in front of the City Park, at the end of the Andrássy Avenue, one of the most important streets of Budapest. This square was build for the 1000th anniversary of the arrival of Hungarians in the Carpathian Basin

Cool. When we went, there were hardly any people there. Thats a bonus for us! The history behind this square is amazing. There is a park behind it that you can walk around in. We certainly did and the whole visit was just over an hour.

Hungary's famous square. A row of great Hungarian rulers, the 7 leaders who came to Hungary first, spacious square where always happens something! Rush to the museums, to the zoo, to skating, or to the park with your kids - this park is in the center, easy reach from Danube by the underground.

Historical. Decided to visit this on the last day and it's a very nice square with a nice park to relax nearby and the museums nearby are very good (even though one was closed)...Good historical monuments and somewhat ruined by people trying to climb them to get good "profile pictures".

If short of time not worth a visit. Don't know if this is worth a visit as it is quite a way walk wise from the river and it is very stark. If you know the history and want to look at it fair enough but I went with a friend and it was a very hot day with no shade and lots of tourists but to me was not worth a visit

A nice place for a walk.. We enjoyed this monument as it has some amazing statues. It is worth a visit although there is not much information about the staues and why they are important in Hungarian History. Fortunately you can find out all of this information on line before or after you go.

Majestic square. This is a large and beautiful square that includes their memorial for the unknown soldier. It is a large semi-circle of columns, with statues of the leaders of the tribes that founded the country of Hungary. In the center is the Archangel Gabriel. It's nice for a stroll to see all the statues, and get some pictures. Also, it's very close to the Széchenyi baths.

Historic tribute. This is a must see while in Budapest. It is a fantastic tribute to the soldiers of WW2. It is near the tribute to the Dracula Castle. It is not a long walk from the Danube and is free.

OK...had higher expectations from it. Heroes Square is a nice place but honestly I thought it would be much more than what I saw out there. I would not like to use a word underwhelming because it does not do justice, but it really did not come up to the expectations I had of it.

Spend time looking at the details. This is a big square with much to see. Look at the details of the sculptures. Combine this with a walk across the road to the park and then a return walk along Andrassy blvd.
Stop for goulash soup, beer and bread for a light inexpensive meal.

Impressive square. This iimpressive square less at one end of andrassy Utca. The square is like those of other european cities eg the grand squares at end of large avenues like paris and berlin. The square also leads into the park behind which is worth a visit and has the large public baths. The buildings around the square are worth a visit too. There is a magyar history museum in the quaint buildings in the park.
The Millenium Monument. The towering column in the square has the archangel Gabriel on the top, with hungarian tribal princes around its base. A tourist hot spot

A square.. It's enormous, it's iconic, and it's a square, and that's all there is to say on the matter. Due to its sheer size, I felt rather uneasy than impressed there. If you go on a guided tour, you'll get some exposition on the early history of Hungary here, while overlooking the statues of heroes.

Budapest Freedom Square. We went around this monument half a dozen times and it has been a centre of the lives of so many of this countries'population & history since Communisn took so much away. Look at it with respect for the lives & freedom lost for so many over that terrible time.

Historical sight. This site is very historical. The area is so large and there were a couple of gypsies trying to sell embroidered blouses. Lots of tourists flock to this area to take a couple of pics. You can just stay for about 30 minutes to take pics and videos. No benches anywhere though.

Imposible not to visit when going to Budapest. This is a very important landmark in Budapest and a very beautiful spot to visit, full of history and symbolism to Hungarian people. In the center of the square there is the Millenium Memorial which is of most importance in Budapest, with statues of leaders of the seven Magyar tribes that founded Hungary. This memorial was built between 1896 (when the first millenium of the country was celebrated) and 1929.This square is located at one of the ends of the Andrassy Avenue, which strongly resembles The Champs Elysees of Paris.

Impressive Square, definitely Worth a Visit. Surely worth a visit ! The Big Bus Company Starts & Ends its hop on hop off service from Heroes Square so its almost automatic that one reaches it. At the end of a very long Enclave, Heroes Square is Impressive and the scale is inviting. Good Sculptures stand more towards the top of the square and for us the highlight was the Live Bands playing in the Center when we went...on a Saturday afternoon. Some chairs thoughtfully placed for Visitors who need to rest a bit.Its close to the Zoo,as also an impressive Art Gallery but that is shut for maintenance for a long time.

Large Square. The square size in not emphasized enough in the travel guide. This is a huge place with a very nice park right adjacent to it.The statues are very nice and one interesting thing about them is that they are replaced every so often (at least that is what we were told) and the old statues go to storage and can be visited.

Ver impressive. This place is iconic & a significant landmark ,it features the seven chieftains of the Magyars & other important national leaders . It also has the tomb of the unknown soldiers right in the center . Can visit anytime it being open . This place often features & hosts many shows & movie shootings . The other day while we were passing by we saw a group of belle dancers waiting for a show .

Michael Jackson shot the video for History in this square. Remember the opening for the video History ? The one with the gigantic King Kong sized statue of MJ ? Well, the column where Gabriel the Archangle tops stands was engulfed by the King of Pop. Watch that video, then come here. For a modern more relevant twist.There are altogether 7 kings, 7 chieftains and 7 statesmen immortalised in bronze here. Even though he is not Hungarian, they did love him so. I wish they would reserve a spot for MJ too for the new hope he brought to a country just 2 years out of communism . Maybe one day it will happen .
worth a visit. We were recommended to visit here and we were not disappointed. It is an impressive open area and statues to Hungary's past heroes within the monument
Night tour. City, squares and parks look so beautiful, especially at night. Impressive and not far from downtown and other beautiful places.

A good stop if you visit the park. There are 2 museums there which you can visit, but more interesting is the Varosliget Park, with it's baths, zoo and the Vajdahunyad Castle. The Heroes Square is the entrance to that park and is a good enough place to take a few photos.

Huge and beautiful square!!!. This is the modt beautiful square in the city with unique monuments and two museums on it. The road to this square is one of the most beautiful streets in Budapest Andrassy street. Behind the square you can find gorgeous park and the biggest baths in Budapest (Szecheniy baths)!!!
Great spot for a pic. Great spot for a shot! I recommend that you go and see sights like these for picture opportunities at night first. They look so much better with the light and shadows

Great Historic and Patriotic Monument. This is located by the City Park and close to the thermal baths, Zoo, etc. great monument showing the Magyar pride for his History and culture, it is a must and can be covered in an hour or so, actually I bought one of those Hop On-Hop Off tours and one of the mandatories stops is this monument, I recommend to do the same and after visiting the square, visit the thermal baths at walking distance or the next stop in the bus route.
Great Monuments and Park. A nice series of monuments. Not to be missed when inBudapest. Great park system. Worth the time to explore.

A real must to visit.. Quite an amazing square that must be visited to appreciate the marvellous sculptures/statues of a bygone age. Budapest is a beautiful city, due to many wonderful landmarks such as this.

Square alongside huge city park. This beautiful square is the outermost part of Andrassy Boulevard, and features an impressive monument. It stands next to a large city park, where this past weekend there was a beer festival going on. Lots of people, lots of action, food, beer, and still clean and very civilized :)

A must visit while in Budapest. I took so many photos here. If you really want to feel it, i suggest you spend at least an hour. Sit and sip a drink at the stalls or just sit and do nothing. Its cool place
Very Busy Tourist Attraction. During our recent visit to Budapest we visited this site. Lots of visitors; not a lot to see, but there was a festival going on nearby that made the visit worthwhile.
Beautiful square. You should visit here. A square which have no special function. It's really nice to go with metroline number 1 and come up stairs and see the whole square opening up front of you.

History's Heroes. This is worth a visit, it was explained to us by the guide that the statue holding the Hungarian Holy Crown and apostolic cross was Gabriel the Archangel. There were also figures of the 'greats' from Hungarian history in between the pillars of Heroes Square. You will also see the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in front of the monument. Lots of tourists but still plenty of opportunities to take some photos.

Beautiful monument. Heroes Square is at the end or beginning of Andrassy utca or street. Bus 105 will take you there from the bottom of The Buda Castle passing Deek Frenec station and the Opera. This monument is magnificently situated adjacent to a museum and another castle. Loads of pic opportunity, which makes one wonder why it's open to traffic at all. Behind the square is a venue for holding concerts on the grounds of the castle. Beautiful castle with a drawbridge. For fun there isa ghoul like sstatue you can sit and take a picture with. Pretty scary!!!

You must see not just daytime but at the night. If you want to take some great photos of Budapest don't miss this powerful place! It's recommended to do at night, I think the square most beautiful at that time, amazing. Nice walk to the City Park (Városliget), there's a lot to do and you can enjoy the nature a bit.
Impressive.. Loved the beauty of Hero's Square. So many stunning statues. The noticeable thing about Budapest, including Hero's Square, is that everything is spotlessly clean.

A Must. arrive there early to avail of the real magnitude of this square. It is seriously popular with tour buses arriving every few minutes. The hop on hop off tour buses give great depth of information on how this square and all the historical statues came about so you discover the story with the beauty - Awesome

A definite photo opportunity. We enjoyed taking in the culture of Budapest but didn't cover Heroes' Square via any of the official walking tours of the city because it's off the beaten track compared to the more central attractions. As a result, we didn't appreciate its significance as much when we first visited, as there isn't a great deal of tourist information at the site itself - though it does lend itself as a very eye-catching photo opportunity as a rare expanse of open space in quite a densely built up city.The best chance to take in the site is part of a trip to the wonderful Szczesny Baths. They're just the other side of the river, which you can either cross 'the long way round' via a bridge, or take the more exhilarating option of crossing it via the stepping stones that sit just above water height. Not for the feint hearted, and best undertaken if you've not got your valuables in your pocket in case you fall in!
visit to Heros Square. visited using the hop-on, hop-off bus ticket and was impressed by how clean and spacious the area was, a good place for a photo opportunity, monuments were fabulous

So many heroes, so little time. Our first visit to Budapest and this was the first site that we visited. Not because it was on a list of priorities, but because it was just there in all its glorious monumental monumentality when we got off at a metro stop. I had no idea who half the heroes were and it takes a good bit of time to track down their names in our guide books, so we just basked in the presence of some finely sculpted works of fierce looking men. After a while, too many heroic statues can get boring, so we stopped into some of the fine museums surrounding the square and indulged in some intimate tete-a-tete with Hungary's fine artists.
Budapest. Well worth the long walk from the Center of Budapest. Historical buildings along the way made the trip enjoyable.

Impressive. Our tour group visited Heroes Square with our guide. This was obviously a popular place for locals as well as tourists. Children were climbing the statues, teens were doing tricks on bikes, tourists were snapping pictures. The history portrayed here is the coming together of seven tribes to form the country. There are additional heroes representing important points in history and a tomb for the unknown soldiers.

Nice Square. Right on the subway lane, nice park right by it and the most famous Budapest bath, Szechenyi Baths. The Budapest Circus is right by the Square too, so a lot to see and enjoy if you are going to the Heroe's Square. Nice for pictures too.
Great insight into Hungarian History. Statues are wonderful especially if you know what and who you are looking at. Watch out for the tour buses - gets very busy.

Huge square with a history of the Hungarian Heroes!. This is a huge open space, centrally located near museums, thermal baths, zoo and restaurants by a pretty lake. It doesn't take long (30 min.) and it helps if a tour guide explains the significance of the hero statues and their place in history!

HISTORIC. The statues of past kings in Heroes' Square are worth observing from the historical point of view. You will find the Museum of History on one side and the Opera house on the other side of the Square. The wide Avenue leading to the square is impressive in it's scope and size. A great location to take pictures.Zoltan Molnar Montreal, Canada
Impressive.. Very impressed by this and we was lucky enough to witness a military parade whilst there. Definitely worth the visit to take some photographs. Stunning.

Cool Square. This square is a cool place to visit a bit further out of the centre of town and near to the Szechenyi Baths. There's not much to do, and I don't really know enough about the history to really appreciate it, but it was impressive.

If you're interested in Hungarian history..... The square is impressive, and is a must if you are interested in hearing about the key features in Hungarian history over the centuries. If you aren't, you might think it's a bit of a distance from the centre of town, and would be more meaningful to those who already know the history.
Beautiful. This is a beautiful area I'm sure means so much to Hungarians a must see on all the bus tour routes worth coming off and taking time out to enjoy

Visit to Heroes Square. Truly impressive. Don't try and walk, go on the Metro, well worth a short visit. We did this while our Buda card was still active so it was quite fun whiz zing everywhere on the Metro but even if you are paying for the Metro ( buy the tickets in blocks of 10, cheaper) it is well worth a look at

A grand monument. A grand monument in the north of the city. It may be far out from other sightseeing spots so it may be worth taking public transport. You may see tour groups giving talks so don't be afraid to eavesdrop!

The Budapest feel - The authentic Hungarian monument. A beautiful and stunning monument dedicated to Hungarian heroes. A huge open air plaza where you can idle around in quiet, sit and watch locals play, skate and have fun. Also very picturesque during evening and night. You can also find beer carts doing a round on weekends and become a part of the real fun.A must must visit if you are in Budapest.
Spectacular Bronze. Hero's square is a beautiful place. Bronze statues . You can get fabulous pictures here ! a bit of a journey to get there...but worth it

Great attraction in Budapest. This is one of my favourite places in Budapest. You can take great pictures of it especially in the night. It is surrounded by museums, City Park. Pay it a visit and you won't regret it :)

Very pretty. the place is a must see because we must have all seen the squares in books. Great way to get there is to take the subway, the yellow line, the oldest subway on the continent, some say (others suggest Moscow's may be older). Nice sculptures.

Stunning grand plaza. Heroes' Square is home to Hungary's Tomb of the Unknown and while we were there, a group of officials arrived to place a wreath there. The two semi-circular colonnades frame the Victory monument beautifully. It is a grand space -- not on an excessive scale, but just right.The ceremonial band, however, needs practice!

Large square with nice monuments but kind of out of the way. This was a stop on our Budapest city tour through Viking River Cruises. It's kind of out of the way so we decided not to see it while on our own. It's a very big area and the monuments and statues are very nice and worth seeing, especially if your on a city tour. I don't know if I'd go out of my way to see it otherwise.

Read your history a bit before you go. I went and thought, yeah, nice statues- what's next? Then I read a bit of Hungarian history and went again. It is an amazing history (my sister says I say that about everywhere I go). Anyway- understanding a bit of history makes it a lot more interesting. I still wouldn't spend too much time there, except on my way to the zoo, baths, museums or galleries which are all near by!

Seen through the hop on/hop off bus . We loved this square. The surrounding streets offer a great view of local life. The square is very impressive. Offers an authentic view of the glory of Old Hungarian culture. Would suggest you visit it if you have the time.

Nice place to walk to. We walked to this square from the Terror museum, it was a lovely stroll up Androssy street. The square is huge, filled with lots of people and statues. Dedicated to the Hungarian Prime minister who was in charge of Hungry during the Communist era. During the uprising of 1956 he began to support freedom and separation of Hungry and its people from the grips of the Iron curtain. He died unceremoniously but later was exhumed and relocated to this square, he was A posthumous hero of the Hungarian people!

You Need A Guide. Lots of statues and a beautiful plaza but if you don't have a guide to explain the why's and wherefores of this square it is lots of stone and marble. There is history and meaning, a great tourist trap if not with a guide (handlers) but worth the visit.

Know your history. Not knowing the history and significance of this square I found it to be impressive but slightly overrated. I would recommend a tour guide if you want a meaningful experience or to read up on the history before you go.

Must see, no cost and easy access!. Really worth the trip. Subway drops you right there for reasonable cost. The statues and view are awesome. Walking distance to Agricultural Museum and Castle. Loved passing through the park, collies are big in Hungary so they were everywhere.
