"wow.....powerful stuff". These statues are quite magnificent and dramatic, they depict a country with a very turbulent history. I wont pretend to understand what was going on, but, as i say it was pretty powerful stuff, well worth a look!!
delightful place to walk around. it is a huge area, with statues around the square.u will love it at night with all the lights.radha aiyar

A Wonderful Window Into Hungary's History. This is one of my favorite places in Budapest. It is the location of wonderful monuments and statues, close to parks and museums and the location of Hungary's Tomb of An Unknown Soldier. The main monuments are frames by two colonnades holdings statues of important contributors to Hungary's history.Take the time to look at the faces of the men portrayed in the statues. And the equestrian statues as well. An amazing national monument.

Impressive Statuary. This very large square (take the metro from the centre) has impressive statues of Hungarian heroes through the ages. The square is often used for local gatherings and events and sometimes has snack vans there.Tip: carry on across the (very busy) road to the castle and park."Fake-old" castle, but pleasant park and two nice places to eat in the sunshine.

Long walk to get there, but a bit of an anti-climax. I had high expectations as I walked from my hotel, found my way to Andrassy ut and then walked right up to the top. There was Heroes' Square. Its a wide open space with an attractive massive monument in the centre and then an array of statues of historic figures around the edge. It took me about 10 minutes to take it all in. To be fair, its probably of great interest to Hungarian people as it highlights their history right back to the start. Also, it was a bleak October day. Probably more attractive in June.

ICONIC SQUARE TO HUNGARY'S PAST. Easily reached on Line 1 (original) of the Budapest Metro, Heroe's Square is a massive open square with arch, column depicting the history of Hungary incl. the 7 Magyar tribes. The surrounding area, Andrassy Ut, is mainly Embassies with impressive buildings, and the beautiful City Park. Definately worth seeing. Great opportunities for photos, and leading off towards the park some interesting, and inexpensive restaurants.

Beautiful. We walked through here after having a look at the nearby spa pools. There was so much happening in the square and plenty of people having fun. Stop and absorb the moment. It is a special place.

Great Photo Op. This square sits outside between the Museum of Fine Art and the Museum of Regular Art outside Vajdahunyad Castle. A statue of the Arch Angle Gabriel sits on top of the square. Lots of pretty picture to be taken here.
Historical a must stop. Located at the end of Andrassy Ut. Bustling with tourists (motorcoaches). Historical landmark worth going on a guided tour for explanations and facts.

Triumphant tribute to Hungary's ancestors. It started in 1895 as a Millennium Monument, to celebrate the 1000 years anniversary of the Magyars ancestors who settled down in the Carpathian Basin in 895. With one year delay it started in 1896 and was completed in 1929. The monument designed by architect Albert Schichedanz took the 1st prize at the 1900 World Exhibition in Paris. The sculptures were designed by Zala György. The column in the centre is 36 m high and on the top Archangel Gabriel holds the holy crown of St.Istvan (Stephen) and the apostolic double cross. According to the legend St.Istvan, Hungary's 1st king, saw in his dreams the Archangel offering him the crown of the country. At the base of the column the statues of the 7 Hungarian chieftains led by Árpád, considered the founder of the Hungarian nation. There are 2 colonnades with Corinthian columns and the statues of various historical personalities of Hungary. In front of the the column, a cenotaph, a Monument of National Heroes or Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. At one corner of the square the impressive 1895 building of Műcsarnok ( Hall of Art) and to the opposite side, the Museum of Fine Arts. A lot of events take place in this square. The reburial of Imre Nagy on 16th June 1989, who was executed in 1958, brought 250.000 people to the square! The Millennium Monument together with Andrássy Ut ( Avenue) belong to the Unesco world heritage sites.

A place where history takes place. What a beautiful tribute to the heroes of Budapests past. This is an expansive monument area and is still where the people of Budapest gather to express their opinions, the US Dept of State sent me notifications a couple times before my visit that there were protests being held about a new monument they wanted to erect. The fact that there was a place that democracy could be demonstrated in a country filled with an oppressive past was quite impressive. Loved the Budapest sign they have erected there.

Best monument . It was opened in 1896. My tourist bus left me at Andrasy square and from there I just walk along the museum it's the tourists visit to see the statues of famous people in Hungary's history. The Museum of Fine Arts and The Palace of Art are also here.

Large impressive square. The vast Heroes' Square was opened in 1896 and although it is a little out of central Budapest virtually all tourists visit to see the statues of famous people in Hungary's history. The Museum of Fine Arts and The Palace of Art are also here.

Unique memorial. The openness of Heroes' Square makes this monument even more special. The statues are quite large and imposing in some ways. The Hungarians are a very proud people and that can be felt very obviously at Heroes' Square. I walked to the monument from the Parliament Building. It took 25-30 minutes and along the way you can see more of the real Budapest I would call it rather than the tourist traps. It can be somewhat alarming but still important to see. The monument is one of the staples of Budapest and is not to be missed

Enormous square. Located at the end of Andrassy Utca this really huge square is at the centre of several attractions. Coming from Andrassy Ut you'll find the National Museum on the left, the Museum of Modern Arts on the right and still on the right you can see the City Park. On the back of Heroes' Square there are thermal bath and the city zoo.

A luminescent square. Took the hop on & off bus to visit the square, where we had about 10 minutes to enjoy a bit of free time. It was in the evening and the square and its heroes were lit up creating a majestic aura. An impressive monument - worth seeing!
Monument. Very big square with this particular monument to the heroes. It is an example of giant architecture as other of this kind in the world
Very Nice. It's really a nice checkpoint :) and you can take beautiful pictures there. When we were there, there was a big Budapest wooden sign sort of thing and it was so cool

beautiful. A really beautiful part of the city, we were lucky to be staying nearby so it was only a short walk away. As a UNESCO world heritage site, Heroes Square is immaculately clean and well-kept. It’s surrounded by a few very busy main roads so be careful when crossing to get to it! There are columns with large statues of seven important people from Hungary’s past. I’m not a history buff so I don’t know who these people are but the statues are really impressive. There’s also a large wooden ‘Budapest’ sign that many tourists like to get their photo taken in front of. It lights up in multicolours at night. I’d recommend spending about an hour here, the tour buses drop off and pick up right outside the museum across the road, so it’s very accessible.
Impressive. A terrific collection of figures denoting Magyar heroes and important figures in the grand history of Hungary. The grave of the unknown soldier is also here.

A must see. The square is situated near a large park with a nice castle in it, just across a bridge there is the Heroes Square, you can't skip this in your Budapest trip!You'll need more than a day if you also want to visit the nearby museums and thermal baths.
Typical square. Large square with statues. Not my thing. If you are in the area it's worth a stop to take some pictures. I wouldn't go out of the way to make a special trip.

A place all Hungarians can be proud of. This expansive square lies at one end of Andrassy ut and forms part of the area that is included in the UNESCO list of Word Heritage Sites. Completed in 1900, the square's most prominent feature is a central column bearing a bronze statue of the Archangel Gabriel holding the crown of St Stephen aloft. At the base of the column are equestrian statues of the seven lords who were responsible for bringing the Hungarian people into the area the country roughly occupies today. In front of the column is a cenotaph that pays tribute to the people who gave their lives to Hungary. Contrary to popular belief, no one's actually buried there. Behind the column and expanding outwards in the form of a semi circle are two colonnades bearing the figures of fourteen historic individuals whose achievements for Hungary between the 15th and 19th centuries are shown in the panels underneath each figure. Unfortunately, there is no explanation of what those achievements are. So, unless you've studied Hungarian history, read up beforehand, or have a travel guide with you, it may be difficult to appreciate the significance of the panels. Overall, it's a nice place to spend some time but be aware that there is no shelter so it can be baking hot or horribly exposed to rain or snow.

Take a crash course in Budapests History.. This is Budapest's largest square and a bit further out than the rest of the attractions so best take some transport. The many statues around the square identify the heroes in Hungary's history and even the Archangel Gabriel overlooks it all.
Unfortunately the day of our visit was cold & wet!. We used the tram to get to the square. A very impressive place. Very well done with plenty of space for special events.

Worth it. This is quite an amazing sight, huge square with busy roads on each elevation, the square has the stunning statues and burial tomb of the unknown soldier and Nagy. Excellent photo opportunities, not very busy, good access for all, just be careful when crssong out of the square as there doesn't seem to be any markings where the square finishes and the road and speeding cars meet.

Astonishing place! ;). I felt like standing in a place built in memory of sth momentous and great. History is calling from those statues. There are a couple of restaurants and cafes near there and also a zoo.
Beautifull. What can you say another of the beautifull sights of budapest, its just so lovely to see, every thing about it and its surroundings are stunning you cannot go wrong
Nice. Visited in the evening. Very nice and got some lovely photos. Museums all around the square but didn't go in. Ice skating nearby in winter.

Wide Expanse near the Park at the end of Andrassy Ut. We walked all the way through Budapest to this huge square at the end of Andrassy Ut. Surrounding the Square are statuary representing former leaders and important people in Hungary's past. Worth seeing and then traversing the very nice park past the square.

Fantastic area for an early morning run!. Runners will enjoy the many sites nearby, and the opportunity to see this square without other tourists, if they go early morning. I was there at 0530 and highly recommend the square and park for a run + sightsee.

You must see this Plaza!. We visit this marvelous square as part of our guided tour. It's an enormous plaza with very important memorials of Hungarian history. We recommend this place to expand our knowledge. Until my next review.
Heroes square. A very big area, with the statue and history. If you not interest to the history, you only can take pictures and nothing to do more.

Pretty place . This site is fantastic, so many people taking pictures and looking around, the pretty budapest lettering in the middle of the square for photo opportunities and the old statues of old gods and warriors. Do visit if you go to Budapest. Also, on the right hand side (when facing the square) there is a really nice information place for free maps and useful facts, and the staff is really sweet.

Large but essentially all this is is a traffic round about.. All the tourist buses end here. There are neo-classical edifices on either side that are art galleries but they looked uninviting and shut. They could have been open but I saw no sign of that. Because iof the spread of the square it's a pest to cross against all the traffic. A real bore.

Great Statues. Huge open space- good to approach it from Andrassy street- the view of the Millenium Column and the Heroes from Hungary's history are better from that side. They've put in a wooden " Budapest" like the "Amsterdam" at the back of the Rijksmuseum, but it's quite nicely done and there's still room for photos of the Column and Prince Arpad and the Magyar horsemen from behind the lettering! The (Greek Temple) Art Gallery only has Temporary Exhibitions-some of the good stuff is currently up in the National Art Gallery at Buda Castle, and the National Museum opposite is currently undergoing major renovations and won't be open again until 2018. That was a bit of a disappointment- but it gives me a good excuse to go back! It's also a good place to pick up the Hop on Hop Off tourist buses and is probably the nearest stop for the City Park, the Zoo and the Circus, so there's still plenty to do and see even without the Gallery and Museum at the at end of town.

I Want to Spend More Time Here. We did the bus tour through the park and nearby zoo, and this looks like one of the places I intend to spend more time on my next visit. Much history on display right here at the Heroes Monument, but I think a day at the zoo might also be nice. Unfortunately, my bus tour ony allowed a 25 minute stop here.
So much is under restoration or closed!. Even the grass and the water in the lake was missing.We walked all around but were able to enjoy little but the views.

Good to walk through. we walked from St Stephens basillica up andrassy street to heroes square. It's a lovely walk. Leave plenty of time because it is very far and there is lots to see! Once you get to the square there are loads of lovely buildings and interesting statutes.
Exciting. Great monuments comemorating the hungarian history,nice park surounding it,great photos on a sunny day.

International Pillow Fight Day . Stumbled upon this Square after imbibing & feeding during the Husvet festival at Vajdahunyad Castle. Much to our amusement, it was International Pillow Fight Day & the swarms of people were armed with -- what seemed to be -- the entire IKEA cushion collection. Such fun! The patinated statues were impressive, as well.
Nice!. Always a nice place to see! This place is a must see! Highly recommended! They keep it clean and right now there is that big BUDAPEST sign in the middle of the place!
Nice to see. It's a great thing to see! and can be easily found as it's right near City park ;) You can get some great photos of it along with the castle near by!

Nice suqere. For me this is just a nice squere. Very close to this there is a nice resturant where the red hop on hop of bus stops. There we had greate Gulasj soup. Very nice place to stop for lunch when you do sightseeng in Budapest

Worth a vist, good photo opportunities nothing too exciting.. Worth a visit and some really good photo opportunities, I wouldn't travel a long distance to come though you would probably spend about 15 minutes at the most.
Worth checking out the Steak House on the lake near by and also the Zoo!!
majestic. you don't realise how big and majestic the sculptures are until you are standing underneath them... very beautiful

Beautiful monument. One of my favourite spots in Budapest, at the end of long boulevard, flanked by National museum and Gallery. Splendid figures of great Hungarians, seven ancient Hungarian chiefs and marvelous pillar with angel Gabriel holding Holy Crown of Hungary situated on a large plaza which only adds to monuments appeal. A must for every trip to Budapest.

Very impressive landmark. Beautifully maintained landmark with historic statues
Very popular to visit so be careful of pickpockets as they are very active here

Impressive architecture and statues. My family and I visited Heroes' Square on a cold sunny day. We had a enjoyable walk along Andrassy Ut to get there. The architecture and numerous statues are impressive (and reminded me of Trafalgar Square in London).

One of my favourites in Budapest. A really beautiful monument marks the entrance to the beautiful City Park. About a 30 minute walk from St. Stephen's Basilica, but definitely worth the trip. I used my Rick Steves book for the self-guided walking tour and wasn't disappointed. We walked to the Szechnyi baths and ended our night there. Very peaceful and much less touristy than the rest of the city.

See it at night when it's so well lit and then go back by day and learn about the past .... Look at the horse covered with branches so it has its own armor in battle. Look at the kings and think about what they might have been anticipating ... go here early in your trip and you'll see Budapest differently. Don't miss Heroes' Square.

Thought I was in Rome for a moment!. We were taken here after a restaurant trip so it was dark, but the whole square is beautifully lit and of course was very quiet. Go to the centre and you are surrounded by roman-style buildings that look like elaborate temples. During the German occupation, Hitler loved this square so much that he named it 'Hitler Square'! You can see many statues depicting every great leader the Hungarian people have had. Go over to the park and you'll find an ancient castle, set in the middle of some lakes. The lakes have boats you can hire during the summer, or in winter when they are frozen, you can skate on them. You can walk through the main gate, even at night, and see the changes made over the years....almost a little history of architecture in one wonderful setting! In the grounds you'll find a spooky statue of a famous Hungarian by the name of 'Anonymus'. He's the guy that used to write poems and stories but never put his name on them....say no more!

Meet the Heroes.. Splendid depictions of ancient heroes and Kings of Hungary, Michael the Archangel at the top of the pillar is particularly good. Apart from the square itself, the museum, which is just across the road shows statues from what would appear to be ancient Greece. The people here are justifiably proud of these amazing examples of sculpture created by real artisans.

Don't drive past stop and have a look.. Saw this from a car on our way to the hotel and made a note to come back on foot. Took the Foldalatti (Metro L1) from the centre to the square and made our way to the centre for some amazing photographs. This is a square made to impress and it does so in spades. Fantastic architecture and impressive statues. Make some time to come and visit.

Unless you are going in that direction not worth the effort. This is at the far end of Andrassy Street before the entrance to the City Park a good thirty five minutes walk from the hub of Budapest. Found it quite disappointing with a lot of traffic at its entrance. Really not worth the effort unless you are going to the Zoo, Flea Market, Outdoor skating ring or baths which are within walking distance. Not all these are open all year round or on every day of the week.

This is the place in Hungary to click a selfie!. The sightseeing buses take tourists around Heroes' Square. This monument is steeped in history and its artifacts have a lot of historical & mythological importance. If you are traveling to Vienna, try to visit Budapest as well.

History Surrounds You. We were so lucky that the sun was shining when we visited Heroes' Square. It made for terrific photos.It's a good thing to read up about this Square before visiting so you can appreciate the history surrounding you. We spent about half an hour here, looking at the statues, taking photos and enjoying the sunshine.

Beautiful!. This square with its monuments are a fantastic sight. We had the opportunity to see it in broad daylight and at night. Both times it was very beautiful. At night, it lights up the whole square. During the day, you are able to see them more clearly and learn more about each man's historical presence.

superb monument's. So glad we took the time out to go and visit this wonderful must go destination while we were here in Budapest.The sheer scale of the place is just breathtaking, amazing sculptures, huge column, great building's, just fabulous and so glad i took my camera. The tourist crowd's here were huge,as this site is so popular.I normally don't go to monument site's like this but went on the recommendation of a barman we had got chatting to in JACK DOYLES IRISH PUB, so glad we took the time out to go here.Great tourist destination and well worth a visit.

Imperial Square. Quite a place, and very much in place for an Imperial City. Lots of open space and with grand buildings on either side, it is a monument to great Hungarians of the past. To get the most from this, get some information on who the various statues are (ancient Kings and famous warriors): the Budapestans like their statues. Lots of good photo opportunities here. Easy to get to, at the bottom end of Andrassy Avenue, on the Metro and on the Hop On/Hop Off routes.
definatly worth a visit. this place is a must if you like historical monuments, the good weather really brought the place to it charm.

Impressive entrance to the park,near Szechenyi Baths. At the entrance to Varosliget Park, Heroes Square is grand in scale - flanked on either side by massive museums and with a very interesting monument celebrating key figures in Hungarian history. You can walk the length of Andrassy Ut back to Deak Ter and the centre of Pest.
Heroes' Square. The square is pretty amazing, you can take nice pictures. Definitively a must see attraction in Budapest. Also the park behind the statues worth a visit.
Great one. Any one go Budapest must visit it its special place and has agood views so you will have good photos there.
A square to visit. We liked this square. There is a lot of history behind it and it is close to the centre, easy to get and you can get amazing pictures from there.

Step back in time. When you view these sculptures and structure you can be forgiven for thinking you have gone back to our past. A true reflection of the manner in which our ancestors recorded events and most importantly those responsible for them. Don't just drive by stop and absorb the atmosphere
worth seeing. Nice Area to view. Check out the nearby ice rink. Museum close by is also good plus this is first stop for the Hop on, Hop off bus tours...

Wasted an hour of my life.... I understand the square symbolises something important to Budapest & Hungary as a whole but i found it a little disappointing.The place was swarming with tourists clambering around looking for that all important selfie, while stags & hens driveby on strange booze bus things. There really wasn't much to marvel at or read.The park and baths opposite the square were more interesting than this.

Heros square. This sight is very interesting and an excellent place to visit the statues are incredible and a visit to Central park which is just across the road is well worth visiting but Heros square is steeped in Hungarian history

Iconic!. Go there for the Architecture! A brilliant square with amazing avenues and architectural marvels! It is a massive place with arched gateways and obelisks with statues! Worth a visit and also you can click some nice photos here!

Worth the Miles we Traveled. We came all the way from the US to see my cousins sculpture here at the Millennium Monument. What an amazing sight to see our Surname carved into the 12th figure. When you leave here be sure to go to park and the baths. A Great place to visit!

A BIG square. We passed through Heroes Square on our way to other things. It certainly is a massive, impressive square. Not really my thing to find out what it's all about but I expect if it was you'd find it very interesting.

So spacious!. I was standing there around 30 minutes and just enjoying, If I was younger would definetely come there with my friends. The monument in the center of the square is very tall and representative in my opinion. And sure that there is always history connected with such places. I can' say a lot abot this square but it is really beautifull and worth seeing while you are in Budapest. From this square you can easily reach many other good places located nearby, like famous baths or the Museum of Fine Arts.

A little disappointed. After reading up on this before my visit, I was built up to see something different. The statues are amazing and the square itself is huge, but we couldn't find anything to explain who the statues were, etc. There did seem to be private tours going on - read up on all the history of it if you plan to visit.

Great statues. Traditional tourist attraction, but worth going to and combined with a walk around the park and surrounding area you get a well spent half day. If you want to enjoy Budapest, don't haste around. Take time to explore.
Worth a look. I went here some years ago. At the end of Line 1 of the Metro a spectacular site commemorating Hungary's fallen heroes. Quite moving.

Read up and know what you are looking at!. This seems to be on all the lists of must-see sights. I was happy to combine it with my trip to Vajdahunyad Castle, but honestly, got very lucky that there was a tour in English nearby and I was able to overhear a bit more about the statues. I researched it afterward, but be aware that there are not lengthy explanations on site, so do your research ahead of time and know what you are looking at!As far as getting there, I walked from my hotel near the opera and found it a pleasant and easy morning walk.
spectacular square. Going there requires a long bus or taxi ride in the traffic. But it is worth going there. It is also close to a large spa.
Impressive . This was very impressive as a gathering place but you needed someone to explain who the statues were of. There was not an explanation anywhere.

Beautiful huge square. The square is at the end of street "Andrassy"Accessible without any problem with the yellow line metroThe square is really huge and stunning beautyFull of ancient statuesA great place to take picturesDo not miss

Must See!. If you need to make the best of Budapest, or are only here on one day and need to cram everything in, this landmark is one not to miss. Easy access from the trains. A great place to capture photo opportunities both day and night. The statues around the square are incredible

Impressive . We visited heroes square when we were out walking to the Thermal baths, very impressive statues and we were lucky enough to have a nice dry day with blue sky's to see the square in all it's grandeur

Atmospheric at night. Saw this on our private tour. Having the significance of the statues explained makes better. The castle to right in the background lit up made for memorable photo. It is next to the metro stop and so easy to get to. No need to stay longer than 15 minutes.

Huge square. One of the most important and biggest squares in Budapest, where many important political and other meetings were held. Huge monument "Millennium Memorial" with the statues on the left and right representing the members of Hapsburg dynasty. Also, there is a statue of Archangel Gabriel, holding Hungarian Holy Crown. Square is almost always crowded with tourists, so if you want to take good pictures of the square and monument, you should probably come very early in the morning.
Nice but.... This is a nice place to walk by and snap a few pictures. I would not go out of my way to see this though.
Great moments in Hungary's history!. I suggest hiring a guide or get a really good book on the sights. This was remarkable, and our guide did an amazing job of explaining so many details.
it was ok!. nice to see but nothing too excited!it is near to Szechenyi Baths and near to a park so its better to combine all together.

Very beautiful . The square is so amazingly beautiful. My boyfriend and I visited it in the night and took a lot of crazy photos. When you visit Budapest, this square is definitely "must see" thing! In the night was specially beautiful because of the amazing lightning :)

Stunning. . Our hotel was very close to the square. We passed it several time and for me it never lost any of its majesty. Surrounded by beautiful museums and buildings it looked amazing. Must be seen at night, breathtaking sights

Andrássy Avenue. Andrássy Avenue is a 2,310-metre boulevard lined with buildings in uniform architecture and linking the City Centre with the City Park. Andrássy Avenue, including the Millennium Underground Railway, running beneath the surface, as well as Heroes’ Square, located at is end, was recognised as a World Heritage Site in 2002. It accommodates the crème de la crème of Eclectic-style buildings in Budapest, among them a wealth of residential houses with wonderful and intimate inner courts, statues and foundations as well as the Opera House, built on the plans of Miklós Ybl.

Stunning. On the "hop on, hop off" bus route, Heroes Square is where we began our 3 day tour of Budapest. The square itself and its many statues are breath taking and the history of the Magyar tribes who founded the city are recorded here. Beyond the square is a bustling market, an ice skating rink and a castle, so allow yourself at least 2 hours to explore this area.

A must see in Budapest. Heroes' Square is should be close to the top of your list of attractions in Budapest. The statues are quite impressive. Travel a little bit farther and you're in Varosliget Park. While I was there Halfesztival was going on and there were tons of vendors selling Hungarian food and desserts. It was delicious.

Awesome Square. This square was really beautiful. Lot of amazing places around the square. There is a small lake as well an Ice Skating Ring near to the square. Can easily spend a couple of hours here. The light during night adds an mesmerizing feeling.

Spectacular !. Well worth visiting but take a good travel guidebook to help to understand the significance of the statues and monuments. As we arrived at the Square both my wife and I went 'Wow' and I can't really think of anything better to add that would do this justice. If you are in Budapest, make this a 'must see' location.

A great area of town.. Heroes square and the surrounding areas are well worth a visit. I went here a few times during my visit. The square itself is beautiful. It is well kept. The art and architecture were pretty impressive. There was a great market nearby, ice skating and the baths were close too.
Simply stunning. The recognition of the tribal leaders and remembrance of their ancestors are something hungarian are proud of. Worth to visit and see the magnificent statues displayed here.

Unique landmark. Heroes' Square is well worth the visit if you are in Budapest. The meaning of this attraction is steeped in Hungarian history and it has been beautifully designed. It is clean, spacious but built with busy roads surrounding it - so be careful how you make your way to this memorial! There are art galleries and the zoo nearby, as well as places to eat, so take your camera and good walking shoes to maximise the experience and the journey there. This is a short (worthwhile) visit, so you will want to incorporate this with something else in the locality.
Wow!. I loved this square, the atmosphere is amazing. I went during the day and night and found the night lights made it even more special. I couldn't stop looking at it, Everyone should see this.

A Lovely Area. The square with all its statues is spectacular and well worth seeing. It is also worth noting that there are a huge number of other sites in this area though sadly they closed the National Gallery four days ago and it is uncertain whether it will reopen in the foreseeable future. There is the ice-rink, the zoo, the enormous park, the museum of modern art and plenty else to see. It is a great tourist area but because of the space you are not overwhelmed by the masses belching from the tourist coaches.
Nice walk around. Nice place to stop and have a walk around and take in the monuments.Clean and tidy every where and a nice park behind
Day or night equally lovely. Definitely worth a visit in Budapest - either day or night. Also near to City Park which has lots of great attractions.

Monumental place with two "Romanians" among the heroes of Hungary. It is near museums and the ZOO. A big and impressive monumental square with statues of the heroes of the Hungarian state. Really beautiful works of art and great attention to details.An interesting fact is that two of the statues that represent men considered heroes by the Hungarians have Romanian roots: John Hunyadi (Iancu de Hunedoara) and his son Matthias Corvinus (Matei Corvin). The Hunyadi castle in Hunedoara (Transylvania) is still one of the nicest in Romania and a big touristic attraction.Near the Heroes' Square are situated some other interesting places to visit, like the Zoo, the contemporary art museum, the Museum of Fine Arts and Vajdahunyad Castle.You can get there by public transport, with a bus from the hop-on hop-off tours or by car (you will not have brig problems with finding a parking place).

One of my favourite sites. I now live in Budapest and Heroes Square is one of my favourite places. It is an impressive Square that throughout the year they put up artworks or displays on show. It's really busy all the time but it does get more crowded during the summer months. Also Michael Jackson filmed here. You can walk around city park and the local restaurants. All these are aimed for tourists with a service fee.

Part of Hungarian history. Heroes' Square (the Hungarian Hősök Tere) is one of the major squares in Budapest, famous for the tribute to the memory of those (the heroes) who gave their lives for Hungary's freedom and independence.
Also other important political events of the Hungarian contemporary history took place in this square.
Awe inspiring. This area is so huge. The stunning buildings and statues are worth a visit just to stand and take in the beautiful streets and magnificent architecture.

Must-do walk through history. Heroes' Square is a must-d walk through the history of Budapest. The bronze statues of the Seven Horsemen are truly awesome. It's worth risking the dash across the busy thoroughfare to get close up and view them at closse quarters.
Amazing!. Definitely worth a visit either by public transport or hop on hop off bus if you are more towards the river like we were. Lovely walk around, lots to see plus the lovely gardens behind.

OK, just OK. . This very highly rated on Trip Advisor and I'll quote the lyric "don't believe the hype". The square is lovely, reminiscent to Trafalgar in London with a massive park at the back. We went on a Sunday as part of the bus hop on / hop off and it was heaving. The local kids seem to use the statues as a climbing frame so photographing it was impossible. The park was tired and was clearly suffering from over use. I'm sure on a midweek day this would have been much more enjoyable. It's a fair journey out of the city centre so be sure you really want to go!

Really impressive. If your in Budapest Heroe's Square should be on your list. We were with a tour guide who explained who all the statues were i think if we weren't with a local guide it could get a little confusing but she knew her stuff which helped us to understand, just watch out for local people trying to sell you clothing and gifts try not to talk to them if you do they won't leave you alone.

A simply lovely place to visit in the day and at night. Whether you are a history buff, or a normal tourist, you cannot skip this place. It is a gem in it's own right, a simply fabulous monument. However it is also next to Central Park which is a park wherein you can spend a whole day as it contain attractions such as the zoo, the circus, Szechenyi Baths, Museum of Agriclture -this is a lovely castle, and the Museum of Fine Arts. And for skating buffs the skating arena is a must visit.

Memorial at its best. I stand in the middle of the square and just look around in amazement. There are so many memories there for the Hungarians. Every time I go to Budapest I a;ways spend time there. So inspiring. Around the Square you have close access to the Museum of Fine Arts, Szechenyi Baths, Millennium Monument, Jak Chapel, Statue of Anonymus, Vajdahunyad and the Mucsarnok Place of Arts and you then have the zoo.

Wonderful !. If you are in Budapest , you should go there. This place is really beautiful and amazing !This is a very big place with this wonderful monument rich of history.We were really lucky when We came because there was the sunset and it was really amazing !

A must see at night . Heroes Square looks stunning at night. Each of the heroes can be seen lit up brightly from a distance; which makes for some great photo taking. The obelisk also serves as a shining beacon for the whole square. Superb.
Nice place full of history. It was raining when I visited the Heroes' square but it was still beautiful. A must-visit of Budapest.
respect. one of the fantastic corner of Hungary you may feel the atmosphere feel like an old times and giving worthy to old times heroes ...
Big open space. Nice monuments, but too many locals mixing with the crowds trying to sell kitschy souvenirs. You should visit with a guide to explain the details of the statues
Beautiful. A lovely open space with stunning monuments. Was great to hear some of the information about them while on the bus tour.
Brilliant. Grand statues on a grand scale. Breathtaking, solemn, wonderful. The tour bus stopped here, reasonably crowded, but you can still ffind space and quiet.
Impessive. Large open space with a magnificent monument. Worth stopping here on your way to the Zoo or Thermal Baths.

Stunning . Pretty hard to take pictures Cuz it was full with tourists, but this region is so full of history, try to walk all around, there is a free tour around Budapest and they explain everything about history, culture, traditions.

Loved it!. Wow! An attraction with no fee, great for photos and lovely from each side. It is spectacular and pretty near to other sites, as the Vajdahunyad Castle and the Szechenyi Baths.
It is definitely worth a visit!

Impressive Square Impressive Area. It is beautifully designed and spectacular to see at night. It is in a great area where you can do several things, so you can visit on the way to the Budapest Zoo, the Vajdahunyad Castle or the Szechenyi Spa/Baths. It does not take long to visit, but worth a look!
Hungarian Kings. Doesn't take long, but completely worth the effort just for the wonderful views around the square and the very cool Hungarian Kings lining the edges.

lovely site. An impressive square no doubt!... Close to Szechenyi, the largest Spa in Budapest and adjacent to a great Information centre, where you can get tickets for various venues. Also adjacent to Varosliget, beautiful, large open air ice skating rink with cafe-restaurant. Should not miss.

Monument of the Hero. I believe this square is monuments built for all Hungary Heroes.
The square is quite big and impressive.
It is located close to Vajdahunyad Castle and around it there are a lot of beautiful buildings.
30 mins is more than enough spending time in this square.

worth seeing. Huge statues at the top of Andrassy av- it is on the yellow metro line and easy to reach from the centre by changing at the main station. On the left is the national museum of fine arts and on the right is the national gallery. A park is behind which is beautiful to explore in the summer.

A review of hungarian history. A trully interesting monument, for the 1.00o years of the creation of Hungary. We visited Budapest on a group organised basis. The tour guide was excellent, presenting to us the importance of the emblematic statues in the Heroes Square, featuring the great Hungarian leaders. A must- see in Budapest. On the opposite site the wonderful Museum of Fine Arts, the Museum fo Contemporary Art and close to all of them the Zoo!

Big and Grand. Try not to miss this, but don't overly stress if you do. It is a big, grand, open square. Bordering on epic even. I went in early evening and the crowds seemed mostly gone, allowing me some great pictures. Vajdahunyad Castle is right around the corner also, and the rest of the park nearby has lots of playgrounds in case you are with children.

Interesting place. Located near the pretty Varosliget castle, Heroes Square itself represents a landmark of Budapest.. but, places like this are not that attractions which make the city so nice.. they are just some side parts of the city. Therefore, I would recommend visiting it just if you have more than 4 days in Budapest..

One of the most famous landmarks of Budapest. Situated at the end of Andrassy utca, this massive square stands a proud homage to the great leaders in Hungarian history. Equally impressive at day and night.
Whole history with historical statues.. A must visit place in Budapest. You will be amazed on how bog they are and how the whole view of them comes together.

Magnificent. We travelled by metro to Heroes Square and weren't disappointed. Make sure you walk through to the outdoor ice rink and the Architecture Museum too. The buildings are fascinating. There's a lovely little Italian Restaurant I can't remember the name of right by the main road - Can recommend the Ravioli and the Canelloni.

Important landmark to see while visiting Budapest. Prior to my trip, when I first saw pictures of Heros Square, it didn't seem like a place that I would be interested in seeing. When we finally showed up with our tour group on a rainy day, the square and the buildings/park immediately surrounding the area are very worthy of your time and exploration.The statutes are very impressive in person and for photographers, the angles, the light make for some pretty great photography. there is also a nearby bridge, park and historical buildings that will make this area fun to see.

Feel like a Hero. Heroes Square May not offer much... but the surroundings of the square definitely Yes.Where do you find a huge place packed with people, all beaming with exhibitions around? Only at heroes square.Around Heroes square, there is a oldest zoo, there are thermal baths, there are exhibitions and there are corporate offices.There is a huge Sand clock too. It has a story which I distinctly remember now. There are consulates near to Heroes square.Heroes square has museums around. Sculptures at the square are beautifully carved.You will love it when you visit. You can dance sing roll in your own way!
A nice large square. There's really nothing to see apart from some statues but a must visit during your stay as it figures some important Hungarian monuments and personalities.
night walk. large and monumental, surrounded with two museums, a great green park, a castle, a zoo, situated at the end of Andrassy boulevard

Huge and imposing. Great to get a taste of what happened here and the "gates" and statues are massive. Still used for protests to this day - worth having wander around as the architecture in the nearby streets is beautiful
Nothing to see, really - but the Kunsthalle museum was nice. Large space with nothing really to see. But a great art museum/gallery. But I understand that it's a historic place.

Nice thing to see... Its a nice thing to see while sightseeing... some of the details on the statues are truly amasing when viewing from upclose... Its one of the things that you must see when in Budapest, especially if you are traveling low-cost, since you dont have to pay for fee. Also, if you come on a summer day, its fantastic just to buy a drink, sit on the side and watch all the different people sightseeing Budapest... Also, there is a beautiful park behind the square, where you can chill for the whole day...

History on a square. A huge square that has the statues of important Hungarian lords and kings such as King Stephen who brought Christianity to the country. In the middle there is the 36m tall Millennium Monument built to mark the 1000 years of the arrival of the Magyar tribes to now known Hungary. On the base of this monument you can see the horseback statues of the seven Hungarian leaders and on the top the Archangel Gabriel holding the double cross and the holy hungarian crown. On the left side across the street is the museum of fine arts and on the right the art hall. A must see for the lovers of history and arts!

A little out of the way but well worth it. Visited Budapest for New Year. Found Heroes square a very impressive place. There is museums and parkland nearby including a very large Outdoor Ice Rink that was about the size out two football pitches. The statues at Heroes square are amazing.
Magnificent. The Heroes Square is a magnificent place showing all the greatest of the Hungarian history. Monumental and beautiful.

Towering Statues. The hotel where we were staying on the first day of our stay in Budapest is just a walking distance from the Herous Square. It is nice to take a night stroll on the square which was well illuminated at night.

Hero's Square. This is a site definitely best seen by approaching via the (yellow) metro line which stops here. As you walk up the steps from the metro the entire (large) square opens before you. Very impressive.
Majestic. The night view is awesome and stunning. Such a beautiful city rich in architectural heritage. Love my stay in Budapest!

Heroes Square. We visited the square as part of a visit to the city park and thermal baths. The statues are amazing in prescence and commemorate ancient and more modern chieftains and leaders. The square is the gateway to the park which currently houses an ice rink, zoo and thermal baths. Might be useful to do a tour first to get an idea of why these people are important in Hungarian history but the sheer scale of the monument is to be admired.

Amazing space and detail. We toured this twice, once with a private tour operator and once with the Viking River Cruise City tour guide. From a bus you can't appreciate the size of the space and sculptures. The purpose and story for each sculpture is too much for the quick bus tour, but does give you an overview. If you plan to see this, it would certainly pay to do a little research first in order to appreciate what you are seeing.

Meh. This place didn't do much for me. It's a huge concrete park with about 12-14 statues up so high on a concrete base that it's hard to tell one from another. Not much in the neighborhood to make this a worthwhile destination. Way too much other better stuff to see and do in Budapest.

Awe inspiring Statues...... I loved this square! There was something excellent about the huge bronze statues of the Kings who defended this area over many years and loved this(these) city so much. I look forward to learning more about this history and that is what makes any attraction special, the fact that it leaves me wanting more.

All about the hungaryan people. This is a monument where you can learn about the oldies and recent times. In fact the youngers dont want to build monuments to the deads, they want to go ahead with proud of the pass. development, knowledge, work and faith... congrats Hungary! That's a long long history to tell and teach!

Wow. We came to Heroes Square and it took us around half hour to see all the statues and to make a pictures. The place is very huge and beautiful. From there we walked threw the park and came to Agriculture museum where we saw Anonymous statue.

So many Statues. What an amazing square honoring so many important people in the history of this city. There was a celebration going on at the time we were there with a wreath being placed in the square. We were not really sure of the occasion, but it was exciting watching the proceedings with the military unit.

A great visit. We stumbled upon this square by accident thinking we were walking in the opposite direction. If we had known about it though we would have definitely visited intentionally. The surrounding area is nice to so definitely worth a day trip here.

Magnificient. An open square with typical european architecture. One can take a leisurely walk around the attractions nearby. There is an artificial ice skating place where there are plenty of locals and visitors trying out their skills even in dancing. Give it a try if sure of not falling!. Not far away are the famous Hungarian baths and also the Zoo. Over all a worthy place to visit and spend some time looking around.
Hungarian History. Our perfect guide used the heroes in the square to explain the history from the first king Steven it is amazing how the heroes shaped Hungarian fate

A little disappointing. The square is surrounded by fairly busy, major roads, and the crossing facilities are not the best to get to it. Wonderful architecture and sculptures to see. The so-called "fairytale" castle was a disappointment, rather grey and uninspiring. There was a huge ice-rink next to the square, used by hundreds of people - and I didn't see one person fall over!
Huge Square. It's OK to visit. There are some museums around the square. Worth enough to stop by and spend some times there,
Huge and the traffic is crazy there. We passed it after visiting Zoo. It is big, it is magnificent, but after a minute, you're ready to move on=).
Huge. Lovely walk to the Heroe's Square. It is a huge monument having the nation's greatest people all around.

Proud. Hungary has every reason to hold its head high--invaders from the Turks to the Russians! This square lies at the end of the 'embassy avenue' of preserved noble town houses (reminded me a bit of New Orleans for some reason). Must sees include the fairy tale Fishermans cottage--more of a castle really--and experiencing the thermal baths--at least admire the entrance even if you do not go further. Wide and spacious, makes a nice quiet area within the city. Recommend getting one of the hop on/off passes as this takes you there.

heroes square. Must see attraction, at the end of andrassy street. About 15 min walk from city centre. Huge square kept immaculately clean, large central column with a statue of the angel gabriel , at the top then two colonades of statues of hungarian heroes to the rear of the column, also large statues at base of column. either side of the square are classically built buildings that i think house museums. To the rear of the square is a very large ice rink that is popular with the locals, further on you find the thermal spa & budapest zoo.

Awe inspiring place .... We walked here all the way from Chain Bridge, via the Shoes Holocaust Memorial, Parliament and the Ronald Regan Statue, a round trip of ten miles or so. It's an extraordinary place, containing wonderful sculpture, and the 'unknown warrior's tomb'. Walking towards it along Andrassy Utca gives the best view. It comprises an enormously large column in the middle, atopped by a King (Matthias?) on horse back, with many more statues of significant figures in Hungarian history on either side set into elegant colonnades that run left and right from the central column. A wide open space is before it. The whole area was built to celebrate the 1900 'millennium' and also comprises the wonderful buildings on either side, the outdoor ice rink - the largest in Europe and a lovely medieval looking castle built to house exhibitions. While in the area, there are many other things to see. The Thermal Baths, Zoo, the park, several museums and of course the ice rink. The underground can be taken to get here if no time to walk.

Great place to go. We got off our hop on-hop off bus tour here and were pleasantly surprised. Walk around a little and you discover a huge ice rink with lots of accomplished skaters and surrounded by beautiful buildings. Then walk through the park to the building holding the thermal spa's. Pop in and you can see the people in the spa. We will be going in next time. Wonderful.

HUGE !!!. Heroes' Square is absolutely fantastic. The whole area is huge. The statues are likened to those at the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin. The main statue is directly in the centre of the Square and is really tall. You need to walk away from this to get the best view. Each side of this are semi-circular colonnades with heroes from Magyar history. On the opposie sides of the Square stand the Palace of Arts and the Museum. Behind this amazing site is the Winter Palace - now an ice rink and just across a small bridge the famous swimming baths with saunas ans all different types of hydros and spas.

Well worth a walk. We walked from the Danube all along the UNESCO street to Heroes Square which is vast and right in the centre if the public entertainment sector. Great for photos and important for all Hungarians.

No wonder Madonna and Michael Jackson visited here. Absolutely stunning square in the heart of Budapest the statues are fantastic and they are worth the visit alone never mind the park and the zoo and the castle you have too go with your camera and get lost in the vastness of the square

The Famous Hero Square. Beautiful square dedicated to the Hungarian emperors. Go by metro to get in into the 2º oldest metro line in the world. Walk one by one emperors sculptures and after it take a breath on Varosliget city park.

Beautiful square. Before arriving I'd say it is well worth reading up on the 19th century's great leaders and important people of hungary. Sadly there are no plaques to explain the different statues. That would have been a plus. But it is a beautiful square non the less.

Impressive. This was on our bucket list of things to see in Budapest. We were not disappointed. The area with the monument is huge and you don't feel crowded. It is not easy to find as it is out of the city center but don't let that deter you. You will appreciate the memorial as it is intended the honor those that lost their lives defending freedom.

Worth a visit. The Heroes Square and the surrounding area are well worth a visit. There are a collection of thing to see in the area including the square itself .You have the ice rink (boating lake in summer) the castle buildings zoo, pleasure park and the thermal baths all within a few hundred metres.The thermal baths are worth a visit even if your not going for a dip.

interesting. I will tell you my review might be clouded by the fact that the skies had opened and pounding rain for the 3 days I was in Budapest. What I could see of the square it was nice and large, I had no real need to get closer. There were two huge museums on either side and that was where my attention went. The square even in the rain looked clean and well kept. I would not go out of my way to visit but on a sunny day perhaps a stroll around the square would be nice

Very large impressive square. The square is very large and impressive with beautiful monuments. It is well worth stopping by and taking in all in. The square has 2 art museums on each side that you can visit once you are done walking around. The Fine Arts Museum houses most of the country's international fine art. Very worth going down to this area.

Impressed. A large open square with massif bronze statues, the guide book will tell you why. From the centre it's 2.3km along embassy street, so you window shop going out have a drink at the top and use the metro on the way back. Or you carry on to the park and zoo.

Iconic sight, but not much to see. Not my first choice to reccommend to tourists here, but since it is on the way to Városliget, you might as well check it out. Since traffic goes through the square, you will note noise and exhaust pipe smells. It's pretty enough for a quick glance.

its a monument. as far as monuments go its a pretty darn good ol' monument its big its pretty and its BIG ! we were on our way to Szechenyi Baths having walked the entire length of andrassy street we didnt really pay attention to it but on the way back we stopped and there were a bunch of people playing Frisbee and couple of families with their kids its a nice place even if your not too big on history when you stand infront of the central monument at a certain distance theres a point that all 3 parts will kinda connect which is nice just keep your imagination open and youll have fun looking at it
Amazing. This is somewhere that has so much space in the centre of the roadway but a tranquil experience. So many roads leading from here, and the park is so close too.

Massive mausoleum memories!. We visited this at night and it was a treat - impressively floodlit and empty of people. It is huge though, a vast well-maintained memory of heroes. The old M1 Metro line was well worth the ride to get there; and we watched the skaters in City Park and then headed to Gundels for dinner.Recommended for an evening outing.

Majestic. It's big! On the day we visited it felt a bit like Trafalgar Square minus the crowds and the pigeons! It's a must see and the park, museums, galleries, spa and ice rink (in December) surround the square so there's plenty to do in the vicinity.

Neat Square. This square was fun to visit. The kings that lined the monument were fascinating, especially with the Pocket Guide - Budapest app. My wife and I took the walk down Andrassy Avenue from our hotel along the river. It was an easy and flat walk and there were a lot of other things to see along that walk. Each were pointed out on that Pocket Guide app. The app also talked about each of the kings that were in the monument, which was also interesting.

A must. This square is magnificent and grandiose. Arrive here with the Kisföldalatti (aka M1) which was the first underground in continental Europe. After looking at the marvellous statues, you can have a stroll in the park. Rent out a boat at the nearby artificial lake during the summer months or skate for a while in the winter. And if the weather is bad, visit the two adjacent museums: The Museum of Fine Art and the National Museum.
fantastic. beautiful architecture to feast your eyes on.Was raining when we were ther but still amazing to see.puts our architecture to shame in this day and age.

Heroes' Square. Heroes' Square (or Hősök tere in Hungarian) is one of the most-visited attractions in Budapest. Many tourists arrive here by metro, an attraction in itself: the M1 metro line that stops at Heroes' Square is one of the world's oldest (it opened in 1896) and has even been declared a World Heritage Site. Both Heroes' Square and Városliget, the adjoining city park, were created at the end of the nineteenth century to commemorate the thousandth anniversary of the Magyar conquest of Hungary in 895. Since many of the attractions weren't ready in time the festivities were held one year late, in 1896. The square only received its current name in 1932, three years after the completion of the Millennium Monument.Since its creation Heroes' Square has been the site of numerous special events, including many Socialist holiday celebrations staged during the country's Communist era. In 1989 it was the site of the ceremonial reburial of Imre Nagy, leader of the uprising against the Soviet occupation in 1956.Millennium MonumentAt the center of Heroes' Square stands the Millennium Monument, designed in 1894 by Albert Schickedanz and completed thirty-five years later. The many statues were designed by György Zala.Soaring above Heroes' Square is the Millennium Column, the focal point of the Millennium Monument. The column is topped with a statue of the archangel Gabriel. Behind the column is a semicircular colonnade with statues of famous men who made their mark on Hungarian history. Statues atop the colonnades symbolize War, Peace, Work and Welfare, and Knowledge and Glory. Around the base of the monument are a number of equestrian statues honoring the seven chieftains of the Hungarian tribes who, led by Árpád, conquered the area now known as Hungary.

For the History Buff!. This is an interesting stop on a tour IF you are a real history buff.Lots of info about the great generals in Hungary's history but it was sad to me. There are gypsies walking around trying to sell sweaters and belts etc. our tour guide told us not to buy, that they were cheap quality, but I sort of wanted to anyway.

The giant can opener. I don't wish to be considered disrespectful, but our guide said everyone thinks it looks like a giant can opener, that's all I could see. (we took a tour of the city...highly recommend the get on/get off tour) We visited this statue by walking up the mildly challenging path/stairs from the lower part of the hill, and recommend that. Hint: if you are interested in purchasing some embroidery, the woman at the top of the hill has better prices than the woman at the top.

Not a lot to see, but better go to see it. It's the kind of place I don't think there is a lot to explore, but it is somehow the top attraction of the city, so it's better to just go and have a look. The park near it is nice tho.

Hero's square-Budapest. Nice square-very typical of Eastern European cities. Incredible statues, but do a bit of research first to get the true picture of them. Budapest Opera House across the street-amazing architecture. Budapest is a magnificent city-actually 2 cities-Buda on one side of river, and Pest on other side. Don't miss Gellert Hill at night-the view is stunning-city and bridges are all lit up.

Steeped in history. . I love places like this, great monumental structure, historical figures and loads of history surrounding it, for me as breathtaking as the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin. Spent about half and hour here, taking photos, would of liked to have stayed longer if the weather was better.

World Heritage Site. This is a huge square with various statues, all of whom have a special place in the history of Hungary. In the center of the statuary is the Millennium Column. In front of that appears to be something like a tomb to the unknown soldier (but I don't speak/read/understand Hungarian). We were with a group from a cruise ship and were advised by our guide not to purchase things from the locals who "came out of the woodwork" as soon as our bus pulled up.
Great to see. Not much to do but a great stop off for some pictures when on one of the city bus tours and also right next to the Rembrant museum.It's a must see being part of Budapest history

Many of the most important personalities of Hungarian history. If you happen to have someone to tell you the stories about these statues of the outstanding people of Hungary you are going to have a rough idea about the past (and bit of the present) of Hungary. From left to the right in chronology and on the middle the famous pagan tribe chieftains who occupied the territory of Hungary AND the symbols of Christianity...Behind Heroes' Square there is a big lovely park with several things to see and enjoy.
Not my cup of tea. If you like statues it isnt to bad not my thing but if your passing that way might as well take a look

Square brimming with national history. This is the type of monument you can find throughout Eastern Europe, but Heroes Square tops most monuments I have seen. It is worth your time to look at the depictions of all the great Hungarian kings, even if you know nothing about their history like me. The monument in the middle and the empty space before it are quite striking. Best seen at night, when the plaza is lit up and free of most tourists.

Beautiful square. This is a very majestic square, especially at night under the lights. Research what each of the many statues mean prior to your visit and you'll have a deeper connection to the heros honoured throughout history. Even if you don't know who the statues represent, it's worth taking a moment to look at the brilliant artistry found in the statues. It really is a lovely square. Once you've seen it take a walk through the park just behind it. I walked all the way up Andrassy Ave which was a nice hike but you can also catch the hoop bus or the metro - both will take you right there. I liked the walk from Karoly Krt, as it gave me time to take in the shops along Andrassy and also see some of the more upscale architecture found in the apartments and houses as you approach the square.

Take a look, stay longer here, youth jump !. it is the huge open space, even without any bench or chair ha ha, but believe me I sit in their stone floor, is very clean and cool ! ;)).Prepare your cameras, mobile phones because it great for photo, this place sure photo-able, many object like building, buises and ofcourse statues, wonderful of Heroes costumed statues.For youth, take your pavourite style, jump !, shout ! ha ha yess it is also suitable for you
Huge square. It's a huge square in the top of Andrassy avenue! You can find there musems and a garden behind it...

lots of statues. The first time we went here was on our own and it just looked like a bunch of statues...but a couple days later we returned with a Viking River Cruises tour guide and those statues all of a sudden had meaning that you can't glean simply by looking at them. A lot of history in Heroes Square and worth a visit.

stunning and very near a beautiful park. the square is lovely a bit far out - we got there using the hopon and hop off bus. its right beside the main spa Széchenyi Thermal Bath which looked good (although we didn't visit) and beside a fab museum which has lovely grounds. worth a wee walk around
Quick walk through. Nice roundabout. Good for a few photis and a quick break but can be seen easily whilst in the zoo and caatle area.

Heroes Square. This is a nice monument to see, we saw it whilst on the hop on hop off bus, was going to get off but didnt appear to be much else around the area ie cafes, bars restaurants so better to stay on the bus and view it from there

A nice review of hungarys history through larger than life sculptures. This outdoor square is very impressive,spacious ,clean and attractive. However there is no written information available so if you don't have a tour guide along make sure you take a tour guide book or audio guide. The history of the empire goes waaaaay back. There is also as tomb and monument for the unknown soldier with uniformed guards on duty.

Historical Square.. I remember walking around the Square quite a bit looking at the monuments and reading my guidebook about the historical significance of the Square in Hungary when visiting in 2006 ... it was fascinating ... but as noted in other reviews there were a lot of peddlers and it gets annoying. So maybe there are better options in Hungary.

One of the most awe inspiring things I have ever seen. Walk up the street towards the square rather than catching the underground to the nearest station and preferably do it in the evening as the square is lit up. It is perhaps one of the most amazing sights I have seen. Its very difficult to explain until you see if for yourself with your own eyes. The best analogy I can provide is when I first set eyes on the Golden Temple or the Taj Mahal or seeing lions in Ngorongoro Crater.

Such history!. Heroes' Square is an enormous square flanked by the Museum of Fine Arts and the Kunsthalle (Hall of Art). The Szechenyi Baths is close by (worth a visit) as is the City Park. Within the square is the Millennium Monument with the Archangel Gabriel at the top of a column and a salute to the Magyar tribes of Hungary in the form of amazing bronzes of the chieftains and their horses. On the colonnades on either side are bronzes of past kings and other important people, all exquisitely detailed. The tomb of an executed Hungarian Prime Minister, Imre Nagy, is also there.We didn't experience any pedlars selling goods.
Hungarian history. End of Andrassy Ave. Sculptures of Hungarian rulers.Many peddlers of umbrellas ( it was raining ), embroidery,warm clothes.They swarm around the tourists taking pictures!

Impressive. this square is just... BIG!It's impressive and you can get lost in this. You arrive there after a long walk through what they say it's the best street of the city (don't agree, by the way), and while approaching it you get the impression of the dimension of this square. When there, you really feel small and all those statues looking at you... Wow! I looked at the Arcangelo Gabriel and felt just a very small human...

Beautiful Historical Square. This is a large square with statues of numerous Hungarian heroes. It's a very interesting place especially with a knowledgeable Tour Guide. There is also the Hungarian Tomb of The Unknown Soldier. If you love history then possibly this place is well worth the visit. Whilst in the square, have a look over to the Kunsthalle that holds Contemporary Art Exhibitions. The beautiful gilded columns and painting above the entrance were paid for by Michael Jackson as he used Heroes Square to shoot a video!

Amazing renovation. Consider replacing all of the stone! What a feat! Stroll around and enjoy the immensity of the project. The amble on to the president palace where you may catch a glimpse of him or he may even engage you in conversation.

Feeling the history. If you are standing at the centre of this extremely beautifull square ang looking around you can have an impression of Hungary and Hungarians. On the middle of square is a tall column surranded at the foot with heroes leading Hungarian tribes to this area, on the top of the column is an angel, who save Hungarians.Behind a half circle divided by two and having our heroes, kings, leaders, important politics!With two worlds - must see!
Most iconic square in Budapest. This is a must visit place in Budapest. The square is quite vast and the statues are quite bold. It makes for a great photo-op.

Statues of Heroes. To the Hungarians heroes come in all forms. They use this square to memorialize men in history with statues. It is best to use a guide or audio so that the historical relevance is shared. Other museums are in the area but square itself requires less than an hour.
Impressive. We walked down Andrassy St to get to the square its all very impressive we went back at night as well looks even better

National Gallop. The best thing about Heroes Square is that we were there for the National Gallop. This is a 3 day event of horse races (some with chariots) between mostly Arab countries, with much pomp, ceremony and gold braid. Go early to get a ticket and a seat. The street market that sprawls out from the square during this event is also fun; food and crafts that are unique to the city.

Interesting and good base to explore the area. It's a good base to start exploring the near by attractions including the Zoo, Haydahunyad Castles, couple of museums and art galleries, several baths and further down the Transport Museum. I particularly like to take night photos here or watch people play with kites.

Can be given a miss.. Its a big square with statues of Hungarian heroes. Its a good place but if you are running short of time in your tour you can give this a miss. If you love history then maybe this place is worth the visit. People may approach you selling branded phones at a very cheap price; DO NOT buy it as they are fake.Nearby this square is a nice park where you can take a stroll or use it as a picnic spot.

Great sightseeing. There is a kind of majesty about Heroes Square which you can sense even if you don't know the story behind the statues. It is worth a look during a visit to the city. It also works as a gateway to City Park, which is fantastic for a stroll and a picnic with picturesque woods, a lake, and several attractions.

Worth the Visit. This is a captivating collection of statues of centuries of Hungarian heroes and well worth seeing. We all were fascinated by the history represented there and the reverence the hungarian people have for this place. If you go there spend some time exploring the nearby park and the other attractions in the area such as the spa, the skating rink and an interesting museum depicting castles through the ages. Afterwards, a walk back towards the Danube along Andrássy út which is lined with what were probably mansions years ago; now they are embassies is worthwhile. At 60 Andrássy Street, is the House of Terror former home of the Gestapo and later the communist secret police, another interesting place to see.

It's a big square...... This is a lovely square with lots of statues of mustachioed Hungarian rulers. It's expansive but there isn't anything too entertaining there. Although, the day we were there we did see the changing of the gaurd at the tomb of the unknown soilder. I would see it if you are interested but you won't need to spend too much of your time there. There are some public restrooms behind the museum that flanks the square. Bring some change!

Expansive. I have seen the Red Square in Moscow and the Palace Square in Saint Petersburg, the Grand Place in Brussels, Belgium, and Old Town Square in Prague. Heroes Square is worth a mention among these great sites. It holds the Tomb of the unknown soldier, and the grave of Imre Nagy, who fought against soviets in the 1956 revolution and was later executed in 1958.

Hero's Square, Budapest. The Hero's Square is located at the end of Embassy Avenue. It was a nice walk from our hotel along the avenue. I am surprised how clean the streets are. The square is large with many tourists taking pictures of the soldiers statue.

Impressive Square. This is a pretty vast square with some impressive monuments. It’s a nice place to wander around for a little bit and admire the monuments. It’s a great photo stop also. It’s a little further out than other attractions but it easily reached by subway

Magnificent. This is a fantastic sight to see. Including the surrounding buildings (of which one was renovated through funding by Michael Jackson in return for filming his video history in the location). A must see

Historical Spot. Worth spending some time wandering around this vast square and studying the monuments. Afterwards you can go into the park, as far as the baths or go to the zoo, all of which are nearby.
Large Open Square. Spacious open square with some stunning monuments and pillars. Busy road around it but still a grand place to be

Epic History!!. The sheer history that is represented by this square makes visiting worth while!! It is quite epic to walk around and look at the statues. It shows the Hungarian people really are a proud bunch!! Fantastic place to spend an hour or two relaxing in the good weather!

Lovely place to explore.. Got off the bus and explores this area, statues are enormous and have such amazing detail on them.
Worth a visit
Stunning in the sun!. Although not usually a fan of statues, the powerful presence of the heroes under a beautiful sun lit sky was stunning! We were captivated by them and took photos to match!
Worth your time. Spent an hour here. We went to honour the heroes and found the park areas just as good for a stroll and our time

site of our first run abroad. Awesome statues and amazing start to our first run abroad. The city park at rear of square is well worth a visit and is well used by locals as well as visitors. Budapest certainly knows how to organise a large running event very impressed and would definitely recommend to others
Impressive. Impressive large area, with monuments and galleries around. At the end of the UNESCO noted Andrássy street. Surely has to be a 'must do' in Budapest.

Fabulous Statues. This is a lovely big open plaza style square with a curved portico of statues of honored heroes. The square is beautiful and clean, very open and inviting. Lots of space for visitors to roam around and view the display. A lovely place to visit while in Budapest.

Large and impressive . This is a large and impressive square. It's definitely worth visiting while in budapest. We were there when the marathon was taking place so it was very busy in the area. There was also a beer festival nearby which was fun.

Impressive monuments and huge public square. The square lies at the end of Andrassy street and contains statue structures containing the sculptures of Hungarian Kings and other important national leaders over the centuries. On the left and right of the square are also the museum of fine art and the palace of art. The square also lies at the start of the public park, an expansive area that includes a huge public bath house, a zoo and other attractions.

Wonderful to See.. Right at the end of Andrassey ut, you can't miss the Millenary Monument, It stands high in the middle of Heroes square. The surrounding semicircle of statues of Hungarian history, include King Stephen and Lajos Kossuth. A wonderful sight, not to be missed. Take your camera for good shot's to keep. Well worth the walk, as we did on a beautiful sunny day. Walk into the city park behind the square, and enjoy the other sights to be had. We had a coffee at the cafe beside the lake and chilled out. We felt safe whilst there, as there were plenty other people doing the same as us, having a nice time.

This place has it!. Heroes square has its own atmosphere. Standing in the middle - you feel magnificence of this place. We were lucky that the sun was shining, so we sat down and enjoyed this place looking at some guys doing freeride biking next to us.

Best of both worlds. Hosok Tere has a relaxing feeling. When you look at the cozy looking apartments and offices surrounding the square, you can easily visualise yourself there after retirement. What I, my partner and my mum found fascinating was, it felt so safe and almost deserted despite the fact that it is very much the focal point of a capital city in Europe.

A big Square with Statues. Sure they are "Hungarian Heroes", but this is just a big square with statues. They are pretty spectacular statues, especially the invading Mongols in the center (Those are heroes?). What I liked is that the statues have changed over the years to reflect the current view of what is a hero. The "heroes' from the communist era have been removed and moved out of town to Memento Park, and replaced with more recent heroes. Worth a visit if you are in the neighborhood, but don't plan a long time for your visit.

Filled with statues. Interested in a bit of history and have an inclination towards statues and sculptures then yes this a great place for you, if not then this is just a big square with statues all around and nothing that requires your extensive travelling.

Impressive Square. Its a very impressive square built depicting the 7 Magyar Chieftains. The square is on the edge of the Andrassy Avenue and is flanked by museums on both the side. We visited the square during the night time and were rather surprised to see it completely deserted - we couldn't quite make out why that was the case - as its quite superb and a wonderful sight to state the obvious.The easiest way to get to it from the city centre is to walk along the Andrassy Avenue or if you are not too keen then you can take the Line 1 to the Hosok Ter - which is right in front of the square itself.The square has been witness to a number of important landmarks of Hungarian history and has a story to tell of its own.

Heroes square ....... OK !!.
