Seriously, if you paid to do this you will feel ripped off !It is readily available via all of the methods of transport in Budapest in minutes and the walk to the gardens and Castle takes only minutes. Transport tickets which cover rail, tram and bus are cheap and easy, enjoy the ambience of this beautiful city without the bull...t !!

A square with statues.. We were a bit disappointed. I'm not sure if we had such high expectations for the place.. But it wasn't really that great. It's a square with some statues.. If you've been ti Macedonia (Skopje) this is nothing. They have statues everywhere. I dont even notice statues anymore.. Anywho, if you're in to statues and stuff this might be a place for you.. You've to decide for yourself. But I wouldn't say that you miss out on anything if you skip this place.
Must do. If combined with a visit to Szehcenyi bath, Museum of Fine Arts or a walk down beautiful Andrassy utca Heroes Square blows me away every time.
Impressive square and statues. Impressive square at one end of Andrassy Avenue by the entrance to City park. An imposing array of historical statues and a good photo opportunity.

what a square. when you step there... you got the feeling that you are travelling back in time, very nice square with numerous statues, each one represent an historical figure of Hungary, this landmark can be visited day and night where you can shoot some great pictures. don't miss it

Don't miss this Propitious landmark. This historical site was built at the turn of the 20th century (1900) as a millennium monument to commemorate the Hungarian kingdom which started by the Arpad Dynasty in the year 896. One can’t disregard the time mismanagement of this project which should have started early enough to be completed by 1896 and NOT 1900, but then again who’s counting. This spectacular site is absolutely gratis to the public and it’s easily accessible by the public transportation, but you ought to visit the site in a sunny to avoid penurious photo experience. Here are some high level description of the site: In the front of the monument is the ornamental chained cenotaph dedicated to the patriotic individuals who fought and died for the independence of Hungary. There are statues of the leaders of the seven Hungarian tribes that formed Hungary in the 9th century. There are two colonnades each with seven statues of Hungarian historical figures such as King Stephen I, the king Bella IV, general Matthias Corvinus and so on. Topping the outer edge of the left colonnade is a statue of a man with a scythe and a woman sowing seed, representing Labor and Wealth. At the inner top edge of the left colonnade is a male figure driving a chariot using a snake as a whip representing War. On the facing end of the right colonnade is a female figure in a chariot holding a palm frond representing Peace. In the corresponding position on the top of right colonnade is a statue of a man holding a little golden statue and a woman with a palm frond representing Knowledge and Glory. Directly behind the cenotaph is a column topped by a statue of the archangel Gabriel. In his right hand, the angel is holding the crown of St. Stephan, the first king of Hungary, in his left hand the angel holds a two barred apostolic cross, a symbol awarded to St Stephan by the pope in recognition of his effort to convert Hungary to Christianity. Behind the cenotaph within the decorative chain, is a flat bronze plate which marks the site of artesian well whose drilling was completed in 1878. The well provides water for the Széchenyi baths behind the monument and the Dagály baths. The well is 971 meter deep and produces 831 liters of water per minute at 74 degrees Celsius.

Great history. Walking up Andrussy St, you begin to glimpse the statues of Heroes Sq, and it is squite pectacular once you arrive. Don't be guilted into attending the Museum of Fine Arts once you arrive, it's completely unspectacular in terms of their viewings.

A landmark steeped in history.. This is what it says on the tin. A square with statues. An interesting thing to see day and night. But unless your a super history buff then this landmark wouldn't be missed if you didn't visit it.

mixed blessings. Heroes square in the city is huge and the figures of the seven kings of the Magyar tribes are impressive and are dominated by the 36metre high statue of the archangel Gabriel holding the crown of ST Stephen the first king of Hungary.

A local square with a bunch of statues. THis is one of many squares that are found in the city with statues in them. I have no idea what they are but if I could read Hungarian then probably make a good guess. I did not spend a lot of time here but diid take a number of pictures as it is attractive. There are food stalls around and a few restaurants dotting the perimeter to chose from.
Impressive - but. in my opinion nothing that extremely special. The statues and the way they present it is really beautiful and cool though. Definitely worth a watch.

Good. Heroes square in the city of Budapest is huge and is surrounded by tall columns and statues. These statues are related to the history of Budapest and you need a guide to help you understand the importance of this location. You don't need to spend too much time here. It's a good place for nice pictures and must do.

national gallop. We happened to be in Budapest whilst this was on, we paid 3000 huf for a grandstand seat . great location and surroundings. Good friendly fun also large festival happening down the main street which was pedestrianised

National Gallop takes over Heroes Square. Horse riders in traditional Hungarian garb take over Heroes Square during the National Gallop in September. Racing around the sand-filled square, they prove their skills to the delight of the cheering crowds. A must-see for all ages!

Special weekend. This is not my first weekend in Budapest, but I was lucky to be here this weekend as there was a fabulous series of events going on at the Heroes Square (horses), the park (meat festival) and on Andrassy avenue.Otherwise, the Heroes square can be a little austere, but impressive nevertheless. Great museums on either side!

Very impressive Square. This location is very impressive, dominated by the huge column and statues in the middle.The square is surrounded by two art museums, one for contemporary art, the other fine art.The square makes a natural meeting point as it's so well known.It's used for many public events throughout the year including concerts and a horse race!The City zoo is right next to the square which is ideal for adults and children alike

Fantastic statues. You won't need to spend a lot of time here but a visit is worthwhile. There are some fantastic and imposing statues of people highly relevant to the country. A very good photo opportunity. It probably helps if you have some sort of guide - a person or a guidebook - to help explain the importance of the area and the statues.
Poignant. A nice memorial to the historical figures in the history of Hungary. It does not take long to see, but worth the stop

The statues in this square are magnificent. Heroes' Square is definitely worth a visit. The statues are beautiful and dramatic. There is a park near by as well as an amusement area.The scope of the square is immense. Great picture taking.
Great Experience!. We could not believe all the monuments in this Square. A wonderful place to learn about the history of Budapest. There is also a Farmer's Museum that we enjoyed.

Heroes' Square. There are several things to see close to this square. We took a couple of photos in the square and then walked to the Castle which is right opposite the street. I am not personally a big fan of monuments & statutes but i enjoyed my time there just the same so someone with such interests will definitely enjoy it the most!

A must see. This square is surrounded by the museums, monuments and art galleries (plus more) so must be seen. A great photo opportunity but a nice tourist trap. We didn't have any beggars or people trying to sell site seeing trips.

Breath taking statues. We were lucky to stay so close to the square because I would really have hated to miss this amazing place. it does get very busy, try and get there early or in the evening when its all lit up.
Spectacular. Wow, what a sight! Wish I had the chance to see this at night, a place of awe!1st and last stop on the Big Bus tour, definitely worth a visit

Heros square one of tallest rememberance of foundTion pf Budapest. One of tallest square in remembrance of foundation of Budapest , about 125 years ago . Beautiful place to visit , if u have time u can enjoy in boat viewing the beautiful hungry , one of place to must visit in budapest.

Wonderful, even on 3rd visit !. A huge square dedicated to the Magyar tribes leaders who came to this land and established the Hungarian state. In the front are the leaders and on the perimeter, the Kings and rulers of Hungary. Very impressive. To get there take the yellow underground, or take a slow walk (2.5 Km) via the Andrashi Blvd. On your way you will meet the opera house, the new terror museum and many beautiful buildings. If tired you may rest on the lovely liszt ferenc ter (square), not far from the opera, for a meal in the "Menza" restaurant, or in one of the many coffeehouses. Another option is to rest in the park, just beyond the square.

Impressive. As you approach the square from Andrassy Avenue you are struck by the tall column in the centre of the Millennium Memorial. The Archangel Gabriel is at the top of the column. Figures from Hungary's past stand between the pillars of the colonnade.The stroll along the whole length of Andrassy Avenue took approx. 15 minutes with plenty of shops and sites to see along the way.

One of my favorite squares in all of Europe. This is a bit of a different take of a square. It isn't in the city center, but rather at one end of an awesome park. Very neat statues representing figures from Hungary's long history adorn the area. Great photo ops. Make sure you save time for a stroll in the park. Allow a few hours at least. More if you go to the baths.

Nice place to start your Budapest exploration. This huge square is located at the end of Andrassy Avenue, and is a good place to start your walks around Budapest. There are two good museums on either side of the square. The statues are all very impressive but you'd need a good guide to talk through the history and significance, because otherwise you'd have no idea who these people were, and why they are commemorated here. The square itself is sparse, there is not much happening here apart from tourists taking pictures. It lacks the hustle and bustle of a city centre because geographically it is located further out from the main tourist hot spots, so you dont get that feel of being in the centre of things. There is nowhere decent to have food - the only places I could find were the small cafes on the porch of the two museums - overpriced and limited choice of sandwiches. There was no ambiance either to sit and have a nice beer etc, as from the porches the square's statues seem too distant and the views are spoilt by the traffic going around it. There is a good tourist information centre just behind the square.
Wow!. I loved Heroes Square. It is stunning and we got some great photo's. It is also flanked on either side by two beautiful museums.We spend half an hour here on our way to the zoo.

Amazing sculptures. (my cousin gave me the history details) . in the center are the seven figures representing the seven arpad tribes that started the magyar community. Behind in a semi circle stand the kings from st. Istvan to Mattias and more. The figures above are men and women in charriots holding bows in active poses. The figures were beautiful and strong. Always great to see
Impressive. Make sure you make a stop in the day and at night. Hero's Square is located next to a ton of the other sites around town so that should be fairly easy to accomplish.

Impressive. walked here from the main square as it's straight down Andrássy Avenue but you can easily get a bus or use the hop on hop off buses.You can see the main statue from quite far away and it makes an impressive site.On reaching the square there are two main sets of statues set into and on 2 large walls and a large statue in the center. There is a museum on each side of the square and the city park is just across the bridge behind the square.If you need help locating anything there is a tourist information center there as well.The zoo is about 400m to the left of the square.Since 2002 the Millennium Monument together with Andrássy Avenue is part of UNESCO's prestigious World Heritage sites.

Sweet - come here at night!. A friend and I took the metro to Hero's Square to look around. The place is really impressive and we were glad we came. We were there at night (it was dark, around 8/9pm) so it was pretty much empty and seeing it lit up in the dark looks great. We saw people climbing onto the main platform where the statues are, so we did too (although it's probably not allowed, so sorry) and got some good photos. The square itself is massive and the monuments are impressive to say he least. The metro located right at the foot of the square is also super convenient so if you're in Budapest, come here for sure, only I'd recommend coming at night!

Nice starting place. A semi-circle of statues commemorate key leaders and kings of the Hungarian peoples. Expansive. It's wise to have a guide or guide book to point out and explain some of the individuals memorialized in the late 1800's. A nearby street and plaza was the site of many anti-Soviet demonstrations before the collapse of the Iron Curtain.

Awesome. Had a coach visit to this attraction as you would need a guide to appreciate it. Statues are in abundance and it needs explaining. Plenty of photo shots to be made and well worth the visit when you visit one of the great cities in Europe. In my opinion Budapest is second to none.

hungarian history in a quick photo. Major square in Hungray. flanked with sculptures and a host to political events in the past. Great photo op and def don't need to much time to visit Heroe's square.

First stop on Walking Tours. Many walking tours of Budapest start here because it is a handy place to summarise Hungarian history. The statues along the colonnade at the back are notable Hungarian monarchs, starting with Stephen the First at the far left. The square was built when the city celebrated it's 1000th year since being founded, in 1896. The column in the middle is the Millennium Memorial. Angel Gabriel sits at the top while seven Magyar chieftains decorate the base. Hősök tere metro station opens direct onto the square. It sits at the end of Andrássy Avenue at the entrance to City Park.
Must See!. We visited Heroes' Square. The statues were very interesting to see. There is very limited parking. We traveled there by tour bus.
Heroes' Square. Wonderful place. Visited with a tour guide who introduced us to other parts of Budapest including National Opera House, Fishermen's Bastion and Matthias Church

Nice to see. Really interesting sight, we we enjoyed it. Definitely get a guide if you can who will explain it all, the only thing we didn't like is the traffic around it, but it's nice at night, a bit more peaceful. The nearby park is great, and on the square you can also rent out Beer-bikes (for those who look for a bit more fun).The main attraction is the Millennium Memorial. The base is characterised by the Seven Chieftains of the Magyars (who were first noted by Anonymus, who coincidently has his statue in the park nearby). The back of the monument is made up of two colonnades, each with seven statues representing Hungarian historical figures.On the left is the Museum of Fine Arts and on the right is the Hall of Art. It goes onto Andrássy Avenue which has two buildings looking at the square — one is residential and the other one is the embassy of Serbia. The attraction is definitely a must-see in Budapest.

Pretty Impressive. We used this as a center site for several walks around city. The statutes were grandly impressive, underscoring the sense of energy, adventure, exploration and violence of Hungary's early history and well executed artistically. Happened to be there for a Commissioning of recent Army Officers which was interesting as well.

Snap some memorable pics here. This monument is a great showcase of Hungary's heroes, military, civil and religious. It's flanked by the impressive Hall of Art (Kunsthalle Budapest) and the Museum of Fine Arts. No need to spend a ton of time here, but it's a fabulous spot for photos. It's also a stone's throw from Vajdahunyad Castle

Worth visiting. Good photo opp. It's a nice stop on a bus tour or similar. There is a very nice park nearby where we stopped and had a drink overlooking the ice skating rink. Worth a visit but don't need long there.

Well worth a visit. Heroes' Square is one the major squares in Budapest, Hungary, noted for its iconic statue complex featuring the Seven Chieftains of the Magyars and other important national leaders, as well as the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. The square lies at the outbound end of Andrássy Avenue next to City Park (Városliget). It hosts the Museum of Fine Arts and the Palace of Arts. The square has played an important part in contemporary Hungarian history and has been a host to many political events, such as the reburial of Imre Nagy (Communist politician executed for treason in 1958) in 1989. The Millenium Moment which is a well known landmark can also be found here. There is more than adequate parking adjacent to the square, just a short walk away.

A must visit. Nice lake and castle near this attraction. The heroes square is a fantastic place expecially at sunset time, when you can take nice pictures of it. Near the heroes square there is a beautiful lake and castle with a nice small bridge. If you are in a mood rend a boat :)

Quick Stop. We passed this square several times, there were lots of tourist, once we made a quick stop at the square & took a few pictures of the statues of Hungary's great leaders. It is a good location to wander as centrally located and flanked by the Fine Arts Museum. We did not spend much time there before moving on to our final destination.
Impressive. The striking monument. I recommend that you visit it at evening, when it is even more impressive thanks to well-placed spotlights
I love it. I'm a sucker for some history, and the name hero square immediately attracted me. It was a really open area and I really enjoyed the visit. Just along in some pictures and a walk around.
Lovely square. A must see…saw it daytime and night time, and would go back. No crowds, beautiful sights, wonderful sculptures!

Very impressive. The statues in this square are very impressive. The horsemen at the base of the column were worth an up close look. They were very ferocious looking. The angel Gabriel at the top was also very interesting. The cross had two cross bars. There were 14 statues, seven on each side. They were the leaders in chronicle order. Two of the statues on the colonnade represent War and Peace. They are quite beautiful.

Lovely Area. Lovely monument but nothing more than most. However, the area it is in is very spacious, nice to sit down and relax. At the end of one of the main roads in Budapest so easy enough to stroll down and see without being a chore, very close to the circus if you are going there anyway (which I highly recommend, but that's a different review...!)
Impressive monument!. to see once in a lifetime. Better if you know its connection to the history of Hungary. However, there are many similar monuments in the world.

It's not what's there, it's about how to get there. In my personal opinion, the monument in the square is impressive and very historical (if you know the history of Budapest, of course), however there is nothing much else. Yet, it's how to get there that is interesting. There are 3 routes to reach Heroes' square: 1) walking uphill the Andrassy Avenue, which is of course highly recommended as it is very beautiful, 2) taking the yellow old metro line, since it is super vintage (the car and the station), or 3) walking for 10 minutes from the Szechenyi Thermal Bath. Number 1 and 2 are highly recommended btw :)

Special, historical square. This was my 3rd visit to the square. I disagree with the previous comment that it's nothing special. If you know some of Hungary's history, it is very interesting to see the statues of the kings and heroes. The architecture is interesting and there is the museum on one side and the very beautiful castle (Vajdahunyad Castle) on the other side. This is a stop on the tour bus ride, and a famous site.

Worth seeing but nothing special. A huge square just at the end of Andrassy street. I recommend getting there by the oldest metro line in the city which have sweet, little wagons and beautiful stations. The monument is impressive but it's nothing special in general. If you're somewhere around or you're taking a bus tour you could give it a glimpse but nothing more.

Worth the trip there. If it was for the square itself I'd say it's probably not worth it, but there is so much more to see and do there. There is the Museum, which in early August featured a Toulouse-Lautrec exibition (which was pricey but worth it), the Castle just behind and to the right of the square (which also has things to see but we didn't go inside), a river or lake with activities, a huge park to walk and really enjoy nature and lot's of other things.

Walk Around. Our "City Tour" took us on a ride around this lovely area and we saw the impressive Millennium Monument, zoo, and baths. It is worth a trip back (ride the tram) to walk around. Be sure to visit the Museum of Fine Arts located on the Square. But, don't miss Vajdahunyad Castle. Walk back through the woods to the"castle". Built in 1896 for the Millennium Celebrations, it represents the history of Hungarian architecture and now houses a museum.
Heroe's Square - Budapest. A five minute photo op and a fifteen minute history lecture. Worth seeing but don't spend much time here.
An impressive monument. There's nothing I can say that's negative. Its free to roam this monument and the castle and gardens behind. Its extremely impressive and very clean.

City tour. If you go on a city tour as we did you'll almost certainly be taken here. It's a huge square with some impressive statues and monuments around. Look also at Andrassy ave leading into the square which they liken to the champs élysées.

Very Impressive. This is a massive square with multiple statues. Definitely worth a visit , it provides multiple photo opportunities. The statues are huge. There are usually a lot of people here but the square has a lot of capacity. The park behind and other buildings such as museums are located just off the square. It also has convenient access just across the road to the underground.

A good sight . This is certainly an impressive part of Budapest architecturally, as well as charting much of its history, offering many good photo opportunities. There is little here other than the monument, although I suppose that is the point, but it is nonetheless well worth a look and backs onto some very nice parkland.

Understand it for what it is. It's important to see the square for what it really is - a nineteenth century attempt at romantic-heroic national-myth-making, on a level with, say, the Altar of the Fatherland in Rome or Boadicea in London. As such, it's interesting, but that's all.

Nice Site for Photographs - on the M1 line. Lot of history - the statue complex shows seven chieftains of magyars and the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. The square lies at tone end of andrassy avenue next to city park. It has the museum of fine arts, city park and vajdahunyad castle. The square has played an important part in contemporary Hungarian history and has been a host to many political eventsIt is on the M1 line (stop Hosok Tere)

a breathtaking experience. Although I've been many squares in many countries, maybe out of nationalism, this is my favourite one. I always had the feeling visiting a square that it is smaller than I imagined (e.g. Trafalgar Square). Heroes Square is huge and easily accessible in the heart of the city, close to many other attractions. One of my first choices to show when a foreign friend comes around! :)
So so. I know that this monument means a lot to Hungarians but it didn't impressed me. Huge square and some nice monuments but didn't found anything special that captured my eyes

Probably one of the best attractions in Budapest...!. We walked all the way from the city centre to the Heroes Square, it took us at least an hour but it worth the effort! I believe is the most important attraction where you can see many iconic statue complex such as the Seven Chieftains of the Magyars and other important national leaders, as well as the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. I strongly suggest to wait under the dawn when the lights turn on, it's just amazing! What's more important than honouring your leaders and all these who fell for their country?!

Huge and simply perfect. It is always difficult to create a huge place and make it even nice, in this case the mission can be definetely considered accomplished. Even if so huge, its majesty is not the best thing of this square. If I had to choose, the wonderful and incredibly well made statues are without any doubt its best thing.

Impressive. Just for context, my wife and I are in our early 30s and are somewhat well-traveled.Worth a visit for sure. Nice statues and a park in the rear of the memorial. There's also a bath house in the park, so make an afternoon of it during your stay. Metro takes you right there.

Take Your Tour Guide or Tour Book Along. This is a very historic site with a lot of information about the origins of Hungary, but you need to do your homework to really appreciate who all of these statues represent. You only need 15 minutes to have a look and review your tour book or listen to your guide.
Definitely see this one.. Although surrounded by busy streets, it's really worth seeing. The size of the columns is pretty impressive.
Heroes square . Nice attraction on the way to the thermal baths. Good for photographs or a good meeting point! Very pretty! Not much to do round here, there are some art galleries / museums
Beautiful and respectful. Awesome place to see! A beautiful nationalism attention!Impressive, historic, looks like a huge triumph arch!

Lots of Statues. We visited with a local guide who spoke quickly about the various historical statues which was interesting, the lay out and size of the square was impressive, we spent very little time there and it seems like parking facilities near by are pretty bad, so a quick look. Funny thing is that we had planned to visit the area again once we were on our own but found it impossible to find on the map. Might have enjoyed it better had we spent more time, if statues are your thing then you will enjoy, if not there are better ways to spend some time.

Nice Park. Heroes square itself doesn't have much to offer but the park is nice with boat hire around the lake and a couple of eating and drinking restaurants.
Well worth a visit especially when the weather is nice

Wonderful place to see. Central piece very special, the square is open for lots of visitors, have nice view on the opera building from one side and the musiem from another. Few minutes from sicheni baths and the zoo. The work on the central monuments are unique. It's great to see all the particular details even on the horse faces. Nice to see
Every City in the World should have a area like this. The area is truly amazing, History buff's dream, a lot of parks and open space to enjoy a walk or a paddle boat ride or a picnic.

A magnificent monument to the Heroes of Hungary. A "must see" sight in Budapest which depicts the many historic figures of the past 1000 years of Hungarian history.
Enjoy a coffee at the Museum Terrace cafe which overlooks the square and let the world pass by.

Make a day in this area. I started my day with a walk to Szent István Bazilika, after that to the Sziget Eye and from there I walked the Andrássy Avenue to see the Opera. The plan was to enjoy that Avenue and walk to the Heroes' Square and then to end my day in Széchenyi Thermal Bath. But after the Opera the avenue was boring to me (I'm in a budget and this was full of shops I don't visit), so I decided to use subway in there for the first time. There was a guy, I asked can I buy ticket from him and he pointed to a little cabin but said that also from him too, so I bought a ticket from him - coming back and in my other subway-trips other men never sold a ticket, but everyone bought it from the cabin. So - I went to the thermal bath and after that, in the evening, I walked to the Heroes' Square. There were few tourists and one couple who was roller skating. It was calm and beautiful in there. It's nice that they have a whole square to the people they think as heroes and all of their statues there.If you have time and you are there for a culture, then I recommend to make a day-trip in that area - there are two museums (both side of the square, unfortunately I didn't get to visit those) and a thermal spa. And places to eat also.

Great to see but long way out. We walked to Heroes square after visiting the house of horror. Both of which were a long walk from our hotel, would have taken a bus/train if we'd dared!Great photo opportunity!
beautiful. very nice place, represt Budapest and the History, loaded with turist...the area is lage, we will recommend to walk all around, and don't for get to take pictues...

Magyar Heroes - Impressive at night. I'm not a massive fan of statues, but seeing Magyar heroes standing in giant archways, spanning half the circumference of this giant square, is a fantastic spectacle.At night is the best time to view this monument, when each statue is lit up - it makes for a very imposing and impressive sight, particularly if you approach it from along Andrassy Utca.It's and interesting site, if a bit far out of of the centre, but if you are on your way to visit Szechenyi baths, it's worth stopping here.

Beautiful Tribute with a nice Park Close By. We walked to Heroe's Square from our hotel (Gerlotsky) along a pretty street with many shade trees. The square is beautiful. The detail in the statutes is amazing and you can spend quite a bit of time walking around and studying each one. We had Rick Steve's guide book which was very helpful, as it provided information on each statute. Behind the millenium monument is a beautiful park, where the most well known thermal baths are located. Many walking trails and parks, and benches under nice shade trees for a picnic or to just stop and sit and look at the beautiful surroundings.

Well structured. It's a really interesting square and at a very central location. I wish they had information plaques to inform tourists the stories behind all the statues. Perfect location for some really creative photographs.

A good photo op.. I would have liked to have had a guide to explain the history of this huge square, but failing that take some photos and read up on it later. Can be combined with a visit to the Fine Arts Museum which is on one side of the square and is excellent.

Looks fantastic at night!. We went there after recommendation from the tourist guide, she said that the evening with the lights on is the best. And it was spectacular!
I wouldn't consider going that 'far away' from the river without that recommendation (and it wasn't as far as it looks on the map as we walked!).
Definitely worth it!

Very Eastern bloc. Impressive, large open square - easy to imagine ranks of marching soldiers - but you must look for the rider on horseback who looks like a character from "Pirates of the Caribbean!!
Nice square. Nice square, located before a big park and between many museums outside the park and inside it. It's an landmark of the city.
Fascinating history. Really enjoyed the visit here. Our tour guide gave us a history lesson and it was very moving and fascinating!

Unique!. With Citadel and of course WestEnd, Heroes Square is also one of Budapest popular attractions. There is a big park behind the square. And a free parking on the right. In winter time ice skating is held on the plateau between square and park. This square is very unique and it's recommended to visit.

So many prominent figures. The whole square consists of some amazing statues of prominent figures in Hungarian history and is also one of the famous places to be visited while in Budapest. You can take metro to the place, line 1(yellow) to get to the place. There is also a beautiful castle to the back of the square and apart from that there are museums and parks around too. Unfortunately the places do not have any useful information around which means that you have to rely on your guide for background information on the place.
Must see. It’s a must see place. Next to it you have few museums and a big park. I recommend taking vintage metro no. 1 straight to the place

Take 5 minutes to see this. A beautiful square with fantastic monuments (minimal but elegant) - easy stop on the walk to Szechenyi baths - beautiful garden walk. Use the metro for this stretch as the walk is it is along the metro line
Fantastic Photo Op!. Such a stunning sight to go see in Budapest, would recommend a trip to see it! It's a fantastic photo opportunity!

Culturally significant monument. Yes, the area is full of tourists depending on the time of day you go. Yes, it is a photo opportunity and you probably won't be here long.However, Heroes Square is culturally and historically significant to Hungarians and you can't help but be moved when your tour guide provides the history of Heroes Square. If you don't go here as part of a tour or with a tour guide, make sure you read up about Heroes Square to understand the importance of this to Hungarians. Otherwise you'll think it's just another photo opportunity.

Visited for Photo. Heroes' Square (or Hősök tere in Hungarian) is one of the most visited attractions in Budapest. We went there to have some photos with the monuments. We went in the evening time the square was almost empty. We had some photos there and then left.

Dripping With History!. At the end of Andrussy Ut, you will find this larger then life display of who's Who in Hungarian history. ( don't expect humility here, folks...the name is heroes square after all...) To get here take the metro, line 1( yellow) from the main station Deak Ferenc ter and head northeast towards Mexicoi Ut. Get off at Hosok tere. So easy...When you exit this station head to your right and cross three streets in a semi circle to get to the centre. Watch for cars...they have the right of way in this country! They are doing you a favor by not mowing you down...It would be good to have read about these kings beforehand or have a guide book. We use sir Rick's of Steve...wonderful tour guide. There is no posted information for the average tourist. I did appreciate the numerous amounts of school kids here on a field trip. Talking with a teacher here, before they can enjoy the zoo, they must learn, by use of these immense statues, the history of their country. As an educator, I must say this is impressive. I wish I could have been taught history like this...Anyway, enjoy yourself here. Visit the Transylvanian castle behind the statues or at least get a few photos. It is an agriculture museum of all things...
Photo op. That's it.. Some nice statues, but over-run with tour groups. You'll take a photo and then move on to more interesting places. Near other attractions so you might stop here on the way.
Beautiful place and surrounding. This square is very beautiful and impressive. Also take some time to walk in the surroundings: the park just behind this square is amazing
Worth a visit. Massive, well kept and good to see on a short visit. Worth a visit to the area, park and baths. Could benefit from an information display.

weekend in budapest. i have seen photos of budapest on webshots by a man called atipapa, and liked them so much i had to see budapest for myself ..it is a beautiful city , and the bus and tram system makes london look obsolete,,. the fountain on margaret island at night with music is just stunning , as is the parliament building ,, and the sculpture on the monuments in heroes square are just superb . i could not see everything in just three days , but i crammed a lot in , and walked miles which is good for me, . i was fortuate to be inheroes square at the very time a parade was starting to lay wreaths on the memorial. and the hungarian army band played beautifully ,, and i am an ex professional musician , 22yrs in a guards band, so i should know. i think that budapest is the most beautiful city i have been yo and i will be back!!! thank you budapest and its hungarian citizen brian little

A great Anchor for near-by visits. Heroes' Square itself is a 3-second glance at a traffic circle with heavy Soviet overtones - however, this neighborhood is amazing and worth exploring. As the central point for the subway, the Museum of Fine Art, the Zoo, the elaborate Park & river recreational center, and the baths, remember its location and use it as a hub for your afternoon!

Beautiful Square Full of History. We were very lucky having a knowledgeable guide; who added a magnificent explanation of the history behind this enormous and beautiful square.We enjoyed tremendously the surrounding well preserved and nice Statues, Monuments and Buildings.

World class, but lacking humility.. Heroe's Square is indeed that. A square to celebrate the heroes of Hungarian history and culture. As we strolled thorugh the square, I felt overwhelmed by the immense size of some of the statues. Almost as though there contribuitions were being forced on you. It's a nice diversion from the city, and a short walk to the Szechenyi Bath. A good way to find the other side of Budapest, but keep your visit to under 30 minutes.

magnificent statues. Magnificent statues in enormous height. Wonder how they they were erected way back then. The square is a gathering place for civil activities. The second time we visited the square, it had a big demonstration.

A place where the city converges. The heroes square is very well maintained and contains statues that are beautiful works of art, they nice and have a cultural value for the people of Hungary.I missed some explanations in any language besides hungarian of the heroes portrayed there but my hungarians helped me later to understand who each of that guys where.The square is located in a busy street convergence, so respect the walking lanes and street lights.To get there you may go by oldest metro on continental europe and when you arrive it is easy to go for other attractions.

A Lovely Tribute. A lovely tribute to Hungarian heroes with the centre column a monument to those, who died for the independence of Hungary. Find out about the ‘heroes’ before your visit to add some significance to the statues, for example, the first statue on the left is of Saint Stephen; Hungary's first king and founder of the Hungarian state. Also, the four statues over the top represent War, Peace, Work and Welfare, and, Knowledge and Glory.Adjacent to the square are the Museum of Fine Art and the Hall of Art.30 minutes here should be sufficient.

Imposing statues. We walked to Heroes' Square from our hotel,. – the most amazing monuments which are well worth seeing. We went into a building called Mucsarnok, which was amazing both inside and out. Very hot day so we walked behind the square and had a drink sitting by the boating lake, opposite the Sleeping Beauty Castle.

Hero Square ...A focal point. Hero Square is not just an opportunity to see the enormous monuments .It is a focal point of museums to the right and left of the square ,(closed on Mondays), also restaurants and coffee bars in the park beyond and boating on the idylic lake .Evening or daytime it is magical..Staying on a tour bus does not give you the opportunity to appreciate the activity that surrounds this iconic venue...Metro One will take you from the centre of the city directly onto the square ( Hossok Ter) or walk from Deak Square along the great Andrassy Street passing the Opera House,The Terror Mueum at No 60..and the many coffee houses , restaurants and 1890s architecture ..Maybe divert onto one of the side streets to the Liszt Acadamy and the many terraces of restaurants.. I am an Englishman living here and never do I tire of this wonderful street culminating in Hero Square and its surrounds..
Heroes Square. My advice, stay on the tour bus and let it drive you round the square. Nothing really to see or do apart from what you see in the pictures.

The Millennium Monument makes this place interesting. It was so uncomfortably hot the afternoon our tour group visited Heroes’ Square that it felt like we would melt into the pavement. Nevertheless, we remained focused long enough to give the place a reasonably good exploration. That actually wasn’t very time consuming. A glance confirms that Heroes’ Square is the largest of Budapest’s squares, but sheer expanse doesn’t compensate for scarcity of visual interest. The two large public buildings flanking the space are handsome, but not exceptional. It is the Millennium Monument that makes this square a destination rather than a drive-by, so that is where tourists converge, and that is where their cameras are aimed.
Fantastic . We loved this great monument to the heroes and past of Hungary.It's huge, majestic and a definite must see when visiting Budapest

Beatiful sight, visit the cafe.... As stated a million times before - this place is a real corner piece of budapest, a must see if you're visiting to get a taste of budapest.while you're here i recommend enjoying a nice cup of coffee or beer in the coffee of the fine arts museum right on the square to have a relaxing view without all the tourists running around you...

Great statues and architecture. Our guide gave us a short historical background of the monuments and the statues of famous hungarians. I specially liked the statue of the angel Gabriel. There were gypsies selling very cheap sweaters and we bought some although our guide was not happy about it. I was able only to appreciate the facade of the museums. I missed the chance to go in. They said there were works of Van Gogh and Rembrandt. Hopefully next time I`ll get the chance.

All of Hungary's history at one place. I suggest going to this square with a tour guide, who can tell you the stories of the statues. Unfortunately there are no written explanations provided on the square, but if you are visiting Hungary and you dont have time to go around and learn all about the country and the history of it, this is the best place to visit. Of course it is good for taking pictures and the museums on each side provide some extra added value, but the main function of this quare really is to tell Hungarian history :)Btw, Toilets are behind Műcsarnok (The Museum on the right) :)
Magnificent and beautiful. Magnificent and beautiful square with beautiful Statue. It is close to Széchenyi spa so you can visit it after going to spa.

Nice place. Open and large square, nice to take pictures but that's it. Access is not obvious, you need to take care crossing the road. If you don't have much time, there are better attractions in Budapest.

Monumental Square. The only thing to see at Heroes' Square is the tall column-with-statue. The square itself is very large and open. It is at the far eastern end of Andrassy Boulevard; there is a metro line 1 stop nearby. Right behind it to the east is City Park. Be careful crossing the roadway, as there is usually quite a bit of traffic and the drivers do not yield to pedestrians. Heroes' Square is worth seeing. The monuments/statues are interesting and of heroic proportions. Plan to continue on to City Park, however, as there is little else to see or do within the Square itself.

Nice Place to Visit. We enjoyed taking pictures and walking around the square. There are museums next to the square that also looked interesting (we didn't have time go into both). The part behind the square is also worth a visit. I think if you are in Budapest, you should see this square as it part of Hungarian history.

Nice square. It is a really nice square with some interesting monuments and sculptures full with rich history. The buildings around the square also have really nice architectural design. It is a nice place for sightseeing and socializing and taking pictures.

Monumental...photo spot. You won't be able to miss this place. It has large monumental sculpture of the founders of Hungary. And of course mythological figures behind. The museums flanking the central square also have beautiful facade.

Great spot for photos. Very impressive spot. Might be better to visit on a tour as info blurbs are absent. We chatted to some local students who filled us in on how it represents the beginnings of the Hungarian territory.
Great monument. We got there reasonably early and got some great pictures. Returning to it later, there were lots of people, so not so easy to photograph things. It is stunning.

Impressive. Huge square with huge statues of important people of Hungary. We did a quick stop, but would like to return for longer next time and to read up more about the people; or maybe do a tour. Impressive buildings surround the square.

Monumental. The square is huge and makes really big impression at the first sight. Sculptures are also very big and shows us some history, but nothing is described. If you don't have a guide, you'll just make some pictures and go away.. we read something about it in our pocket guide but I think there should be some information about the sculptures there so that tourists would know what they're looking at. It poses a beautiful gate to the city park behind the square and it's obviously popular with tourists.

Historic Site. If you visit Budapest you have to visit Heroes Square. When you visit it if there is a guided tour there eavesdrop to learn of its historical significance to the Hungarian people. There is also a lovely view down the Andrassy Avenue from the Square

Excellent Historic Attraction. These series of statues hold great meaning to the Hungarian history. It's a massive square with huge statues of important people representing sugnificant moments in time. It's a great photo opportunity and a must see when traveling to Budapest. Close by is a circus, a man made lake which becomes an ice ring in the winter. There is a fantastic park with work out areas and attractions for the kids as well as a Handful of great coffee shops.

Synonymous with Budapest. One of Budapest's main historical landmarks. One should visit this monument together with a guide or someone who knows the stories the monument recounts since the descriptions are only in Hungarian.
A wonderful open place. This square is another place you should not miss if you are into the countries history and the monuments they have constructed to celebrate.

a must. impresingly big statues, beautiful building all around the square, which itself is extremely big. you'll find it outside the center, at the end of a long street in which you'll find many museums and the book cafe.

Impressive. This lovely square is just off the main park with stunning statues set in beautiful surroundings. The day we visited, a group of men ( stag party ) rode up on a beer bike and caused some amusement posing all around in their very colourful suits !! Bright as they were, it did not detract from the wonderful architecture of this grand site. Worth a visit.
Lovely square. Really nice location and square with the beautiful buildings and the park surrounding. Nice spot to sit back and relax and also plenty to see with the different statues.

Impressive Square. Heroes square is beautiful with a large monument in the middle. We didn't spend a lot of time here but we did visit it again at night at it was pretty all lit up. I would highly recommended to visit it at night also.

Big square and a big monument. The monument itself is really high and it is nice to look at, but you won't need too much time at the site. On both sides of the monument there are museums, which makes for a nice framing.

Place to learn Hungrian history. I have been 3 times and learn a bit more every time about Hungarian history. Our guide gave us a very good overview of every person represented on monuments on the square.
If you have time check out the surrounding museums.

Impressive!. I have visited this sight many many many times, and it never ceases to impress me. It is a Budapest must-see. Any and all visitors I've taken have found it fascinating. It's worth having a good guide book or printing out info on the figures represented and reading them as you move from statue to statue. The statues tell the story of Hungary's founding, conversion, periods of glory and trials and tribulations. The expanse of the open square is a great place for photographs, and there are several other very important attractions nearby. If you choose to walk up Andrassy blvd. towards Heroes' square you have the experience of it raising in all its glory to meet you. At night the square is beautifully illuminated. You don't need a lot of time to see it, twenty minutes at most, but you will always remember the sight.

Worth a visit. Heroes square is a worth seeing attraction and photo opportunity but only for a quick stopover. We visited on the way to the park and the zoo and would recommend including other places in the vicinity to justify a journey to the square.
bit boring!. its in the middle of a busy round a bout, the statues are nice, but as we had no guide it was a bit boring. you could prob spend 15-20 minutes here at the most.
Beautiful space, great history. It is frankly a must see in Hungary. It is wedged between two art museums, so it isn't as if it is in the middle of no where. Take your time and enjoy the space.

very impressive. We were impressed by this dedication to the fallen heroes' of the war. The plaza was stunning and the whole place gave you a sense of humility and brought home the sacrifices of those that died on our behalf. Lest we forget!

Great architecture. Beautiful buildings to either side, in the middle the Heroes' Monuments in a massive open space. Its size means despite the throngs of tourists there's still plenty of space to move around and take photos. One to see on foot rather than from a tour bus, in order to appreciate the space in all its glory.

It's impressive!. What a beautiful space! Huge open space that lends so much majesty to the Hungarian hero's it is meant to honor. Best done on foot, so you can wander and touch and get the real "feel" of the place. I'm sure that a tour is a good idea for something which so much historical value, although we did not take time for that. Still impressive. The Széchenyi Thermal Baths are just a couple of blocks from here, it's a good time to tie in Heroe's Square if you are headed to the Baths. Also had a lovely lunch at a nice place just off the square called Varosliget Cafe & Bar 1895. A really nice afternoon!

Just a Square But A Bit More Than That. At first glance Heroes Square is a large, stately square -- many cities have them - adorned with statues of Hungarian heroes. There were tourists, protestors (they wanted their mortgages forgiven) and locals out for a walk on a beautiful day. What is nice about the Square, besides the few minutes of sniffing about you should so, is its location. It is the gateway to City Park, a stopover on the way to the great Szechenyi Baths, there is an underground metro stop right there, the Fine Arts Museum is right there, a Modern Art Museum is there, and you can walk to see several other memorials or grab lunch at a somewhat over priced (for Budapest, cheap anywhere else), somewhat mediocre tourist restaurant with a nice outdoor cafe. If you have time, plan at least half a day, take the tram or Metro to the Oktagon, go the one of the best museums anywhere, The House of Terror, then go to Heroes Square, walk though the park or get on the subway and go to the baths. A perfect day.

Historic attraction. Well worth a visit to the top of Andrassy avenure and can be fitted around a trip to the baths a short walk away. Thats what we did anyway. Some nice views down andrassy and further! Beautiful parks next door also.

Huge square. This monument is in a huge square.
I really liked it.
There were many boys skating and families walking around.
It is in front of the Gold museum.
You can take some pictures and then walked to tge park behind the square.

see this (Heroes' Square) with a tour guide. We visite Heroes' Square while on a tour of Pest - our tour guide Bridget (I forget the tour co., but we got it with our 72-hr Budapest Pass) gave a very interesting talk about the history of Budapest --we'd never have realized what we were seeing unless she'd explained it all. We were there in January, lucked out with a sunny day. Our tour began at 2; by time it was over it was getting dark and quite chilly. Dress warm!--most all of the tour is outside.

Impressive statues, no explanation. Like so much of Budapest, this is an impressive monument with not a plaque or sign to explain what it is. We didn't read up on it prior to attending, so we literally took a few photos and left. It was a nice collection of statues but still to this day I don't know what it was trying to say.

Great place, long walk. The square is very impressive and the monuments too. There are no explanations of the context or meaning of the various figures at Heroes Square but there are plenty of places and apps which will give you a good background. The walk back is quite long but the buildings down the main drag are impressive and quite regal, close to the square there are several embasis now occupying these larger properties. Whilst at the square head off to the right and look for the Time wheel (http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timewheel).

Very popular. A tourist Meca. Try and get in either very early or late in th afternoon as many tourist buses and tourists visit this area on a regular basis. You can have a wander around this lovely area and surrounds, not just the square.
Impressive. Definitely worth checking out this square, one of the stops on the hop on/off bus red line. Very close to ice skating and the Szepmuveszeti musuem.
lots to see. worth a visit, lots of beautiful buildings & of course the square with monument at the end, also close by the ice skating & castle, also szecheyni thermal pools.

The entrance to the Millenium. This auspicious space was the entrance to the 1896 Millenuem world 's fair celebrating 1,000 years sine the 7 founding tribes arrived to establis Hungary. The statuaries are simply stunning.
AMAZING. Just massive and an amazing thing to see. We went after visiting the nearby Szyenki baths and was just fascinated by the size of the memorial . a must see if in Budapest
Worth a visit. Must see part of Budapest with great views. Easily reached on the metro and free. You can also visit the museum , ice rink and Zoo from here.

Great square. One of the top 10 places to visit in Budapest.The place as such is beautiful but maybe the surroundings are also a very good reason to go. Very close to other places to see (Vajdahunyad Castle).
Opens up a lot of other attractions. . Get the yellow line metro to the square. Lovely open area with access to museums ice rink zoo thermal baths and lots more. Lovely picture opportunities.
Very impressive place. I have been there a many times. I like it actually during the night, specially in summer. There is enough light to take good pictures too. Just go and see for yourself.
Impressive. This square is very impressive, with statues of heroes of Hungary from different periods of time. Don't waste your time on reading my review, go see it yourself ;)

Very impressive. Great walk from the city centre to the Heroes Square. Impressive statues of past leaders of Hungary and quite awe inspiring. Take a walk into the park to see the ice rink and the castle.
Glorious ,Glorious. Big square,with glory impression,See it at first from as far as possible,and then go close.We see the place at early afternoon and it was glorious.

go at night. we went by day and again at night ,what a sight helpfull to take a tour guide ora trip advisor app on phone so you cansee who is there and is very easy to get to by train,tram or bus.get a travel pass which comes in very handy.
Just look. Visited this today 30/01/2014. A very very impressive monument. As much as it is a big wide open area you need to just stop and look to Appreiciate how magnificent it is.

see it in the evening! then... see the square in the evening when its lit up! its absolutely stunning! then afterwards, continuing walking away from the center of the city towards the thermal baths! great way to spend the evening! also, look up some historical pictures from heroes' square before you go.... its awesome to know what events happened where you are standing, and who stood where you stand. MUST see.

Spent as little or as long as you like. Although a large open area, you won't take long walking around unless you stop to appreciate all the features of this attraction. There is of course no guidance so you're on your own. I would think the visit would be most valuable if you do your homework first to appreciate the significance of each figure. Although that isn't essential. It is still an interesting monument, and even more breathtaking at night.

Past and present history of Hungary. The Heroes' Square is one of the most importants (if not the most important) symbolic sight to see in Budapest with many other attractions in the neighbourhood, so it's a must see, highly recommended.
what a sight. very impressive, stands out a mile. beautiful during the day and even more spectacular at night. a must see attraction.

Lovely but long walk.. We visited the square late afternoon believing on the main road up was vibrant with restaurants and bars. There was not many if at all, the square is a very long walk from the city center and would recommend to get on the tube when visiting. However the square was beautiful and extremely impressive at night when all lit up.

Visit twice, once in daylight and again under the lights. After Buda Castle and Chain bridge, this must be the popular tourist spot in Budapest. It is an impressive square that features a Tomb and an arc filled with statues. At the foot of the tomb you can spot the heroes riding the horses. It looks beautiful in the daylight and even more beautiful under the lights. Make sure you don't miss the latter. Just behind the square you can find the Vajdahunyad castle and in the winter there is an ice skating square between the castle and the square.The underground metro just in front of the square can connect you to the city centre in minutes. Don't miss this attraction during your visit to the wonderful city of Budapest.

A huge and beautiful construction. The square is huge and full of really beautiful statues. The construction spans one whole edge of the square with a column in the middle. It was worth worth the journey to visit the square.
Not much to do beyond 10 minutes. Best time to visit - good daylight. U can appreciate the vastness of the square. U can see it as part of the hop on hop off tours. But must see

Celebrate Hungarian History Amongst Heroes. The statues in Heroes Square are breathtaking. To really appreciate the artwork, bring a camera with a good zoom so that you can see the gold leaf details and beautifully chiseled features. It's a great area for photo opportunities and is located right across the street from a metro stop. If you're seeking a day of culture, the Museum of Fine Arts and Palace of Art sandwich Heroes Square making it a great area to visit. If you travel during the winter months, a large outdoor skating rink is located to the rear of the Heroes Square colonnade. And, if you want to take a dip in a thermal bath, Szechenyi Bath and Spa is within walking distance.

Hungarian history in statues. This is an amazing square. Hungarian history is condensed in this square, from the first magyar tribe leaders, to the kings and important personalities are depicted in statues. Be sure to bring a guide book or study a little to enjoy fully this square. Also be sure to check the two museums nearby and the ice skating rink nearby.
stop by. go see all the folk heroes that played a part in Hungary's history. I enjoyed resting my legs here. It's a quick tour.

Impressive monument. Beautiful statues of all kings of Hungary and an imposing center piece. Extremely clean plaza and if you happen to be there during winter, I certainly recommend the ice rink which is 1 minute away.

Centre of Art. Hero's Square contains two important museums and the memorial to fallen heros. The Museum of Fine Art is the most important and houses a major collection of European paintings including Da Vinci, Michelangelo, Raphael, Vermeer, El Greco, Durer, Cranach, English and French Masters, Rembrant, Rubens and Van Dyke and many more. There are some important travelling shows as well. The other museum of contemporay art is housed across the square in a magnificent building but sadly the collection is not very inspiring and is many large installations of very limited interest. If you walk in the neighbourhoods surrounding Heros square you will find many of the best examples of Art Nouveau, Sessionist and Art Deco Houses in the city.
Take 5 minutes to marvel. Check it out on the way to the bath. It's grand, but in my opinion not worth seeing on its on... But just a few steps from the city park
Impressive honor. The monument is vast and certainly well maintained. The statue is stunner. There is also park behind the monument.

Heroes never die. A great city to visit with a lot of sights to see, like building with great cultural architecture. I mostly love the Heroes’ Square located near City Park. It’s a very vast memorial monument that always has space for people who visit the place. I appreciate how the locals treated their heroes to a place where people would get to commemorate them and visit them up until the modern days. The statues in the area are well made and they really made me think about how it was made because I was really fascinated by its form. As a person visiting the place from a completely different part of the world it was a wonderful place to relax in. Its location is near all the best establishments in Budapest.

Impressive momorial. This well maintained monument is in a vast square which can be reached easily by the Metro or if you are feeling energetic by walking the length of Andrassy Utca which is an interesting street in itself. The park behind the monument is is expansive and there is much to see in the area, spa baths, zoo, and museums to name but a few attractions.

A National Symbol. It's hard to miss as you're driving to City Park. It's the massive square with the Millennium column that towers over it. The statue of the Archangel Gabriel is at the very top of the column. The angel is holding St. Stephen's holy crown and apostolic double cross. The colonnades behind the column have statues of Hungarian historical figures. It's a very impressive looking square that is a national symbol and memorial to the heroes who gave their lives for freedom. It's definitely worth a visit since it's also near other points of interest such as the Vajdahunyad Castle, the Széchenyi Baths, the Museum of Fine Arts, and the City Park.

Imposing. The square is pretty expansive, to begin with. Then there's the massive monument in the middle that kisses the sky. A truly imposing sight, with tremendous significance -a memorial for the fallen throughout the city's history. Awe-inspiring indeed.
Nice and impressive square. The statues are impressive and the huge square looks good, especially when lighted at night. Worth a visit.
Hero's Square. This is a nice place to visit and it's located in a lovely part of town near a beautiful park. If you're in the city in the winter, it's located next to the outdoor ice skating rink

Impressive monument. This is a huge memorial to the fallen from many battles and wars. No matter how many people are in the square there is always plenty of room, its huge. It stands at the end of a long avenue which in itself is worth a walk along. The park and zoo are close by too.
Indeed you feel like bending your head with admiration. A spectacular square. You do feel the glory it meant to transfere. Beautiful statues ,very hilarious.

Nice place for a relaxed walk. This is very nice monument area with a great adjacent park is at the end of Andrassy Street (Budapest's answer to the Champs-Elysees in Paris). Great statues, a major museum and a Hungarian bath are nearby. The day that we were there was a National holiday - Revoulution Day - October 23 - and the square and Andrassy street were incredibly packed with people for the Prime Minister's speech.

Quick overview of Hungarian History. Heroes square is worth a visit if you happen to be in the vicinity and you are interested in Hungarian history. You can either take a metro or walk to it but it is a long walk. The sated are quite impressive though they may not accurately depict he real asiatic features of the original Magyar people. The stayed are quite nice and the frieze below depicts specific scenes important to Hungarian history. However to appreciate Hungarian history, you will need to read up on t before understanding the significance of each of the statues.

Oh come on, it is a square!. But it is a lovely one. Serves as a great entrance to a park behind it. We walked around all the statues, took about fifteen minutes (with reading all about them from our guidebook). It is quite nice, but it is just a square, so stay, look, take pictures and move on.

Beautiful Monument. Heroes Square is gorgeous. It's a little out of the way from the main part of the city but you can take the metro to get quite near to it and then it's a straight walk to the square. It doesn't take long to look at the statues (which are great for posing with), so once you're done you can hit up the museums located right next to the square or the Castle right behind it. Worth the trip if you need to fill in an afternoon in Budapest.

Great symbol of history. Came here as part of walking tour where we were explained the history. You need the history to get a feel if this set of monuments. Had quite a few tourists but not enough be crowded or stop shooting photos. A must see in the city.

Heroe's Square to St Stephens on foot via Andrassy. OUr first stop in Budapest. Wait to see the change of the guards. Worth your patient. After that take the Andrassy street on foot until St Stephens cathedral, it's a great walk

Grat place to visit. Make sure you leave a bit of time to visit the square as the park is behind it, which incorporates the zoo, circus, fair and baths. Lots of sights to see and places to chill and relax. Worth the visit most definitely
Nice to walk through. A great open space. Clean and nicely laid out. More like a place to pass through on your way up Andrassy, but definitely worth checking out.

A sight to see. Huge and very clean area and statues.Art museums either side of square. Could easily spend whole day in area combining walk in park, visit to baths and museumsWe were staying in hotel very nearby and also on bank holiday when they were setting up for a visit and speech by President. The next day it had all be cleared away - impressive

An interesting walk!. We first saw the monument on a drive by bus tour and decided to walk there again in the afternoon from the Opera. It was a long 50 min. walk although we were told it would be about 30 min. On the way, we were able to view the beautiful architecture of the buildings. Finally, after arriving at the monument, we were impressed with the meaning of it. A true inspiration to the Hungarian people and a reminder of their heritage.

beautiful open square. Very nice square with impressive monuments. Nice to walk up Andrassy ut seeing the square in the background - and on the other side of it you walk right into the park where the Szechenyi Baths are.

Nice place. A beautiful place in a beautiful neibourhood.You better visit it in the afternoon, because there are no more tourists. The first time we saw it was very crawded an we wasn't able to see almost anything.
Very Impressive. Heroes' Square is a large area bordered by two museums. The monuments on the square are impressive. The museums are worth seeing if you have the time.

Impressive piece of Hungarian history. What a sight for panoramic photographs! The Square is definitely worth visiting. Although buzzing with tourists, you get a sense of national history there. We read about explanation of the Square and its history after our visit from the web, though it would have been great to have some explanation at the sight itself. In the online article, it was heartbreaking to see old photos from the communist era showing these statues covered under red blankets and out of sight. I can only imagine the significance of the place for the Hungarian people. During our visit, the city of Budapest was preparing for the memorial day of October 23rd uprising and many of the festivities took place on the Heroes Square.

At the end of Andrassy boulevard - a good starting point. For the monument itself, get a book or a guide to understand all of the statues, otherwise it is a bit dry.It is a good starting point, surrounded by 2 museums, then you walk along the nice houses along Andrassy bld, visit the Opera and end up on the popular Erzebet square.Or it could be your ending point, then you go past it to relax in the Szechenyi baths behind it, they are open very late in the evening.

Read the history about Hungary before coming here!. If you read, than enjoy the beautiful view of the statues and you will know how important they were!It's easy to reach this place, and next to it, there is a massive park with loads more to do!
Nice statues detailing the rulers of Hungry. The best thing about Heroe's Square is the park with the bath house which is very relaxing after walking all day.
A lot of turists but worth the visit. A big square with monuments and close to a really nice park that looks like an ideal place for a run. Will visit again soon.
What an amazing place. We walked through and admired the statues and the square. Some how more imposing than Marble Arch of the Champs Elsysee. Definitely worth a visit

Great architecture!!. The square is on the end of the Andrassy ut, and represents a tribute to the Heroes of Hungary. It is huge and breathtaking!! A great way to start the walk around the park that is situated behind the sqaure (the park has playgrounds for kids, horses to ride and a lots of memorable views!!!

Heroes' Square. First, you need to have a guide or a guide book to explain what you're looking at and its significance. The square is extremely large and clean, and the history behind it is really interesting. It's a nice tribute to the Hungarians who fought in wars and to St. Stephen.

A Fabulous Tribute to the Heros of Hungary. This plaza is simple and elegant. It is best to have a guide - either a guide book to tell you what statues represent what, but even without that, it is worth a visit! These are the people who made this country great!

Lovely. A must see !!!. I like the atmosphere and if u r an art fan , there are contemporary art galleries from various artists every season.
I come here every time I m in Bidapest for an official mission

What's wrong with people today?. After an exhilarating visit to the Széchenyi Baths, DW and I walked over to take a look at Heroes Square. It's an absolutely beautiful monument to historical figures from the region, with the obvious centerpiece being the central monument with the 7 medieval heroes. Around the colonnade to the rear are more present day heroes of the region. What I don't get is this (and this is not exclusive to Budapest: why is graffiti tolerated? This is the Magyar equivalent to say, Wellington Arch, or the Arc D' Triomphe, yet the beauty and significance is sullied by crude attempts to display "teen culture." I just don't get it. You want to paint up the sound barriers along the train tracks, knock your socks off. Otherwise, let your heroes be heroes and show them the respect they richly deserve. And, I digress...... Had the place not been so desecrated, definitely a 5 rating.

An Impressive Area. A Square not unlike Tianeman Square in Beijing. A large square to honor past heroes, both God and real. The surrounding area contains large historic buildings housing museums. Take the time to examine the statues in some detail as they are as realistic as possible with minute details.Behind the Heroes is another large area that beckons your exploration Vajdahunyad castle, City Park, Szechenyi Thermal Bath, Budapest Zoo and a large open-air skating rink during winter.We spent a day exploring the whole area and having a bath as well.
Heroes Park. Nice stroll through, and you do not need a long time at the site. Nice to get off the bus and stretch.

Beautiful open area at the edge of City Park paying tribute to 1000 years of Hungarian kings and leaders. Yet another structure built in the late 1800s in honor of Hungary's 1000 year anniversary celebration. It's obvious that the country was doing alright for itself in the late 19th century, as there were many beautiful structures and attractions built during that time which we can still appreciate today. This one is fairly easy to get to as all you have to do is go east on Andrassy korut or go east on the Metro 1 line. It is definitely a bit of a walk from the Danube/city center, especially during cold or inclement weather,  This place is an essential stop for any visitor wanting to put faces to some of the names that are most revered in Hungary. It would pay to know a bit about the history of Hungary before going, or finding an online audio-tour, or just doing a little research on the people whose statues are on display. The surrounding area contains Vajdahunyad castle, City Park (Varosliget), Szechenyi Thermal Bath, and during the winter the lake in between Heroes Sq and Valdahunyad castle turns into one of Europe's largest open-air skating rinks. For Michael Jackson fans, this area might also be familiar from his music video "History" ( http://youtu.be/ybPQ4UpLncA ) as it was shot primarily at Heroes' Square and with the help of some computer graphics, was made to look quadruple it's size.

Very impressive area, beautiful square. We went in the summer, and it was so beautiful. The kings represented in the statues were beautiful. Would reccomend taking some papers about the background and history of the various kings . There are two museums facing each other is a square. Lots of things to do in this square, close to the metro stop. Also the vajdahunyad castle behind the square is a must see. Highly reccomend this to everyone!!! Thanks for your time.

Grand statues staring down at you. Though a little far from the main tourist attractions, this is definitely worth a visit. The multitude heroes looking down at you from, literally, their high horses, has a certain timeless charm. So much so that after a time, you even imagine the sentries guarding the place to be statues also ... only to find them twitching their nose and blinking at you ever so slightly!

Wide, imposing space.... Stayed in a hotel just next door so saw it during the day and at night. Worth a visit just to appreciate the immense scale of the square. Very pretty and there's a handy stop on the M1 metro line.
Very Grand. This is a superb area, very grand building and statues, you can imagine the events in it by the communists.

Interesting stories and presentation. Fascinating stories about the history of the Hapsburgs and Attila the Hun. The bronze statues are mesmerising. It is very popular with tourists so there can be a bit of a walk. If you are not on a bus tour, public transport is probably the best way.

Bigger than expected and interesting history. A long walk from the centre but worth it. Huge square with museums either side and a huge park behind housing the zoo, kids amusements and the Szechenyi baths.

Wide open space. It's good to sit around and "feel" the square. I brought my guidebook with me and read about the square on the spot. The statues were really magnificent and life like. They look so real and strong.
It's easy to get to using the subway. The stop is Hősök tere on the yellow line.

Go when there is an event on!. This place is worth walking through on your way to the park if you are here on a short visit. Take pictures of the cool statues and the lovely mosaics on the museums that border the square. The square really shines when there is an event on, however. I was just there for the national horse racing event weekend (happens in Sept every year). The square itself is sectioned off and turned into a racecourse (you need to buy a ticket for that) but you can see bits and pieces through the stands. The cool thing is that there are stands with food, drink and crafts all around it as well as buskers, costumed people and floats. This is free to walk around in and enjoy and it stretches up the main street leading in (close off for cars that weekend) which is all very pleasant and exciting.

Monment and thats all. It was ok, the army were there doing some sort of parade when we went so it made it a bit more interesting but other than that its just the end of City Park. It was pretty but we stayed 5mins as there's nothing much to see.
Walking around. Large open space to wander around. Interesting statues to view. A number of Art Museums/galleries nearby.

If you have time see this with a guide. Our tour took us here by subway. It's huge and our guide was able to help us understand the significance of it. They were getting it ready for chariot races - can you believe that? I wish I had the time to go through the park, but I was glad to see what I did.
A lovely plaza. A wide plaza with a beautiful monument at the entrance to a lovely park. Try getting there before or after the tour buses.
An impressive square. Easy to get to and great for taking pictures, this is one of the most impressive squares you'll find in Europe - well worth the visit.

Very Moving. I was struck by the beauty of the square and the wonderful statues. There were lots of visitors when we were there but due to the large size of the square it wasn't difficult to find a good spot to take photos. I loved the statues and the stories they represented in the history of Hungary. I found it to be a moving experience and to be able to stand amongst the statues and admire the craftsmanship was very special. I felt very privileged to experience Heroes Square it really is beautiful.I did not like the street hawkers who were hanging round the visitors trying to get a sale, this was the downside of my visit. We were advised by our tour guide not to purchase anything from these people due to them being dishonest. Some were pushy and very irritating.
