great place to take a picture. If you visit this place during high season - in spring, summer or winter holidays.. There will be crowds of tourist in front of the monument

Very Big and Beautiful Square. The Square is one of the main attraction in Budapest.There are several other attractions near - the zoo , circus and city park .In the square are many statues that represent Hungary Kings.The place is beautiful and do not forget to take a camera .There are also several museums near the square.

A moving experience. A huge area in Budapest, with plenty of room to move around. The statues depicting Hungarian heroes, particularly from the 1956 Revolution, are very lifelike and really tell the story of Hungary.

Lovely Time. One of the beautiful pieces of art here stands in the middle of the Square, Archangel Gabriel, symbol of Roman Catholic Church , also the equestrian statues located at the feet of the statue represent the 7 chieftains of the Hungarian tribes, Arpad, notable being one, started the royal line. The square gives you more insights how the significant moments of history happened here with their issues politically and ideologically.

Wild have liked more info. We only had a quick amount of time here and I wish I'd had more. I did however enjoy the short time I had, it was very impressive. Low season meant not many people around so it was a good wander.

Nice square just out of the citycentre. This square, at the end of the more than 2 kilometer long Andrassy street, is a wonderful testament to Hungarian history. Next to the square is a large parkinglot (free, but sometimes there is a guy directing you to a free place and askign for a fee) where we parked our car and we took a walk to the square. Our idea was to take the subway from here into town, but this idea was dead before we started. We didn't yet have any Hungarian money, so we figured we could pay for tickets with our bank our creditcards. Normally this would have worked, but the machines for this were broken. When we went to ask one of the subway-employees about nearby ATMs they didn't understand us or couldn't explain where to find one. Either way we were forced to walk down the Andrassy street, where we found one about half way.As a general hint I would like to repeat there is a free parkinglot next to the square, and I would suggest to bring some cash forints if you would like to use the metro.

Very Impressive. It reminded us of the Tienanmen Square in China although a smaller one! We went to see the Circus nearby and than wandered off to nearby Heroes Square - we were quite impressed with the erected figures and the art museum. The square itself is expansive we had a lovely time.

Impressive. We hired a private guide which made this more meaningful. Understanding what each figure represents helps to understand the history of Hungary. The bridge and City Park was just beautiful. We spent over an hour just strolling through the park. It is beautifully landscaped with a treasure at every corner. The water features are so tranquil. We did lots of people watching as locals enjoyed this oasis in the middle of the city.The Castle Vajdahunyad is very impressive and well worth the visit, if only to photograph the outside. The lake provides an amazing opportunity for reflections of the castle. This was a high point of our visit to Budapest. There are many other attractions, a zoo, amusement park, art gallery, circus, botanical garden, and baths. We just could not fit all into our schedule.
Worth the Trip. While it was a little bit out of the way....historically and aesthetically well worth seeing. Also found a few nice pub type eateries out that way.

Impressive. Wander down from the nearby baths and spend time simply looking at this huge monument. It's in the middle of a busy road intersection so take care in crossing to get to it.
Well maintained and a poignant reminder of the struggles Hungary has faced

No trip to Budapest is complete without visiting..... Easy to access via the #1 metro, and located right next door to a massive park with the city's most famous of healing baths. This is a must see. It's a monumental square showcasing some of the finest leaders from Hungary's past. (Suggest getting a book or research on internet and take without you) if not getting a tour. Beautiful to walk around amongst some of the finest "heroes" of the last few thousand years.

A Monumental Square. Come here to get a sense of Hungarian history and pride. Need a guide book to learn about all the figures. It is flanked by two museums which take time to visit. Nearby is a park, zoo, amusement center, skating rink in winter, an old castle (now Agriculture museum) with eclectic and varied architecture styles [e.g. Transylvania] and fame Szechenyi Baths. Easy to get to by metro from city center.

Must-see in Budapest. I visited this when I was doing a tour of 'Pest' and it was magnificent! A trip to Budapest wouldn't be complete if you didn't come here and I'd advise doing a tour or getting a decent guide book so you know what the different statues :)

GREAT ATTRACTION - PITY ABOUT THE BRITS!. This square is a stunning example of the Hungarian love of the grand statement. Awesome statues that evoke the power and prestige of former empires. Easily reached via the Metro system which cost approx £1 per single ticket... ( I think... the Forin is a hard currency to get your head around.... my mind anyway.) On either side are two galleries, one featuring classic art, the other showing contemporary artwork. A great place to visit. Sadly when we were there a dozen or so young men peddled into the square on a contraption known as the beer bus, I think.... they then started acting like complete morons, even urinating openly in front of woman and children visitors to the square. My dismay when I heard their English accents cannot be put into words. The guide on our tour bus said, "every nation has its national traits.... this is the English way of doing things. Mortified!

Nice. The National Gallery of Fine Art on the right of the Square should be visited if you are there. The yellow metro (1) takes you to the Square. Remember leaving the entrance is on the other side of the boulevard from where you exited.

It does what it says on the tin. On the edge of the City Park, a good start to discovering about the ancient History of the peoples of Budapest.From a distance the sculptures look life size, when you reach the square the immense size and scale truly makes you in awe - as befitting heroes.Read a guide book so that the statues make sense- worth knowing what they all stand for.

Heroic Square.. Hero's Square is so large it makes one feel small. it can easily be reached by Hop on Hop off bus, or the Metro. The square stands in front of City Park where you will find Vajdahunyad Castle which houses the Agriculture Museum.

Overwhelming in Size and Scope. Heroes' Square is a stand-out monument in Budapest and should be visited. The Square is in a lovely part of the city near a Museum, an Art Gallery, a Park and a Zoo so a free stop here while visiting other attractions is a great idea! The statues of warriors and leaders are on a huge scale and are very impressive. I'm glad our guide took us there and I would certainly recommend it to other visitors to Budapest.
World Heritage Spot. Yes this is a must visit for anyone!!!Be sure to visit the square at night as well for incredible photos!!!

Huge square with huge monuments!. Entering this square you will feel extremely small. It is a huge open square surrounded by museums. In the center you will find the horse/rider statues and in the back about 14 hungarian important people like kings, saints and warriors. The sculptures are huge as well. For me personal one of the best squares. It is great to be visited combined with the park or some museums. A must see when in Budapest!
One more square. Just one more nice square with really nice statues but no more. I would visit the square only as part of a visit to the zoo and the park with the lake which are located nearby.

Amazing Square. I particularly liked this square. First of all it is huge as is everything in it. But I really liked the statues that were located in the square. Further walking up the street towards the square is quite nice as well as walking around the large park behind it.

Beautiful Monument. Went there in the middle of July with my girlfriend. We actually wanted to go to the Museum nearby , but we were astonished by the constructions. It was a nice summer day and the temperature wasn't that hot. It is just a beautiful monument. Everybody should go, because a part from the monument itself you have a museum and a very nice park all nearby!!
Huge!. Nice place to visit, just to see the enormous statue that they have put up here. Definitly a photo moment. The monument symbolises the 7 tribes that founded Budapest/Hungary.
A beautiful space. We enjoyed the space and memorials and then wandered into the park which has so much to see (and ice creams and welcome shade).
.... It is pretty amazing to see so if you are in the neighborhood, be sure to stop by! It's something that you have to see once :)
good, not great. It is a pretty monument but I can't say it is something extraordinary. The whole setting is nice to watch but it is not the best thing in Budapest.

Impressive. A really nice monument, situated in a beautiful location. Hungarian heroes are expressive and have a proud attitude. Architecture is a special one. It is a place that makes you feel proud in the presence of the heroes.
Large square with statues of heros. Large square in Budapest devoted to statues of it's hero's. Certainly worth a visit while in Budapest.

Monument But Gateway. This monument to fallen heroes and the tomb of the unknown soldier is beautiful and moving. It is flanked by art galleries and forms a gateway to the City Park with its many attractions such as its boating lake, zoo, spas and beautiful tree lined walks.
Nice to see. Very large square in the city with terrific statues. Worth a walk through while you are in the city. ON many transit routes.

Awesome. An amazing square. Very large. Like so many parts of Budapest, everything is large. Incredible statues give a sense of the place. Beautiful park behind the square. Amazing architecture either side with a gorgeous boulevard leading to it.

Impressive. This is a huge place where there is a lot of tourists. Worthy of going there to take a few photos. The Museuem of Fine Arts nearby is worth visiting as well, which is free for Budapass holders.

Wonderful architecture and sculptures. The Hero's Square is located near the city park, with majestic structures and sculptures of 'heros'. The place is wonderful except for the fact that there is no shelter nearby and it gets rather hot if you are going on a summer morning. Remember to take a photo of the museum left of Heroes Square!

Go there with a guide or guide book. One of the most visited places, but its really worth it if you know why are those huge statues there! Also interesting the area with the Andrassy Avenue, the City Park, Zoo, Amusment Park, and the two museum.

Take a quick stop here during your trip for a good photo opportunity. This is certainly a must see on your sight seeing itinerary as it is easy to get to on the metro and is an impressive monument. Stop here, take a few photos and then be on with the rest of your day; it is close to the zoo, circus and one of the bath houses so simple to incorporate in to another outing!

A Main Attraction in Budapest. This is a huge open square with beautiful statues of Hungarian heroes and kings. The square is flanked by museums/galleries and is adjacent to the city park. The statues are beautifully lit up at night

Square of Hungarian Heroes. Please note, that this square primarily is not a set of "the fashionable 21th century, most exciting, hidden treasure" type of place!!!It was built up to remember the great people of the Hungarian Kingdom who influenced the history of the nation. Ok, a few of the previous Habsburgs were replaced after the WWI, but most of them are the same as they were planned for the millennium in 1896.This is exactly a place where you should not go by hophop kind of tours... Take your guide (book or person) and get closer to them, let them reveal their stories to You.It can be fun with children to watch the horses, learn the names of the 7 leaders (Árpád, Előd, Ond, Kond, Tas, Huba, Töhötöm:)) or find out the main deeds of the kings in the semicircles by the subjects around them... as it is NOT audiovisual&interactive, pepole have to use "old type" of sightseeing. If you are not really for history, just go through the square to visit the City park, and for photographers I definitely recommend to return at night... it is worth visiting to learn about the history and culture of Hungary.Once you are there you can visit the Museum of Fine Arts for really good paintings and various temporary exchibition, with good cafe and bathroom possibility.

Overrated.. Heroe's Square is pretty! But it's not an activity. It's something you can see on the way to the market or the baths. In my opinion it's a little overrated. Maybe we just went on a slow day- but it's not the biggest "must see" on my list.

It's a 360 degree treat. This is only rated average because there are so many lovely examples of fine architecture in Budapest. The hop on hop off bus gives you the best chance if you are only here for a short time but I think you need at least 2 days. The square itself has some magnificent statutes and although it was v busy if you are a photographer, aim high and miss the crowds. Enjoy

Nice!. Not really in the center of the city but just at the end of Andrassy street (one of the most wonderful street of Pest), when you came out from the metro station you can see a very mirabile place with a statue on the center. Behind it there is a big park where you can relax and also the thermal bath. If you visit Budapest you must see it!
I felt like a queen!. Something about standing in the big square with impressive statues just made me feel like I was a hero too!

Huge & historical landmark of Budapest not to be missed ........ This is one of the historical landmarks of Budapest not to be missed ! A huge square with a monument that tells you the Hungarian history. Very good spot to make some photo shots, especially group photo's :-)

Very Nice Square. It is huge, and is filled with a very nice column and statues of important Hungarian people. Worth the time to take a moment, browse the figures of Hungary's past, and to watch the commotion of this city. Worthwhile experience for sure.
Very Impressive. HUGE when you get close up, interesting to wander round, easily accessibly via metro and close to city park for a nice wander

A go see location. One of the main attractions that Budapest has to offer. It’s quite a walk from the city center, but the street from the center to the square is a very nice one as there are many big and classical looking buildings along the way so you’ll have plenty to see. The first part also has lots of shops and cafés in case you fancy stopping for a drink along the way. The statues are nice to see and the square itself offers a starting point for the nearby zoo and ‘castle’ (which reminded me of these classical fairy tale castles).In case you don’t want to walk to the square and are already doing (or planning to do) the tourist sites, buy a ticket for one of the hop-on/hop-off busses.

Heroes' Square and Millennium Monument. I didn't dare miss one of the World Heritage sites, Heroes' Square. It is a spacious area with important significance to Hungarian history. It is between the Museum of Fine Arts and the Art Gallery, which I unfortunately did not have time to visit. It is within walking distance from Budapest zoo.

Imposing, grand , Impressive!. We approached Heroes square from Andrassy Bvl. The tall milleniumn column and the Victory bronze dominate the sky. Lower down there is a plain stone tomb for the unknown soldier and a massive stone pedestal displaying named bronze horsemen who figured in Hungarian history. The backdrop to the square are opposing plinth and column displays figuring the kings and statesmen of Hungary.These two imposing backdrops are themselves topped with enormous bronze chariots and liberty figures. A stunning and majestic display of liberty and nationalism.This square is a must see for tourists.Avoid buying the clothing offered for sale in heroes square. One wash and and the garment shrinks excessively.

Hero's Square - Budapest. Its a memorial building, so i guess theres no graves around, i dont really enjoy visiting this site, compare to the pallace and the parliament building, i prefer their architecture rather than this one

A significant historical point of Pest. I was on a Discover Budapest walking tour and Heroes' Square was part of the tour. I appreciated the historical significance of the area with the wonderful explanations given by the guide. Either read up the Square before you go, or join a walking tour.

Majestic Square. Heroes' Square is one of Budapest's major attractions. A majestic square dominated by the Millennium Column, it is easily accessible and has a great atmosphere. Built in 1896 to commemorate the arrival of the Magyars into the Carpathian Basin, it is flanked by the Museum of Fine Arts and the Art Gallery on either side.The City Park is also adjacent to the square. You can reach here by the yellow line of the Budapest Metro

You are the Hero !!. You ... The Hero , this is the feeling when you be there , in front of the Statues and the history you are one of them , the best time to be there between sunset and beginning of dark , amazing .
Loved the atmosphere. A place to definitely visit.Didn't know Hungary had so many heroes - the place is great for an early morning run.
Good place to start your adventure. This was a great place to begin our tour. Our guide gave a thorough overview of the seven tribes and the kings. The statuary is inspiring.

A Bliss to the Eye!. It is indeed a Bliss to ones eyes when you see the Heros Square. I wasnt aware of this attarction in Budapest,luckily while on the Hop On and Hop Off bus i got there and once saw it i had to certainly Hop off the bus to have a complete view of it. It is a huge round area with statues. A must place to see when in Budapest.

Take the metro!. The square was pretty impressive although it reminded me of the Brandenburg gate in Berlin, Germany. It's a easy metro ride to the square and once you take your photos of the square, you can take a nice stroll towards the park and the bath is right there too.

A huge and remarkable square.. Without a doubt this is one of the most beautiful attractions in the entire city, is great indeed immense and the monument that surrounds is admirable, this vast area gave me the impression of grandeur and majesty.It is not very crowded and for this reason I was able to enjoy it.Reach it is easy thanks by subway train station located around the area.

We didn't allow enough time for this end of Andrassy. We explored this area briefly, and in passing, on our way to the Baths, and it was a mistake. Most of our time was spent in other parts of Pest, all great, but I think we should have allowed more time for Heroes' Square, and surrounds, including galleries/museums and park area.But it gives us a good reason to go back!
Gives a good overview of historic leaders. There was a lot of tour groups and getting nice photos was difficult. Easy to find with bus transportation nearby.

Monumental. If you think Brandenburg Gate is spectacular you have to see this! Ominous characters and the size of the square is quite amazing! Went here after visiting the park and the baths ( a must do) - then walked quite a few blocks towards the Danube for a lovely lunch

Great feel, must visit. Andressy Avenue culminates in Hero's square which is a huge Square with a tall column in its center and is a shrine to all the slain soldiers of the World Wars. In front of the column are statues of 7 men on horses (who signify the 7 tribes that settled here in the 9th century and thus formed Budapest). Behind it in 2 semi circular formations are statues of some of the kings of here and freedom fighters.On both sides are the two imposing & beautiful buildings; Museum of Fine Arts and the Palace of Arts. On front is the Andressy Avenue and behind it is he City park which has the zoo as well.

Majestic view of the architecture. This is a large square in Budapest with statues and columns. It is flanked by two buildings, the Museum of Fine Arts on the left and Palace of Art on the right. One is supposed to be international art while the other more contemporary art. We did not visit the museums so unable to comment. Across the road from the square there were some slight of steps leading to an underground toilet. The most expensive toilet I have encountered in Eastern Europe, Euro $1 per visit although it is modern, clean and pleasant.

A must see. We visited heroes square, and were impressed with the statues and the atmosphere. Definitely worth a visit. Just behind heroes square is the park, which is also well worth a walk around. Very pretty.

Asian link in Europe. At the centre seats warriors on horse backs. They looked awesome in their armor and weapons. It was explained that they actually come from Asia. Amazing to learn that Asians also played a part in European history. The other statues at the square featured different heroes and rulers who have influenced Hungary. Being physically at the square gives one a 'heroic' feeling, no matter where you may come from. It would be a great place, especially for students, to have an outdoor history lesson of Hungary.

Good. This did not make such a big impression on me. It made lovely photos though. There are a lot of thing aroud this to see. This erea is very beautiful. I think a museum of art or art gallery is situated right nect to the Heroe's Square, but unfortunatly it was not open on the day we were there. That might be an option doing it in one trip if you are an art lover.

Lovely square. Lovely square at the end of Andrassy Street(easy to get by yellow lane metro for example). Lots of other attractions around the square too. So it's a day visit if you go to zoo, city park, Vajdahunyad castle etc. same time
A lovely Monument. A lovely Monument to the hero's who died. The square is stunning at night when it is lit up, there is also a beautiful fiver behind it with lots of cafes to visit.
Best Place in Budapest!. Heroes´Square is my favorite place in Budapest.I just love the view down the Andrassy Utca.Its best when its already dark to see the lights.
A must see. Great to visit early in the morning when it's quiet - great space for taking photos, nearby museum / park & Zoo can all be visited to make a good day out
a grand square. We disliked the ultra-right-wing demonstration, attended by three onlookers. Loved the big square, which made the fascists seem even more pathetic and insignificant.
Beautiful to visit at night. You can take awesome pictures there. Winter snow gives it a very nice feel. And you get to use the historic underground.

Beautiful to see. Beautiful to look at, but stay away from violin player looking for money from Americans. They always hang out by heroes square and if you approach they start playing. Now for the attraction. There's a lot of information and history about heroes square. We were shown in during a Segway tour and the guide explained about each figure represented. It's a 10 -15 minute attraction.

Great memorial. Very beautiful memorial and a must see if you are in town. We stopped here during a bus tour. The rain prevented us from doing the bike tour. But it was worth stopping on the bus and seeing the beautiful monuments.

Good for a visit. Very impressive square - quite difficult to access because of road layout and lack of pedestrian crossings, but worth the effort - we went on to visit the park beyond the square and it made for a most enjoyable morning visit
Historic point but that's it. Not to undermine history, it's one of those points to tick off on the visit list, not really a great deal to see.....
Meaningful Monument. Heroes Square deserves a visit and your appreciation. A monument to great Hungarians of the Past. The statues are beautiful. Also has the tomb of the unknown soldier.

Peaceful park adjoining Heroes square. Very interesting square and statues to see. Adjoining this was a large and peaceful park with a large lake, and restaurants nearby. We spent several hours here laid on towels on the grass in a quiet corner in the sun. Very relaxing before joining the hussle and bussle of city again.
A vast place to gather. It's an inspiring place to visit for the locals and you will be too when you see it and walk around. Nothing like it anywhere else.
Outstanding historical tribute.. Magnificent statues in a clean inviting park setting. High on the visit list and think there is a market available on the weekends.
Enjoy the view in the evening`. Nice place to visit,spent some time in evening and waited till the lights were on,enjoy the heroes' Square view and near by areas.
Nice. A nice memorial. We were not able to get off the bus, but the memorial was very nice from the bus. It would be worth it to stop and get out,

Good place to start. Heroes square, adjacent to a large park and several museums, is a good place to start off a tour of Budapest. If you can either use a good travel guide or (even better) hire a local guide to step you through who the statues represent, you'll get a concise history of the Hungarian people -- and a nice framework on which to place further information from other sites you visit.Easily accessible by metro or bus, it's also not a very far work from Deak Square -- the main transit hub in Pest.

Nice but pompous. As always when nationalism and history merge, it often is a bit too much for me. The setting is ok, clean and straight (as everything in Budapest). Worthy of seeing but not a too big loss if you don't have the tine. There are places up in Buda which are more to study.

This was a really long walk and quite disappointing. The park behind is worth a look, there's some beautiful buildings there, especially if you take the right hand side. The square I would say is just OK.

Big round square. Go for the museum, park and bathes that are around it. The square is full of statues of historic figures. If you are knowledgable regarding Hungarian history or really care to learn then the experience of going here will be more valuable than it was for me.

Historic and Beautiful. For Hungary's 1000th anniversary (in 1896), the city of Budapest decided to build palatial monuments to show essence of the countries history, and look to the future.Heroes square is one of those monuments built in the Budapest city park (the park was also built for the 1896 celebrations).The statues display the Kings of Hungary, as well in the center the 7 Vezér that brought the Magyars to the Carpathian basin to settle... now modern day Hungary.In the central landing of the monument is also the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.The square is facing southwest, directly looking onto Andrássy Street towards the center of Budapest.Parking is limited, and so the best way to get to the monument is perhaps a trip on the Földalatti (M1 subway). The Földalatti was the first underground subway in continental Europe, also built for the 1896 Millennium celebrations.(...of course it has since been updated and maintained to modern standards).In the city park, you will also find a man-made lake surrounding a replica castle displaying differing architectural styles (Vajdahunyad Vár, now the agricultural museum). On the lake boat rentals are available in the summer and ice skating in the winter.There are many other attractions in the city park, so plan your day for walking, and make sure your memory cards have space to take a lot of pictures.This sight is breathtaking!

Must-visit. A beautiful monument which is one of must-visit places while in Budapest. We were lucky to see some sort of a tribute by the army when we were there. It was in the afternoon. There is also a big park nearby. Located at the end of the popular Andrassy way, it is the place to go for tourists

Beautiful square with pretty buildings. This heroes square is one of the most visited place by tourist. We took hop on- Hop off bus and one of the stop is the heroes square. It has got some pretty buildings surrounding on all four sides. The history behind the name is that it was named after all unknown soldiers or Heros during the war and this name is to honor them and remember their heroism for ever. Also close by is the Zoo which is one of the oldest zoo in the world. Just walking around in the square and visiting different building is fun.

nice to see. we visited this location with our tour it was nice to hear the history about the statues as well as looking around the area. there is a park behind the square. go take a look when you visit..

Great to see it again (and again). The entrance to the nice park behind and the Szechenyi bathhouse; heroes' square is definitely worth while a stop. Also visit the surrounding museums and go for lunch to the famous Gundel restaurant.

There are many activities to do there. In Heroes' square area you will find many things to do, there is a small lake in which you can rent a boat and take a trip there, a Zoo, Circus, a wonderful palace, go to the fine art museum, have a drink and shisha in Kara cafe which is close to it.

Lovely area in Budapest. Arriving the square by metro, we started by the city park and walked through it to the Heroes' square. It is a beautiful one surrounded by beautiful buildings. We enjoyed it. One can spend some time seeing the those buildings and taking pics of the statues in the middle of the square.

Tour Guide made it worth the stop. The tour guide shared the history that each large statue commemorated and added lots of context. Without his direction we would not have stopped. Parking is a challenge. Watch out for busses in the parking area. Ignore the "vendors." Especially ignore the iPhone salesmen.

Historic square. On every tour group’s itinerary it can get busy at such times with added hawkers peddling guide books and knitted jackets. But the square is big enough. The statues are large and interesting but without a guide to explain the significance of what one is looking at a visit will not be as meaningful.

It was ok.... It was just a square to me and I chanced upon it after visiting the par and the Szechenyi Baths.
There was a small parade going on and the soldiers look sloppy with their March.
Amazing scale.. Its a big square alright but worth visiting just to stand in the middle and get that feeling of space in an urbam pile.
Fantastic. Well worth a visit, not only for the monuments but its proximity to many other 'must sees'. Walk up Andréssy and enjoy some spectacular examples of buildings.

Fun. It's great for photographs or watching amateur artists sketch. The statues are gigantic. Worth a look if your in the area. It's surrounded by art galleries if you like art. It's in the middle of the road and it takes some patience getting across. Was nice to see but I wouldn't go out of my way next time.

Great walk to Heroes Square. My friend and I walked down Andrassy Blvd from the Opera down to Heroes Square and it was very nice. It's a bit over a mile and you do pass by a lot of different buildings from the House of Terror to various embassies. The street is lined with canopied trees making the walk very pleasant before you reach Heroes Square.
Lots of history. Huge square full of history. All of the statues surronding the square were part of Budapests' history which was very interesting to learn.
Worth the Visit.... It is a typical memorial, but the statues and history are quite impressive. If in Budapest, this should be one of your stops.
Impressive view. Do your homework what these all statues are all about and you'll get much more about this and learn Hungarian history, too.

Amazing, Amazing, Amazing. Our tour with Discover Budapest, was a 3 hr walking tour and our tour guide Andi, took an amazing amount of time to explain each statue to us. Beware of peddlers in the square as they are selling everything from books to food.

History and art combined. We had a wonderful guide who explained the history of the many sculptures and bronze statues to us. Not to be missed. In retrospect I would have read up on the history of the area prior to going.

Nice. The Hero's Square is a nice piece of architecture that represents the rich cultural and historical past of Budapest. The zoo is located right next to this and hence we visited this place enroute to the zoo.

Gigantic Intimidating Square. You really sense the grandiose achievement these heroes did in any field they were in, by just standing in the middle of that square. so impressive and one of the best and unexpected squares in Budapest, and we were pleasantly surprised by this location as my husband and I were just wandering around in the city. It is a must see of course.

Imposing. This is a truly imposing site, dominated by the statues representing the chiefs of the seven Magyar tribes that settled in the current area known as Hungary. I'd hate to run up against any of them on the battlefield. The square is plenty large enough to hold all the various statues without seeming cramped. Easily accessible by metro. You need to go.

Superb!. In the end of Andrassy ut, this square is absolutely the best one in Budapest! The statues made all the square very suggestive, because they represent the portraits of the 7 leader of the 7 clans that founded Hungary.
' A big Square'. A big square surrounded by traffic, reasonably impressive monument but nothing to get excited about.

Lovely setting. This monument is constructed away from downtown where one can really enjoy the statutes. The two museums nearby are not at all distracting, and it gets you into a quiet area. Very well done! You need to research this before you visit.

Awe inspiring!. Beautiful location! The statues there are well preserved. The place remind me of Paris in a way. Both sides are 2 museums with murals which are beautiful and also well preserved. Lots of parking space.

magyar history at its best.... tourists central, see panoramic views down the andrassy ut...and across too the vajdahunyad castle from transylvania...a mini open air museum...is here and varosliget the city park behind...szechenyi baths...too

interesting. Again we viewed thos site with a guide. This is a must so as to get a proper perspective on the history of Budapest and Hungary, its rulers, its heroes as well as the role the Church played in the past venturies

Stunning Statuary. Amazing statues, close to the Fine Arts museums and nearby is a beautiful boating lake and castle and the Zoo!The Antique cafe just adjacent to the Fine Arts Museum is a wonderful place to sit and have lunch and a coffee outside or in!We walked staright up from the Terror Museum and sat on the steps for a rest which was lovely.

Impressive Square. We knew we wanted to see Heros' Square, but didn't know we would come out of the subway right across the street. As I walked up the stairs, I was struck by the magnificence of the statues and the wide open space. Even the buses of tourists didn't deter me as there was plenty of room for us all. You don't need to plan for more than 30 minutes here, but if you are going to the museums nearby, add this to your itinerary.

A must while in Budapest. Heroes Square is a must and is flaked by the Museum of Fine Arts and Palace of Art. Don't miss the city park a stones throw away where there are cafes and boating lake. Also there is the Vajdahunyad Castle. Beautiful building
nice place. very inpresive to see all the passt leaders of hungarian people during the history the square is very large and the muzeums on both side of thes quare are very inpresionant

Special treat, we saw their Memorial ceremony. The square itself is a large plaza area with a number of Hungarian heroes depicted. Makes nice photos. We happened to be there when they were laying memorial wreaths and having a big military ceremony complete with soldiers, flags, and bands. So it was interesting to have that experience which does not happen every day.

Beautiful statutes with nice mustaches. The walk down the promenade to Heroes' Square, lines with the various countries' embassies, trees, and cafes is gorgeous in itself. The end point into the Square is not breath-taking, but it is rather nice. More research on it is needed for me to understand who the people are and why it was built, but the statutes were huge and well done. There is one horse rider with a killer mustache, too. He was my favorite. Plus, there is a palace/museum and a park behind it on a little lake that are quite charming. Plus there is a beer tent with live music for those more interested in that kind of fun :) Worth the trip and it will not take all day.
great to see. Only saw this from the top of the tourist bus but it was very clean and the statues are amazing. Well worth seeing.

Heroes Square. Great architecture & memorial to Hungarian heroes. Located next to Hungarian museum of Fine arts, Szechnyi baths etc at the end of Andrassy street - so all of this can be visited the same morning or afternoon.
Awesome. Great square with many historical memories of the previous past of this country. Good location to visit the main park of the city and on the line of old metro of Budapest

An historical landmark in Budapest!. After a wonderful meal at the nearby Paprika Vendéglő Étterem, our family took a nice evening stroll to Heroes Square in Budapest. This is one of the major outdoor areas in the city, and the history that is depicted here is amazing. Located at the intersection of Andrássy Avenue and Dózsa György Way, the square itself is bordered by two important and imposing buildings. The Hall of Art [aka the Palace of Art] is a museum of contemporary art, and the Museum of Fine Art [Szépművészeti Múzeum] houses over 100.000 objects in the areas of Ancient Egypt art, classical antiquities, Old Masters’ paintings, early sculpture, drawings and prints, and art produced after 1800. Also bordering the square is the Serbian embassy, as well as a private residence. The City Park also skirts the square. If you have plenty of time, visit both of the museums, and also take a leisurely walk through the park...they’re all worth a visit!!At the center of the square is the famous Millennium Memorial, which features a tall column with a statue of the Archangel Gabriel on top, holding the Hungarian Holy Crown. At the base of the column are statues of the seven chieftains of the tribes that established Hungary as a state in the 9th century. Their leader, King Árpád, is considered the founder of the Hungarian nation. The statues are imposing figures on their horses.The other statues found in two identical colonnades are of famous people in Hungarian history. Each colonnade is topped with bronze statues that symbolize war and peace, labor and wealth, and knowledge and glory. This historic Hungarian square is awesome in the daytime, and is even more majestic under the lights at night!

A must for all visitors,gets busy and has lots of hawkers. The number of coaches parked up informs you that this is a cornerstone of the visit to Budapest. It is very interesting, but gets very busy and there's a need to keep your wits about you in terms of personal possessions and personal space.
Everyone stops here, and so should you. Filled with history, and mobbed with people, the Square is a must see, but a short one. Much else to see with greater enjoyment.

Large and imposing square. This is spectacular the statues are amazing, we were lucky enough to see the soldiers on parade and dignitaries were placing wreaths on the memorial. This is a memorable location.

Hero's Square - Hungarian History. Although the square itself is nothing special, remember that you are standing in a location with historical significance for Hungary. The site of many demonstrations, including the location of the Stalin statue that was pulled down and destroyed during the Hungarian Revolution in 1956.
What Scale. This is on a large scale, telling the story of Hungary with huge statues and archway. It rivals anything in Europe and is a must visit
Go to the parks behind the Square. It is a really interesting square however visit the parks behind the square. Boating pond, restaurant and a medieval castle await.

Impressive!. This is a huge open area and the monuments around it are extremely impressive. We were there last week and were lucky enough to be entertained by a full military marching display and band. Excellent!

A must see in Budapest!. This was an awesome attraction! So, amazing. According to my husband it's better in the dark. There are lights right behind all the statues. It's really interesting. Make sure you go after lunch around maybe 2pm. It won't be so crowded. :D

Monuments to Common People. Well again this City makes you feel very tiny everything is on a grand scale such a huge area paying tribute to their ordinary people I know it's politics and not everyone had such a good time in this era but the square is very impressive. We had a nice reasonably priced lunch in the Art Centre in the square.

Impressive square with beautiful monuments. A must see for any tourist to Budapest.
Great place for photographs to mark your visit to Budapest.
The Millennium Memorial has statues of the leaders of the seven tribes that founded Hungary in the 9th century plus other famous Hungarian historical figures.
A sense of History. Originally built to commemorate 1,000 years of Hungarian history, but updated with a memorial to 20th Century conflict. Some great statuary. Well worth a guided tour.
Very interesting. It's a must-see place in Buda, together with the Vajdahunyak castle nearby - lots of statues, very beautiful and artistic.
Beautiful architecture. Well worth a visit. Each piece of architecture tells a different story which only adds to the interest of this incredible city

Heroes Square. big open space and if you like statues this place has a few. Good for the bus tours and there are a couple of large exhibition halls at either side, These have different themes.
Also a very nice view of the Avenues
Sense of history. A worthwhile place to visit, plenty of space to walk around just watch the traffic as you cross the road to get onto the main square!

At the end of lovely Adrassay Ave lies Heroes Square. Flanked by two museums, the square is an interesting stop aftera walk along the avenue.
Most tour groups stop here briefly.
It is also the home of the wonderful Fine Arts Museum
A magnificent place. The most amazing sculptures and you can really get some great pics. Spent ages there and took lots of pics.
impressive,. it's an impressive square, but also the castle behind the square is very impressive and surprizingly non-tacky

A wonderful place close to parks and spa. Historic times reflected through the various statues of rulers and royalty, it is well worth having a guide to explain the importance of the constituent statues of this monument and you will then start to realise what a myriad of identities and changes Hungary and Budapest has had to endure over the yearsIt was summed up for me when the guide said since 1989 after shaking the yolk of communism we are a new young country still trying to come to terms with our freedom!

Worth visiting as you're passing through. This Square is huge, built in 1896 ish before the millenium celebrations. Huge place, large grand statues, lots of tourists.Located at the top of Andrassy ave and near the City Park, so good to spend some time snapping.
Great specticle. To visit the tomb of the unknown soldier in any city is a moving experience the architecture of the monuments is worth seeing.
Visit. When you have the time and the weather is good, walk into the park behind Heroes' square. In the park is also one of the 2 popular bathhouses.

Nice visit. Went here while on a Trafalgar tour. Good place for pictures if you're interested. It has all of their important kings/queens/rulers in sequential order and is something the Hungarians are proud of. If you can't get over, no worries though.

Take a enjoyable break. If you have been disappointed with the Buda side - the citadelle and the royal palace (more a market than a historic place), please visit this park and these monuments to gain respect for Hungarian history and present time. Very lovely and relentless park. Tasteful monuments and beautiful historical buildings. Also the international neighborhood supports the idea of honorable history of Hungary.
Peacefull but not at night. A lovely square but can be spoilt by skateboarders a great photo opportunity and a nice walkway to the park and the baths

an insight into Hungarian history. what a majestic show piece to outline the history of the country. If you get a chance to visit the square with a guide, it will make more sense, but make sure you take a photo of the statues of the Magyar horsemen. Then go visit the baths.

Be amazed. What an incredible city, I was totally amazed at the wonderful architecture, fantastic buildings, wonderful views. Stunning when all the historical buildings, bridges, and the castles are all lit up at night with the beautiful river Danue following in the middle. Walk up to the castle during the day and be amazed at the panaramic view of Budapest and the Danue. Restraunts are plentiful and top quality, prices are about the same as in England. Change your currency in Budapest you get a much better exchange rate than at your bank.
Huge. This is a really impressive square with amazing statues around the perimeter and heroic monument in the centre - the statues all looked like something out of Lord of the Rings.

Big, bigger, biggest. Take the millenium metro line from the city to the Heroes'square.It will take you to a journey into the 19 th century...Heroes'square is impresive, big, bigger. It is all about history, politics. Take the opportunity to visit the parc and the baths.

Heroes Square. We visited here again during the day and night and to try and get an amazing photo you have to dodge the tourists, although our night photos are excellent and the square was empty, maybe due to the fine drizzle at the time. Certainly worth a visit

Well worth a visit!!. What a lovely place! My friend and i visited here. Everywhere so clean. There is also a Museum nearby that you can visit. Unfortunately we couldn't as we were short of time,so much to see!!

I expected more. We visited in winter and so it was a little uncomfortable to be outside in wide open spaces for a long time. Maybe this affected my enjoyment of the experience. It is an amazingly large square and the statues are very striking, but I did walk away feeling a little underwhelmed. There is a huge park and open air ice rink nearby!
Nice square, worths a visit. Go there during daytime, walk on the wonderful Andrassy blvd, that end there. Then continue to the Szechenyi baths and the City park.

Impressive square. The Heroes' Square is very impressive and great for some lovely holiday photos. Worth visiting along with the park behind which has the famous baths, and also a zoo and a fair. There is a flea market in the park also which is bustling and full of bargains but be prepared to rummage to find those gems!

Place to start journey in Budapest. If you're in Budapest for the first time this is the place where you should start your journey. Heroes' Square is one of the biggest squares, and apart from its size it has so many attractions nearby. When you arrive at the Square don't miss visiting Museum of Fine Arts and Art Gallery to indulge your artistic interests. There is also Zoo, Vidampark and Circus for entertainment. Walk through the green fields of the park behind the Square and you will get to the Museum of transportation. And after a long day around Heroes' Square you should spend the evening at Szechenyi Termal Bath, of course if you can afford it because it's not very cheap.

A monumental piece of history. The hero square comprises the monumental sculptures of all Hungarian leaders, from the settlement of the Hungarian people into the Pannonian planes until the Hungarian revolution in 1848. Under each statue there is a relief depicting some of the important scenes from the rulers' lives, each with an adequate description (though without English translation, unfortunately). Whether you are a history buff, an art admirer or just keen on a pleasant walk on a large square (or perhaps, on your way to the city park), you will enjoy the Heroes square.
Worth a Visit!. A quiet park like setting in back of statues. There is a small castle, benches to sit and have a snack, and the famous baths:)

A heroic-sized square. This is a very big area and the best thing was the statuary done in bronze. There are many representations of kings and rulers past that are huge and fanciful. There also stone statues of all Hungary's past important people as well.
Amazing views all the way down Andrassy way. Great wide open space, next to Cinderella palace. Fantastic statues but some English interpretation would help most non hungarians
impressive. The tall statues are very impressive. They really seem warrior like When you think they were made in a time of budding nationalism you can understand the sentiment of the makers.
Lovely place for a walk. We went Sunday, surrounded by parks and museums and boating lakes. A must see as the actual square and the statues are amazing.

Great to visit day or night. Appears to be very popular with coach tips. At night the monuments are all lit up and there are many restaurants to visit by the lake.By day you can also visit the zoo, the spa baths and many museums that are adjacent to the square.
Wasn't amazing. The metro line we got onto to get there was a bit shoddy, and it wasn't the best place to visit, just a standard huge square with some statues
Budapests Trafalgar Square. Impressive statues and column. Cross the road and stroll round the lovely park with a stop for drinkies at one of the cosy cafes. Metro right to the door.
great statues. worth a visit before heading to the Szechenyi Bath as its close by. the statues are really worth taking pictures of.

A NICE SQUARE WITH ALL HEROES OF HUNGARY. Thanks to God we had our guite , a very sweet Hungarian girl , who told us all the history of Hungary,standing in the middle of this large square, where is the Millenium Memmorial.We saw the statues of the leaders of the seven tribes of Hungary, some other heroes and of course the statue of St. Stephen, the 1st King og Hungary.The Heroes Square is at the end of Andrassy Avenue where you can find also the Budapest's Opera House. Left of Heroes Sq. is the Fine Arts Museum and right, is the Palace of Arts and the Turkish Baths oh Hungary.Very near is the Zoo, the city-park and an artifficial lake.It's a good to go there if you have enought time,you can take the M1 line of the metro and it takes you direct.

A grand monument at the end of beautiful Andrassy. This monument is the gateway to a park, near two museums, and is at the end of beautiful Andrassy Avenue, a UNESCO World Heritage site, for its beautiful architecture and high style. Go here is the morning and spend the day in the area--it is well worth it. Another reviewer said it reminded them of the Brandenburg Gate, and while that is somewhat true because of the semi-circular construct, this monument has a proper grand setting that makes it more special and impressive.

Put it in the to do list.. It is a great place because it is near the city park which is really nice to go for a walk and also after that you can make it on foot to go all the yay down to andrassy street (where the posh shops and opera are)...As a square is really big but don't expect something very special!

A Place to Learn More Than First Expected. The centre of Heroes Square is dominated by a monument to the leaders of the warrior tribes that first settled in the area we no geographically call Hungary. It's really interesting to take a guided tour in your own language to hear about those leaders that many Hungarians would be unable to name. Around the square are monuments to the great leaders of the country and nearby there is a Zoo, Parkland Amusement Park and a former castle now housing the agriculture museum. A place to learn more than you might first expect.

Impressive square. We crossed the main road taking our lives in our hands - we couldn't find any pedestrian crossings to reach the square, and the traffic was going round like a roundabout! But all was calm in the centre, and the sheer dimensions of the monuments were impressive. Then to cross the road again to get off - use the traffic lights!
Touch of time.... Touch of time truly, you feel the powerful heroes there! Amazing. Tip: take a walk to the octogon square.

Add another square to my list. I have been to many squares - Tiananmen Square in Beijing, Red Square in Moscow, St Peter's Square in Vatican City, St Mark's Square in Venice, Times Square in New York, Trafalgar Square in London, Concorde Square in Paris. Have added this to the list.This square is next to a park and there are restaurants around this place.
My Hero. Nice square flanked by two art museums on opposite ends, and also a park on the one side with a castle. Great historic purpose and fabulous statues. Easy to get to by Blue Bus or Tram.
Beautiful. A beautiful place to walk and admire. Unfortunately some of the buildings are damaged. In April the weather was cold and cloudy, but however we really enjoyed the visit to this place.
Amazing Place!. Heroes Square is absolutely huge and really impressive. A little tricky to get across the busy roads but it is well worth a visit and an excellent photo opportunity
Hösöm ter. You'll get the best pictures when the sun starts setting... from there go to the castle (in the back of the square). It's worth a visit.

Like so many others. Like so many squares with so many monuments in so many cities, taken on it's own there is nothing to particularly set this one apart, but spend a bit of time here and at the other sights in the park and it's a pleasant way to spend a lazy afternoon.
Historic area. Located in a park-like area it is dedicated to all who have died fighting for Hungary. A must see and don't foget your camera.

Inspiring place. Not sure why I enjoyed this as much as I did, since so much of Budapest is just spectacular. I think part of it was seeing the grandeur of it just steps from the subway. (I recommend using the subway to get there)
A nice square. A nice location at the top of Andrassay. Lovely walk up to it and lovely stop off to walk around the park.

HUGE!. All the statues represent important Hungarians throughout history, including Kings, Politicians and men of Faith. Surrounded by the new and old art museums in Budapest, the Square can get a bit mobbed by tourists, but visiting early helps. Convenient for visiting City Park too.

Large, green surroundings, history. This square is one of the MUST GO places in Budapest, there are statues of the most of the influential Hungarians around the square. It is very close to City Park, thermal Szechenyi bathes, Amusement Park, circus, etc.
Magnificent. Truly a great Palazzo, given to the essential historical characters of the Hungarian Empire. Lots to see and learn. A definite must when visiting Budapest.

Yeah but..... It looks impressive - at the top of a marvellously long road. BUt it was teeming with tourists moving around like ants and ultimately we felt a bit underwhelmed by the whole experience.
Take care crossing the road, and don't expect to find an array of places to eat and drink there.

very nice place to have photographs..especially by night. Get M1,to "Hosok ter station", M1 is a very very "primitive" metro, ( you may do not believe that there is still a working Metro like that!!!". Very spacious square. May be the largest in Budapest. Prepare your Camera for a lot of photographs.
A good area to look around.. We did a hop on hop of bus tour and it was worth getting off here to have a look at the square then cross over to the thermal baths for a swim.

A sightseeing must!. Just recently back from Budapest on our latest annual City Break trip with work colleagues. We initially caught sight of Heroes Square on the Hop On/Hop Off bus tour on the Friday morning. Having decided that we must try the Szchenyi Spa & Pools, we decided to walk to them from the Hotel, later that afternoon. We stopped at Heroes square to take photos and judging by the amount of tourists that actually get off the bus at this particular spot, it is easy to see why it is such a popular landmark for tourists.The square itself is immaculate and it is certainly one stop that you should make on your visit to Budapest
Nice place. It is one of the places in Budapest which obligatory to visit at least once for everybody. Not for from the Hero's square you may find the Szecsenyi Baths. Do not think - go there.

Come with a guide or guidebook. Heroes Squares captures a lot of the rich and challenging history of Hungary in one spot. A visit to Budapest without a visit to Heroes Square would be shortchanging your trip. However, unless you have a good guide or a guidebook that explains what you are seeing in all the busts, statues, and national symbols, you will not get much out of this impressive area. A little bit of advance preparation and reading will pay off here.The site is relatively easy to get to via the Millenium (Yellow) line on the metro. Nearby are other stops that you might want to consider: the City Park, the zoo, Gundel restaurant, the Szechenyi baths, and more.There is no cost to visit the Square.
Impressive. Visited on a fine, sunny day. The dimensions are impressive. Building in those days was on a magnificent scale. Worth a visit but make sure the weather is fine.

Epic!. To your average tourist hitting the high points in Budapest, this place is nothing extraordinary, but to hear some of the history from a local, that indeed is worth the visit. I would highly recommend a visit to this area. Take some time to soak it in and imagine what it was like the morning when heroes were born.
Hero's Square. On a rainy day it still makes a strong statement, or maybe even more so as there are few heros without death and foreboding weather suits it well.

Paris has nothing on Budapest. Paris has their De Gaulle and Napoleon- well, this is Budapest's answer to Paris. Beautiful square lots of good photo opps. Be sure to visit the Scheyngi Baths just behind it ( yellow building) and the Park with a Transylvannia Castle replica!

I've seen more impressive squares. Just a nice square, looks very Soviet, i was surprised it was built in the times of Austria-Hungary. Check out museums, oldest stations of Budapest subway and Vajdahunyad castle.

Great, but needs more English explanations. Very beautiful and pleasant square, with huge potential in tourism. But just like many other beautiful sites in Budapest: needs more English explanations!i would love to know who are the heroes and what they did while passing good time walking on the square
Androssy utci. the complete package of walking this avenue from deak ter to the heroes square is something that needs doing and the square at the end will be a memorable finale.

Hilarious statues!. This is definitely a pace to visit with a guide and a camera. The history of each of the statues is really interesting and the area is very picturesque. I don't know whether the Hungarians have a deliberate sense of humour when it comes to their statues but many of them are either very camp or wearing "interesting" garments! Recommended.

A Landmark. Every tour that you'll do of Budapest will at least drive you past Heroes' Square. It is a rather imposing square in the middle of a busy traffic circle with a museum on either side of it. The statues in the square are huge and will be the subject of any pictures that you take of the square. Don't miss it.

Good but - not as spectacular as I thought it would be. Walked here via Andrassy from my hotel one Saturday - and went to the Park and the Zoo after it. The memorials are impressive but once you have photographed them and taken in what it all means, there really is not much else to do - okay for what it is
beautiful square but nothing mus to do. It looks beautiful and can walk along the Andraasy avenue all the way. It is nearby the metro station.Nothing much to do here after taking few photos

Great Square. Its a beautiful square.Nice pictures can be clicked here..Behind Heroes' Square is City Park where you can visit other places like Vajdahunyad Castle,Sezncheny Thermal Baths, the Great Circus, the Museum of Agriculture etc. You can spend a day(or half) in this area covering these places.
Spectacular. very splendid and bigger than expected and a great opportunity for photos, if a little dodgy with traffic!
Heroes' Square. We took the Metro to Heroes' Square saw the Monuments to the Founders of Hungary and then walked back into town down Andrassay Avenue to the centre.

Beautiful!.... Nice area to spend the day. The walk to Heroes Square from the Ibis Heroes Square took maybe 3minutes. The square is beautiful...It is an easy trek on your tourist-filled day. Take lots of pictures and enjoy the view and the time spent at this lovely location. The statues surrounding the square are lovely and tells a story. Its a must see!The zoo, another attractioin is not too far. The fine art museum is also adjacent (if you like da Vinci and a world class museum). The place is absolutely in a great location and close to many tourist attractions. - REALLY worthwhile and in my opinion, you have not visited Budapest until you have seen this square. There is no cost for this attraction.
Pretty Square. Easiest way to get there is to take the subway. There's a stop right at Heroe's Square. Also, near the square-Szecheniy baths, Circus, and zoo.

Interesting square that reflects the history of the city. The statues are very interesting when you read up on the history behind them. The park behind the square is well worth wandering around, there is an open air ice rink in the winter and the famous baths at the back. Despite the area being interesting for turists, it is full of locals taking their dogs for walks at the week end and has a pleasant atmosphere.

Pictoresque square surrounded by interesting monuments. The central monument, remeniscent of Nelson's colume, is surrounded by other interesting monuments. It is a lovely square to walk around, and many other thing to visit are found nearby.
Iconic. You'll feel small standing in the middle of this square. Get a panorama shot, then walk over to Varosliget.

Must see in Budapest. This is one of the must-see places in Budapest. Grand and glorious. Two big and interesting museums on both sides of the square and of course the great City Park right behind it (with a castle, flea market and famous spa). So there's lots to see and do in this area after you've seen the grand square with all it's heroes.Ps. If you're going there on a nice day, there are two wonderful boulevards nearby. The great Andrássy út of course but also Városligeti Fasor (runs parallel to Andrássy). So if you like walking, stroll down either of these wonderful streets.

WOW!. This is on the Yellow Metro Line 1, in itself worth a trip. The stations have all been renovated and have white tiles and beautiful woodwork. The station is Hosok ter. As you come up the steps, the monument is in front of you- a real WOW! moment
Don't miss these fabulous statues. Wonderful statues - even though it was a really hot day - I spent ages walking around. Then across the street to a lake and rehydration
Beautiful place. A nice park near by, ice-skating ring in the winter and definitely worth a glance when coming through Budapest
breathtaking. the statues around the square are amazing, plenty of photo opportunities and also a good place to people watch, walk through the square on your way to the baths and gardens
City Break. It was raining at the time so didn't stay too long - loved its size and buildings/monuments. Great for photographs.
Great area. Whilst in Budapest ,don't miss the chance to visit Heroes' Square. It is off Andrassy street in the picturesque Park area. Adjacent to the Zoo,lakes,and pleasant City parkland.

great memorial. very impressive to walk up from the metro and see this huge square in front of you with the giant statues of the 7 men who led the Magyars to Hungary and the important people in the niches behind. Heard some people behind me just gasp as they walked up the stairs. we approached it from Andrassy street and it looms in front of you as you walk down the street towards the river and park. quite magnificent.
Heroes Square - worth checking out. A great place to go is to take the tourist bus to Heroes' Square. The square itself is OK but its the surrounding attractions that are amazing, especially the Lido
Large square near Zoo and Baths. When you visit the Zoo or the Baths you are likely to walk through the Heroes' Square. The bus tours provide a nice description of the figures and scenes.
Nice for pictures and thats it. It's a nice view and great place for pictures, but besides that I love the park more. The place is typic hungarian but not worth travelling through town for
heroes. this was a stop off on the bus trip very good and very clean there are things to see around the square but we never went to look
Beautiful memorial. Beautiful memorial situated in a square.and well worth a visit. Situated next to a park which is also worth spending a couple of hours visiting.

Very fun many things to see!. Its a fun square to walk around in, also the ground is very flat and i usually see people riding their bikes or roller blading. Its a great place to visit because there is the central park right behind it and its beautiful with many restaurants and during the winter season there is an ice skating ring . During the summer there are ducks to feed(very fun for children!) A very nice opportunity to enjoy a day of with nature!

Nice place for photos. Combine additional activities.. At the square you can find some impressive statues of the heroes and you can make very beautiful photos. It is a bit far from center specially if you are staying close to river. Very close is the Budapest Zoo and Thermal Baths, so you can combine additional activities if you finally visit the square.

Impressive. The scale of this square cannot fail too impress. Having wandered round it is well worth walking back down to the river as there are many wonderful buildings, including the Opera house, to view.

Obvious must-see when in Budapest. This is one of the greatest monuments in Budapest, and I would recommend that everbody studies the history of the square and the statues before going there (or on the spot) so that you get more out of it! The square is surrounded by other big monuments, so you definitely need to go there.

Impressive Sculptures. This monument is easy to access and near 2 other museums, the zoo and a thermal bath. I was a little dismayed at the locals that milled about skateboarding, making out, having picnics, etc ON the actual monuments. It is a huge open space and a great tribute. Definitely worth stopping by to see...and it's free so that's a bonus! Be sure to walk around the area behind and to the right of the square as there is a neat "castle" and park area to explore.
Heroes' Square. you can easily get to Heroes' Square from the Metro, very visually attractive, do not have to pay money to view it, which is always a good :)

Historically important..... But not an awful lot going on! It's a big square, but oddly once you have made the trip either on foot, bus or metro, there isn't much about. I wanted to nip across the road and sit in a cafe and take in the view of the square and people watch, but no such luck.
good location. great plaza, near many other things andrassy avenue, terror museum spa baths opera house zoo circusdont want to write 50 words

Monumental - literally!. As a fan of big public spaces & monumental architecture I think this ranks as a good one. The statues are great but people really shouldn't be allowed to clamber about them.The impressive facades of the two flanking museums add to the view. It was a mild fine day but I wouldn't recommend visiting such a wide open space if it was cold & windy.
Nice to visit. This is a place you cannot miss. It is a wonderful circle and the buildings around are gorgeous. Take your time visiting the museums around the square.

Ok, if you're not agoraphobic.. You like big spaces - then feel free to roam around to your heart's content. For my part, I visited just to see the square - not the flanking museums - and the best I can say about it is that it is indeed er ... square. And not small. The statues are impressive, but the broken tiles underfoot were reminiscent of the worst Canarian resorts and after ten minutes I was ready to move on.
History in one place. You can visit this square every time on the year day or night no matter always looks great.All Hungarian king in one place, plus the Unknown soldier.
Lots of history . . . .. Large spacious open square with lots of history portrayed by the many wonderful statues around it.Great view right down Andrassy
Must to go Place in Budapest. You can feel the hisory and glory of Hungary. I recommand those who are interested in history. Hungarians must be proud of this historic sites.
lovely statues. We first saw how impressive this was on the hop on/off bus and made a point of having a walk here another day.good photo shots worth seeing.

Heroes' Square. Take metro line 1 from Deak Ferenc Ter to Hosok Tere to reach tis attraction, swhort walk to the Varosliget (People's) park see the sculptures and Hungarian Agriculture Museum , a tip is to see the square at night , lit atmospherically.
Impressive.. Found this on a cold and wet day looking very imposing. We walked past the statues and on to the large park. I'm sure this all looks very nice on a sunny day!

heroes. hmmmm...noy much too say about it... big square, with few statues, nothing impressive.
at the right side of square, it is a big park, with small waterfalls, ducks etc
excellent. large, powerfull, long walk to get to though but certainly packs a punch, the museums assist its strength

beautiful. This Square is monumental, full of statues that resembles Hungarian History.
The place is great to visit both on daylight and nighttime, since it has an amazingly well placed lighting system.

Carch it at night as it is all lit up!!!. It is a wonderful experience to see it lit up at night against a blue sky. There are statues of all those who helped Hungary become free over many different time periods.
Impressive monument. Walked from town, a lovely long avenue which opens out onto this impressive site. Flanked by imposing museums at either side too.

What an amazing space.. This vast square at the top of Andrassy Avenue (pretty much the Champs Elysee of Budapest) has statues representing 14 of the early kings of Hungary as well as the mounted horsemen representing the leaders of the seven tribes who came to settle their people here in 896AD. The statues were a major part of the 1896 first millennium celebration of the founding of the country that became Hungary and have enormous national identity and political implications to this day.
Amazing statues in Heroes' Square. This splendid square in Budapest boasts some magnificent statues and glorious columns. It is wonderful to admire, especially lit up at night.

Imposing. This was just 5 minutes walk from the hotel. The statues on and buildings adjacent to the square are formidable and well worth seeing as is the spectacular view along the 2.5km Andrassy Avenue. The place seems to express the history of Budapest. Close by is a castle, thermal baths, zoo and open air skating rink. For us it was an ideal place to commence our Big Bus Tour of Budapest

Nice sqaure at the end of Andrássy. This square is surrounded by statues, a museum and a gallery. There is also an ice rink nearby and is a short walk from the Szechenyi thermals baths. It is nice to walk along Andrássy ut and finish up at the square.
A Must See. Really impressive with statues and columns. Walk through the square to the castle, ice rink, zoo and thermal baths.

definitely go see and leave yourself lots of time. I ran out of time here, I think it can take all afternoon if you want to go to most of the museums and take a nice stroll around the area and take pictures enjoy yourself and the quietness, I went during the day, don't know how it's like after sundown but its near the train station so not near the "tourist areas", take the metro, it's fast

Stunning. We only headed towards the square as we were on our way to the zoo, but so glad we came across it. All the statues and buildings surrounding it looked very well kept. When we went it was fairly quiet but would imagine at times it gets very busy

Big square with impressive monuments but nothing to do. The Hosok Ter is an big square with some impressive monuments on it. On both sides there are also 2 museums. Not bad but it gives a kind of isolated feeling and there is nothing to do, except taking a few pictures

Heroes square. Based on my research on trip advisor I wanted to visit here, we came via the metro. This area is huge and such a photographic area, so much history. As we visited during the winter this area has one of the biggest outdoor ice skating rinks I have seen and so busy (the ice skating rink is only there in the winter) if you go beyond the ice skating rink there is a beautiful building and park to walk through

A must see. This square is totally grand and imposing - capturing all the important figures in Hungarian history. We took a walking tour and were given insights into who each statue represents and it was all very interesting. It is a great area to explore and very different from the rest of the city.

Snowing but still magic. Walked here in the snow storm, on the way to the circus - that in itself was fun. Was here last August and was hot sunny then.Very different today - the square still has magic. Well worth the visit.

Heroes Square and Szechenyi Baths. Monday is a great day to see heroes Square as everything else is closed. The square consists of four arcs of columns displaying all the good kings. The bad are not remembered. Off course you will see more on other days. After the square we walked to the Szechenyi baths, a few minutes walk. It is a huge complex of historical buildings, and if it isn't Monday you can have a thermal bath.It was wet, and Monday, when we went so we almost had the place to ourselves. You can walk or take the metro. We walked there so as to see the opera house and all the historic buildings on the way, but came back on the metro. Local transport is very cheap.

Look behind. Heroes' Square offers a look into the proud history of Hungarian people and you can see all their most important historical figures there. Surrounding the square are museums and just behind it is an awesome castle and a beautiful spa. If you are with kids there is also a zoo nearby :) It is easy to get there - just jump on the yellow line and you will be there in 10 or so minutes.

Prepare your camera ;). Lots of very nice sculptures to take pictures. You better read about the composition and background story to understand about them. 2 art museums at both sides. Very near to the thermal bath and zoo. A must at Budapest.
A beautiful monument. Heroes' Square is a beautiful monument, and definitely worth a visit. While you are there, you can take a walk through the City Park.
Heroes Square. This is worth a visit. Very large open space with impressive statues and monuments, and the unnamed Hero's grave. There was a protest at the time of our visit, but not many people.
Lots of Art!. Really recommend that you go into the two galleries situated on either side of the square - especially if the weather isn't so great.

Worth seeing, even on a rainy day. We went there on a rainy day and even though it took a little bit from its beauty it was still worth to see it. It is huge and magnificent. We walk along Andrassy Avenue to reach it (from Opera) and it took us about 30 minutes walking. We bought a little book about Heroes' Square (300ft) at the Terror House and read about it's history. Nice!

In Budapest Put This on Your Do Not Miss List. If you find you only have limited time in Budapest this is a must do.Magnificent both in day and at night.The central focal point of the hero's square, as well as one of the most recognized landmarks of Budapest and all of Hungary, is the Millennium Memorial sometimes often referred to as Millennium Monument or Millenary Monument. It is comprised of several statues of the leaders of the seven tribes that founded Hungary in the 9th century and other outstanding figures of Hungarian history . They surround a Corinthia column topped by a magnificent statue of the archangel Gabriel. In his right hand the angel holds the Holy Crown of St. Stephen the first king of Hungary. In his left hand the angel holds a two barred apostolic cross, a symbol awarded to St. Stephen by the Pope in recognition of his efforts to convert Hungary to Christianity.Directly in front of the monument sits a large stone cenotaph surrounded by a large iron chain. The cenotaph is dedicated "To the memory of all the heroic men and women sacrificed and gave their lives for the cause of freedom and national independence." While some guide books refer to this as a "tomb" it is not a burial place.One interesting and little known fact not to be missed here is a flat bronze plate within the decorative chain that marks the site of Budapest's first artesian well whose drilling was completed in 1878. Additionally this well provides the water for the Széchenyi Baths behind the square in the city park.The back of the square consists of two matched colonnades, each housing seven statues each representing great figures in Hungarian history. Both of these matching monuments consists of two semi-circles that on top of sit the Greek symbols of War and Peace, Work and Welfare, Knowledge and Glory can be seen. The niches within each colonnade are decorated by the statues of kings, governors and other famous characters of the Hungarian history. At the foot of each statue small reliefs depict the most important moment of the life of the personality.The square is flanked on two sides by two very magnificent and important museums the Museum of Fine Arts and Hall of Art both worth you time if you have it. And in the front by the Unesco heritage sight Andrassy Avenue which is a nice way to arrive from above or by the Yellow metro line Europe's oldest continental subway line and the second oldest in the world.In closing I should finish they way I started. If you find you only have limited time in Budapest this is a must do!!! Magnificent both in day and at night.
Must see. don't visit the city without a visit. It's very impressive - with some imposing statues of the leaders of the tribes who originally migrated from the West
