Imposing. A massive space in the busy heart of Budapest. The statues are huge, and are fine in their detail when you inspect them close up. A mecca for tourist photos, must a must.

Go by day or night. Either time of the day is a great time to see this place. Walk from Andrassy Way and see the Berlin Wall piece along the way. Stroll around the square and stop for a bite to eat in 'Antique'. The Square has a great history. Leave time to stroll City Park too.

Stop and stand still for one moment. When i visit places like this i stop stand still and center my sight on a main part of the square in this case the central column - review my thoughts on the historical events that this place marks, close my eyes for a minute or two and then open them - the feeling you get allows me to imagine what if and why these things have made a difference - well worth a visit. located next to the major open air park.

Absolutely Breathtaking. Interesting how varied the reviews are here. If you walk from Andrassy (the beautiful tree-lined street) after visiting the Opra House and the Terror House (15 minute walk), walk to this beautiful Square. It is an easy trek on your tourist-filled day. Go to the Opra House and the Terror House (on the way) and go to this beautiful square and take a few pictures of the beautiful statues. The zoo is right next door (really interesting and one of the oldest in Europe with historical cages). The fine art museum is also adjacent (if you like da Vinci and a world class museum). The place is absolutely in a great location and so many touristy things to do - REALLY worthwhile and in my opinion, you have not visited Budapest until you have seen this square. There is no cost for this attraction. Take a look at the photos I snapped. I would HIGHLY recommend planning your day as follows: Visit the opera House (be careful as they have selected times) then the House of Terror and then look at Heroes Square. Then spend a couple of hours at the Fine Arts Museum so when it is dark you can see the square at night before having dinner or whatever you decide to do. I wish someone would have told me this itinerary before I went!
Nice memorial, nice area.... This is a lovely square & a nice walk from the Opera...behind it in winter is a large ice rink & a castle year-round, a little further the Széchenyi thermal bath.
A memorable spectacle. The imposing statues of heroes square are once seen never forgotten. Well worth visiting at night when they are beautifully flood lit.
Nice square. Large nice hisyorical square, unfortunately earlier on today when we were there the main monument was wrapped up in plastic, i am curious to know why, actually.
One of symbols of Budapest. This place is like a gift to people who walked all Andrassy Prospect along - open area and simply nice square with monument!
beautiful. There is nothing in Budapest I did not like. Heroes Square is lovely and close by is a quaint Ice skating rink that is fun to watch or join!

Not the best thing. Make sure you go there, otherwise you have not been in Budapest. But don't wait for too much: the square itself is nice, bur there's not too much to see in it. Behind it, though, there are great things like the hot water spa, one beautiful fake gothic castle and other nice things. The avenue that takes you from downtiwn to this square has the best places to eat.

Impressive site. The scale of the Square is the first thing which hits you, even though traffic flows round it. The memorials are on a grand scale and the staues are of Hungarian Heroes from 800 ad to the late 1800's. Nearby you will find two art galleries. One, the museum of fine arts has regular exhibitions. There was an impressive Cezanne exhibition on when we visited.
Piece of art. The statues standing on this monument present the most important kings and personalies oh Hungarian history, as well as the 7 tribes origin of the Mayars. Worths visiting!

Awesome!. Heroes Square is home to enormous and magnificent statues. I saw a lot of the sites just be using the hop on hop off buses. Very cheap and didnt have to wait long at all. YOu will need time to marvel though. I loved Budapest!
Beautiful Expanse at Night. This is a terrific plaza to visit (on a metro stop) before or after a trip to City Park. You don't need to spend a lot of time here, but it's worth a look.

Only worth a short glimpse. Heard about it a lot from locals...But have to say compared to other budapest attraction this is a dampener.....If your short on time...give it a miss..though walk down the lighted up andrassy ave can make up for the this
A waste of time.. We saw this square as we hopped out of the subway, had a look around and we were not impressed. Wouldn't do the effort again.

Nice to see but not for long. The square was very large and the memorial was educational but there was'nt much else to see.The lake at the back of the square was beautiful as it was frozen over for ice skating.
beautiful. beautiful photos, especially looking down the andrassy during a sunset. shame it is in the middle of a roundabout though as the rushing cars ruined it slightly

Treasure hides behind. On the back of the Square try to find castle, spa and park. In fron of it is beautiful boulevard. You can walk to square, or just take metro line. Place is overcrowded with tourists so maybe you should wake up earlier and avoid crowd.

Great place but crowded. Great place, and it's much larger in real life, than what it looks like on the pictures. Unfortunately there was a lot of tourists there when we went, and they were climbing the statues.

BIG EMPTY SQUARE. We saw this square nearly every day as we were staying nearby and the metro runs from there. All the main tour uses also start from there. the staues are impressive but there is a strange feeling on the square which is not easy to describe you have to be there to feel it.
Not that impressive really.

Interesting square, nice surrounding park. I visited Budapest for the second time in December 2012, and had a very nice impression of the city. Yes, it is cold, but there are many opportunities to eat great food, see beautiful architecture, and take interesting historic strolls throughout the city. I went to Heroes' Square during my last visit and really enjoyed the statues and museums on either side of the square. A Hungarian friend pointed out that the museums are actually different sizes, and therefore the square was created asymmetrically to give the effect of equal size. I cannot commend on the insides of the museums flanking the square, but if you have the opportunity I do recommend walking around the adjacent park. If you're there in the wintertime, stop at the thermal baths or throw on some ice-skates, drink mulled-wine, and enjoy the Christmas markets. While I'm not entirely sure that this style of Christmas market is "Hungarian", after a few hours walking around in the snow you'll be happy to have some warm food to warm you up! Be sure to check out interesting buildings inside of the park- they each have an interesting history!

Gorgeous. This is the one place that must not be missed, most especially for the gorgeous buildings around this area including a disneylike fairytale palace that is so beautiful it looks like a film set.

Impressive, even in the rain.. A must see! A proud taxi driver told us of its history. It rained when we were there but a Cezanne exhibition in the museum got us indoors - the rain was not too bad, just a drizzle really. A stroll up Andrassy street afterwards is a good idea. Machines in the metro wouldn't dispense tickets!
Cool sight!. I went at night and during the day. Both times were great. The square is large and it is difficult to get a picture without other people.

Hero's square. Our very first site we visited on our walking tour which we accessed by the Metro. Our guide gave a full description during her commentary, I only wish I could recall half of what she said but a most impressive site.

A place with history. Grab the metro, yellow line and it takes you to Heroes square. Every part of this square reveals historical figures of Hungary. Spend some time there and cross the road to visit the museum of fine arts.
Amazing. Very impressive square. What with all the statues and the vast area - definitely worth a walk around.
Magnificent view at night.. I would reccommend to go there at night. The statues looked magnificent with all that lighting around them.

Impressing. This place is very impressive, especially at night when the lighting is beautiful. That statues are massive and there's a nice story about them (the ones on top of the arcade represent war, peace, fortune..., the ones between the arcades are the first rulers of Hungary, the horse men around the pillar are the tribal heads that first conquered and united the region that would become Hungary)

Great square. The square is situated in Budapest VII this it is advisable to use public transport to get there (metro takes you right on the spot). The square and the statues are lovely, and beyond the square there is a great park and baths!
Well worth visiting. A lovely area Togo for a walk, take a picnic and if it is winter go skating on one of the biggest out door rinks I have ever seen.
Very nice!. A must see. Also, you can't miss it for it is at the end of the Andrássy st (which is also a must-walk :)

Nice place to stop and get your orientation to Andrássy Avenue. Wiki: Hősök tere (meaning "Heroes' Square" in Hungarian) is one of the major squares of Budapest.
It is part of a World Heritage site. I would include this as a must see in the city tour. There's a ice skating ring nearby. A famous bath too.

Fitting monument. Although there isn't much in the square, the monuments to Hungary's founders and Kings are striking and bring a real atmosphere to the area.
Definitely a must if you like a photo opportunity with statues in the background. Kind of like Trafalgar Square only bigger.

Impressive. beautiful square with a huge history. Make sure to visit Heroes' Square with the tourist guide who will explain youthe meaning of every monument ...
impressive history.

Must see. If you love statues your in the right place with this one. It was lovely to look at and surrounding it is other great buildings including a castle which is a museum and the water spa which looks amazing so take your swimming costume with you!

A must see. I walked from Chain Bridge to Heroes' Square, a two, maybe three mile walk. It was a freezing cold day and snowed that evening and I don't regret one step. Certainly a must see on any trip to Budapest.

Nice to wander. We had a wander around Heroes Square. Very busy with other people so hard to take photos without anyone in them.Such an amazing place. Hard to comprehend that it was built so long ago (it was damaged during WW2 so had repairs done)There was a memorial service there in the days around our visit, so we got to see it with wreaths lain in memory of the heroes who gave their lives for the freedom of the people.The kids enjoyed seeing the Archangel Gabriel statue.

A place of reverence. Interesting to know that this place is a tribute to the fallen who fought for the freedom of their country. I was most impressed that their sacrifice allowed me and others the chance to stand their and appreciate what this square represents.
Hero square and museums. This part of budapest is great to spent the entire day. You have hero square and two museums on the square, you also have the huge outdoor skating rink as well as the zoo
Historical square. A square "describing" the early history of Hungary. Combine it with a visit in the Museum of Fine Arts and in the famous Széchenyi thermal baths.

Don't miss it. This is one of the key sites in Budapest - don't visit the city without seeing it. It's very impressive - with some imposing statues of the leaders of the seven tribes who originally migrated from the west to found Hungary
Breathtaking. It is easily reached by metro. The view is surprisingly amazing. It is nice for photographers. It's free, so be prepared for loads of packaged tour groups.
Very nice. Very interesting monument. The history of Hungary and Hungarians gathered in a square, in a beautiful monument
Amazing monument. Very impressive monument with great statues, even more so at night. Close to the park and ice rink, definitely worth a short visit.

Good to see, not a must see. It is good to see if you have a bit more of an extended stay in Budapest, and is good to venture to the area to see the park and zoo nearby. Not forgetting the ice rink in the winter!

Quick Visit. We walked though this on our way to the baths and it looked good but I wish we had some further information on what was represented here. Good photo opportunity though.If you are going to Szechenyi Baths I would recommend getting off at the metro station Hősök tere, taking in Heroes' sqaure and then walking through the park and seeing Vajdahunyad Castle before reaching the baths.

Quick visit on way to park. We enjoyed visiting the square on the way to the park. It was a great wide open space for kids to run around and the statues were magnificent. We popped into art museum for a special exhibit but just missed the kids Christmas market nearby.
Very nice. It was cold and snowy out so we didn't spend as much time here as I would have liked. Beautifully done and worth the visit.

Gigantic Monuments of the Giants. The reverence shown for those who provided great leadership and devotion is obvious for all to see. The heroes are displayed along with great artistry. No pictures, no media will ever be able to capture the power and awe one experiences as you approach from a distance and then stand among them.

Not worth a long walk. Unless you have a guide or happen to be in the area you can skip this and not miss anything important. A guide does help to bring it alive, but if you have limited time this can be skipped.
Very Heroic. Very impressive statues and all on a grand scale. Felt like a hero myself. Great ice rink set up adjacent in December.

Fantastic Monuments. Absolutely a must if you visit Budapest. All the statues are fantastic and the Archangel on the tall statue in the middle of the square is breathtaking. Many tourists were crawling over the monument to get their photos which we felt was completely disrespectful and embarrassing, so don't do this if you go.

History Lesson. What elevates Hero's Square from a fine memorial to outstanding is the series of frescoes identifying the important events in its history. Also go for the major art museums on the perimeter.
A must see!. Took lovely photos of the heroes. Humbled by the grand statues in this monument built in 1896 to commemorate the 1000th anniversary of the arrival of Hungarians
Definitely worth a walk. We walked down to the square one evening, the lighting and size of statues made the place seem very grand. I wish there had been more information on a sign there.
It is a square. Yes, famous places but still it is a square with few statues. The castle, pond and park nearby is even better.

Photo spot, not much else.... There's not much to see or read here, but it is a great place to take a picture and see some great public art before popping into the museums on either side of the roundabout this sits in the center of.
History. Wonderful history in an awesome venue. Made much more informational using Rick Steve's book. Worth the visit.

Heroes' Square. If you're going to visit this site, it may be worthwile going with a guide who can explain the history behind the different statues. You are then also right next to the park with the Baths and the zoo, just combine it all in one go :)
Impressive. Impressive statues, clean, big. Not much to do but close to the zoo and other things in City Park. Great area.
Great Space. Amazing space, really. Art Gallery, Museum, Zoo and huge Thermal Water Park all within a few minutes walk. Easy to get to from any part of the city.
Heroes Square. In the Snow. Great once you get there.imposing buildings, shame about the busy roads. Interesting in the snowy conditions and plenty of information.

Very impressive.. We came here along andrassy avenue and it was very impressive. The weather was great and the sculptures are beautiful. It's close to the museums, the skating rink, the baths and circus in the park so it definitely worth a visit.
lovely at night. The square, the museums surrounding it, the skating rink to the left and the castle behind out makes for beautiful night imagery after a stroll down andrassy ave.

Check out the atmosphere of this magnificent square.. Visited Heroes Square in the height of summer 2012 ..... mistake ..... big mistake .... too hot. I have to say though the square is magnificent with the wonderful statues and can only wonder what it's like in September when the equine event takes place. Similar to the Pallio in Sienna. It must be magnificent. Well worth a visit just to gawk at the bronze statues which are stunning. Have a walk around and get yourself to Gundels or its family restaurent Boglar (?).

Worth a visit. Heroes’ Square was on my bus tour of Budapest (highly recommend the tour to get around the city, it is a large city!) I had enough time to jump off the bus to take a photo of the square. There were also some Hungarian military onsite for some ceremonial activity (I’m guessing) but it was cool to see.
Plan to spend some time here. We were disappointed that our tour only gave us about 15 mintues here. The statues alone would require about 45 minutes just to briefly view each one.
Sightseeing. We saw this from the riverride bus so didnt get the chance to stop and take a real look. It was very interesting to hear the guide tell us about all the characters that are represented.
Worth a look.... Before entering the park, you will come across the Heroes' Square. Although I didn't read about it before I went there, I still appreciated the sculptures.

Knowledge makes it FUN. Funny title right? Well, i say that because if you head to the Heroe's Square without knowing much about it, it'll seem like just a beautiful open square with amazing sculptures. Head to Wikipedia to learn a little bit about all the sculptures before you head for the Square. The sculptures are amazing and you should go with a camera that can get you a good zoom photo. You'll appreciate it better. A video camera will help too. For the best picture quality, head to the Square between 10am - 3pm. Unless its summer time.

It has a history to tell. We went to the Heroes' Square on a hop on and hop of tour which can be highly recomended. The tickets for the tour last 48 hours and the audio information you get is very good and the voice in the audio set is very easy understandable with very clear pronaunciation. The information is also avaiable on - I think 15 other languagesThe Square have statues of many important person,military and civil, who have been a part of building Hungary
Impressive!. This is a wonderful marvel - openly grand with it's large, impressive bronze sculptures. You will want to take photos from all angles! Beautiful!
Big statue. Its a big statue with a big angel on top. Behind the square it will only take 3 minutes to Shershenyi bath.
Amazing Statues. This vast square is definately worth a walk round, the statues are huge and you can't appreciate them unless you are standing right next to them.

Just a bus ride away. Lovely wide open space with art galleries on two sides. We had really travelled there for the one not-to-miss attraction of Budapest - the nearby Szechenyi thermal baths, which ar ethe deepest & hottest of the 123 which can be found in this city. No visitor to Budapest should miss this experience.

Glorious!. Impressive huge square, well kept and looking glorious. Worth a visit also because it is at the edge of the City Park Varosliget with its beautiful Castle and the fantastic enjoyable Szechenyi Baths (Spa)

Very Scenic and Picturesque. Good camera shots, and a great place to choose as a meeting place as everyone knows where it is located. Always something going on, but be careful of the distractions and an eye on your purse. Children begging for their parents, but you may have seen the TV specials about this. Often looking where you keep your money more than a hand out itself. Same security you would use in any place.
One of the nicest place from Budapest. The squre is situated on a pittoresque lake. You can find historical statues on the square.There are many concert in the summer on these square.

another must go spot. remember to bring your wide-angle lens with you otherwise don't go!! You might miss the best shots. You have to walk close to savor each artistic carving. Its beautiful at day or even during sunset. Don't miss this place ; )
Ok but bleak in november. Big square. Big statues. But don't use point me there from the app. It sends you to wrong place! Just walk always up Andrassay avenue

the park behind is alot nicer. The first night I visited the park a classical piano player was there with a piano. Strange. There were alot of shady characters hanging around too. I passed through the square several times over the coming days and enjoyed the park across the bridge. The noise from the outdoor skating rink was not pleasant either but that's not the square. No idea what people like about Andrassy Avenue either.
A must see. Quite a long way at the top of Andrassy Street but it it worth it. The statues are amazing and it is buzzing with atmosphere. Have a look at the castle at the back too.

bam. this is one of those things that kinda suprises you. we were walking down a regular street, with no purpose of direction and then bam! a great big roundabout, bam flowerbeds, bam a bunch of people. bam great statues. a nice site to see (it's not that surprising, but i'm telling a story ain't i) :D

what a lucky weekend to go !!. We happened to go to Hero's Square on the day of national celebration. There was stable-boy horse-racing around the square, lots of ethnic food stands and folk dancing and crafts stalls. We came away with 1/4 kilo of fresh paprika for just a couple of pounds, and had a great day.

Huge Sculptures of Heroe's. Visited on Remberance day with marching soldiers, bands, military and dignantry. Amazing sight and sound. All around the square steam coming up from the drains from the thermal springs.
History. For all those who like history it's worth stopping by. It's a big square with great statues of important figures of Hungarian history. Liked it allot.

heroes square. a bit out of the way but worth getting off the sghtseeing tour bus. in city park which is a lovely park, ice skating in the winter and pleanty of mulled wine available. interesting architecture and has a zoo and fair
Majestic. This is a grand square with a neat semi circular coliseum structure housing imposing statues of famous figures from Hungarian history. Worth the metro trip to see.

Central to alot. This wasnt a planned visit or even on our list of sights in Budapest but we're glad we went.Andrassy avenue is a great walk, from the city to Szechenyi park.When we got to the end we where amazed when we saw Heros square. Bordered by Szechenyi park, Palace of art and the Museum of fine arts anyone visiting Budapest should end up here.the square only needs a quick walk around. Its size and location create good photos opportunities.

Like Statues? I Don't.. It was a chilly cold day when our tour bus gave us the option of getting off at this attraction or staying on. Traveling around the actual Heroes' Square, looking for a place for the bus to park I saw enough. I stayed on the bus. There were many tourists taking photos of the statues representing heroes but for me, it wasn't worth the bone chilling winds. It's a very large area and in my opinion, you can see enough simply by driving by.

Millennium and more. Square is rich with monumental statues of important figures from Hungarian history opened in a new cast of Hungary. A meeting point for Hungary and the world, surrounded by museums, castles and park.
Huge, beautiful square. Right off the metro stop. Very beautiful plaza. Reminiscent of a huge plaza in Russia. Very close to the baths also.
Magnificiant. Heroes square is flanked by two grand museums and is near many other attractions including the zoo. It is a truly wonderful space.
Fantastic Statues. Wonderful history brought to life through these huge statues. Meanwhile modern day traffic is roaring around you as you soak up the atmosphere.

you should go. Once in Budapest, you would definitely want to see City Park with its famous landmarks Szechen… Thermal baths and Vajdahunyad Castle. Flanked by the Palace of Fine Arts and the Palace of Art and situated at the entrance to the City Park, the Heroes' Square stands in honor and memory of the great leaders in Hungary's history. it one of the best sight.it amazing attraction

Nice design!. Once in Budapest, you would definitely want to see City Park with its famous landmarks Szechenyi Thermal baths and Vajdahunyad Castle. Flanked by the Palace of Fine Arts and the Palace of Art and situated at the entrance to the City Park, the Heroes' Square stands in honor and memory of the great leaders in Hungary's history. So if you are in the area, why not spend some few minutes at the Heroes' Square.

Heroes' Square. Heroes' Square was once the gathering place, for government sanctioned demonstrations. It is impressive, but don't go out of your way to visit, or feel that you have missed out if you don't have the time.

A MUst. You have to go here if you visit....Budapest and all of Hungary have a proud past and one of much suffering and adversity through all of which they have prevailed; they are lovelyaspiring people!

Average square. I was a bit disappointed with Heroes' Square. It was nice looking enough but I had read a lot of great reviews that perhaps I had too high expectations. The explanations about the history of each of the characters in Heroes' Square is interesting enough, but not the best thing to see in Budapest.

Hero's Square. This is a large square with compelling statues. It is surrounded by the Fine Arts Museuam which is wonderful and another museum. The visit will not take long but the staures alone make it worth the time.

Read the history before you go. It pays to read the history of the square before you go. Once you do that you can spot the headmen of the six tribes and also identiy the statues. The walk up to Heroes square along the Andrassy Ut is pleasant. If walking is not your cup of tea then you can take metro 1. It terminates at the square.

Neglect and it shows. The centre piece of Budapest, it is truly beautiful and huge. A tribute to the seven tribes and the great kings, it is the place to visit. What is disappointing is the maintainance around the area. The colours have faded and running at places. The memorial has no illumination. some efforts and this could be the place you could spend most of your evenings
Amazing. The sheer size of the square and the statues are just incredible.The archangel Gabriel Sits on top of the column presiding over the square-very impressive
Heroe's Square. We walked from the Danube to the square because the road leading up to Heroe's Square was so grand and once there we were not disappointed.

Where are the heros of recent history?. No memorial to all the fallen in the First & Second World Wars, or during the Communist Era but the Square is very impressive. Perhaps recent history is too painful to remember?

Beautiful!. Heroes Square is a large square, with wonderful sculptures of historical Hungarians, that you can reach either after a long walk up Andrassy Avenue, past all the fantastic houses and embassy's or an easy metro journey. On the left you can see the Museum of Fine Arts, containing Hungary's wonderful collection of foreign art. Behind is the city park with the famous Szechenyi thermal baths. Heroes Square itself is beautiful. It is very historical, and depicts the different periods in the history of Hungary. There is a memorial to the Unknown Soldier in the middle. The statuary represents different heroes and conquerors of Hungary. It is worth seeing, it is part of the culture and history of Hungary. Just beautiful.

Impressive Statues. The square itself is large and the statues are very impressive. Unless you have read your guide books thoroughly, you will not know what they are about. Go a couple of blocks south east of the square and walk south west along some of the side streets to see some of the old mansions, a few of which are now embassies.
Visit October 2012. Flanked by the two art museums the square draws you in to the central column with the impressive equestrian figures with even more impressive moustaches.

Impressive structure but lack of info.. This monument was next to our location so we came across it, unfortunately everything was in Hungarian, and so we didn't look for long. Most of the main attractions are the same, massive structures but no information. Impressive buildings etc, but I like to know what I'm looking at and the history behind it, none of this was evident in English.

Nice enough but not worth special trip. The plaza is nice enough but not worth a special trip. We saw en route to large thermal baths just across park. Difficult to cross the streets safely. Police standing at some intersections were of little help and seemed disinterested in helping people cross very busy street with fast moving traffic. Their English was non existent too! Pickpocketing also a concern in this area.

Good worth seeing.. Wonderful area. Lots of space and large statues. Quite impressive.
Kept very clean. Heroes Square nice place for photographs

A mini-central park. It's about a 2 mile walk from Vorosmarty Square or you can take the metro. The park behind Heroes' Square has a small lake, bath house, zoo, Gundel restaurant, etc. Great area to take children, or spend the afternoon.
historic square. after reaching this place there wasnt much to do other then take some pictures and stroll to the park nearby
worth a trip. We went to Heroes' Square as we going to Szechenyi thermal spa and this was on the way. It's a good picture opportunity and is a really good memorial
Awesome. Although the man made lake has since been filled the surrounding structures and environment is truly something to behold

Impressive!. We approached Heroes Square on the subway from the old Town. It was built in 1896 and is beautifully tiled with wood trimmed kiosks and mouldings. In comparison to other subway lines that are much deeper in Budapest this one was gorgeous.The square is part of a larger park that contains famous baths so an excursion out here is very worth the effort even for the subway ride.
Stunning. We walked down to the leafy street to reach the stunning moments of here's square. It's about. 4 mile walk there and back but it's worth it

Nice enough but not a must see. An attractive square with some nice statues round & about. You can see some parading of the guards or some kids skateboarding depending on when you arrive. Worth getting stopping to take a look if you are going to one of the attractions in the park or the museum of art but I wouldn't go out of my way for this.

Can survive without visiting it. Just a large concrete square with some nice statues of I guess some hungarian famous kings riding horses. You can survive if you dont visit it, but anyway you have to pass it if you go to the Szechenyi Bath, the large city park, or to the Wadi amusement park.

Good place to meet friends. The square is impressive, but not something you want to spend a lot of time looking at. However, there are many good cafes, and a beautiful area in which you can sit at the museum. I went alone...so not so good, but I was tired and it was a nice place to relax. That said, it would be a wonderful place to just sit and visit with friends while enjoying the art :)
heroes sq. lovely walk to heroes square and the castle and park was worth the visit too. the zoo and baths are there too so nice for youngsters

Beautiful in the autumn sunlight. This open space with the statues and monuments looked wonderful under a clear blue sky. It's located right at the end of Andrassy Avenue so we took the metro down there and, after enjoying the square itself wandered down Andrassy Ave for lunch near Oktogon. There's also an excellent art gallery at heroes Sq and (in winter) an open air skating rink. It's very close to the Szechenyi baths.

great place. In there are many places to see like Museum of Art , like the buidling of Museum of Agriculture, like place for skating , and the best of all Shehenyi Thermal bathes , the biggest in Hungary just great

Symbol of Budapest. Colossal Square with the monument's "Heroes' Square. Probably the most interesting square in Budapest, placed at the end of Andrássy Avenue, often called 'Avenue of culture', due to the many cultural attractions that it settle, among which the most famous opera.Millennium Square is dominated by a monument, so named to mark the millennium of Hungarian immigration. However, it is fully completed until the 1929th when it got its present name.The monuments are seven statues of tribal leaders and many other historical figures, among others, Stephen King, Bela IV., Matthias Corvinus and Lajos Kossuth. Occupies the central part of the monument 36 feet tall Corinthian column, topped by a statue of the archangel Gabriel. At the foot of the tomb of the unknown soldier.The Heroes' Square (Hősök tere), on its side, there are two major museums - the Museum of Fine Arts (Szépmûvészeti, www.szepmuveszeti.hu) and the Museum of Contemporary Art (Műcsarnok, www.mucsarnok.hu), and near the Zoo.

Monument of Millennium. In the center of Heroes' Square, which closed 2.5-kilometer avenue is a giant monument "Millennium of Hungary" (architect A.Schickedanz , sculptor György Zala). Center of the composition of the monument is 118 feet tall column with the figure of the Archangel Gabriel on the top. At its base the bronze statues of the leaders of seven Hungarian tribes. Between the columns of a semicircular colonnade statues of kings, princes and great men of Hungary. Colonnade decorated with symbolic figures of Labour and Welfare, War (left Colonnade), Peace, Honor and Glory (Right Colonnade).

Good stop on your way along the park to the Szechenyi Baths. We exited the metro at Hosok Tere and walked through this grand square, along the park, to the baths. It is pretty and nice to see but definitely just a walk through. Because it is out of the way, you'll want to go to the city park and/or baths so you don't make the far trip to just spend a few minutes in the square.

Nothing fantastic. Went to this place expecting a lot more than we got. The square is in the middle of several busy roads, great monuments etc but something was missing, probaley atmospere. Go steady crossing the roads.

Hungarian Roots Displayed. The site is a testament to the founding Kings of Hungary and the sculptures in bronze and cement statues are a landmark worthy of a proud nation. Where tanks and May Day parades were held the Hungarian people have moved on and today multiple tour groups and school groups can be seen in the square. This is a fine starting point for the galleries to either side the castle and churches just a bit further in the park and the baths. The square is a good walk from the river but easily accessible by tram or the metro.

Angel Gabriel and the Knights is which he protects!. This vast square is worth a visit, but not sure if it is a big must see.The size of the statues are quite a sight in them selves and there is a story that goes with them.The Angel Gabriel Towers over the square protecting the Knights of the past! The square backs in to a lovely park with ponds and ducks and is a lovely place to take a picnic to eat after you have strolled around the square and gazed up at the gigantic statues!

Amazing place to visit. The scale and the amount of sculpture done in these statues is just plain amazing. The photo opportunities are many and it seemed like the traffic would ebb and flow so you could find times without too many people in your pictures. I would suggest bringing a long range lens as well as wide angle to get in the details and the scale of it all.

Including the area around, it is worth going to see. Either a long walk up Andrassy Ut or an easy metro journey takes you to Heroes Square with The Museum of Fine Arts on the left containing Hungary's wonderful collection of foreign art. Behind is the city park with the famous Szechenyi thermal baths. Heroes Square itself is beautiful. A big square with wonderful sculptures of historical Hungarians looking like a cross between King Arthur and his knights of the round table and Asterix. Look our for the horse with deer antlers tied to his face projecting forward as weapons to do damage. The city park is a pleasant park with grass and trees. For me a most interesting thing was The Hourglass. This is a huge +++ disc incorporating an hourglass but which measures a year instead of an hour. It was built to mark the time when Hungary joined the EU. Sadly it now has anti EU graffiti on one side of it. We had lunch afterwards at a Greek/Turkish cafe over the road where we had a Greek salad and toasted sandwich whilst men at tables around us smoked their hookah pipes
Worth the visit. Know the history of it and it will make your visit there even more enjoyable? The museum on the square had a fabulous exhibit of contrast-then and now. Check it out

Hear it for the Heroes. This was one of the few areas that we visited on this trip that was not overrun with tourists like ourselves. It is a vast open space with impressive monuments, framed on both sides by beautiful museums. This was so impressive and we appreciated the moment.

Heroes Square, You need a guide to explain it!. Our guide was a little jaded, I mean she told us that this is an odd monument for a country that never won a war. It is very historical, and depicts the different periods in the history of Hungary. There is a memorial to the Unknown Soldier in the middle. The statuary represents different heroes and conquerors of Hungary. It is a large square, bordered by two large museums. We only stayed a short while, but it is worth seeing, it is part of the culture and history of Hungary. I would read about it before I go, unless you have a better guide than we did.

Lovely square and park. Emerged from underground station to see this magnificent square at 6.30 am.Apart from myself and 2 chinese doing relaxation exercise no one about.The square and statues are very grand befitting the people profiled.Sad part was the weather was horrendous such heavy rain and no brolly.Always wanted to visit and so glad I did.Because of weather did not stay as long as I wished,so carried on walking visiting a few more attractions in the park.
. Beware of the map in this app.. Wrong placement on map, as mamy other places in this app. Beware of the map in this app. Place of heroes is beautifull!!!

These heroes are indeed heroic. Ok, it is only a square but Ive never seen such impressive large scale statues, these are national heroes on a very grand scale. Definately worth checking out. Its also just in front of the Museum of Fine Arts - fabulous collection of work
nice place. one of those place you have to go and you don't really know why...if you are with a tour the will take you... by your own there are more interesting thins to do

Part of Budapest Tour. A large square with many big statues, memorials and monuments. Some with horses and riders which are good photo subjects. Throughout the square are a number of "gypsies" trying to sell their articles of clothing and other things. Our tour guide suggested we ignore them because the quality of their merchandise is really inferior. If you're in Budapest, it's one of the points of interest you should see.

Beautiful. To get here. Walk the Andrassy Avenue past all the fantastic houses and embassy's. So beautiful. And at the end you are greeted by this amazing square. We were very lucky as we visited this at the end of the day during rush hour. There was only a handful of people in the square and the sun was setting casting beautiful shadows across it. Just beautiful.

Impressive. Hosok tere by itself is pretty impressive but the surrounding precinct holds some gems as well. Right behind Hosok tere is the Budapest Outdoor Ice Skating Pavillion (very dry in Summer, but nonetheless imposing) and the Agricultural Museum is beside that. The Agricultural Museum is housed in a replica Transylvanian castle that is something else - the grounds of the place are predictably classy and the adjoining Városligeti Park is very relaxing.Easy to get to on the Metro with a stop right at the front door! Don't miss it - an impressive precinct!
Nice place. It's actually nothing special, other than being a large square with some statues. Although simple, the location of it can make a nice visit as it lies in the end of the Andrassy avenue.

a must thing to do on your visit. always something going on here when we went ie hungarian band and dignitaries laying wreaths down , but it wonderful place to go see all the statues of hungarys past and massive colomn with angel on top and horses and chariots on top of the statues of famous men , plus also visit and night when dark to see it all lit up  after seeing this plenty to do in the park , we visited the superb zoo 200 metres away
Pretty area. Lovely square to see, with pleasant surroundings. Nice for a wander; we weren't going in the agricultural museum or zoo and there weren't many cafes, so only needed an hour max there.

Memorable. When we visited Heros Square the Army were having there swearing in Parade of new recuits which was different. Lots of dignateries there. A lovely memorable place to visit with lots of Historic building surrounding
Great view. Best time to be ther is at sunsets. We had lovely time there with all the other turists. Great pics before during and after the sun sets down. very impressuve.
Lovely. I loved going here because it looks interesting. if you take a hop on hop off bus ( this bus is recommended, 5000huf for 2 days, very cheap) you only need 30 mins to see what you have to see

Lovely. Really enjoyed taking many great photo shots here. It was really sunny too when we went. Its not something that takes long to visit but is great to fit in and worth visiting as its close by to many other attractions.

Worth a visit. The immense size of the square is overwhelming. The beautiful statues (stone work) are certainly worth a visit. If you are visiting without a tour guide google a little history before you go.

Stunning!1. Hero's Square is amazing. We were there on Oct 6, which is some kind of holiday in Hungary, so we were able to witness a changing of the guard for the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. It was beautiful. The whole square is lovely and very close to the zoo and turkish bath. Invest in a day by day book and it will explain what all the statues are. It truly is amazing.
WONDERFUL. people you should never miss going to that square. it is beautiful and nice. I had the best days in my life there
Lovely iconic place. This is a great place to start a wander through the city park and it's a really iconic photo opportunity.

Worth a visit but nothing special.. Its a square with some nice statues. When we were there there was a miltary event on which was more interesting. The park behind has a baths (Szechenyi) and a strange building (Vajdahunyad Castle) that shows different forms of architecture. The baths were nearly all empty due to cleaning and repairs. If you are pushed for time forget it.
A must see. Nice atmosphere! Beautiful statues, all HUngary's history in one place, surrounded by museums! Take a nice walk around the lake too. It is a skating ring with music in the winter!
Stimulates the senses. Mind -blowing collection of imperious statues,memorials and museums.We were under time pressure so didn't get into the museum and gallery -next time...
Beautifull monument. Make sure to go into the City Park right behind it, if the weather permits it's an excellent place for some peace and quiet.

It's a square. It's nice to see and I'm glad we went - but there's not that much to it. I found mnyslef even more interested in considering that Dozsa Gyogy street, which runs past the square, is where the communists held their annual May Day parades.
It's a must. I visit Budapest every week and I always pass by the Heroes Square, but I have to say that it always amazes me. If you visit Budapest, you have to see it.
heroes square. nice space at the end of Andrassy avenue with imposing statues of past royalty with a central column, framed on either side with museums.
Good photo spot. Another landmark and photo spot of Budapest city. We got off the hop on hop off bus at this stop and spend 20 min at this square which is more than enough time for some photos.
Great entrance to City Park. Fantastic reward after a walk up Andrassy Utca. The square also sits at the entrance to City Park. Great for photos.

Another must see in Budapest!. To really get a feel for the sweep of the history of Hungary, you must go see Heroes Square. There are statues of each important founder, Saint and King, starting from the founding in the 10th century up to the revolution in the 19th century. The large plaza is flanked by a modern art museum and a national art museum, is close to a world famous bath, and across from a nice park with cute little cafe/restaurants. Plan to spend several hours exploring everything in this area!
beautiful. we seen this as part of a tour and liked it so much that went back at night to see all lite up it was fantastic it is amazeing
The World Heritage List. Very interesting square with central figures and statues relating to Hungary's past. Lots of photos to take.
Circle like in any city. Nice place. It is not in the city center and all you have to be there is one time for nice pictures. Did you know that Michael Jackson filmed his video there?
cool statues but avoid the crowds. These statues are worth a visit, but you might want to try it early or late and avoid the throngs of tours that pass through here.

The Best. Heroes square is a wonderful sight to see. The statues in the square are unbelievable. I didnt know what to expect, but when we arrived it was much more than I had expected. Itis a large square, again very clean. This is a must see.

Very nice. Visited this site on our city tour with Monograms. Got some very good photos. Went back during the Horse Show and wasnt able to get in the center to get more shots. A nice walk from our hotel to the square.
well worth a visit. The various statues are breath taking and a good photo opportunity. You also get a very good view of a castle made up of various designs

Massive, massive, massive.. There was a ginormous fare and national event going on when we were there involving villages competing against each other by personal representatives on horses in the arena and the whole lot being on TV on huge screens around the food/clothes/tourist within Hungary Fair. For about £6 you can stuff yourself with three complete meals in as long as you can take to queue and eat them. Heroes? Yes, don't forget that Hungary is probably the most put upon country in all of Europe, so has plenty of freedom heroes to remember from across the centuries.

Wow, they take their heros seriously.. The Heros Square is very impressive, and I believe it is one of the finest squares in the world. The architecture asserts emotional impact on the visitors. You can walk around and admire the sculptures and let the history sinking in. There are two art museums on the side of the Square. One is the Fine Art Museum which has a substantial,impreesive collection of the old masters.The second museum appears to be for current exhibits. We spent 3 hours here at the square and the fine art museum, a very enjoyable visit.
Huge, wide-open space in the heart of the heavy traffic.. Always awe inspiring. Interesting and historical. Worth walking down Andrasi Utca to get there. Watch the traffic crossing into the Square!

Add this to the list. Our tour guide Adam Botta took us here. If you visit Budapest, you need to understand their heritage. There are 7 statues for mongol rulers. There are also statues of each of the various rulers of Hungary over the last 1000 years. Put this on the list of must sees while there.

Impressive sculpture and fun activities. The sculptures in the square are impressive, the park is a relaxing and enjoyable escape from the hustle & bustle of the city and the activities (zoo, spa, amusement park) are entertaining for adults and children alike.

Catch the underground or bus here. Is flanked by two art galleries, plenty to do around here in addition. Is quite a walk so I would recommend catching public transport. Go as the sun is setting for the most beautiful views. It is also quieter then as most tourists have gone home.

Big doesn't describe it. This place has to be seen in person to be believed. The grandiose statues and square just doesn't come across in any pictures I've seen on the Internet. It's well worth a trip. It's a nice walk up Andrassy ut too... some very pretty homes and embassies along the way.
Grand. The square is just like you'd expect from seeing it in the photos and post cards. It is large and beautiful. Prepare to take many pictures!

Good to see on your way to the baths. A nice stop in a clean, open square with the monument at the far end of the square. I recommend stopping there on your way to the baths and castel park but you won't need more then a few minutes to take a few pictures and move on. And the area between the Square - Baths- Castle is quite dirty and several homeless people are I the area.
My favorite square!. Huge, gorgeous with fantastic statues! It is located so near the baths and the beautiful castle and park.

Great. after a long walk along Andrassy Ave, (i would take the metro or bus) we were greeted by loads of tourists and coaches looking at the fab statues. It is a masive square kept clean (no grafitti , of which there is loads) well worth the visit. There is a little cafe get drinks etc which in the heat you need evey 5mins.

Impressive Statues. Heroes Square is on the yllow underground line (I can't recall if it is near Opera or Oktagon) and is easily reached by public transport. It consists of a series of staues on plinths near a roudabout but it is also at the entrance to the main municipal park where the baths are located which means you can do both in one trip.
You will see it. You cannot do Budapest without being here. Every one is passing from this historic an beautiful square full of history

Worth a visit even though just average.. We visited this more for something else to do. Plenty of architecture to admire. We then walked back along Andrassy. Some of the houses are spectacular and are foreign Embassies. If you are reasonable fit it is worth the walk, otherwise you have options for public transport. Stop 6 Giraffe.

Take the underground to Hosok Ter!. Very powerful square and monument. Please please take the underground to Hosok Ter station. As you walk up from the station steps you walk out onto the view of the square. It's quite impressive. Over then that the square is small and there isn't much to do other then take photos.

must see. Square about the size of a football field with immense Hungarian hero statues around one end. Two main museums bookend the square-easy to spend a whole day here. Cafe/bar in front of one museum for necessary refreshments.
Nice. The square is very powerful. Nice to look at and if your into that stuff then Id say it would be amazing!

Think about a bus. Although perfectly walkable, (at least a 2km distance) as you slowly get to the square the liberty monument and surrounding columunade are enough to overcome even the most weary feet. And if you have an extra hour or two head next door to the Art Museum and poke around it many stories.

Square within a round. Beautiful wide open square with magnificent statues and monuments. Also the tomb of the unknown warrior. Views of Andrassy Street. To the back of the square are lovely gardens to walk or sit in.
Must see!. Heroes square is at the top of Andrassy Avenue, and the joining point for our bus tour, some great monuments and buildings and handy for the zoo, park and Szechenyi baths,

Impressive area. I took the metro out to Heroe's Square on a swelteringly hot August afternoon. The statue area was truly impressive and I certainly wish that I had known more of the details of Hungarian history so that the impressive monuments would have had even more impact on me. What I did really enjoy was the park behind the statues with nice walking areas, the bathes, the circus and a small church and castle-like area which was a very welcome respite from the blazing hot temperature. If I were to go again, I'd do a bit of research in order to be more aware of the lives of the Heroes, themselves.
Huge area. The statues are beautiful and the area is massive however I would not have known what anything was if I wouldnt have had my travel book with me.. more information would be nice..

The Hungarian Kings. I have fond memories of this place. It is a nice square with lots of open space and well maintained. The statues of the kings are definitely impressive and give you a quick overview of the history of the country. As with all places in the center, it is hard to park if you go by car so be prepared to walk...
Nice!. Big empty square with few significant monuments. Take a stroll to the park near by, there is a very pretty church. It did not rock my world but worth seeing.

Impressive. Epic square. There's also an Antique cafe just across in the corner if you want to hang around peaking at the square, but I wouldn't say service is very good. I wanted an Americano, they didn't know what it is so I described. I ended up getting espresso on the rocks. But the square is very impressive.

A great gathering place.. Heroes Square is a large open space mostly. It has a tiled floor and two curved sets of columns made into a wall topped with four figures that represent Labour, War, Peace and The Sciences. Between the columns there are more figures who I believe represent the great and the good from Budapest's history. In the centre of these two sets of columns is a tall tower with another figure on top and surrounded by fiercesome warriors on horseback.There is a park at the back of the square, a zoo nearby and a museum right next to it. If you walk to the other side of the park that is where the Szechenyi Spa Baths are.

Nice place. We liked the place. A nice monument to show their respect to Hero's of Nation. We sat near the pillar for sometime. The panoramic view of this monument at night was awesome. Not crowded, no anti social elements around.

Heroes Square Budapest. If you want to make a half day trip in Budapest with some relaxing time, I recommend you to go to Heroes Square. After you check the famous Monuments (the square), you must visit "Varosliget". It is a beautiful park nearby the Heroes Square, where you can boating or just walking. Moreover you can go to the Szechenyi Bath and Spa, which is in this park too.

Lit up at night...memories. My father left Hungary in 1956, so it was great to visit the Hero's square in memories of the hero's.We visited at night after the St Stephensfireworks on 20 August 2012! The atmosphere was wonderful!
Great place. You can learn a lot of Hungarian history... A very rich area of info... It is better to have a tourist guid,... There is also a lake some palaces with gothic style, barouk etc.....

Heroes' Square. A great monument to see and learn the history behind it. There are two museums nearby that are also worth a visit, as well as the park and castle nearby. We stopped at the cafe overlooking the pond and had some drinks. An easy walk from the metro stop. Take your time and enjoy the scenery!
Interesting. Whats to say really-its a square with lots of historical monuments. Its also close to the hot pools-about a 5-10 minute walk

Lots to see. Take the time to walk up Andrassy to Heroes' square as it is very reminiscent of the big avenues throughout Europe, e.g.Champs Elysees. Once there it is a huge square and you will need a guidebook to explain the significance of the statues surrounding it. Take the time also to explore the wonderful park right beside it. Truly gorgeous. A nice place to relax and watch the day go by.

Best to visit with a guide.... To truly appreciate the symbolism of the statuary, it is best to visit with a local guide or use a good guide book. It is easy to get to via public transportant. Do take the time after seeing the Square to take a leisurely walk along picturesque Andrassy Boulevard, which leads to the square.

Breathing space.. How amazing to have this huge big space in the middle of Pest, dedicated to war heroes. It was just so peaceful to sit and be watched over by these great freedom fighters and sit in the sun. behind the square are traditional baths and a huge park but unfortunately we didn't have time to see these.

A fine finale to Andrassy Boulevard. It is worthwhile to have a good guide book to understand the history behind this area to fully appreciate what you are looking at. If you enjoy walking, this is a fine culmination to a long stroll along the full length of the very interesting Andrassy Street. Also take the time to walk beyond the square to the city park which offers boating, a zoo and one of the more famous thermal baths of the city.

Recommended!. Heroes Square lies at the end of Andrássy Avenue and is in between the Museum of Fine Arts and the Hall of Arts. We visited the square in the evening after our dinner and the illuminated statues were really a sight to behold. (See pictures :)

Impressive. This is one of the biggest squares in Budapest with spectacular statues.The Art Gallery and the Museum of Fine Art all within walking distance.There is also park behind it.Read up on the history to best understand what you are looking at.
Nice. Wonderful monuments. We took metro to reach there. Beautiful monuments in the middle of the square, We liked it will recommend others to visit as its a very important monument

I remembered the comunism .... Heroes Square show the men that built the Hungary. It is a great area, only this ... The statues of heroes are looking to you. I think this site it is not interesting for all people, maybe to History students as me finding points of interest.
Great sculptures!. Huge open space, with marble crescent & interesting statues with Hungarian heroes throughout their history.

Heroes Indeed!. This is a fitting monument to those who are honored here. Impressive and well worth a visit ... you can get to this on the off/on bus tours as well. And from here you can walk to one of the famous baths.

Hungarian history in a nutshell. A must-see when visiting Budapest.
Located at the end of an iconic street and very close to several museums, the zoo and other attractions.
Great monument. Heroes' square is one of the main Budapest attractions. At least to me the mythology-like type of statues were rather appealing.
Very impressive. Very impressive square and statues, good photo shoot and a little bit of history regarding Budapest. Take the to walk round the park behind the square
impressive nationalist statement. The square is a true landmark and is beutifully lit in the evenings. The story behind it is interesting. Full of tourists though.
Heroes. You feel insignificant standing in such august company. A true Heroes Square and can imagine the gatherings down the years when the Hungarians had joy/sorrow to commemorate.

Most beautiful square in Hungary!. This has to be on the top of every list when visiting Hungary!
So much Hungarian History in the statues surrounding the square!
Worth having a local explain the significance of each figure.

Great Start to your leisurely walk in the park. A fantastic moument to some national heroes. Pay your respects and learn a few facts before heading into the park behind for a stroll, bath or boat ride. A great afternoon.

Impressive. A collection of statues of famous Hungarian leaders. They have certainly put a lot of effort into showing off these statues. There were a lot of people already visiting when we went but the place is so big that you can still read all about who these statues a dedicated too. Located at the end of Andrassy Avenue it is well worth walking from the town, down the avenue and ending at Heroes' Square.

Very Interesting. the sculptures are beautiful pieces of art, the attention to detail are great and the history behind each one of the pieces is pretty amazing plus the museum next to it is worth visiting.
Lot's of History. What I loved about this square is the story that it counts. This is an excellent point for you to learn all the history of the city and the Hungarians.
Heroes sq. WOw! they know how to sculpt these Hungarians. Very dramatic and awesome statues. I was impressed and recommend

Step there& you feel a hero too!. I have been there 6 years ago, but was winter and didn't had time enough to listen the guide's explanations about this place.It is the most spectacular square in Budapest, sited at the entrance to City Park.If you come from Andrassy Boulevard, you can see it from far, it is a 36 m high column in the centre of the Millennium memorial, on top of which is a statue of the Archangel Gabriel holding the Hungarian Holy Crown and apostolic double cross. Quarter -circular colonnades extend to both sides of the column. Figures of hungarian history. The tomb of the Unknown Soldier is positioned in front of the monument.We had great time there ....Go there, don't miss it.You feel so good afterwards.
go to see the statues. Very interesting architecture here. many statues, as Well as several museums on the sides of the square. Next to the park containing the zoo.
go at night. This was beautiful, We went during the day and at night and at night it looked magnificent and gives some amazing photos
Beautiful. I printed off some info about all the stautues before hand and found that really useful when walking around. Hop on hop off bus also goes there and gives some interesting info.

A BIG Plaza. It pays tribute to heroes of the past, who contributed to making Hungary what it is today.Many statues of these heroes form the back drop of the square. We may ahve enjoyed it more if it had not been so hot out the day we were there.
monumental. There is nothing to say more than I really could apologise this place to sightsee during your staying in Budapest.
Epic. Visit the heroes square, as you will find a great thing to see, also around it you'll find the National Gallery and many others

A rally Place. A very large open square in the central part of the city. Lots of monuments to commerate the country's heros. Enjoyed the walk around the very open large sq. learning about their history and heros.
Magnificent. Near the Museum of Fine Arts ant the and the baths and the zoo. All this makes it a hot spot for all Budapest tourists.
A dedication to the past. This square should be seen with a guide to explain all the statues and the relationship to Budapest's history.

Beautiful square thats worth experiencing. Great place to take a few photos and admire the work that goes into such an impressive area. Also a nice place to rest if you have been walking around for some time.

Take a picture from tourists from all around the World. :). One of the most touristic and most beautiful squares in Budapest. If you want to take a picture of yourself with other tourists on the photo, you must come here. It's always busy, but it's also a "must see".
Good but a long way. Interesting to visit this very large square with its large memorials and art galleries, but it is quite a way from the city centre.

Nice square at the entrance of the park. At the end of the beautiful and large Andrassy Avenue, there is this imposing square. It is spacious and right at the entrance of a park where you can chill out or rent little boats to row along the river.
Best seen at night. I recommend going to see this after sunset when it's all lit up- it's really spectacular against the backdrop of the night's sky.

Heroes' Square. An interesting site to see, but be sure and get the history from a tour guide, much more interesting. Be prepared for many tourists however. Beautiful to see on a clear day with blue skies! Check it out!
A perfect tribute. Wonderful site. Be careful of the traffic getting across the road but worth taking the chance. Such a perfect tribute to the heroes

go see. the column supports; the statuesof the tribal chiefs on horse back, King Steve are fabulous plus the neoclassical chariots really something you must see. while here look for the worlds biggest hourglass behind the Mucsarnok, remarkable
Lost on the big square. You feel a bit strange at the large empty square, but you may enjoy the monuments and statues and be happy to get away into the Gallery of Fine Arts or into the park

Never ceases to amaze me..... I have been here many many times, and the place is just amazing. Looking up at the statues that comprise the 7 tribes that formed Hungary. So so rich in history. Surrounded by museums, and the Varos Liget (City Park). A must see for anyone coming to Hungary. On the Yellow Metro Line (Line 3, Kis Foldalaty). Just get off at Hosok Ter and walk up the stairs. Make sure when crossing the extremely busy and crazy intersection use the crosswalks. I have witnessed many many near misses.

Must See. Walk down the main road - don't go there by bus. It is a little like the Champs-Élysées, just at the end of the road there is the Heroes' Square not the Arc de Triomphe.Afterwards check out the park behind the square. Relaxing. (The Szenchenyi Bath is located here as well.)

Hungarian Pantheon :). All the great leaders from previous centuries in one place. Shows a bit of Hungarian megalomania and the inspiration in the ancient times. Worth seeing (and there are Szechenyi's baths and the Vidam park just around the corner from here).

Importand and Beautiful. I thought this would be overrated, but we went because the tour bus stopped there and OMG was I wrong!!! Besides the historical significance, the beauty of the monuments, and sheer size is spectacular and will amaze! we even had time for a small boat ride on the lake behind
Impressive!. Huge open space. Looked just as impressive at night as it did in the day time. Tall columns and many huge statues. Gathering place for all sorts of events and rallies.
excellent. Put me in mind of Trafalgar Square in London but with a lot more to it, presumably because of the history of Hungary
Beware!!!. Definately worth visiting, however cross the very busy roundabout at your peril!!! And you may not make it.
History of Hungary. It would mean more for the hungarians because of the statues of their kings and generals. Well done, but just average to our group.

Great History, Go with a guide.. This beautiful square commemorates the 1000th anniversary of the Magyars in Hungary. But to understand it and appreciate it fully go with a guide who can explain it all too you. Street vendors are all around so be prepared to shoo them away.
Impressive but noisy. It is impressive square but also very noisy because of a lot of tourists. Very traffic road goes around the square so be prepared.

Subway ride and castle near by. There is a lot happening in this area. The baths, zoo, and a beautiful castle that is from Transylvania. Worth a visit. You can ride the old subway (oldest in Europe) from the vaci utca to Heros Square.
What a magnificent site. The statues are fantastic and awe inspiring. It is a sight to behold and great photo opportunity. Definitely worth a visit.

Impressive monument & square. The monument at Heroes Square can be reached via the Red Line Metro exiting at the Hosok Tere station / stop. The monument main / centre has a massive 36metre column with a figure depicting the Archangel Gabriel. Around the outside on curved mounts are various figures in Hungarian history starting with Magyar tribes who inhabited the Hungarian lands of modern day Hungary. Well worth a visit to stand in awe of the shear scale of things & to take an impressive look down Andrassy Avenue.
Impressive square. This is an impressive square at the end of a beautiful avenue and the park is worth a walk around too.

Interesting. Well worth a visit, beautiful site. You can get there easily by metro, and it's not that far from the city centre, so we just walked. If you're going to the zoo, city park etc., make sure you see this on your way there 'cause it's pretty near.
Worth the trek.. Heroes' Square is quite impressive with all of the statues. It is worth the visit up there to see this and to explore the surroundings.

Nice to see. Beautiful square but it is far from the main parts of Budapest. If its really hot take the metro or some form of transport to get there - you can obviously walk but it's just farther than it appears on the map

Interesting Area to Visit. The statues at Heroes Square are quite beautiful. I visited late one afternoon and there was quite a crowd of tourists there. On all sides of the Sqaure it appeared to be Rush Hour with lots of traffic. Cross the road from the Square and you are in the main City Park.

Interesting!. Well worth taking the M1 underground to this site. Fascinating to see the various statues and architecture. There are museums located here as well. After visiting the site you can take a walk in the park where you will see many other attractions including the zoo, thermal baths and an amusement park. An added bonus for some is that if you take the M1 underground you get to ride through the first underground on the European continent!
Make this A Must See. Heores square is a must see when in Budapest. I suggest you take your time viewing the area. Recommended time - 1 to 2 hours.
A pleasant retreat from the city. Just a short metro ride takes you to an area of tranquility where you can relax by the lakes and soak up the surrounding history. Well worth a visit
you can miss it. it is quite good sightseeing but is nothing special. you can definitely miss this sight and go somewhere else.
Good attraction.. Little far out of the city centre's main attractions, but worth visiting for the historic value and the photos of course!! Best to access via one of the many tourist buses!
Magnificent. Well worth a visit, you can get there on the metro, the statues are dramatic and well worth seeing, don't leave Budapest without visiting here.

Amazing. Heroes square is an amazing sight to see, check out the detail in the statues. The area has the zoo, a castle, walking paths and 2 museums. It's an interesting area, you'll need a few hours here.

Great to visit in the evening. We loved Heroes' Square, especially in the evening with the statues lit up and all the locals gathering in the plaza. I suggest bringing a guide book describing the heroes so you know who you are looking at.
Good experience. Large square full of history. Luna park close by so its a great visit for both adults and children. Very peaceful surroundings and great for walks.

Impressive - Huge. You'll need a guide book to know who the statues represent - or google it before or after. However, even without that knowledge, the square is so large and open - and the statues beautiful. So worth a visit if you are around that area.
Heroes' Square Awesome. Which one was Grandpa? A necessary visit since I read up on Hungarian history between my class breaks at the college.
Awe inspiring. This square is completely breathtaking, I would recommend it as a "must see" to anyone visiting Budapest

Worth a visit. Heroes' Square is worth a visit, the history is very intersting and you will get some great photos here. The area surrounding is very beautiful with the zoo, parks, baths and museums close by.

Picturesque. My teenage daughter and I visited in June 2012. Heroes Square is a beautiful monument with lots of statues to look at, museums flanking its sides and the City Park directly behind it. The Square is beautiful to look at; but mostly meaningless if you don't have some guidance. We used the Rick Steves guide to teach us some about the heroes pictured here. Loved his commentary and felt we had learned a lot about Hungarian history afterwards.We visited on a very hot day, and there is no shelter; so come prepared with water, hat, etc.
Worth a visit. The location is great, although one of the buildings was staging the local franchise of "The Voice", and was decorated in a manner I could live with out

Respect to Heros. A large square constructed in 1896 for the millennium of the Magyar Conquest of Hungary. The square's Millennial Monument is flanked by the Fine Arts Museum and the Mucsarnok Art Gallery.Beautifully constructed and maintained. Will sense of pride to the citizens Others will learn how to respect their freedom fighters. Must visit
Lovely location. Surraunded by great Museums, Parks ,Thermal Bath, Zoo , botanical Garden. Do not miss this site with good planning.

Magnificent men on display. After a long walk down Andrassy blvd we finally got to the square. It was magnificent! The statues were grand and detailed...each one labeled with the persons name and below it was a scene depicting their contribution to the history of the country.
Extremely Impressive. We liked the large open space, the statues representing Hungarian history and the park and lakes behind were lovely for a stroll in the sunshine.

impressive. This area contains the tomb of the unknown soldier and impressive statues. (I wish I could remember the history right off.) If you are adventurous, you can rent old fashioned two wheeled bicycles (one very large wheel and one tiny one) nearby for $4 for 1/2 hour.

Stunning. A lot of fun things to do at Varosliget with kids.. Like the proximity to museums, park, zoo, bath house, and metro. Great coffee cafe nearby. We took the metro and spent the day in this area with our 10 year old.
Heros Square. Large and beautiful also very pretty river and surrounding area
Powerful. Although built to commemorate in-fighting prior to the Soviet invasion it was difficult not to see an allegory of the later problems suffered by Hungarians.

Cool Square, but Andrassy Avenue and the City Park. are better visits. Loved all of them though
http://gonewiththeguys.blogspot.com/2012/07/high-fives-budapest.html
Check out my brief review on the 5 best things to do in this city!
Love it. It was a long walk, but worth it to enjoy the different structures of the buildings. I really enjoy it
Impressive!. This is a must see. Massive! Just imagine the history that took place here. The statues are amazing
Yet another Wow!. Very impressive statues, bronzes, obelisks and all so very well kept.

Interesting, especially with a good guide or guidebook. Heroes' Square is an impressive collection of monuments, focusing, of course, on Hungary's heroes. One can certainly pause and take pictures and say "wow" without any further information, but, as I indicate in the title of this review, you really need a good guide or guidebook to describe who all the statues are and why they are heroes.

Impressive. Worth walking around and taking some snaps - the statues are extremely impressive from a distance and up close. There's no shade at all however - in 33 degree heat we could only stand it for so long!

Beautiful Historical Square. We visited Heroes Square and did the RIck Steves' Budapest self-guided tour which took us through each of the statues. A fantastic way to remember the people who made Hungary the place it is now and for tourists to learn about their colourful history.
once beautiful... it was impressive in the past , today it looks untreated and it's a pity!
Hook Tere. Memorial stAtues to the ancient kings of Hungary and some modern heroes. Across the street from the museum of Art

Photo Ops Galore. This is a place that many people come to look at, but never really see. They don't take the time to look at the details of the statues or learn who the people are. The artwork is exceptional and worthy of dozens of photos.

Heroes' square. Right next to City Park can get very busy with lots of tourist buses. Great open imposing space and beautiful statues. Plenty of time to walk through the park and see the many attractions there too.
Interesting area of Budapest. The Heroes Square was interesting and scenic, but the area around it adds to the atmosphere. Definitely worth taking a walk in this area.
Horse Races. We went to the museum and then sat on its deck and watched the horse races and drank the most delicious beer.
Main square, part of World Heritage. Nice, historical statues and square. The Heroes square and the Andrassy street are also part of world heritage

Wonderful large Square. I didn't dislike anything it has to been seen and an easy way to get to it is either take 105 bus or a very long walk down Andrassy ut or on the tour bus it was a privilege to have seen this.

A natural centre. Stand in the centre of this enormous space and it is not hard to imagine the scenes of protest over the years. The two National art museums flank either side, with extraordinarily interesting temporary exhibitions. It makes a good focal point for an evening walk from the Izabella Residence.

Great square. get a booklet with information on the sculptures, on the square there are no souvenirs shops where you could buy them, walk behind the sculptures to visit the park and get some cool drinks during a hot day
Stunning !. Incredible monuments & art - becareful crossing roads as some cars & cycles tend to zip about a bit fast. had good walk round here then on to the
Awesome memorial. Huge memorial - overall kept very clean, but as with lots of cities there is a lot of graffiti.

Beautiful square-worth a visit.. We thought the huge square was so beautifully laid out with the most wonderful bronze statues.
near by is "sleeping beauty's" castle on an island which is lovely for a stroll and for some lunch. Worth going out to see.
Imposing Monument. Wonderful statues set in an imposing setting with colonnades and pillar, all in a huge formal square.
Make sure you go see. Impressive art and surroundings...walk and see it and the surrounding areas.
Large square. So of course you have to see Heroes' Square but then I suggest you move on to the Fine Arts Musuem!!!
Impressive monument. If you're someone who appreciates decorative and ornate monuments, this is certain a sight to behold.

Make This a Part of Your Budapest Experience. At the far end of Andrassy, is this square that is a memorial to the fallen. We were here on a chilly day in February so there weren't too many other people. However, I can imagine it gets pretty crowded in good weather. There are museums on the square, as well, but our time was limited in the city, and so we just stopped in the square to check it out and take some pictures. You are likely going to check out Andrassy, since it is a main road in town. When you do, stop by this square, as it is historic and won't take much time.
Heartbreaking. Memorable lesson of history. All visitors hould remeber the price Hungary pid.
Dramatic space. A very large square with dramatic statues and friezes.

Bella!. Nice square. Easy access with metro.
