Take a walk in the park after the square. Its nice!

Huge Commemorative Monument. All those Hungarian heroes immortalised as statues in a vast square. Get here early or late in the day to avoid the hoards of tourists taking their photos. The perspective and the enormity of the enterprise is best appreciated when there are only the statues and the central column to see.
This is a free attraction.

The trafalgar square of Budapest. Nice to go and have a look at this square. Similar in feel to trafalgar (slightly less traffic though). Some good art galleries either side if you are into that as well.

A must see during Budapest Visit. We spent around 15 minutes in Heroe's Square during our 4-hour afternoon private tour in Budapest. The guide explained the history of the statues. We enjoyed the tour in Heroe's Square. But, I really enjoyed the statues displaying war and peace.
Average. Good to see statues but not much else to it, 5 minutes is enough unless you are going to one of the museums or the park
Hero's Square. Hero's square is a must to see. It is a grand display of statues and a lovely moment to remember. Watch out for ladies selling sweaters.
spectacular.... What a wonderful tribute to Hungary's past..... a must visit! It is located in one most beautiful areas of Budapest
Such Impressive Statues. The immenseness of the sculptures here is mind blowing. Don't forget your camera.

Well worth a trip. Again if you buy one of the hop on hop off tours this one will be part of your tourist itinerary. The square its self is huge and massively impressive. We too the metro to hosok tere and hopped out from the under groud to find the square in front of us. We did nt do the tour thing as we wanted to amble around ourselves we bought the Budapest card from our hotel and for 29 euros each we had the freedom of the twin city.Also lots of discounts on bars cafes and resturants / museums. Although if you want to know the exact history of every monument take the tour . heros Square is really worth taking a look at but is full of people so mind your bag.
Quick visit. If you are a Michael Jackson fan, you WILL recognise this square. The hop on, hop off bus will stop right there.
Best part of my trip. Heroes square is brilliant. It's very near a subway stop, there's galleries and the people's park nearby. There's also a lot of traffic so be careful!
massive a bit pompous. Huge square with military sculptures - just what you would expect
Stunning. Large open area not for visiting in temperatures of 37 degrees which we had when we were there. Well worth a visit, quite busy

Amazing Space. This is a huge square, flanked by museums and close to the park. The statues are impressive, but other than visiting the museum's there isn't a lot to do, but you should visit as part of the Hungarian experience.

Great square and meaningful for the Hungarian people. The Heroes' Square is a complex of statues situated at the end of Andrassy Ave. and at the entrance in Varosliget (City Park). It worth wandering around and admiring the statues of the greatest leaders in Hungarian history.
Stunning. A place not to miss but make sure you take an umbrella in hot weather, as there is no shade.
Godd place to go spend the day. Beautiful park. Great for spending a good part of a day. Plan ahead.
Old Style Communist Square. Large open space with a significant monument and 2 imposing art museums at the end of a great street and by a super open space where the Budapest locals come out to play.

A monument - but not much else. As monuments go this is OK - but other cities have more impressive ones.Apart from the monument itself - there isn't much else actually in the square, apart from an ice cream seller or two and lots of tourists, but its flanked by two good art galleries and backed by the city park and a great spa bath -so worth passing through.
Magnificent to see. Well worth a visit. Jump on the hop on hop off buses and make sure you get off here.

Beautiful!. We walked most of the way up Andrássy út, but then decided to take the subway for one stop to come out at Hero's Square. So glad we did! The view coming up from the subway is breathtaking, and the effect would not have been the same if we had walked to whole way.

Beautiful!. Only visited it at night so not sure what it looks like in the day. It was stunning. Clean, gleaming - which I appreciate could have been down to the lighting. Very beautiful. If (or should I say when) I return to Budapest I will visit it during the daylight.It's right outside the metro station so it easy to get to. Definitely worth adding to your list of things to do in Budapest. We did ours at the end of a long day so we only spent about 10 or 15 mins there altogether.

Don't miss this. A nice place with statues depicting the most important men in Hungarian history. There are two museums nearby, ZOO and a nice restaurant called Paprika not faraway. And I can't forget the lake, the castle and a vast park with several cafés.

what's all the fuss about?. Every guidebook told me I should visit this memorial to worthy historical figures but I found it a bit of a letdown. It IS one of Budapest's biggest open places but I found it a soulless, empty space devoid of atmosphere. Fortunately the presence of the nearby large public park of Varosliget with its excellent, if modest, transport museum, and the Szechenyi spa complex (where you can play chess in the bath!!) made the journey worthwhile. Especially when it meant travelling the length of Andrassy Utca on the magnificent World Heritage Metro, the oldest in continental Europe.
Very grand and impressive. It's easy to get an idea of grander days gone by when standing at Heroes' sq - the whole set up is very impressive.
Facinating. Beautiful square near the Szechenyi Baths, easy access via the hop on hop off bus.
Remembering with monuments and sculpture the history of Budapest. Very tasteful design. Easy to conceptualize Budapest history from Celtic to Roman and into modern times.
Cool to see. Most of the heroes are central to Hungarian History. It is a very warm square, and it got crowded with tour buses.

Visit the Square then walk down Andrassy.. There was some sort of demonstration involving taxis when we were there but it was peaceful. You can walk down Andrassy to the House of Terror and the Opera House from here. It is a great walk.
Grand imposing. Gives wonderful views down the avenue, make sure you wander round the parks behind the square, lovely in the summer
Must see. If you are in Budapest you have to make a trip to Heroes square. Also visit the nearby worlds largest hourglass - more interesting than it sounds!

Inspiring. There were so many statues and columns in the square it was hard to keep track of them all. This square was always busy and we went through it on the Hop on Hop Off bus several times . It's just amazng to see all the statues and the archway and column at one end. Definitely worth a visit.

History personified. This square has a couple of museums, but the square itself is rich in history. The statues are of Hungarian heroes, and the square was the site of numerous propaganda gatherings during the Communist era.

Spelndid. Its one of the main squares in the city - with rich historic and political connotations. There is an interesting history which spans from left to right of the square. The monument consists of two matched colonnades, each with seven statues representing great figures of Hungarian history. Topping the outer edge of the left colonnade represents Labor and Wealth. On the right colonnade is a statue representing Knowledge and Glory. At the inner top edge of the left colonnade represents War, while on the end of the right colonnade represents Peace. Truly Magnificent.
Photo Op. Great place for a photo op. When we were there we had rented bikes and actually got to ride around in the square.

Take a guidebook that explains the sculptures. This is a beautiful square. It will be more meaningful if someone explains the statues to you or if you can read about it in the guidebook. The Cluj Museum just off the square has a good gift shop too.

If you are in the area. If you are in the area visit it but it's best to have a guide to explain the meaning of the statues and scenes or one can't fully appreciate it. It's part of the history of the country and is quite interesting. Otherwise it'll just be a nice photo.

great pics. i went in the late afternoon in May - great time to go to get great pics with the sun in the right spot....be sure to cross the street and go to the park....the castle/museum in the park is amazing too

A Must See. Take your camera, the square is opposite a gallery and the statues are great. We had a company pic taken in the square.The coach stops outside the gallery and the tour guide telle you everything you need to know. I would go again!
Impressive. Our guide walked us here and gave us the history of the conquerors of Hungary. Big square with statues.

A great destination for a walking tour. Walk down the length of Andrássy Utca until you get to Hosok tere. This is one of the nicest avenues in Europe and the square is the meeting point of a few fine venues including the Nagy Circus, the Zoo, amusement park, the Secheny baths and a huge open park.

Majestic square. This square is a majestic place to visit and behind is beautifull garden with a palace where is now a museum, with a house with thermal pools, with nice statues and a lovely market with some souvernirs, candies and different types of food. I trully recomend a walk through this square and garden.
Wonderful. We took the metro to get there and walked to the castle behind it. There were many activities and food stands as well as souvenirs. We enjoyed a traditional lunch with our friends.

The Budapest Pantheon. Heroe's Square, marks the entrance to City Park in Budapest, which sits at one end of Andrassy, Budapest's Champs-Elysee. It is a sparkling marble square places between the Museum of Fine Arts and the Palace of Art, and housing statues of great leaders from Hungary's past. The column in the center is surrounded by statues of the Seven Magyar Chieftans who were believed to have founded Hungary, and the colonnade behind commemorates Hungary's great leaders including Kings and great warriors. The towering statues and gleaming marble give one a sense of the Budapest of the 1890's with its glorious innovations that caused reflections on Hungary's greatness. To visit this spot is to understand that part of history as well as to understand a Hungarian's pride in the past.

A World Heritage Site. Listed by UNESCO. As a Workd Heritage Site, it is one of Budapests most impressive spaces. It's sheer immensity is impressive as well as it's open space in which so much goes on - from tourists photographing the exquisite buildings (now museums and galleries) either side of the square to locals break dancing :)

Proud nation. The name of the square says it all... Hungarians are very proud of their history. And their former empire lasting 1000 years. Obviously, you can't boast more, than build a square with massive statues of all important men standing next to each other.
Beautiful place. great for a stroll and pictures! Impressive sculptures.

Monument with historical figures. What made this interesting for us was reading the entries in Rick Steve's book describing each of the historical figures. Without something like this guide, much of the significance of the site could be lost. Heroes Square is the entry to a beautiful park.

exactly what you would expect. It has the fancy architecture with columns and such, but doesn't really tell the story of what it is commemorating. And it isn't near all that much else in Budapest, although the park next to it is quite nice.
Impressive. An impressive entrance/exit from the park. Can see the tomb of the unknown soldier here too
not to be missed. this is another place that needs plenty of time to visit it has budapest's history also a place to relax

Located at the beginning of Andrassy Utca.. Make sure you walk from Heroes Square (this monument) right down through Andrassy Utca, as it is a beautiful avenue. Also, a free concert is hosted by T-Mobile near Heroes Square every year. It attracts hundreds of thousands of people.
Interesting. I liked hearing the history of the memorial and how it is divided into two parts- the right being the strong Hungarian kings and the left being the less honor-worthy Ottoman leaders.
Stunning square. Impressive and stunning squa especially the archangel Michael
famaous building in budapest. this place at city centre so dont missed it to see it!! very very amazing.. near of this place also had historic place
Fantastic place. This is a must see even if its just from the open top bus!

A must-see!. Spend a leisurely afternoon exploring Heroes Square and the beautiful City Park. The buildings are amazing and there is something for everyone! From the awe inspiring square itself to the 'fairy tale' castle in the park... the funfair, the baths, the circus, museums, art galleries, etc., etc. Oh, and the beer tent! Wonderful!

Important to visit and respect. It is quite a spectacular monument and an important part of the countries culture. The history is important to be aware of so, either do a tour or read before you go. We were pestered by ladies selling knot wear, avoid!!

So amazing. Considering when it was built. There was a market on whilst we were there, full of all sorts of things!
.

What a green space in a major city. The people of Budapest have a gem right in the midst of their city. The Heroes" Square has lakes for boating, lots of sunbathing areas, major museums, architecture to rival anything in western Europe, yet a sedate atmosphere that makes everyone seem relaxed! Take the Yellow Subway right to the front of the park
Lots of stuff here. There is so much in this area that a whole day can be spent, Zoo /Baths/ art gallery/ gardens/ cafes/ Aeroplane museum/ just wander and look around

Impressive monument, but the parklands nearby are even better. There's really not much to say about Heroes' Square - the type of monument dedicated to a nation's founders doesn't vary much. Having said that, it's of course still worth seeing.
However, just nearby is a really nice park with a number of restaurants, ponds etc. Quite a nice spot for lunch and a walk afterwards.
Put it on your list!. Another must see, there is just so many special places and monuments, make sure you pack some comfy walking shoes and enjoy.

Simply breathtaking. I am a lover of statues (particularly horse statues) so I wasn't disappointed when we reached the end of our long walk up the Andrassy Avenue. The vista opens up to the most amazing buildings with verdigris figures racing chariots across an endless blue sky. We only scratched the surface in Budapest but fell madly in love with this breathtaking city.

If you are in the neighborhood. Nice to to see while you are on your way to something else. I shouldn't travel special forthe square to Hosok ter. But because it is the entrance to the park were of lot attractions are situated and at the end of Andrassa utca (nice boulevard) you might come sometime in theneighborhood.
great. the place is very big and close to the park. go and walk inside the park.

Great place to escape the crowds. This is a monument to the founders of Hungary and is an open square and park that are not heavily visited by tourists. At the end of a beautiful boulevard, it was a welcome retreat from the crowds at the Castle and Chain Bridge.
A big square. A big square with a lot of statues from historical events.
Full of History.. You need a guide to get whole story of the square, about the nation etc. Recommend highly.
Nice tribute.. The hero's square was simple but special for the history hero's.

So many "hats". We have visited Budapest 4 times in 3 yrs and have always walked to down Andrassy Blvd to Heroes Square. It has rained on us, the sun has shone, we have been there on quiet days and days crowded with tourists and on other days it has been turned into a race track for the National Gallop or a parking lot for bicycles during Critical Mass. With the museums on either side and the monument in the middle, there is always something to see and do. It is one of our "have to's" when we are in Budapest.
A must for history buffs. A vast square with the millennium monument and statues of Hungarian kings and others. It is at the gateway to the city park so hard to miss but not very interesting
Monumental. I pass here every day, the statues are part of my everyday life.

Great place to spend part (or all) of a day. I am including the park area behind Heroes square in this review, because the whole area is worth a visit. You can easily spend a day here. We were there on a Sunday afternoon, and there were a lot of locals out enjoying the park as well as tourists visiting attractions. It was very beautiful. We had a Rick Steves guidebook to tell us about the square and surrounding area, which was very helpful. I could not talk my son into visiting the baths this trip, but we will definitely return to Budapest and both a trip to the baths, and a return visit to Heroes Square will be on the agenda.

A grand square. A wide open area near to the City Park - grand monuments to view. Very accessible via the Metro and worth a visit. As are the Park, the Szechenyi Baths and the Gundel restaurant which are all in this vicinity
Wonderful Large Open Memorial. Towards the end of the oldest subway line (Yellow line) in continental Europe, is Heroes' Square with its broad, open space and art museums anchoring either side.

Good to see. A lot of monuments to the great and good Hungarians which is right on the edge of the Park, so can easily be combined with a trip to the flea market, the Vajdahunyad Castle or Széchenyi thermal baths.Alight the metro at Hősök tere or walk to the top of Andrassy Utca.

Impressive. It's a huge square with impressive statues. And I loved seeing the big park behind the square. We didn't visit during the night, but apparently it's fun too. Again this place was extremely busy.
Heroes' square. Very interesting square with central figures and statues relating to Hungary's past. Very photogenic area. Plenty to do near by, including beautiful baths and park areas.
Impressive. Definately worth seeing, perhaps after you have been to the Szechenyi Baths and Pool and explored the park.
Go in the evening. Wander there for a walk after 10 p.m., square is empty and well lit. Bring a good guidebook for an explanation of the statues.

Worth a look.... Heroes' square is definitely worth a look, but there isn't much here to hold your attention. Definitely combine with a meal at one of the restaurants, or a broader walk around the city park adjacent to the square.

Really lovely. We saw Heroes' Square as part of our bike ride. It is a beautiful square but the experience was enhanced by the fabulous guide explaining what all the statues were and the history of the country and the square.

Worth the walk.. We walked for ages in beating sunshine but well worth it. The tour buses go there so you dont have to walk, but really nice big square with gallery on one side and museum on the other. Reminded me of the Brandenburg Gate or the big square outside the Hermitage in St Petersburg. I really wanted to go at night to see it lit up, but didn't manage it, oh well, definitely next time...
Very impressive memorial. This is a huge area, beautifully designed and everything on a very large scale. A great "entrance" to the park just behind it.
An Awsome Experience. When we visited it we were completely blown away by the design and beauty of the statues. It is a wonderful part of this city.

Modern but beautiful. As most of Budapest memorabilies, its new (not few hundreds years old). But it doesnt matter. Its great piece of monumental heroic architecture and nice way to give face of most important Magyar rulers.
Wonderful History lesson. Interesting to see how things changed over the centuries and decades.
It is very romantic in the winter!. Near by Heroes' Square is my favorite place in Budapest in the winter! That is Ice Rink! :)
Nice day or night. This is one of those places you have to see when you visit Budapest. It really doesn't matter if you visit during the day or night, but it is not much fun in the rain.
Magnificent!!. This place is huge in real life, looks smaller in photos, a real must see for the huge statues and architecture!!

Try at night as well as in the daytime. the atmosphere here at night is wonderful. The statues are amazing when lit up and so is the park. In the daytime it is impressive too. If you want to go into the Art Galleries don't go on a Monday - we did and were disappointed to find them closed.
Awe inspiring. I recommend having a guide so you can really appreciate all the history. I took the small group tour offered by Greyline and really enjoyed it.
Heroji ne plaču. It is a great place with statues of Hungarian kings and i"m not sure about the feelings i had when i came there...a litlle bit scary how they all look at you...

Great to be seen - Heroes' Square. Wonderfull square to all hungarian Heroes. Hungarians are not known as a worriors but still they make this square, but I don't for who. Neverless it is nice to see, anyway.
Vast open space.. Large open area with statues of Hungarian heroes. Next to the Art Museum.

NICE. A nice place and beeing there and found out about the importance that this place had in the past, and it's signification gives you a nice feeling. It is located at the end of one of the most important Bulevards from Budapest, Andrassy Bolevard and on one side you can see the Museum of Fine Arts and on the other side the Hall of Art. In the middle of the square is the Millenium Memorial with status of the leaders that founded Hungary.It is really nice and it is woth to be seen! So ENJOY !

Large Park in central Budapest. Large Park a little on from the Terror museum and Octagon. Has a Spa, Castle and Zoo with ice rink in the winter. Good place to take the kids if in Budapest a bit longer with big open spaces.

big. It's a big square. Have to know the history of the country to get its significance. Keep walking at it's a wonderland of park spaces, castles, museums, and many more sights. Great location to start expiring in most any direction.

Ancient History told by sculptures. This large square is dominated by beautiful sculptures of the kings of Hungary. Before coming to the Square (with a guide), I had no idea of this country's amazing past. It was breath-taking.
great square to visit. heroes square is a must see on yoru list of things to do in budapest

You have to see this while in Budapest. Even if all you can do is drive by, you need to see this landmark. Good to look up a little history to let you know the background before going. The Art Museum to the north is worth a look as well.
Ok for a short visit. If you have some time left from you trip to Budapest come and visit this Square and maybe stroll around it. Not that impressive.

Impressive square, yet..... ...yet considering the splendor of the city of Budapest and its innumerable magnificent buildings, I expected something more breathtaking.
Well, maybe i just got too spoiled...
Must see. Were few times during stay, morning, noon, night, it is always different and impressive.

Do your homework!. When you come up at the Hosok Tere stop on the metro, be prepared for the magnificent sight that is Heroes' Square! A lovely area to just spend a little time wandering around and a great spot to start a family day out as the zoo and city park are only a walk away from the Square.I would recommend that you do a little homework before you visit as it is nice to know who the different Heroes are in these larger than life statues and there is no information available on site. Enjoy!
Impressive.. Impressive.Impressive, one of the biggest square available, with a beautiful garden and museums adjacent.
Big. It was very big and impressive. The statues were all pretty cool and the whole thing was a neat thing to see.
Family weekend in Budapest. spend half day and take lunch in the excellent restaurant on the lake

ephemeral. Wow, what a place huge square with two curved galleries with statues of past leaders and in centre place a huge column with statue too. the park beyond is lovely and peaceful and there is a small cafe there too.
Amazing square. We visited this as part of the City rama tour and it is a must see.
Vast. What a place big,open area the 7 Magyars look down on you and the Archangel Gabriel looks down on them and you as you look up at him, Vast monument, take the Metro from town its great.

Worth a stroll. It is worth a stroll to get more acquainted with some outstanding figures of Hungarian history - on your way to the Museum of Fine Art on the left and Palace of Art on the right or to the famous Budapest Zoo.

Nice point to view the city. At the end of a nice avenue, this magnificient square is a nice point to have an opn view of the city. There is also a huge park behind, nice for a walk during a sunny afternoon, and 2 museums right next to the square. Do not go if you mind to get wet during a rainy day, since its an open place with hardly any place where to find shelter
Heroes' Square - visit to the Hungarian history. Very impressive monuments! We could learn from this small but very proud nation!

Monument. Heroes' Square monument is located in Andrassy utca. On your way there, you will also reach the House of Terror . The monument itself was built in 19th century, and it has hystorical background as well. In my oppinion, after visiting Parliament, Chain Bridge, Buda Castle and St Istvan Basilica, you should aso visit Heroes Square attraction and enjoy in the wonderful view.
Statues are impressive. enjoyed walking out to it but the only drawback was a lack of information in English so really didn't get the full picture - maybe you should viisit this as part of a tour.
Hosok Tere. Impressive!Great!Monumental!Quiet place at this time of the year!
Historic and next to a beautiful park. Walk around the park and the court yard of the museum before leaving the square.
The Square. Big, historic and the statues to the leaders is worth seeing. Be prepared to do a lot of walking. Also there are limited signs in English.

Amazing Views from Andrassy Ut. Great historical landmark that was well worth a visit, plus we were lucky to be staying right around the corner from it. Flanked by two museums and also walking distance (10 mins) from Széchenyi Thermal Baths.
worth a peek. reminiscent of the other great entrance pillars of Vienna and Berlin
imposing site. a brilliant location to check out some of budapest's history and great photo opportunity on the way to the szchenyi spa baths
Strong statement to a past. Scale and scoop of area - flanked by 2 museums and a large park area - set the tone for a look at the leadership and focus of Hungary's past.

Historical Landmark. We stopped here as part of the Budapest Bike Breeze Tour and got a great explanation of the different elements of the square and related history -- otherwise we probably wouldn't have been as impressed if we had just stopped by it with little or no guide.
Tacky. The square was a disappointment and surrounded by what seems like an amusement park with poor catering facilities.Nice park if u get away from the fairground element.

Heroes Square. Heroes Square is at the end of Andrassy Avenue. It's worth walking along Andrassy, seeing the sites including designer shops, and then getting to Heroes Square. On your way back, take the 'Yellow line' subway. This subway is the second oldest one in Europe.
Beautiful Square. Great to stop by for some pictures. But not worth it just for the square unless you plan to visit the park, baths or museums.

A lovely area. We arrived on the hop on/off bus and the weather was warm & sunny for March. The area was lovely but we could have spent a lot more time there if we had not had a time restraint. They seem to be developing some of the area which will add more and attract visitors.

Great view. First time I saw Heroes' square in the evening, and I was impressed by lights. It's large, and it's very good place to walk in the sun or listen to guide who tell you about all the statues. Of course you should remember that nearby there are so many attractions: Budapest Zoo Szechenyi baths, city park, museums, metro station - the first metro line with old-fashioned vagons. The place is one of "must-see" in Budapest

Very Impressive Square. A very impressive place, a wide open square at the top of one of the cities main shopping avenues.Surrounded by very impressive buildings the Square itself is dominated by central pillar/statuethe bottom of this pillar is surrounded by statues of tribal leaders from old.On the different occasions that I have been to the square it is usually filled with people, and has a wonderful atmosphere.There are usually quite a few school trips and also tourist coaches and embarking and disembarking their passengers.However it all adds to the atmosphere

The Square and adjacent city park are worth the visit. The square and park are great places to watch the locals having a good time. There's a castle, duck pond, skating rink, eateries, thermal baths, a zoo, and other attractions.
Impressive statues. Very nicely designed public monument with wonderful statues. Well worth the visit, and there are interesting park areas nearby.
Grand square. Grand square, amazing statues. World class sight. Beauriful architecture and a lovely park around.

A nice sight. This is a majestic square and it's fun to go here and people watch, enjoy the weather, see the beautiful buildings/museums surrounding it. If you have a good guidebook or a local with you (I was lucky enough to have both) the explanation of the imagery on the monument is very interesting.

Need a guide. It's a long walk from the centre of Budapest, and when we went it was pretty much just us there. I think it would be a lot more interesting if you had a guide to explain who all the statues were.
A tragic Past. You need someone here to tell you the story of all the heros. The monuments are incredible.

Vast and suitably bombastic. This monument is an enormous and rather elaborate tribute to many famous Hungarian kings and leaders from Árpád to Lajos Kossuth. Its depiction of historical figures is a bit fanciful, but offers many interesting photo opportunities. The equestrian statues are quite attractive, and the sculptures on the colonnades give an interesting potted history of Hungary through the ages. Definitely worth a visit.
Must see. Very imposing and a must see whilst in budapest we had a guide with us which helped as he explained everything to us.

One of "must see" places. If you spend 10 days in Budapest then dining in Aunonimus restaraunt or some budget place around central park plus looking onto Heroes' Square and may be art museum definitely worth the time
Iconic!. The Hungarian equivalent of Trafalgar Square - not to be missed.

Heroic moment with the Statues. The Heroes' Square is very spacious and it makes a good backdrop of group photos. The central column is known as the Millenium Column and in front of the Column is the Tomb of Unknown Soldiers. The square is also well known for the site of many rallies and protest. However, when we were there, we encountered none of it. Just opposite the Heroes' Square lies the Museum of Fine Arts.Take up the challenge to pronounce the names of the 14 prominent rulers on the semi-circular arcades, as seen in the Amazing Race Asia 2 where one of the detours requires the teams to correctly pronounce the names of these rulers in local Hungarian accent before they can received the next clue.
Big. In the summer heat it's not a big enjoyment, but other times quite good to give a visit to the statues of Hungarian kings and other historical leaders.
A long walk for an ok monument. The actual monument is ok but the surrounding park is not worth the trek to get there

Not much information at the site.. Suprisingly empty, not sure that unless you do this as part of a Tour or had a good guide book you would find enough information at the square, but if you are visiting the baths or skating rink in the area it is worth the diversion to take a look.
Large square in a Large city. A number of Statues depicting various heroes' and some modern sculptures that had me scratching my head!
Very impressive. Not the best time of the year to see the Park next to the square (winter) but the statues etc are very impressive and a fitting monument
I do not know what shkuld go in here. heroic scale, like Place de la Concorde. Monuments, the Fine Arts Museum, Exhibition Hall, Zoo nearby

Stand back and Watch. I loved Heros Square and admire these Great Magyars that saved the Country in the course of Hungarian History. Each and every one of these men are hero. Just stand back and watch and it amazing feeling, go there during the day and at night.... Always have tourist around there as it is one of Budapest must see landmark. Without history these mens wouldn't be standing...

Good picturepoint. The square is located near the central park and the museum of arts. It's easy to reach by metro 1. It's called the millenium memorial with figures of famous hongarian people. It's a nice place to take a picture, but nothing more. It's not really a nice area around.
Very nice. This square is amazing. There are 7 figures of the 7 big rullers of Hungary. In the middle there is an obelisc with St. Gavrail on top who is the keeper of Hungary.
Good pictures. Its just a square with statues but its good for photo oppurtinities

Good at Night. I took a stroll through the Square at night and found that it was worth the trip. It was very picturesque with all of the lights providing good opportunities to take some dramatic night shots.
Go here. It is not on the Top Ten of Budapest. Why? It is excellent with a wonderful castle behind it.

Heart of the Magyars. The spirit of the Magyar is there !!
All hungarian kings and the gabriel are represented in the heart of the city.
Walked the whole way.. Take a taxi or subway. it was too far. But I went there winter and summer. It's nice. haven't try the bath there though.
Impressive. Quite impressive to see all the statues and the vastness of the square itself.

A monument which every historic capital would have. It is similar to many monuments in Europe but I think it is definitely worth a quick visit if you have the time. Adrassy Avenue goes with it; a walk down this avenue with heroes square makes you understand why this city is nicknamed "the paris of the east" ... (comparing it to Champ d'elysse in Paris)
Whaaaaaahhh...... Amazing square and the walk from there to the center is nice. Shame there is so many cars are going around there and neither English explanation.
The Who's Who of Hungary!. All lined up according to history with a lovely view of Andrassy street.
sight seeing. inspiring and well worth seeing. Mkae sure you have a guide or information or you will miss out

Impressive. Very impressive square on the edge of the city centre completed in 1900. Impressive monuments dipicting hungarian leaders from 9th century and other key figures throughout the history of the Magyars. This is a nice inclusion spending a day exploring the sights just out of the city centre

Lot to do - museums, fairytale castle, zoo, fair, food.... My fav park in Budapest is the City Park behind the square... lot of history, a fairytale looking castle, iceskating in the winter... Szechenyi baths and outside pools, zoo, fairground, good restaurants, museums and much more... in a small area.But even if you dont want to spend much... just walk around and enjoy the great atmosphere... perhaps have a picnic :)
Beautiful monument.. The monument itself and the square in general are beautiful with 2 major museums nearby and a gorgeous looking park, too.
Big square. Many statues, big square and not far from one of the main bathhouses in Budapest. Like all sights in Pest near subway station

Beautiful memorial. This is a grand square. We had the pleasure of being here, early morning, on a foggy, slightly misting morning. This provided an ominous background and we were ahead of other tourist - so we had the square to ourselves. Do read up on the history so you can appreciate the statues from St. Stephan onward. Great history.

We 've been there on 31st December 2010. In the middle of this square there is an important monument dedicated to the Hungarian heroes. Other admirable sights are very close to the square, for instance the famous baths and also museums and galleries!
Another link to my past.. I have pictures of my mom and I (at 5 yrs,) here. Neat to be back. Also a great reminder of my heritage.

Nice. A nice place to visit if you are in Budapest. There are a lot of people around, some of them are locals, so it is a good place for people watching. We didn't go into the art galleries.Basically the square is just a nice place to have your picture taken in front of a huge statue.

2 fine museums, plus the millenium memorial. (not that of 2000 ., but that of the Hngarians settled here in 986 (?). A lovely site. An old underground will take you there, which is basically no more then an underground tram, the first one on the continent.

Heroes Square. We had a tour to Heroes Square . It’s an amazing collection of statues..The Central Column represents the 7 Magyar tribes and the left and right colonnades feature Hungary's rulers. Behind the monument is City Park. It has a replica of a true Transylvanian castle, a zoo, massive bath/swimming complex and many walking paths. It is a very pleasant place
Rollerblading at Heroes' Square. Beautiful square to visit. Also a great place with a lot of space to rollerblade or cycle with friends.
Heroe's Square. Magnificent monument! The size and scope are very impressive!
Grand!. I loved visiting Hero's Square quite often and City Park. The grand structure has historical significance and is a great tourist attraction. Take Metro line one to Hosq Square to get there.

Very Impressive Historical Monument. I took the metro to Heroes Square to see the Millennium Monument and City Park, The Millennium Monument is very impressive in size, history, and detail - very well done. I am glad I went to see it.The Central Column represents the 7 Magyar tribes and the left and right colonnades feature Hungary's rulers. Beneath each ruler is a relief depicting an important scene from his life. I walked around the monument checking out each ruler and the relief beneath him. My guidebook provided a self-guided tour.Behind the monument is City Park. It has a replica of a true Transylvanian castle, a zoo, massive bath/swimming complex and many walking paths. It is a very pleasant place to unwind.
Great photo ops!. I went in January so it wasn't so crowded. I got some great day AND night shots (because I visited the Square before and after my visit to the Szechenyi Spa). So... great photo op!

If you are in Budapest, it is a MUST visit place.. I would suggest you to start your journey across Budapest over here as loads of sights can be found here. Let me start with the famous ZOO. Opposite to the Zoo there is a Restaurant called Robinson's, which has a great kitchen, pricey though. It has a nice terrace just over the Varosliget Lake. Nice scenery. You can find the world famous Gundel Restaurant next door to the ZOO. Across the ZOO, there is the also World famous Szechenyi thermal bath with its 22 thermal pools. Stunning architecture, very nice place to relax. Also in this area you can find one of the biggest, IF not the biggest ice skating ring right next to it there is the copy of the Transylvanian Dracula's Castle (Vajdahunyadvara). At the both side of the Heroe's Square there are two Museums, which worths to visit. Museum of Fine Art. NOt the mention the Heroes Square monuments. At the same place, you can find the beginning of the Andrassy Blvd (Our "Rodeo Drive"). If you go along on that blvd you can see the Opera House, The National Ballet Institue, and also you can find all the TOP Brands store there, like Louis Vuitton, Burberry, D&G, Nespresso, Vertu, etc.

If you have a working camera, get to this place.. It may not be the biggest, grandest, but it seems to new visitors to capture the Hungarian tradition. Take the subway and then zig-zag down Andrassy and side streets toward city center. You will be enriched for having done so.
No a real lot to see here. Would only visit it time permitted. There are other more amazing sites to spend time at before this.
Large and imposing. This is a large square that features large statues of leaders of the country from very ancient times. I found the looks of these old warriors pretty fearsome.
Camera at the ready!. Although it is very busy, it is very pretty in the winter sunlight and is an impressive square. Visit at day or night.

Hungarian history in 3D. Best place for foreigners and Hungarian children to learn about us. You can find some of the greatest men of Hungary depicted in sculptures - read on the net to find out more if you are interested.

Well worth a visit. Although a bit out of the way, this large square, which is characterized by a semicircular colonnade whose central area is​​ Millennium Memorial, with statues of the leaders of seven tribes that founded Hungary in the 9th century, while the other statues represent other rulers from Hungarian history. Behind the square is a lovely park. Heroes' square should not be missed during your visit to Budapest.
a quick walk past. If i remember correctly this is now a surface car park
Reminds me of Berlin!. Interesting square with museums and monuments aka Berlin and then expanding from there the lovely City park.
nice. Nice as well as the park behind it, but a little bit out of the way of the other attractions!
Beautiful!. What an awesome history! There is no shade so make sure you wear a hat! Love this place too! so clean!

A great Memorial.. From the statues of heroic hungary, the buildings, the scale of the site. Proud of their heritage doesn't begin to express the feeling you get standing amidst all this history and listening to the tour guide and feel his pride in such a great country and history.
Big and empty. It was a big square which was pretty empty but had a nice story

Hungarian History in one location. The statues of the rulers and heros of the Hungarian past are all in one location to see. There is a massive park attached with a lake and some places to eat (Robinson Restaurant) The park is full in Summer with sunbathers. There is a castle to view and other attractions like the Zoo and the Bathhouse.

Nice square. There standing the statues of Magyar's kings, it is a very nice open air plaza/monument, especially during the winter, the crowds were modest, and as I had experienced... places and monuments in Budapest are fotogenic
stunning. a night visit as it is visually powerful & stunningly lit up!
Spectacular Monument. A straight forward but spectacular monument to the heroes of Hungary. There's not a great deal to it, but it looks pretty impressive, particularly around sunset.

Could, or should, be seen by the tourist. At the entrance of the city park this vast square with the many memorial statues is a part of a World Heritage site. It also includes two museums: the Museum of Fine Arts and the Hall of Art. The square has imposing dimensions, but if you don't know that it was built around 1900 you could very well think it was a Soviet propaganda construction...The Andrassy boulevard starts here and ends almost down at the Danube bank. Under the Andrassy boul runs the Metro line 1, which is the oldest underground line in Europe.

breathtaking. The statues of the horsemen, leaders of the tribes of budapest, are haunting. Not heroic looking. But they reveal the exhaustion of leadership and constant wars. Like so much of the best Hungarian art, the true human experience rather than the symbolic effect (like "heroism") is portrayed foremost.
A Must See Attraction. It's definitely worth paying a visit to Heroes Square- it's very central to the Spa and the Zoo and the monuments are stunning!
enjoyed. very nice, very clean... great park behind must see...

Huge and well-worth visiting.. Much bigger than expected and nearby was huge ice rink. We also visited the Fine Art Museum which is on the North side of the square and loved it - full of Medieval paintings and Old Masters.

A really huge square. Take the yellow metro to reach this square. Walk around as the locals do, sit down and take a good look of the faces of the heroes. The statues are very impressive. There's an art museum across the square and the Szekenyi Baths nearby and many other sights in the Park across the Square. You can spend at least two hooours in the area

Éljen a Magyar!. A great place to reflect on Hungarian history or to rendezvous with friends for an outing in Pest. For the tourist, an excellent starting point for an exploration of Hungary's rich cultural life. There are museums in the direct vicinity and plenty of other attractions within easy reach via mass transit.
Hungarian really know how to do statues. The statues here of the chieftains of the Magyar tribes are some of the best I have ever seen. The sculptor has managed to convey a real sense of majesty.

Nice visit.... centrally located place with a few things nearby... i tried the skating rink nearby and it was fun.... this was the only place where i felt like a tourist since bus loads of tourists poured into this p[lace...

Apex of Hungarian Nationalism. Great but long walk from the center (take different meandering routes there and back). You will get a great cross section of Pest and its 19th century boom. Lots of places to stop. One of central Europe's grand squares, and even a Hungarian history buff might be challenged to identify the figures and significance in Magyar history.
Interesting.. Heroes' square is set in th middle of a park area but is very impressive. There are statues all around the square and in the centre. Well worth a visit.
Interesting. Avoid the gypsies selling jumpers etc. An interesting place to walk around.

worth the effort. We walked down Andrassy Bld one cold Sunday morning and the monument at the end was very impressive. The park behind was full of autumn leaves and there were people and families all enjoying themselves. An interesting Square with an interesting history
Not much to see. If you don't know the history, this squre wouldn't mean much to you. The surrounding streets and buildings are a good area for a walk.
A must see!. A great tribubut to those from Budapest who led and made this city what it is today, the location is perfect as it enters directly into the City Park.
Beautiful. I thought Heroes square was a beautiful tribute, it was well kept and immaculate well worth a visit.

Huge open air memorial. Heroes Square is at the top of Andrassy Ut and iot is worth doing the 2.5kilometre walk along this beautiful avenue. Heroes Square is a typical communist affair with a huge open space and memorials to Hungarians of the past.
Looks impressive, also similar. A great square, staues of hungarian kings placed monumentally, also statues of some austrian kings. Similar squares happens to be in Rome, london, Vienna, etc.
easy to get to. Easy to get to via metro. Close to public parks and outdoor swimming. Massive area with impressive monuments.

A must visit when you are in Budapest. This is a place you must see when you are in budapest. You are surrounded with history. In summer time people inline skates on the heroe square and this year ( 2011 ) they just reopened the oldest Ice rink of europe next to it. Must go

A Budapest Classic. Pretty cool square at the end of Andrassy Ut. and the large park with the Szechenjyi baths, can't remember the name. Walked through it many times on my way to the park or when on Andrassy

Nice For Views and Pictures. The statues are impressive and different from most western European style. It has a very eastern European feel to it which I liked. Had a funny experience happen to me on the bridge leading up to the monument. There were two small cars one with the top cut off that had two guys dressed in Santa outfits. There was a red chair in the back seat and a red phone in the front. One of the guys was pretending to "make calls" from the phone and he was giving me these weird cheeky grins. Then the car behind them started throwing candy at people, not to them, literally at them. Then they speed off around the circle and not long after a police car went after them,The area isn't dangerous, seeing how fast the police came. In all I think they were just having some cheeky fun. It was close to Christmas ;)

Impressive Square with many things to do. The square is very impressive but no something special. It worths to go there because it has many things to do and see in this area, like fine-arts museum, thermal baths, the lake and the zoo.

A monument to Hungary's history, but a bit artificial. This vast expanse was built, like much of Budapest's public areas, for the 1896 celebration, and this one includes huge statues of many of the key figures in Hungary's history. (Interesting how many of Hungary's heroes led movments or armies whose endeavors ended in crushing defeat!) The sheer scale makes it worth seeing; it's worth more time only if you want to dig into the history these figures reprsent. Also, it is the gateway to the City Park, which is definitely a pleasant place to explore and chill!

take some photos then leave. came across this by accident on way to park, lake and river. its also near the zoo.The traffic is horrendous around the square so take the required photos the move on quick to somewhere more picturesque and peaceful. The park nearby perhaps?
Lovely!. Easy, inexpensive Metro/subway ride from the Intercontinental Hotel area. Great chance for photos and near the Zoo and Szechenyi Thermal Baths. Big stop for tourist to take pictures.
Nice Park. Will write not just about Heroes' Square, but the whole park. Had a great walk around the square and into the park, including the Anonymus Statue and the flea market.
Interesting....expansive !. Enormous area..... impressive statues and reliefs
Amazing atmosphere. This was one of the most impressive sights in Pest when we were there it was virtually empty so we could get the full powerful feeling of the vastness of this place

Lovely statues. Have been there once, many years ago.
Have not been lately, not sure which metro to get on on my own.
Worth a visit. Nice photo opportunity. There are also art galleries there but we didn't visit them. Not much else there. Short trip on the metro line 1
awesome statues. nice open space, museum's either side, well wrth a sight see
Lovely squere. This is a very beautiful square - simple but the Hungarina heroes monuments gives the square the sophistication. This is in close aproximity of the zoo, museums and city park
History through Statutes. A tour through Hungarian history through statutes of the major players. Nicely lit at night.

see it at night. While the statues stand as aspiration for a country leveled repeatedly in the Crossroads of war, it, and Andrassy come alive at Night with transcendent architectural lighting. A magical inland echo of the view of the river, bridges, and castle, which is, is among the finest of any great cities of Europe.
nice monument. The great about this place was not the square actually but the park just beside it. A nice ride by bike could be done there
Hero's Square. This place is huge. Spotless and you would think there was cleaners polishing the marble every night. it's an awe inspiring place. well worth a visit
Nice perspective, impressive statues. Get the chance to go there with a guide to learn more about Hungary's kings

monumental. The square is really monumental, but it lacks other qualities...The statues are maybe too big and too warlike...it's atmosphere almost reminds of Hitler's Germany (you could almost visualize him giving a speech there)...and there's nothing green there...it's too cold

all history on one square!. Just breath taking. How they managed to put all history in one square! You realy have to take your time here, and look into faces of all the statues. Best to visit at night or in the everning. lights are incredible and you will be the only person there. They should have a special tour only for this square, to explain all the statues on it.

Statue Heaven. A must see if you like statues and bronze, this square has been used in several film scenes and Michael Jackson filmed a full video here, don't miss it ( close to the city park and Szechenyi Baths, do all three in a day)
See all the Kings. A great story of the history of the Kings of Hungary.
Stunning. Fantastic for photos especially if you have a blue sky. Nice to sit and have a takeaway coffee and bun and admire the surroundings.
snooze time. along walk four a few monuments not worth my shoe leather
Beautiful!. A monument you will appreciate seeing..refer to a guide book for explanations of the statues! The history is very nice to know!! Then you can hit the gorgeous park across the street.
Powerful monument. Again worth visiting for all the past rulers and heroes, or otherwise, of Hungargy.

Not much to see. There isn't really much to see on Heroes' Square. You are pretty much done in 10 mins. What is nice however is the castle behind the square. Very pretty. And also the zoo on the other side of the square. Had a really nice time there.
Big and grand. Nice place to take pictures. Make sure you have a guide with you who can explain what it stands for (or maybe a guidebook). That will help you appreciate its purpose.

Truly amazing feat of engineering. The scale of the statues at Heroes' Square took your breath away. The Archangel Gabriel and various Hungarian kings and national heroes are magnificently cast and impressive. Very pleased we saw this tribute to Hungarian history.
Magnificent Statues. A commemoration of Hungarian Heroes but only up until the end of the 19th Century.
Heoroes' Square - Very Interesting. This is somewhere you should really go to if you are visiting Budapest. The square itself is pretty amazing. It is only a few minutes of your time.

Magnificent Magyar Monument!. The traffic around it can be ignored. The statues arrayed around you, the mosaic floor, the central tower and architecture, the beautiful art museums around it and a place for people to hang out. What a place!

They don't make monuments like that anymore. It's huge, it's pompous, it's awe inspiring. A massive square with huge statues in the classical style.
Don't need to spend a lot of time there, but you should see it. I went at night, which may have made it even more impressive with spotlights and darkness contrasting.
Long walk, should go with the car.. Should take public transport or a car if you stayed near the river, walk is good but too long from the Danube, but lot of sights on the way.
Historic. We went here on a bus tour and it looked very impressive. A bit like Trafalgar square in London.
Heroic. Majestic, brave, strong, courageous - all captured here.

Dramatic. A reasonable walk but the Hop on Hop Off bus stops there. It is worth the trip to marvel at the square which is very interesting and the area behind the square is also worth exploring. (One of the spa baths is very close and we thought that it was much more pleasant than some of those closer to the city centre). The Liszt Museum is also close by andn well worth a visit.
kings of Hungary. This square is huge and you can see the most famous kings of Hungary. There are 2 museums too and a castle nearby.

Beautiful, especially during sunset. I saw Heroes' Square while on a hop-on/hop-off bus tour of Budapest while there on business, but wanting to finish the whole tour in one go I didn't get off. I later realized it was only about 2km from my hotel, so I walked there later that afternoon, and had the good fortune to be there just as the sun was beginning to set on an unusually warm September day with few tourists around. The sky was clear blue, so the sun was able to progressively light up the entire square in golds and oranges as it set. The light and shadows on all the statues was amazing, and changing second by second. It was impossible to take a bad photo. Add to that the buildings immediately around the square are also impressive, and the massive city park directly behind makes for a very nice walk. This was my favorite area in Pest.

A must stop. We were on a hop on hop off bus tour of Budapest and stopped here for about 45 minutes to see it. There are no audio tours but we had a tour book that explained the entire square. Without this tour book, we would have been lost, but with it our 45 minutes was packed and very enjoyable.In the center of the square is Gabriel surrounded by the 7 chiefs of the seven tribes who settled hungary. Flanking this statue are 14 statues of Hungary's most important people.Heroes Square is very large, very clean and very well done.If you are not on a tour, do your homework before you stop at this attraction - especially the 14 statues.

The most beautiful place in Pest, in my opinion. Gorgeous. It's a bit far from the centre, but, I assure everyone, it's worth all the effort in the world. It's a giant square with statues of Hungary's old kings and national heroes. Behind it, there is a huge castle, it's a museum, Agricultural museum or I'm not sure. We didn't go in because it was closed but, it is worth to go and walk around the castle as well. It's perfect. Plus there is an art "museum" right in front of this castle, ON THE LAKE! I highly recommend this place to everyone, I really really enjoyed it.
Beautiful statues & monuments. It's a square with a monument and statues. It's very beautiful & clean. best of all, it is close to the public park as well.

It isn't just the square, but everything around it too. Heroes' Square is a major Budapest landmark that shouldn't be missed. It depicts the major figures in the country's history. Together with Andrassy Avenue, it is a World Heritage Site. Rick Steves' city guide tells you about each of the many statutes in the square. But the half hour it will take you see the square itself will be worth any trip, because lots more is nearby. All within walking distance: two art galleries, flanking the square on two sides, the zoo and a fun park, the Szechenyi Baths, and Vajadahunyad Castle -- the last an intruiging hodgepodge or architectural styles. There is a metro stop at the square.

Visiting Heroes Square is a must in Budapest. If you are in Budapest on holiday or buisness or just passing through and have some time to spare be sure to visit Heroes Square. Upon arriving there I was struck by the beauty and magic that surrounds the Square. The area is huge and monuments surrounding the whole area are magnificent. In the middle one can find Attila and rest of his men on horses. Around the square the monuments of kings surround the whole place.Take a tour of if you prefer buy a lonely planet and read all about these great warriors. Tour does not end there.If you keep walking straight you will enter castle area and lake and garden surrounding it.
Greta Square. Loved Heroes Square. The statues are so big. It on a sunny day it was special.I especially liked the Kings on horses.
Well worth a visit. Great AttractionA number of museum's are located in this area also the Zoo and spaAlso on route of Hop on Hop off bus

Impressive!. An interesting celebration of the history of Hungary. The centrepiece is the Millennium Monument, built in 1896 to commemmorate the 1000th anniversary of the Magyar conquest. Statues of famous kings, variuos symbols (war and peace, work and welfare) can also be found, as well as equestrian statues commemorating Arpad and the seven chieftains of the Hungarian tribes. Andrassy AVenue is also worth a stroll, as well as a visit to the Museum of Fine Arts and Art Gallery. Lots of tourists .. and vendors who will try and sell you everything from tourbooks to sweaters (some take no for an answer .. others not so much!). Well worth a visit, especially if you have limited time in Budapest.

Very impressive. Huge square with a beautiful statue in the center. The scope of the square is large so it is difficult to photograph. Particularly enjoyed the fine art museum. They had some lovely paintings even though they were poorly displayed. The Spanish section was especially rich. The square is fun to walk around particularly if you go into the park on a weekend. Many of the locals come there for the amusement park and the stalls that are set up with souvenirs and food. It gives the tourist a chance to actually see some of the locals enjoying the sights.

impressive. This huge square is very impressive, yet feels relaxed - kids were riding bikes around, tourists were climbing on the statues, and no one seemed to care.A women seemed to be trying to sell me her top - she didn't seem to be a retailer, she just seemed to be trying to sell one crocheted top??!! - but it was okay, she wasn't scarily persistent.
A very impressive monument but you'll need a wide lens or stood in front of the road. A fantastic square but I needed to stand right on the edge of the road to get it all in

Get ready with your camera. This is a very iconic place of Budapest.You need a wide angle camera to cover the entire region into your lens.Try climbing up the warriors idols and it make a wonderful pose for your photos.If you are some one who like landmarks and stuff for example the Eiffel in paris, I am sure you will certainly like this place.

Impressive, Good Galleries. Heroes' Square is on the yellow metro line, and at the end of Andrassy ut. The Fine Art Museum and the Mucsarnok (Palace of Art) face each other on this square. The Zoo and Szechenyi Spa are both very close to here.The main attraction is a wonderful composition of statues. There is a tall cenotaph or Millenium Memorial in the middle surrounded by statues in a semi-cicrle. The statues depict the 7 chieftans wholed the Hungarian tribes into what is now Hungary, and there are other important historical figures and kings included as well. There is no traffic on a large part of the square, which makes a nice change and lets you have a wonder round in the middle. It is impressive and huge, and I am pretty sure it has all kinds of political connotations.
Great to see. If u have time make the effort to visit, a very impressive sight, very big square looks amazing

Must see when visiting the city. Heroes square is quite impressive and worth a visit during your stay. Andrassy Avenue is beautiful with lots of things to do such as the Terror Museum, so incorporate Heroes Square into your day.

Quite an attraction. Every who goes to Budapest should visit this place and get a taste of the culture and history of Hungary. It is quite a large square and is usually filled with tourists. If you like animals, it is close to the zoo.

HUGE memorial to hero's and kings, a lot to see and do around. This memorial is HUGE! with several segments like the gods of war/peace, all the different kings and the main statue itself. There are various museums and arts centers around. Andrassy street leads up to the square and also contains a lot of culture/touristy thing (House of Terror, Opera House..) Behind the square is a huge park which contains many statues, a castle and church, baths, a circus, etc. I would read up or get a map on all the little things to do/see here or you may get lots in the park/woods!
Scenic Square - visit if you can!!. It is an impressive square. The metro stops right by the square which makes getting there very convenient.

Must see by day and by night. This is a beautiful monument that can be tricky to get to as it appears Hungarian drivers aren't concerned about hitting pedestrians. I ran the risk, literally.
If you walk a little further up the road directly past the main monument, you'll find the Széchenyi Baths.
Wow!. I was thoroughly impressed with the symbolism, artistry, and thought (not to mention the grand scale) that went into this monument. It is quite an impressive display of national pride.

Beautiful by night. It is worth visiting this square twice: by day as the starting point of a trip to city park, the nearby galleries, zoo or Szechenyi Baths; and by night, when it is spectacularly illuminated, as a fine conclusion to a stroll up Andrassy ut. after dinner.

Huge Square. This is a must do in Budapest, even though it's quite a simple place. The statues give a history of the city. We got there first thing in the morning around 8:30 and there wasn't another soul in the square. After that we walked around in the City Park located behind the square and took a look at the Szcehenyi Bath building, through the park some more and then back to Hero's Square. On either side of Hero's square are two art museums, but we didn't go to them this time around.We took the yellow line metro across the street to our next destination. You really need to pop down there even if you aren't going to use the metro. The yellow line is one of the oldest underground transportation in Europe.

A Must See. The Square is awe-inspiring and the statues provide a great tour of Hungarian notables across the centuries.The location is also great - near to City Park, two art museums, Szechenyi baths, the Zoo, the Fun Park and Gundel restaurant.

Scenic Square. A place to have a stroll and appreciate some of the history, through the heroes' of the square. Not as grand or spectacular as other 'squares' in some cities, but still worth a visit. 30 minutes is sufficient. We linked this with a stroll down Andressey Utca and a visit to the Zoo, which resulted in a very pleasant day out.
